This is a great palce to view Tokyo, and on a good day, you can see Mount Fuji. I did see Mount Fuji as its a sunny and beautiful morning. The outer is filled with beautiful flowers and picture perfect moments.

AMAZING VIEWS! . This is a must do in Tokyo, especially on the first day. It gives a great view of Tokyo & surrounds! I have done this during the day & night & they are both just as magical! On a clear day (apparently only about 3 times a year?!) You can see Mt Fuji which would be cool! A must do! Free too!
Great experience. Great way to view the city for free. The view from Skytree is higher but there are less people at Government Office which makes it more calm.
Free view of Tokyo! . Came here twice, once during the day and once at night. It was very busy, but you got a great view of Tokyo. Don't miss out on this free activity :)

Stuffy, crowded with a poor view. We had visited the Tokyo Tower during the day and thought it was a decent visit so we decided to give this place a try at night for a different view, especially given that this place is free. The place was easy to find and the elevator ride was smooth and there was no line. However, the floor was quite crowded with very poor ventilation. It was about 70 degrees outside but it felt like 85 inside with humidity. This was not helped by having a restaurant and a kitchen on the same floor with no windows. The view was really quite average. The glass window gave a lot of glare and reflection making taking photos difficult. But I think mostly because of the stuffiness we left after a quick 10 minutes. I do not recommend this place at night.
Nice view. The view is ok, you can see Tokyo tower and all that from a far, But in all it's a tourist trap with souvenirs standa everywhere. But it's good when you've got time to kill.

Great free views. We made a day of views of Tokyo. This is a great stop, free, and has its own unique views, particularly of the shinjuku skyline. Wish Fuji had been visible. South tower is recommended for the day and north for the night.

Great views. Bring binoculars!. There is a line to ride the elevator, but the ladies in charge of the queuing system were friendly and efficient at getting people into the elevators so we didn't wait too long (maybe 8 minutes). There were windows on 3 of the 4 sides of the building and each side offered great views of Tokyo. We brought binoculars and loved looking at the various buildings in the distance. It was too bad that it was rather muggy so we couldn't see as far as we could have on a clearer day.There are a few gift shops that are interesting to check out and a cafe that serves light food.

Great Free Views. Visited for sunset. Be prepared to wait about 30min for queuing time. The lift can only accommodate approx 10 people.Decent views of the city. There is a toy shop and a bar at the top. The bar is a bit pricey and does have a sit down charge... But it is the best beer i had in Tokyo!
Wonderful view over Tokyo. This is the place to go to enjoy a panoramix view over the city. You can even see Fuji San when the wheater is good enough.And last but not least, it's free !
Good Vie. Had a nice view from the 45th floor. The floor is kind of busy with a lot of people and shops but it is free.

If it weren't for free, no need to go up. The view from Metropolitan Government Building is nothing to write home about. Lots of souvenir stands and sellers, limited view. Taking the elevator up is for free, though . . .
Beautiful views; free elevator ride. Best bargin in Tokyo. Just go to the lower level to catch the elevator. Great views of an endless city.

Magnificent view. If you go to the observatories of Tokyo Sky Tree, Tokyo Tower, Roppongi Hills, or any other place, you have to pay the entrance and maybe have to wait in line. But the top floor of Tocho (Metropolitan Government Office) is free! It is located in Nishi-Shinjyuku, but within a walking distance from JR Shinjyuku station. Before you get an elevator, there is a security check. So, it is advisable that you travel light. From the top floor, you can enjoy a magnificent view of Shinjyuku areas, and if you are lucky, you can even watch Mt. Fuji.

FREE GREAT CITY VIEW. Thank you Tokyo for offering us this great view on your city.North and south view of the city. Take elevator at first floor and off to 45th floor.An fluent friendly english guide is eating at top floor to give you details...This what you call service!
free city view. Nice views to Tokyo at no charge; highly recommended if it is not very cloudy and visibility is poor.

By all means, you should visit this FREE observation deck:). The Tokyo Tourist Information Center on the 1st floor of the main building is full of English language pamphlets; the staff speaks perfect English, too. Just get off on Tochomae subway station, and it'll be right there when you alight. Nice views!!!

Magnificent 360 degrees view of Tokyo - for free!!. We all know that Tokyo is a beautiful city. But if there's one spot where one can observe this, in all its glory, it is from the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office building. And there's a good reason to get excited. Access to the top level of the building is absolutely free. You might need to spend some time in a queue leading to one of two lifts that take you into two corners of the top floor, but the wait it well worth it. What you are confronted with, when you reach your destination, is a view that, on a good clear viewing day, could take you as far as Mt Fuji (which I, personally was not privileged to see, given the overcast nature of the weather on the day of my visit). Weather notwithstanding, Tokyo is spread just in front of your eyes and you can discern things that otherwise would not be visible from ground level. For instance, one thing I discovered (actually my wife did) was that the taller buildings were masking whole blocks of lower apartment buildings, creating an interesting maze of blocks of tall and low buildings in a fairly organized manner. You can also spot the multitude of high rising buildings with helipads on their roofs. All in all, an excellent spot to grasp nearly the whole of Tokyo in one go. Well worth the time investment.
Best free view in town. After staying in Shinjuku three times, I finally made it here. The view is fantastic, and it's free!

nice and one of few FREE things to do.. Had a good view. unless you have a thing about being super high, it had a nice view. it was free which is nice as many places are really expensive and then a let down. South tower had a couple of toy/souvenir shops and a cafe. North tower sold prettily packaged food and had a resturant. There is a big park nearby.

So good we went thrice!. We went on a Sunday originally and they were having electrical problems so it was closed (I don't think this was usual). The next time we went was 3 days later and it was late afternoon/sunset so we were able to get lovely views over the kanto plain (it looked like the city stretched forever!). We went back when it was dark to see how it looked with the city lit up. Worth visiting at night too but not necessary if you're after the view. Restaurant seemed expensive but there's too not much around if you're hungry. Be prepared to queue for the ride back down.You could call this a rainy day activity but you'll not be able to see as far.

Excellent view of Tokyo (for free). From 45 floors up, you can really get an appreciation for just how expansive Tokyo is. It's a great view from up there. Recommend going on a clear day, when you should be able to see Mt Fuji in the distance from one of the 2 observatories.
Great views of city for free. It was quiet when we went up so no queues. The views were great and the coffee shop serves great pastries and iced coffee. Nice shop too.

Free stuff and really worth it. The view is really good, the area around is really clean. it is located in NIshi Shinjuku which is walking fdistance to kabukicho area. The great thing is eventho it is really nearby, you can really see the differences between these 2 areas.Suggestion : If you wanna go during new year. you have to check the schedule, because there will be days that they will close.

Amazing view over Tokyo. It was the rainy season, so when the sun came out we rushed over for a late afternoon view over Tokyo's sprawl. Security was just a bag check, and it was free. The view was impressive, even though haze meant we couldn't see Mount Fuji. The glare on the spotless pics meant less than perfect pictures, but there was lots for the architecture fan to enjoy.

Great view of Tokyo for free. Free views of Tokyo (and on good days, even Mt Fuji!) from the 45th floor at day and night (open 9am until 11pm I think) The North and South observatories have some overlap but also some different views (only one is open after 5pm though) At night the windows with the "sparkliest" views are the first ones you pass as you exit from the elevator, don't forget to look there like me!
Good views. There is an observation room in each tower, but visiting one would suffice. There is a coffee shop located in the room and a lounge you can sit in. Admission is free.

beautiful night view of Tokyo. Located just beside Hyatt Regency hotel, this is the place to go for a nice night view of Tokyo with no fee entry. Just line up at the designated area, where there are staff to guide and keep things in order. There is a restaurant and shop selling cute toys and souvenirs at the top and we ended up spending an hour there shopping while enjoying the night scenery with glimpse of Tokyo tower from afar.

Brilliant view - FOR FREE. We didn't pay a cent to come in here - seriously so good! Has an amazing view over the whole city, plus Mt Fuji (which was covered in cloud when we were there). I was expecting it to be really jam packed full of people - and it wasn't. A pleasant surprise! DEFINITELY visit here!

Great View. After reading other people's reviews, we decided to come here instead of the Tokyo Tower. Great decision! First of all it is free to the public, Second there is a guide that took us all around to each of the views and told us what we were looking at (in English), Third it wasn't crowded. I don't know if we just hit it on a good day, (Wednesday mid-afternoon), but it wasn't crowed at all and we could get right up to the windows to see out! Great way to stop here first to get a perspective of the size and layout of the city!
Nice view for Shinjuku . Free and easy to get access to the north and south wings of the building. Both have almost the same view of Tokyo, especially Shinjuku.

Tokyo Skyline. A breathtaking view of Tokyo Skyline and a virtuale tour of the city from the sky. Excdllent for taking pics due to the later closure of the venue ( 11.00 pm ) . A must for a trip in Toky
Great view over Shinjuku area. Bad weather to get the best view but we had great overview anyway. Unneccesary tourist shop at highest level.

Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Cafeteria. The panoramic views from the 45th floor are incredible. I had read reviews regarding tourists accessing the staff cafeteria on the 32nd floor for meals so we decided to try it. Firstly it is not so easy to access. You have to each complete a form carrying address and phone number details ( no english version), then receive a visitor's pass and be ushered to an elevator. Once at the cafeteria, you can see glass cases exhibiting the plastic versions of the meals on offer plus prices. Next, you order these through a machine, inserting appropriate payment. Then proceed to the appropriate counter for your meal. We were assisted by a very helpful staff member. Note that we arrived shortly after opening at 11.30 am. If we had been much later, we would have been included in the hundreds of workers arriving for lunch. Ditto with the cafeteria seating. The meal was great value. We were the only westerners in the room and hurried through our meal as we did not wish to interfere with workers on their lunch break. Verdict? Authentic Japanese food, great value, but not so easy to access.

Beam me up Scotty!. Once you go through a security check, you enter an elevator and are taken up, up and away! The views of city lights go on forever - such a huge city... We only visited at night, but it was a lovely experience. If I'd had more time in Tokyo, I would have liked to view it during the daytime. Free of charge, this is a great way to get your perspective of exactly what Tokyo looks like. The light reflection from the windows makes photo taking pretty hard. There are SO many shops you can stroll through before descending - they are full of all sorts of tacky touristy things, but if you have children, you can buy trinkets for pretty reasonable prices.

A Surprising Observation Deck. Out for a walk one afternoon, I decided to venture up to the Observation Deck, and found a slightly musty room with two kitchy gift stores, a restaurant, and windows all around. It was fun to see this very dense, high-rise area from above. Admission is free, though you must go through two metal detectors as this is the equivalent of our city hall.

Panoromuc view of Tokyo from Shinjuku. Was there at night- was a breeze going straight to 45th floor( no que at all)-and best of all it's FREE The signage to the entrance was not well displayed though - need to ask the passerby - it's at the basement liftIt's open till late at night- last lift up around 10.30pmGood view from the top- able to see most landmarks of Tokyo such as Tokyo Tower etcWill recommend to go

Great views and free of charge!. I added the Metropolitan Government Building to our agenda after reading the reviews on Trip Advisor. If you like towers and skyscrapers, visit the Tokyo Tower and Skytree. If you just want a free view of this incredible city, I recommend just visiting here. Tip, we found out later, the views are better from the South Tower. Many in the North where we went are obstructed by a restaurant. If you have time, visit both.
Great views. Amazing views at the top that is free of charge. Great if you want to see a panoramic view of the city.

Great photos, poor view ( at night) . Got some great pictures, however due to the large amount of light being emitted in the room itself, the window reflection is quite bad. The pictures are good though. Short waiting time and no entrance fee made up for it.

Free nice views. The sky wasn't that clear but it was nice to see these fancy buildings from the top, line wasn't not bad free better than pay for sky tree Tokyo, there is a shop on the same observation floor it was over priced for us - American we buy good deals on Amazon- bathroom and water fountain, love it

It is not just the views, pay attention to the architecture!. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is located in west Shinjuku. It is very easy to arrive by metro. As mentioned in other reviews, the views are great!. It is free and it is very easy to find. Lines are short and move fast. When I visited was not crowded at all. This is a big complex with a semicircular plaza. The design was made by the famous architect Kenzo Tange. The facades are very interesting as they recreate traditional architecture and electronic circuitry. The skyscrapers are impressive and their architecture very modern and with a clear Japanese style. Just pay attention to all the buildings around the Metropolitan buildings. To detail the architecture you have to visit at day time. At night time the views from the tower are very nice. They are also nice at day time simply a different perspective.There are small shops where you can buy small and cheap souvenirs.Look for the cute Lady Bugs in the ground floor, close the building. This is a nice site to take photographs.

Excellent first stop during our trip to Tokyo!. This was a great first stop during our recent visit to Tokyo. We visited shortly after opening on a Sunday. Went straight up the South tower with no wait in line. It really gives you a sense of the vastness that is Tokyo!
Nice views and atmosphere. How can you beat free night views combined with bar dining area with piano playing in background. A must when visiting Shinjuku.

The never ending city . This is a must do. Not only is it free but what a view! You can see for miles from every window on the 45th floor it looks like it never ends. Such an amazing view. Today wasn't that clear but you could make out Mount Fuji as well.

Free View. 5 minute to wait to go up for a free view of Tokyo from very high up. It wasn't overly crowded either which was an added bonus.
Can't really complain when the Skytree and Tokyo Tower are both charging are substantial amount for essentially the same thing.

Free lookout. I'm not sure why anyone would bother with the Tokyo Skytree when a free lookout is available here. The views are nice (not 360 since there are a few other tall buildings surrounding it) and absolutely worth the walk or subway ride from Shinjuku.
Nice views. Nice views of the city, its free, I suggest going there by night as it's much more beautifull this way. There is a restaurant and a souvenir shop on the floor.

Excellent View. We visited the viewing gallery in the afternoon, and the view was spectacular (can't imagine if you went at night - it'll be lovely). You could see Tokyo and if you're lucky, Mt Fuji too! The entrance was a little difficult to find, you have to walk inside and underground too. However there are signage guiding the way so it should be fine. There are several souvenirs shops in the building so you can do some shopping after sightseeing. Admission is free!

Wonderful night view. Went there at night and I must say, the view was worth any travel. You get a beautiful site and a true feeling just how big Tokyo is. At no cost and only a brief elevator ride up to 45th floor, this is worth it!

Stunning nighttime views. The views of Tokyo from here at night are truly stunning. Lights to the horizon. It was difficult to find the entrance (it's on the lower level). Elevator takes you quickly to the viewing level where there are plenty of souvenirs for purchase and signs showing the buildings you can see.
Excellent view. Perfect for a grand view of Tokyo. Free admission which was a plus! We had lunch in the restaurant which was lovely. Definitely will return.
Tokyo Metropolitan Building. This is a great place to go early in the day before you head out if staying in Shinjuku. We had great views of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji, plus it is free!
The best views of Tokyo. I really enjoyed this experience. I recommend it to everyone, it is free and you won't regret coming here.

Spectactular view. A great view for free from the 45th floor of this building. There were no people waiting for the elevator. On an a sundaymorning the entrance is at the right side of the building. For the best view of the skyline you have to enter the restaurant, but will be send away without ordering food or drink. Doesn't matter, there is enough opportunity from the sidewindows. In the shop sunglasses for ¥1.000.

great view and its free. I think this makes it worth the trip because its free and not very crowded. The view is nice too. for another free view and some fresh beer visit the asahi building to see the skytree area for free

Observatory . The observatory at the to( not sure but I think it's on level 45) has a good view of the city. There is no entry charges. There's also a nice souvenir shop located at the same level. Such a shame that there's no air conditioner.

If you are looking for a view of Tokyo this is it!. It is free to visit the observatories at the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. Helpful staff in the building will gladly direct you to the elevators that take you up to the observatory. The elevator attendant was very friendly and keen to practice his English with us. Once in the observatory we found it to be quite empty. There are many places to take photos and you are offered a 360 degree view of Tokyo. In the observatory there is also and extensive giftshop selling many packaged Japanese foods you could take home, as well as a more traditional giftshop as well. The cafe in the observatory is quite nice and the price were reasonable.

A free view to watch Tokyo skyline. The reason I visited is to take the ride to the tourist level free view. is worth the walk from the Shinjuku station as the walk is very lighted no good architecture.

Free view of the city . Entrance can be tricky, enter by the basement and not the 1st floor.. not many people coming up for the view but was fast and organised. The view up top was simple with city lights in the distance. Has a small gift shop with cute toys and a cafe. Spent about 20mins.

views of Tokyo for free. get Tokyo views from the 45th floor for free. we went on a Wednesday evening for sunset and it wasn't too crowded. good place to go if you want city views for free. apparently on a clear day you can see Mount Fuji.
Great views. Excellent views of Tokyo in all directions from both towers both day and night. During the day, there are volunteers standing buy to answer any questions that you may have

Definitely worth a detour. The views from the top of this building are amazing - as are the gift shops that greet you at the top.The highlight though is visiting the staff canteen - it's a bit of an adventure to find and select and pay for your food but you get the best traditional japanese food with a grand view surrounded by the Govt workers in the building. Great experience

Great free observation decks, but be prepared to queue before they open. We visited the South Observation Deck in the Tokyo Metropolitan Office and were impressed by the view provided of the urban sprawl that is Shinjuku. Unfortunately, it was a cloudy day and we couldn't see far into the horizon, so sighting Mt Fuji was not possible. It would be definitely worth a visit on a clear day, just to catch sight of Mt Fuji.Entry to the observation decks are free, so be prepared for a queue when they open in the morning. We were lucky and caught a lift to the deck that wasn't too crowded (it might have helped that we had the baby in a stroller). Subsequent groups were packed into the lifts like sardines.There is a small souvenir shop in the observation deck and a shop selling Japanese goods (foods, drinks, skincare). The prices were a bit inflated, as expected, given the location.
It's free and I was able to see Mt. Fuji. Luckily the sky was clear and there was snow covered Mt. Fuji off in the distance. Good views of Tokyo and helpful volunteer staff to answer your questions.

Wonderful View of Tokyo. Highly recommend going to Tokyo Government building at night to see the city view! This was so worth taking the time to take the elevator to the top of the building. It is not so hectic and you are able to take your time to enjoy the city lights at night.
Beautiful viewpoint for free. Great view over the Tokyo skyline completely for free. Highly recommend having a drink a the bar to see the full 360 degree view
Great view of Tokyo. We went and saw the view of Tokyo which was really nice and free also which was great. Bit confusing trying to get into the building but we managed to find our way.
Free Views!. Highly recommended for any traveller. Office allows visitors both daytime and nighttime to the top floors for cityscape viewing. Price is free and staff is multilingual.
beautiful view. you can get up for free , and there are two towers , you can choose which one you want to get up ( both are free ) , if the weather is nice , you can also see the mountain Fuji!

City views!. The building itself is pretty creepy but once you get up in on of the towers (we went to the south one) the view is really nice. Also, we got to talk to a very nice man working there, telling us all about the surrounding buildings, the history of Tokyo etc. Well worth a visit if you are in Shinjuku. It is for free!
Towers. It is very good. It has 45 flors. You can go tu the flor 1, 2 and 45. It has got very good view. The 2 towers are conected with a bridge.

Beautiful View. This building is fairly large, looks impressive from the outside, and from the look out point it does not disappoint. There isn't much to do while your up there, souvenir shop, a restaurant, but we went for the sun set, which i recommend, it was a nice sight, quiet and allowed us to take some great pics.Take the time, drop in, see the sun set, head to dinner.

It was nice stop. On my last day in tokyo, i stopped here to take a look at the tallest building in tokyo. i did not make it to the observation deck, since i had already been to the top of the skytree. it was nice to sit in the middle and look up and admire its height. its worth stopping by and having a gaze, but just prepared for the shinjuku-ku metro. it can be very confusing and its combined with an underground mall, adding to the chaos.

The Most Popular Observatory for Great Views in Tokyo!!. This is one of the great observatories in Tokyo, along with Tokyo SkyTree, Tokyo Tower, Roppongihills, World Trade Center(Seaside Top). But, this is the most popular one because it's free. When you exit the JR Shinjuku station from its West Exit, you walk straight the underground street until you get out of the tunnel(5 min), and you walk another 3 min, and the Toyko Metropolitan Government Building is there.

Wonderful views. Of the City and very well organized...two areas north and south observatories help you get an aerial view of the city...in each observatory there were different things to see also...one was Japanese embroidery....Worth the time to go and if you are in Tokyo for a short time this is a great place to visit...

Free to visit with 360 degree views. The clouds cleared and there was Mount Fuji. The gardens around the Government Building were modern and very beautiful, full of cherry blossom. No queues, so straight up to the viewing tower with a 360 degree views. There is a coffee shop and tourist shop at the top too. Once back on the ground floor, we found a very helpful Tourist Information Office, with very useful free maps and guides.
Grand Design and views to match. Beautifully designed building with great views over Tokyo and beyond from the 42nd floor and all for free. Worth the walk from the metro station!

Incredible views of Tokyo and if you're lucky, Mt.Fuji. Spent an hour or so waking around the sky deck of the Met. Government Building in Shinjuku. After jumping through many stages of security I took the elevator to the 47th floor sky deck.Firstly, it's with noting that the South facing sky deck offer far superior views than the North facing one (Separate towers).The views from the top are breathtaking. Overlooking thousands of high rise buildings covering downtown Tokyo, you can also pan round to the distant mountain ranges and views of Mt.Fuji. The whole experience is completely free.
Great view for free!. If you would like to have a great view of Tokyo for free just go to the Metropolitan building, easy access by train.

Difficult to find. We walked underground from Shinjuku station, signs kept pointing to "Tokyo Government offices" we finally found it, but could not find the entrance. As we were leaving we discovered there was a train stop next to the building. On a clear day you can get a good view of Tokyo. However our hotel, Tokyo Dome, was 45 stories. There is a restaurant on the top floor, but you are welcome to go into the bar and experience the view. This was a more central location and also free.

Best view of tokyo on a clear day. nice and best view of tokyo on a clear day you would love it worth the trip there but have to line up and wait to get up there better view here then tokyo tower my view
Nice night view. Very nice night view with free access. Brought my parents there and had nice night view at 45 floor. Within walking distance from prince hotel.

Amazing skyline view at night. The view at night was amazing. However it was very busy. It was also difficult to actually find the entrance to get inside the tower as there was one specific door to a specific lift to get upstairs to the panoramic view floor (we weren't the only ones who struggled).
Great view, great deal. This is free. I've heard that the sky tree is quite expensive, so if you're with a group and want to get vertical, this is your best bet.Enter from ground level.

Superb service and location. Nice to visit the Tower, and the Tourist Office at Level 1 was superbly well connected with Events, Places to visit and information on Sights for ALL JAPAN.Staff spoke English and were very proficient in explanations and information.One stop for all your needs.I booked a Volunteer tourist guide for Tokyo withotu expense. Only needed provide travel an food with you.Tips were not expected and not accepted."It is my pleasure to bring you around to share my country , Japan withyou", was their response.Need to book guide at least 1 day in advance.It made travel and connections and explanations more enlightening and easier.
Great views . Wow . Pretty impressive view and best of all it's free . Was a little overcast when we went but still pretty amazing the size of Tokyo

Free Views!. If you are in Shinjuku then this building should be on your list of attractions. Free views in either tower from the 45th floor reveal the staggering size of the city. A great way to kill an hour and imagine Godzilla rampaging through the city.

Great views, long queue. You can see all across the city from the top of the building. On a clear day apparently you can see My Fuji too. There are topographic signs to indicate what you can see where. Only problem is that you may only queue a couple of minutes to get up, but then you get stuck and have to queue 20 minutes to get back down!

Great viewpoint. Decided to check out the view from the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office after seeing it on TripAdvisor. A huge bonus is that it is free to visit the top. You have to go through very short security before getting in the lift but that's it. There was a max 10 minute wait in a queue. You can choose whether to go up the South or North tower, or both. The view from the top is very impressive. I was surprised with how large the viewing room is, which was also a bonus, as it can seem quite packed at times. You get a great view of the whole city, especially if it is a clear day. I would definitely recommend it over other viewing points that you must pay for and often queue quite a while for.
Great Views. We went at night and there were no crowds. You go up to the 45th floor and you have fantastic views over the city and it is free.

Free observation towers in Shinjuku. It was a beautiful clear day when we went up the towers in the hope of seeing Mt Fuji but unfortunately Mt Fuji was still in cloud. I don't know how many days a year you actually get a view of Fuji from anywhere in Japan but it certainly isn't very frequently from my experience and from what I've heard. Still, it's worth making the short walk from Shinjuku station to the government buildings to go up to the observation decks as it's an amazing overview of Tokyo and surrounding areas. The souvenir shops are also surprisingly good and reasonably priced.

Day and night visit. After reading this in a travel blog i decided to give it ago. The view is pretty good. We stopped in at breakfast on the first day the food wasnt bad for the price.Given the its free to get into the building.The view is pretty good though tokyo is smoggy so it depends on the day as to what you can see.The entrance to the viewing platform is from under the building.The south tower is the one that opens the longest it is also taller than the north tower but both are free.

Free is good. What more can I say it's free and you have great views. It can get pretty busy but can't complain it's free. Went to the observation deck at Roppongi and also the Skytree, which you have to pay to use. I'd say it's worth experiencing all 3 but if you are on a budget you cant go wrong with the Metropolitan Government Building.

Good for the skyline but that's it!. It's just a tall building from where you get to see Tokyo's skyline. I've seen better skylines including that of Hong Kong. You can give this a miss. Because we were in Shinjuku, we decided to check it out.

Excellent free view . We visited in the evening about 8pm. No line going up short line coming down of about 5min wait. Great view of the city from 45th floor and its free. If you have a JR pass there is a JR station about 800m away. We weren't aware until after and used subway about 200m from entrance.

Free and nice. The view is amazing! Plus we had a guide throughout the visit that told us everything we could possibly want! From the name of the hotel where "lost in translation" was shot to the height of the towers!
And all for free!
I prefer the view at night but it's also good day time.

Great view for free. If you want a view of the Tokyo skyline and city in general and don't want to pay the ridiculous price for something like Tokyo SkyTree, then visit here! You just get your bag(s) quickly checked and are escorted into the elevator, which takes you to the observatory. Yes, there are some tourist trap souvenir shops, but hey, it's a view of the city and its free.

Worth a visit.. Short walking distance from Shinjuku station, this is well worth the effort. Admission is free and there are two look outs, the south and the north, South is the best during the day as on a clear day Mt Fuji can be seen. The northern tower is best in the evenings as you can look over the night lights of Shinjuku.
View. If you want to get an amazing FREE view of the city go to this place on the 45 th floor , you have a panoramic views and beautiful for your photographs. Also good gift shops also can be found .

Great views for free. It is great to be able to see quite how large Tokyo is for free. The views are very good. I arrived at about 6pm and got to see views at dusk, sunset and night - I would recommend this. There is also free wifi. The restaurant did not look to expensive but there was a 1000 Yen charge for the music being played, starting from 18:15 onwards I think.
Decent view...and its free.. Good place to get a great view of Tokyo and its free. I suggesat getting there early...the lines look like they can be pretty long.

Trying to see Mount Fuji . We arrived in the afternoon and Mount Fuji wasn't visible at this time. We enjoyed the view of the city. The souvenir store on the same floor as observatory is very nice. There was a line to wait for the elevator, however it was very fast and nice opportunity to connect with other visitors. Recommended overall. For best chance to see Mount Fuji it is advisable to arrive early in the morning.

Great views for free. Few observatories are truly free but this one really is, and it is certainly worth a trip up to the top to view the huge expanse of Tokyo. It is hard to conceive until you see it!On arrival we were advised that it was a half hour wait but I think we probably only queued for about 20mins. The line moves quickly! The queue and ascent is well managed. The view from the top is excellent (we went late afternoon on a very clear day) and there are helpful signs to show you what everything is. We were also just able to see Mt Fuji which was a real treat! I didn't rate the shops- a bit overpriced and very touristy- but others seem to enjoy them.Very much worth a visit for a view of Tokyo from above. Recommended!

Stunning few from the 43rd floor!. You have to be early and it is best to go on a clear day if you want to see mount Fuji at its finest. All and all just a great (and free) attraction to see tokyo from up high.If you go a floor down you have a tourist information centre and in the other building next to it they have a really nice lunch room.

Skip the Skytree, the views from here are incredible, and they're FREE!. The Tokyo Metropolitan office is a short walk from the Nishi-Shinjuku subway station, accessible on the Maranouchi (red) subway line. With all the tall buildings in the area, it's not immediately visible when you leave the subway. It took me about 5-6 minutes or so to walk to the building from the subway exit. Take the elevator to the one of the observation platforms on the 45th floor and prepare to be blown away by the vistas of Tokyo in all directions. On a clear day, Mount Fuji is clearly visible. Considering that it's totally free to access the observation decks here, I can't see why anyone would pay a few thousand yen to see the same views from the Tokyo Skytree.

Free view of Tokyo. We visited this building as to its free to go up to the top. Not a 360° view. There's a cocktail bar at the top but they won't admit you if it's too close to closing time. Saves £12 per person than going to the Tokyo Skytree.

Beautiful Night View from 45th floor and FREE!. We got to visit this TMG Building to see the city from 45th floor at night, it was so niceee and it also free, inside the observatory you can buy souvenirs if you want, they sell mostly characters and I almost broke if I buy it haha..you can go to this place by walking from nearest Subway Nishi-Shinjuku Station (M07) or Tochomae Station (E28) rather than walking from Shinjuku Station which is little bit far, around 20 minutes..from the top you can also spotted Tokyo Tower :) I visited this place before taking Willer Bus to Kyoto so while waiting my bus time I went to TMG Building :)

Quite disappointing..... Well, I heard that the Tokyo metropolitan building was a nice alternative of the Tokyo sky tree since it was free and had good views anyway. I researched quite a lot about the opening hours and what day it closes.... and I thought that the 4th Monday of the month would be a good time to visit. Anyways, it said that the south observatory was open on the 4th Monday of the month. BUT, I was really disappointed to arrive there having the guard block the entrance and say "it is closed." Why would the website say it is open and then actually come there in reality, knowing that it was closed?!We had to walk very very far just to arrive in the Tokyo metropolitan building, only to find out that it was closed....it was really sad....

better to visit during day, it's okay. even it is free and open during night, I can recommend to visit during the day, so you can have a nice view and take photos. shop on the visit floor is expensive, skytree has much better view however it is not free :(
OK. Visited the building after the Tokyo Skytree. A bit disappointed. The view is not closed to the Skytree.

went to the Observation floor. Even up to 11pm you can see the magnificent sights of Shinjuku and Tokyo from this Government Building and even shop for things plus have a nice drink in their Bar. Great surprise at how wonderful the View was and how many people were there. Worth the trouble to go there especially late at night
great views from the top and its free and accessible. there is a souvenir shop on top and very accessible and staff very friendly, this attraction is free and is a must see, near train station

Beautiful architecture and free views over Tokyo. I love looking at the building from the outside, but if you want a free view over Tokyo, this is the place! Sunshine 60, Tokyo Tower and the Sky Tree all make you pay, but here you just sail up (either side is fine) and get all the view you want. Perfect for doing spontaneously on a fine day.There's a wee cafe and bar where you can sit and sip a drink while you look out over the city. Very peaceful.

Great View of Tokyo and Place for Souvenirs. There are two towers, North and South. For free, you can go to either tower to its 45th floor to get a panoramic view of Tokyo. There you can also buy some souvenirs and find machines that could make souvenir coins while you wait.
Good services, Free panorama. Also some souvenirs shop over there. Have to go there once. Good landscape. Important free! On floor 45th you can see good view from there.
Free views of Tokyo. Excellent free attraction in Shinjinku. We went up both towers and to get views of Tokyo. Both had souvenir shops and a café to eat at.

Very good and gorgeous building blocks . High rise building blocks, each block had a sitemap for directions but not so clear if we need to find whether the south or north wing. We are visiting when golden week so a little bit quiet near here because no office activity. Surrounded by other building block and five stars hotels
Excellent Views. We went up to the viewing deck on the North building. We were there as the sun started to set. No chairs so you could not hang around a long time. There was no charge for the visit.
Views n city haze. easy to access great views (360 degrees) over Tokyo. Plenty of gifts shop souvenirs on offer and at standard prices. Nice cafe also available - good cake and coffee.
Nothing much for a free pass to the top. I think it wasn't worth the time, and I had plenty of time. Skyline was vague on the horizon, wanted to find Fuji but couldn't. Was at the northern tower .

View of all of Tokyo 360 degrees. There is a quick and free elevator ride that gets you to the top of this great view point for all of Tokyo.
There is a restaurant type establishment on the top, but prices were exaggerated. Gift shop on top with nice souvenirs
Amazing View. You can got up and see the whole of Tokyo and its free. The view is pretty amazing and on a good day you can even see Mt Fuji in the distance.

Good view, IT'S FREE, and some interestiung souvenirs available. A Shinjuku MUST! It's free, a short stroll from the station (underground, much of it on moving walkways). Gives a great view of the Tokyo skyline and the skyscrapers. And we found a better selection of souvenirs here than in many other parts of Japan.

Free View. If you happen to stop off at the TMGO, it's a beautiful and free view of the Tokyo skyline. The only thing is be prepared to spend money on touristy stuff when you get to the top! You will definitely spend money if you have a kid that cries when you try to keep him away from the toys. I did manage to find some nice name plates that had your name translated in Japanese.

Why visit any other tower??. I can't fathom why anyone pays the entry fees at other observation decks. Not only was it free here, and the views as good as anywhere else in the city, but it wasn't that crowded. Unfortunately the haze blocked views of Fuji, but that's just luck of the draw.

Not suitable for panoramic photo-shooting. Free of charge attraction, well-maintained and well-organized. Good to have a glance at the skyline with description boards in place. Not suitable for panoramic photo shoot as the windows are not connected (separated by pillars).

Free. Nice view over the Tokyo. Easy to access, at least if you are staying Shinjuku area. There were no long lines to the lift. The most important thing is really that there are amazing view and it's free!

Average. Average view at night. However it was free so can't complain too much.
May be better in the day with the other tower opened.

360 view of Tokyo. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office are two identical towering buildings near Keio Plaza Hotel. One can access the South tower for an elevator ride to the 45th floor to get a FREE 360 view of Tokyo. You can even get a glimpse of Mt. Fuji on a clear day. It was cloudy on the day we went unfortunately so we were unable to see it. Crowd is not too bad and moves fast. Definitely a MUST stop if you are in Shinjuku area.

FREE amazing view of Tokyo! . My hotel was really near. The building have 2 towers with free amazing view. The northAbd the south tower. We visit both of them. One is only open during the day and the other one close at 11 pm and it's free. So sometimes going back at 10 pm to our hotel we would just go up and have a great view of the city before going to bed. From Shinjuku station follow the signs Metropolitan Governement Building or MTB and there's a long tunnel you can walk trough to get there.

Great view & a great place to buy some souvenirs. The day I went there it was pretty cloudy, but I still found the view from the 45th floor amazing! Also the souvenir shops were full of lots of items with popular characters like Rilakkuma, Gudetama and Totoro on them. The elevator ride might have been free, but I know I wasn't able to resist buying some souvenirs!
It's Free. Went to both, north and south towers where you can get a panaromic view of Tokyo from the 45th floors. Mt. Fuji is visible depending on the cloud covering. You can't beat the price.

Free elevator ride but best view blocked by restaurant. . You get a free elevator ride to the 45th floor (660 ft) to check out the view of Tokyo. The views are killer but the best view is blocked by the restaurant/bar that you have to eat/drink at the gain access. Now in all fairness the food smelled heavenly. It serves mainly Italian food and a couple of curries. It was reasonably priced too, but not for those on a budget. The rest of the floor is filled with knickknack shops of Japanese toys. Go at night bc it's free and pretty but remember the best view is blocked.

Free. The most important you should come here because it is free. You cannot find any high building than here in tokyo with free entrance ticket, imaging that you have to pay 3k yen(30usd) to enter skype.. From the building, you can see almost tokyo from the top. You shoukd come here at night so it maybe beautiful with light.

Free great views. Just across the road from the Keio Plaza Hotel where we were staying. They have 2 free lifts marked North & South that you queue for, but we were processed quickly. The view of Tokyo is excellent but this is subject to the weather on the day of your visit. You may even be able to see Mt Fuji. They have information on the various sights to be seen on the window shelfs around the building. A souvenir shop is also located on the floor.

An excellent view. A beautiful view of Tokyo. Well worth the trip. The restaurant at the top was almost empty. This has to be the best breakfast view in town. The coffee was not great but it didn't detract from the experience.

A view of the city. It's about 10mins walk from the train station. We got a view of the yoyogi park and nearby. Also got booklets of all the cities in Japan. What to see, eat and buy. Maps. Very useful.
Great view of Tokyo. This is a good way to get a panoramic view of Tokyo and it's free!!!Quite easy to find, staff were very helpful. Open till late so good to see Tokyo by night aswell

excellent viewing opportunity. the observation from the top of this highrising building is breathtaking. only from above you can get the full impression of this mega metropolitan city. highly recommended.
Great views from the 45th floor. Free attraction, great views, if you are lucky you might even see Fuji-san! Access is till late so you can watch the sunset over Tokyo.

More than just a city hall. You never fully realize the size of Tokyo and what it takes to govern that many people until you see this building. You can see a great view of Tokyo from here, but even more, you can watch and appreciate the sheer size of the city from this building.
Great view of the city and it's free. This place is worth a visit. It's easy to access and free. The park just across the road is also pleasant to wander through.

Sun set beside mt. Fuji. The reception were very very nice. The elevator can contain lots of people. The queue was quite long but we can pass through in a minute. It was 44 floor you can see all city view of Tokyo and my Fuji (very far but amazing). It is a must visit when you reach shinjuku.
Nice view and good value.. Nice view, but through glass. You can see Fuijisan unless it's very cloudy. Good gift shop. A bit of a wait but it's free!

Panoramic view with great souvenir shops!. A FREE panoramic view of the city and the best place to get souvenirs! There were many different souvenirs stands, and especially one that had many great Japanese Star Wars items.

Observation Deck. Free observation deck in the two towers on the 41st or 42nd floor. Lift takes about 50 seconds from ground to observation deck, my partner gets a little funny with heights but she was okay with this one. Panoramic view of Tokyo and on a clear day can see Mt Fuji in the skyline. Cafe is also located on this level with restrooms.
Beautiful view. We went in the evening so that we could see Tokyo by night.. Was beautiful although it was raining outside so the pictures was not the best. But we managed to enjoy the view.

Panorama of the city from the 40 floor. Panorama of the city from the 40 floor is not bad, you can go, if you are near this place.not a big place, on the floor has: a gift shop, a restaurant and a panorama of the city from a height.Maximum time is needed: 30 minutesPlus : this place it's free and easy to find.
Free spot with good view. No need to pay to watch Tokyo. Get there and do it for free from 45th floor. Get there on sunny day for great view all over city or ven futher.
Must see observation deck. This observation deck gives you some amazing views over Tokyo and best of all its free! Plus when we went up there they were having a food fair which a lovely little bonus.
Wonderful view. There are two views. One north, the other south. There's more to see to the south. So better take that elevator.With some luck you can even see Mount Fuji!

A fun way to get blown away by the sheer size of Tokyo - for free!. This is a free service, apparently, and really (as is typical for Japan) well designed from a process flow perspective. They ushered us into a line, elevator and onto the 80th or so floor of this really high Shinjuku building, and we spent a good hour strolling around the 360 degree sweeping panorama. Plenty of huge windows, plenty of seating, a little restaurant and gift shop all made for a pleasant environment from which we were able to form an impression of the hugeness of Tokyo. I've heard you can see Fuji-san from here but it was too cloudy.
Good observation deck for free. . Good observation deck at no charge but not much else. The surrounds are quite bland but it's worth the visit even though it will be brief.

Free views of the city. Free. Easy to access with Shinjuku station nearby. Just follow the sighs to city hall. Entrance in the evening is on the lower level, follow the signs. It is also free. Views are spectacular. There is a gift shop with a lot of random items for sale. Do not forget to your stamp, near the elevator exit.

Good view and it is FREE. The top of the building offer a 360 panaramic view of Tokyo. On a good day, you may even see Mt. Fuji. The staff operating the lifts are polite and even bow as the lift close. What more can u expect. The ground is well maintained and it is all FREE.

Underrated, considering it's free!. It was somewhat difficult to find, farther away from the station then expected, but manageable. We expected to be impossible to enter, but it was weekday and almost closing time so we didn't wait at all. Fast climb to the top. It wasn't 360° view because there is a cafe in which you can't enter without buying drinks, but well, they must cover their expenses somehow. So I didn't give them 5 but 4 stars. If there is a reflection from the glass, use hands to cover the lens.

Good view, but greenhouse effect. Great view, and it's fantastic that it is for free, however we went in early October, and the place was absolutely roasting warm. The air con (if there was one) was not turned on, and the sun bounced in and around the walls of the viewing area. It was very hot up there.There's a nice little gift shop and a place to eat, however we found it too uncomfortable to stay long.

Let them eat cake. There is a great view from up here, but the café was one of many disappointing experiences for vegetarians in Japan. They had three savoury dishes, all meat. I ate a croissant for lunch. As later meals consisted of chocolate cake (2) and cheesecake (1), I guess a croissant isn't too unhealthy. Long queue for lift to go down.

A free view of the city. These towers are complimentary to the public and well worth the two block walk from the Tokyo Hilton. Arts and crafts are available on the upper floor, along with eager English speakers.
Great views. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office offers amazing views of Tokyo and its FREE! During nighttime the views are better...avoid going during the weekend

Superb views of Tokyo and it is free!. It is really worthwhile visiting Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office for its top floor views of Tokyo. The additional benefit of this is that it is free of charge. Be aware there may be queues to go up. We visited at night time for truly spectacular views of Tokyo's neon skyline. We walked from Shinjuku station - this took about twenty minutes of brisk walking through underground tunnels. Highly recommended.

We visited at dark and had reflection behind us. Go during the day. From the 40+ floor you get an exquisite view of this extraordinary building. There was a queue of about 15 minutes. Bags are searched. A must to get a picture of this great city

A great view of tokyo. This is a great activity to familiarise yourself with the city of Tokyo. There were move places I discovered from my visit to the viewing floor than I had time to discover on this trip.

Free, Cool views. Awesome 360 views of Tokyo, funny how they have access from the JR Shinjuku station but dangg it was really far, like a never ending walk haha. But it was definitely worth it. They have an interesting toyshop and dining at the observation deck. I saw the menu it wasnt that expensive. Would probably nice to try next time.

Great place for night view of Tokyo. Sightseeing platform is open until 10PM so you can enjoy both day and night view of Tokyo. However, since platform is within the building and covered with windows, the glass can be reflected in the photos. The vieviwn platform is free, which is really great bonus. Upstairs is souvenir shop and restaurant.

Free and a must do!. If you're on a budget and can only do one observation deck. I recommend this one. You can look into the concrete jungle that is tokyo but also spot the space reserved for greenery. Loved it.

Worth visiting. The two towers in the Government office building are worth visiting because there is no charge for going to the 45th floor of both the north and south towers. Here you can get a 360 degree view of Tokyo and the views are quite spectacular.

Night view experience. Not bad, open late so we headed to the top after dinner. View was nice, but certain areas were hard to see out of due to glare from the indoor lights. Still worth it, probably better in the day or just as the sun is setting.

Beautifull at night. In night time the view is so beatifull, and the best part - its free, but you don't get that feeling!
The staff is very polite, gives you direction and take the job very serious.
I guess after 15 min you will move to the next attrection

Free view. Followed the signs at JR Shinjuku station, took us roughly 20 minutes till we reached it. View was decent, however since it is for free, you can't really complain. There is also a restaurant above and some souvenir stores.
Great meeting spot with amazing views!!. Met friends at the top which turned out great since we could easily find the building and enjoyed the expansive views of the city we were about to explore.

Nice view of Tokyo. wonderful to see the aerial view of Tokyo on top of 45th floor
great photos opportunity when it's clear and sunny

Much better than Sky Tree or Tokyo Tower and much cheaper!. Go on a clear day. That is all I need to say.
Well worth the price of admission (FREE).
This is one of the highlight attractions in Tokyo Metro area.
Plenty of great lunch places nearby.
Close to Shinjuku Station and Plaza.
South Tower. The tower should offer a view to Mt. Fuji but only on a clear day. No charge to visit - have to wait for a lift but not too long. Very good view of the Shinjuku high rises.

Relaxed and friendly fun staff. There were no crowds or waiting in long queues . The staff were fun and friendly and there was plenty of room at the windows for everyone to get good views. A beautiful building with a lovely forecourt at the bottom level. I highly recommend and it's free.

Cheap sky-high view. If you're put off by the price of the views at the SkyTree or the Tower, then this is the place for you...it's free!! Offering as great a view as both the SkyTree and Tokyo Tower (I've visited all three), this is the place I return to and send all my friends.

Great views. This is one of the best places we found for views of Tokyo and the best part is that it's all free :) You can look out from all 4 sides of the building, there is a little shop at the top and a restaurant. There are also toilets and a smoking room at the top.

Free views of the city from the 48th floor. We went up this building on a Sunday and only one of the towers was open (I think it was the south). We had to queue for half an hour which I don't think was bad. The 360 degree views are breath taking and there's a coffee shop up there which was very quiet and so had lots of seating available in contrast to those at street level. For a free attraction it's great.

Great views, but there are better. Massive building best accessed via metro. Helpful information provided in the offices, lots of bits and pieces on sale from the viewing floor - north floor. Whilst the sky tree provides views are gob smacking, the building is worth a visit before the sky tree if in Shinjuku

Awsome!. Saw this building on the tourist guide book and was not too keen to go and see a building, however this building is so impressive and it towers into the sky. I wanted to go to the observatory but my husband has a fear of heights. the architecture is amazing. Must see this building.

Fantastic Views - North and South Towers. While Tokyo Tower offers views like Eiffel in Paris, Tokyo Metropolitan Government (TMG) Building offers even better views from its two towers for free; Very convenient; 45th Floor and Great restaurant while you view 360;

Great view of Tokyo !. I would thoroughly recommend visiting this building for a panoramic view of Tokyo and Mount Fuji on a clear day. Best thing of all - entry is FREE ! This attraction is only a short walk from Shinjuku JR station.Highly recommended.

Nothing to write home about. Well okay, it's free, but that doesn't make it great at all. Rather spend $15 and go to the observation floor at the Mori Building in Roppongi Hills. The view there is much more beautiful and much more interesting. And Roppongi Hills and direct environment has more to offer.
Amazing. Stayed at a hotel across the road from this building it looks stunning when lit up at night. I recommemd going to the Keio plaza bar to get an amazong view at sunset

A nice view over Tokyo. This isn't bad but nothing amazing. It's nice to see out over Tokyo and it's free entry which makes it good value for money at least.
We went on an overcast afternoon which was a shame as we couldn't see Mt Fuji.

Superb views from the free viewing floors. The public can have free access by fast lift to the observation floors (Level 45) of either the north or south tower which offer commanding views of the city and, on a very clear day,even of Mount Fuji. The indoor viewing rooms have informative displays in English pointing out the main landmarks and there were several volunteer guides who were keen to talk to us and explain many of the sights.

Great view of the city and it's free. The towers are a great way to get an idea of how big Tokyo really is. It was a great view of the city, not far from Shinjuku train station, and it is free. If you are in the neighborhood, walk a few minutes to get a new perspective on Tokyo.

Observation Decks are FREE to visit :). Lovely views of Tokyo. Visit both sides of the tower - North and South views. Fall in line and have your bags checked. Elevator rides take less than a minute to the observation view. Worth visiting!
Free... not impressed. Can't complain since it's free.But viewing facility is a bit old and the view isn't impressive.Would only go if had lots of time to kill.
Free to access the observatory!. You can access the observatory for free and have an excellent view of Tokyo city! It is located quite close to Shinjuku station.

Skip it. I live in Chicago, the home of two cool observation towers in the Hancock and Willis Tower buildings. Plus I work on the 64th floor of the Aon Center. I never tire of the views. But Tokyo doesn't really have a skyline. Only a couple of buildings could really be considered skyscrapers. I was totally disappointed by the views. Maybe if it is clear enough to see Mt Fuji, it might be worth it. But otherwise don't waste your time stopping here.

東京都庁舎　［新宿］　Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building, Shinjuku. I went to the obersavation deck of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building during my lunch break when I was staying at the Keio Plaza Hotel which is directly opposite. I could see the twin peaks from my hotel room. Between 1990 and 2007 this was Tokyo's tallest skyscraper. Since the viewing deck is free entry, everybody should go.

Great views over Tokyo at night. This place is a must if you are travelling on a budget in Tokyo. It's free and provides great 360 degree views of the city. Follow the signs from Shinjuku station, through the subway, to get there

A magnificent piece of architecture. Don't miss the trip to the top.. This is a breath-taking piece of architecture by any standards. The trip to the viewing floors is a must-do. It's free - look down on the vastness of Tokyo. There are 2 towers, at least one is usually open. On a clear day, you might see Mt Fuji. The tearoom in Tower 1 is a quaint and pleasant experience.
Nice view for free. I don’t know if we were lucky, but there was no line when we were there. As mentioned in all other reviews you have a nice view over the city for free.

Better places in Tokyo to see a spectacular view. Okay, it is free to go up the MET Building, so if you are on a tight budget and aren't' going to go up the Sky Tree then I guess this is a good option. Views are fine, but it is busy and not very high up in comparison to a lot of the other buildings. I'd really urge people to go tot he Sky Tree if they want to view the city... I wouldnt' wast my time going here.
Free view of Tokyo. Free trip to the top floors. One us also open at night. Lots of shops on the observation floor. OK .Tokyo Tower is better but you have to pay.

Its free and gives a great view. The main benefit of this place is that its free and should the fog be out (as it was most days for us) you'll get just as good a view as anywhere else. Its easily located from the subway and you can stamp your passport (or postcard) if you wish. There is a gift shop in the centre of the observation deck and a café. If its a bit foggy then don't get your wallet out for the Skytree, come here!.

Fabulous Free View 45 storey's up above Shinjuku Tokyo. It's not the Tokyo Skytree but you can still see Mt Fuji on a clear day.The South Tower Closes earlier and the North Tower is open much later and good for those night time views.If you can offord the Skytree then you can do the Skytree as well and you can see both the Skytree and Tokyo Tower from T.M.G.B.We decided to do this building first and looked at the cost of the Tokyo Tower and Skytree couldn't justify doing both so we did this building and the skytree but the Tokyo tower is cheaper your call.I was happy with the photo's i took and the souvenir shops are also more affordable at the Government building and also had some souvenirs i hadn't seen yet in my travels around JapanAnother must do, it's free and if it's nice weather you can do the other two observation towers depending on your budget.
Perfect view for free. Really nice place to see Tokio for free. Easily accessible. Directly next to the subway. A good start for exploring the city

Decent view of the city on a clear day. The south tower gives a good view of the Shinjuku Garden and the Meiji Gyoen/Yoyogi Park. I lucked out on seeing Mt. Fuji that day since it was pretty hazy. Access is free and there's a quaint cafe and souvenir shop at the viewing deck.
Free lookout over Tokyo. Go and get to the observation deck. It's free and you can get a coffee or other at the top. . ............................

Wish we had done this sooner! Panoramas at no cost.. We went to this spot on our last day in Tokyo, I would recommend it very early on in a trip to Tokyo. Not only do the buildings have an abundance of tourist information but they have free viewing decks that give you a 360 degree view of Tokyo and beyond. We waited literally 30 seconds for a lift and then were straight up. There were very few people up there and it was a peaceful and enjoyable activity that didn't cost a cent.

Worth visiting. You are not as high up as at the Skytree but A. it's free and B . you are able to identify all the different buildings so you have a greater perspective of Tokyo and Shinjuku's skyscrapers in particular. Also, the southern tower stays open at night until 11pm so you can go back a second time. We also enjoyed the exhibition and sale of specialities from all the different Provinces of Japan which was on at the time. Another bonus was the friendly English-speaking volunteer guide who took us around and gave us a lot of interesting facts we would otherwise not have known.

Best view from the top :). By night, you can visit one of the building towers, where there is an observatory. You can have a GREAT view of the city from the top there, and at night it's just great with all the lights :) Close to the elevator in the observatory you can find a stamp for your passport in case you like attractions stamps. :)
Free view of Tokyo from 30+ storey. It was a great view and most important free. We also did Sky Tower which was paid and didnt find much difference. It has a restaurant and memento shops too

A bit touristy but amazing views of the city. Such an impressive building right in the middle of Tokyo. Easy walking distance from Shinjuku station and the view you get is amazing! The day we went up was very clear and we had a great view of the city. For a free attraction it is well worth the visit. The shops are very gimmicky, but can be avoided.

Great, free view of Tokyo!. Wait in a short line, then take an express elevator to a fantastic free view of Tokyo! Plus there are lots of tourist brochures and government sights to see. Great people watching and overall a totally worth it trip, especially if you're staying close by.
Fabulous and FREE. Amazing view of the city. We left this to the last day but suggest it earlier in your stay as it gives a great overview of Tokyo.

Do note the opening hours!. The north tower closes at 23:00 hours but they stop admission half an hour before, at 22:30 hours. Wrote this review as I saw people being turned away at 22:31 which I felt was a waste if only they knew about the entry closing half an hour before the closing time. Came here in the day last year and the night this time. Nice views, free of charge. They check your bag before you go up so don't carry anything you shouldn't.

It was closed . This is one of the famous viewing spots in Shinjuku but it was closed and no signs in English told us that it was not open. Even the Japanese who were trying to enter were surprised. The website says it opens every day but this is not true

Well worth a visit on a fine day. The usual Japanese efficiency to get in and out. If you look like a tourist all the staff know what you are there for and point you to the lift access.Great view and the best part it is FREE. ID photo boards around the windows to tell you what you are looking at. We were there around 11.30am and it was easy to get around.Highly recommended.

On a clear day ...... Firstly you line up in a short, orderly queue, squash into an elevator, shoot up to the observatory level and pour out into ...A space largely occupied with souvenir stalls with relatively little window space to enjoy the quite amazing views. The best views are reserved for the high-end restaurant which takes up one quarter of the available window space, the rest, the rest is a polite juggle into the best position for a photo then vacate that spot for the next person. Sure, the views are incredible, buildings all the way to every horizon, but the experience is nowhere near what it could be. Try the Tokyo sky-tree instead.
Scenery viewing. Free of charge scenery viewing of Tokyo. Not bad for first timer but probably you just need to go once for taking some photos.
Amazing government office . The walk way has blossom trees. This building was in the middle of Washington hotel and shinjuku grand tower.

Great for sunset photos. From the observatory you can take beautiful blue hours photos of Tokyo. You will find the place crowded, so arrive early and find you spot. No chairs, just clean widows and several superb landscapes

Free! With great tourism information and views. If you are in this region of Tokyo I definitely recommend taking the time to stop by here. The observation deck is free and has tremendous views of the city. I traveled here during the day so I am not too sure of the hours at night but you can see the entire city.

Free panoramic views of Tokyo. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government building offers 2 separate free observation decks one in each tower of the building. The view is wonderful from either tower.They have some souvenirs for sale as well. I recommend a visit at Sunset or after dark to soak in the beautiful glow of Tokyo. There are lots of places to enjoy views in Tokyo and this is one of the better places.

Hidden gem. Both towers are free and if you go during a week day there is no line. The view from the South tower is bit better, but in the restaurant on the north side you can get a table right by the window with amazing views, and the food and drinks are very affordable, albeit with a limited selection.

Amazing infomation. We managed to get on a free tour and it was amazing the lady was very friendly and pointed out all these interesting things you can see from the towers. Had amazing knowledge and her English was amazing

Better than the Tokyo Tower and it's free. Their are 2 observation galleries; one in the North Tower and one in the South Tower. Go for the latter, as it provides near 360 degrees viewing and views of mount Fuji if the weather is kind. There are also a number of guides (yellow jackets) who will tell you what you can see and also how the towers swaye 2 metres in the last big earthquake! All this for free and the queues move pretty fast. Once you are up you can stay as long as you like and enjoy refreshments too. Top value.

Good views of Tokyo. Of the few viewing towers in Tokyo, this is the odd one out in that it's free. Gives a good view of Tokyo. Just too bad that it was quite hazy on the day we were there. Weren't able to see very far. There's a restaurant and shop at the viewing gallery, and sufficient viewing space for all. There's also a tourist office at the ground level. Don't miss it if you need help with advice or tour bookings.
Good view. You can get a good view of Tokyo from here. It is not a full panorama as there is a restaurant that takes part of the floor. Clean toilets located one floor below the viewing floor.

Nice, free and lacks some animation. Very good directons to getting there. Kind staff speaking fair english. You can eat for normal price some ice cream at the top. There is no animation at the top. Still , taking into account that it is free of any charge, it is an excellent choice to make on a nice day with beautiful panorama over Tokyo.

Up to the Observatory. Went up to the observatory to look at how big Tokyo is. It's huge.We went up in time to see the sunset behind Mount Fuji. Well worth the trip. There was a queue to get up but it went quickly. Gift shop in the observatory was packed with the usual touristy gifts.
And it is Free.

good view over tokyo. Went at night and was able to see Tokyo lit up at night. Great views, and free compared to Tokyo skytree or tower so this would be your better bet. A bit of a walk from the JR station line though, don't think its worth the walk to go more than once.
need to visit both sides. We visited north side in day and south side at night terrific views from both towers with free entrance well worth visiting

Excellent views - for free. The South tower (recommended by our Tokyo guide) was an excellent visit. Great views - including a fuzzy view of Mount Fuji.
And its free - great value!

No inside visit. This was an impressive building and the structure of it is incredible.
For obvious reasons we weren't allowed to go inside.

A must-do if you want a free panoramic view of Tokyo!. Got there around 5pm and the queues were starting to get longer! However the process to go up is pretty smooth and fast. The lift takes you all the way up to the 45th floor, for free, and you get to enjoy some wonderful views of Tokyo. It was a bit hazy when we went so we didn't manage to see Mount Fuji unfortunately.A little cafe is available on that floor as well.
Observation Deck. Great spot to see a free view of the city. Always a favorite. Has a souvenir shop and cafe for you to enjoy.

Go on a cold but clear day. You could see Fuji-san on a clear day, and the lounge is a great place to unwind after a busy morning or going around exercising or shopping (or both). There is a smoking area one floor below, where you would be able to check out the other tower (the fire exit/staircase is close to the elevators)P.S. I went there alone! I wish my friends have told me to visit the cafeteria, which serves good food also!! Will do, next time.

Free and great view of city. Short queue of about 5 minutes, not overly crowded, at around 3.30 pm. Lovely view of the city. It's amazing to see this for free since most other such places in other countries there is usually an entrance fee. Tourist info at the basement level with lots of booklets and info for travellers.

Great place to see tokyo from above for free. We came on a weekday (it's closed on weekends) you can see a very nice 360 view of tokyo (the 360 view can only be seen from the south part!!). On a bright day you can also see the amazing mount fuji. We came one hour before closing time and there was no line so we got up pretty quickly to the 45th floor. There's also a restaurant where you can sit and drink coffee or eat a light meal, but it's rather expensive and it's not near the window so you can't really see the view for there. All in all it's a great thing to do when you are in tokyo.

Great view of Tokyo for free!. Fantastic view of Tokyo. You can go up the north or south towers and have a great view across the tokyo. You appreciate the size when you are up the top. It's also free!
Close to Shinjuku train station.

Nice view over the giant city. 10 min walking from shinjuku station, you can enjoy a nice free spot to observ the city, especially the shinjuku area and the big parks around (Meiji-jingu and Shinjuku Gyoen).

Great views and free!. We visited twice, once during the day and again at night. There was no queue in the afternoon but we queued for about 10 minutes in the evening. I would recommend choosing the correct exit and following the signs from the station, even if you don't arrive by train or metro, as it was easy to get lost on the busy streets.

Wonderful view of Tokyo. In no time you will be on 45th floor enjoying 360 degree panoramic view of Tokyo. We did not have clear view of Mt. Fuji (only on perfect days) but this did not ruin our experience. Access is free.Another thing, not known to many visitors, is free access to the cafeteria located on 32 floor. You will have to register with security guards and your access will be granted. The food ordering can be a bit challenging since there is no signs in English. In any case consider it as a game (at least we did) and we had real fun, You will have to match the color and the number from the displayed food, purchase the ticket from the vending machine and then match the color of the food outlet. Good food at very low price. Recommended.

A breathtaking view!. Such a wonderful, breathtaking and romantic view of Tokyo!Really recommended! And moreover it's for free.So no excuses, just go and enjoy the amazing view of Tokyo from the 45th floor.
Worth a trip for a few minutes. The ride up is free and the view is fine. On the way to the hotel it was a pit stop and the view was fine. Would not go out of your way to see this.

Free Attraction with Good View. Do not go with a high expectation.The place is easily located near Shinjuku and you can walk there.The view allows you to have a feel of the shinjuku area and do some people watching

45 floors up and free!!. This was great. Short queue for the lift up. 360 degree view of Tokyo (and Fuji-san...on a good day)...shop selling all kinds of stuff and all for free. 500m walk from Shinjuku station. Can't go wrong.

Great in the day, poor at night. Wonderful views and its FREE :)I visited both in daylight and night time, as there is no outdoor space, during evenings you can only see your own reflection in the glass making it a very poor trip!Go during the day

Quite easy to get to, free access but dated facilities, and no heater nor aircon at viewing deck.. Take the Oeda line to the metro station directly connecting it, else it's well over 25mins walk from Shinjuku JR station.They're used to large crowds, and have 2 dedicated lifts direct to the top to view Shinjuku, Shibuya and nearby wards (pictures below on clear day).They turned off all heater and air-conditioning to save electricity (w/a big sign declaring it proudly near the ceiling), and it becomes unbearably stuffy if you've cold wear on (jackets/pull-overs). Many tourists were thus disrobing in public due to small toilets at viewing deck.View was fantastic, as it's the tallest building in Shinjuku/Shubuya districts vicinity. Had 2-3 touristy shops selling various knick-knacks, in the end bought souvenir gift coins from the coin stamping machines.Tried the fusion Italian-Jap cafe at viewing deck, tea set was simple and decent at ¥1k, and many tables had good views of the surrounding.

birds eye view. Been living here for over a decade & have always taken my friends & family visiting Japan, to this place. It is free & the view clearly illustrates the meaning of concrete jungle. If you happen to go in the evening/night it would be difficult taking pictures without the reflections of the internal lights. There is a cafe but it is expensive. They also sell souvenirs. Definitely worth a visit if you are around Shinjuku.
Great views.. We visited on a clear day. Fantastic views of Tokyo. Well organised with relatively short queues. It is also free.

Amazing views of the city. I went there in the evening - u will get great views of tokyo under lights.And the entry is free (unlike the Tokyo tower which is almost the same height). totally worth visiting.
Bird eye view of Tokyo. Free view from the 45th floor of the govt building. Exceptional view of the entire city. Two different platform views. Worth the view

Great 360 degree views and it is free!. There was only a few minutes wait for the elevator up and the viewing area was not crowded. One could get a feeling for Tokyo's environs and also of some of the nearby attractions such as Yoyogi Park and the Meiji Shrine.
