YOU CANNOT TAKE PICTURES THE VIEW IS HORRIBLE. If I could give an even more negative rating for this observation deck I would. It was absolutely horrendous, we went at night the glare on the glass windows is so strong that you can't even see the skyline in photos on an iPhone or even a professional camera! (Unless you have a glass repelling filter lense for you camera which we didn't!) there were so many people all trying to take photos in one space (therefore making the glare even worse in photos) we walked 30 minutes for this view everyone talks about and it wasn't even worth it. Disappointed, at least it was free.

Amazing tour guide and fantastic view. Upon entering the building we were greeting by a very kind man who offered to volunteer as a tour guide. He took us to the government chamber and told us all about it. We then went to the very top of the building and saw a view that we would never have seen anything like in our home city. When we were done he offered to take us anywhere in Tokyo for an hour. He was in retirement and had been working for a telecommunications company his whole life. We really enjoyed coming here

Great views for free!. We had read about the offices in our guide book saying these were the best views....and it was free to go up. The kids had a great time looking out of the windows and were a hit with a chinese tour group there. I have one red headed boy and one blonde baby boy!
Great view from the top. Been there several times with family and friends. Great place to see Tokyo and it is free, which for Tokyo is pretty good

Tokyo is huge!!. Love that it's free! Amazing views and a good spot to get a couple of souvenirs. The view really shows just how large Tokyo really is - it's almost overwhelming. There's a cafe up the top that we didn't go too, but looked OK. A great spot to spend maybe an hour at and pretty easy access from Shinjuku station.

Free tall Tower. Great views of Tokyo, however avoid the cafe at the top, very expensive and not worth it. However the view is great.... walk down one floor to the smoking room to have a smoke and enjoy the vista!
Great views . Went on a week day so there were no crowds. Great way to start my visit to the cityand its completely free.

Free to go up, great view and helpful staff on hand to answer questions.. Definitely worth a trip up. Excellent 360 view of the city, apparently you can see Mount Fuji on a very clear day, but you'd need to be there first thing in the morning. We didn't see it.
There was an informative display of regional foods, with examples to look at.

The Only Place to get the BIG view of Tokyo. Free observation decks with reasonable souvenir shop. Go to both observation decks. Relaxed with a drink and snack at the observation deck restaurant. A must visit. Easy to get to in safe area.

Beautiful City View and FREE. We read about the observation towers in the Government office before our trip and wanted to make the trek. Turned out our hotel was just across the way so it was perfect.There are two towers to choose from. We flipped a coin and went to the South Tower. It was a gorgeous 360 degree view. There were others around, but it wasn't so crowded that we couldn't get a good view and many pictures of our own. We had a cup of tea in the cafe afterward and even perused the local fair that was going on at the time. We never made it up the Skytree. We enjoyed our view of Tokyo so much from this building we didn't find it necessary.

Great views at great price. Highly recommend visiting the observation decks at the Tokyo Metopolitian Office towers. Can't beat the price- free. Recommend an evening visit. Wait in a short line and take a quick elevator ride to the top for great views. There is also a restaurant and and gift shop.
Amazing view. We went to the top of the building to see the fantastic views. I would recommend getting a drink at the restaurant near a window.

Free city view of Tokyo. I was told it is free to go to the top of the building and you can see the view of the tokyo city. So I went there in a late afternoon, the gate wasn't very obvious but not difficult to find. The view is just awesome! it is close to shinjuku so you can just go there in the afternoon then have dinner around.

FREE top view of tokyo city. The best thing of this place is you can get free entrance into the building to have a great view of the tokyo city. It has two different observatory sites (north and south building) that offer different view of this giant city. Compared to skytree that cost about 2000+ yen, this place is definitely a better place especially for budget traveller.It is easily assessible and the staff are very friendly even though they are not really good in English. The top of view of tokyo is great but it might vary according to the weather. It was a bit blurry on the day i visited this attraction but it is still worth a visit.

Straight up the lift with a smile. A bit if a hit and miss day weather wise, so not expecting a great view. Yet, considering the drizzle and cloudy day, the views were superb. Not many people looking either. What a great service to offer. Happy Hour for drinks at the lovely bar starts at 15.00 and such lovely views. Then to our delight in a bolt of sunlight, out came Mt Fuji!! Wow. An absolute must

Wonderful views of tokyo. Went here for the first family outing and loved it. There were great views of Tokyo from every angle with large windows. The only downfall being the queue and the fact that the restaurant wasn't open ( 6pm at night ). Overall a great experience.
PS - on the top floor were some great souvenir shops.
Amazing view. If you have time definitely head to the viewing deck... it gives an amzing view of just how large Tokyo is... well worth it as it is an easy walk from Shinjuku station

Free admission.. There's North and South Observatory decks. North usually closes at 2300 hrs while South closes at 17.30 hrs. It was a cloudy day to begin with so the view wasn't so spectacular. The Observatory deck was a little too warm and stuffy. I didn't enjoy myself.

Great view for free . Definitely recommended to go there. Great views over the skyscrapers of Shinjuku. The North Tower is open until 11pm. After 9pm it is quiet and there are no queues at the elevator. Please note that there is glass windows only which makes it difficult to take pictures. Also tripods are not allowed.

Mt Fuji views. This govt building allows you access to a floor high enough to view the majority of Tokyo and on clear days a view of Mt Fuji as long as the mist/pollution allows. Best part it is free. The floor itself has its own restaurant and souvenir shop and is definitely worth attending.

Busy! Not much to see.. For a free place to visit in Tokyo it's somewhat worth the walk and wait. But it was so packed on the obversatory that getting around and getting down was a mission. Do not buy souvenirs or food up here. It is obviously overpriced. The 'free' wifi here was so over crowded it couldn't load anything just like any other free wifi Hotspots in Tokyo.I would recommend to pay a bit more and go to Skytree instead for a better view of Tokyo. It does have a lot of visitors but has a much more rewarding experience.

View was great but surroundings disappointing. We went in the evening and spent about 30 mins to queue which was fine.When we got there the view was great but we were a bit disappointed by the building itself. We expected there to be some kind of outdoor viewing platform and a panoramic view but instead it was all enclosed and you could only see half the skyline.Coming from London, we're used to free attractions that offer incredible views of the landscape that is very user-friendly for visitors. This was nowhere near that which was why the experience was a bit deflating. There was also no information about the skyline etc, where different buildings and areas were, which would have enhanced this experience and I would've expected this as a minimum. There's literally just an overpriced gift shop and restaurant and nothing else.Perhaps the paid-for Sky Tree is better but I don't think you should have to pay for a decent view and experience.

Amazing. Fortunately the person I was going with, knew about this gem. We went there by evening so we had the evening view over Tokyo. + opened until 11pm+ free entrance + souvenir shops + amazing view over Tokyo+ possibility to eat at a restaurant (no view to the outside though) Tips: - hard to take good photos because of the reflections of the windows

Great view and it is free. Other Tokyo towers cost quite alot of money, but the entry is free here. Easy to access and open long hours. Great place to go on arrival to Tokyo to get a great perspective of how big and busy it is.

Great View, Great Location.. Located in Shinjuku, Tokyo Metropolitsn Government Building is one of the major tourist attractions in Tokyo. It is about 10 minutes walk from Shinjuku Station. It is open till 11.00 pm. It has two observatory with north observatory being open to public free of charge. It offers great view of the city and the area in which it is located is also great and peaceful especially during the night. On a clear day one might even see Mount Fuji form the observatory. A must visit.

Worth a trip. If you want great views of Tokyo without the price tag of the Sky Tree or Tokyo Tower, this is the place to go. It's easy to get to, the line isn't too terrible, and you can see for miles and miles. I'd definitely recommend a stop if you have time and are nearby, but I wouldn't go out of the way for it unless city views are something you're pining for.

A must do. We enjoyed going up to the south tower to look out over Tokyo. The view is expensive yet the city never seems to end. We were assisted by a very friendly volunteer guide who pointed out all the major sites of the city. There is a cafe up there as well.

Good Sightseeing. Although there is an observatory, you can get a visitor's pass at the front desk and go to the 32nd floor and enjoy the views from the tea room or the cafeteria. You are also able to purchase food at a very reasonable price

Must go if on a budget . Since it's free, if you want a good view on Tokyo without buying tickets, this is your place. My first tower in the city was the Tokyo Tower. That was nicer as a building itself and had better view at night than this daytime visit. So that's why it's only very good.

Top notch. You can view Tokyo from the observation platforms of the Tokyo Skytree or the Tokyo Tower, at a cost, or you can go to the 45th floor observatory of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (either or both north and south towers) and see it all, for free! And that includes seeing the Tokyo Tower and the Skytree themselves (which you can't see if you're in them!). On a fine day, you can even see Mt Fuji (good luck with that!). Day or night. Indeed we went twice - once in the daylight and once at night.Easily accessible by subway to one of the Shinjuku stations (one is right underneath the building). We didn't find the queues that long - 5-10 minutes wait to get up and down.There are gift shops and toilets at the top.There are other interesting skyscrapers around, plus department stores with big basement food halls, and Shinjuku itself.Do yourself a favour - it's free!
Interesting place to see the city. This is a free way to see the city from 202 metres above ground. Spend half an hour in the building travelling to the 45th floor to see this view.

Free alternative to Tokyo Tower. Tokyo Tower and Sky Tree are expensive and this was a free option within walking distance of the Park Hyatt Hotel. The view was great and there's a small restaurant. I was surprised that we could see MT Fuji. And yeah, the price is right.

A nice FREE view of Tokyo from above. Tokyo Tower and Tokyo Sky Tree are the famous spots for getting aerial views of the Tokyo, but we were staying in Shinjuku and the hotel staff recommended this as a free alternative. The view is pretty awesome and you can see Sky Tree, Tokyo Tower and Mt. Fuji sooooooo, yeah, you can't beat free. There was a cafe on the observation deck. We didn't try the food, but we we had coffee there. It was a wierd mix of business people and tourists and families so kind of interesting for people watching too. If you're in Shinjuku you might as well go because it's free. There's not much else to do there, so it freed up time for other things in our day.
Good Perspective of the city!. Free attraction, good place to see the city and Mnt Fuji if its a clear day. Good eye opener in see how big Tokyo really is!

Good views, low cost, literally right next to my hotel.. This is pretty much right down the street from the Shinjuku Washington Hotel. Kind of hard not to check it out given that it's probably less than a five minute walk away.

Free is good, so are the views. We enjoyed a leisurely stroll over to the Govt building from Sunroute Shinjuku Plaza Hotel. Great way to take in the magnitude of the city, scope out the parks that you will retreat during your Tokyo explorations. It was hazy when we visited so no Mt Fuji views. If you happen to catch Fuji when you visit consider yourself very lucky.It's free!

go!! its free!!!. a bit of a walk from the train station, its free and you will be able to see the tokyo skyscrapers. have a restaurant at the observatory deck and stalls for the souvenirs. go coz its free

Tokyo Metropolitan Building. If you would like to see the city from the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Guverment Building for free, well this is the place.Just to let you know that there are two buldings, the north and the south. And I will say the south building has better view and nicer things to see (even mount Fuji).

Worthwhile visit for the panoramic view . I had some free time in a morning and decided to spend it visiting the viewing gallery of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building in Western Shinjuku. It was a nice visit, and especially wonderful that it is free of charge. There are two viewing galleries offering views from different direction and both have restaurant/cafe as well as some souvenir stores. One also has a good display of pamphlets and local goods from different prefectures. I don't know if this is a permanent arrangement but I do find it really useful for tourists wanting more information on other parts of Japan.

Thought it would be better . Was expecting a much better view, but only a few windows to look out of. Unfortunately it was a bit overcast so Mt. Fuji was hidden. Cool experience though going up high above. And of course free never hurts
Good view in Shinjiku. The view is very good on ShinjikuYou can see also the sky towerThe weather was not good enough to see the Fuji mountIt's free

Free Views to my Fuji. Free view over Tokyo. Yes that's right I said free! From the 45? Floor of the Tokyo Government building you can (depending on the weather) see as far as the eye can see. We were blessed with a clear day and could see all the way to Mt Fuji. Spectacular views of the immense city of Tokyo. There are also volunteer English speaking guides who are very friendly and will point out all the main buildings and sights around Tokyo. A great way to get your bearings. They will also explain the engineering if the building that helps it withstand earthquakes. Well worth the visit. Go early in the morning - it opens at 10am and you can also go at night. We did both.

Loved the views.. We went up the viewing tower late in the afternoon and the queues were very short, even at the weekend. The restaurant was shut, not sure what the food would be like but it looked interesting. The shops have an enormous range of kitsch items,
Tokyo Night view. Located near my hotel. 3 min walk. Got there at night (21:00) and did not wait to enter. After climb to 44th looked around for 10 min and out.

Good view, free. The entrance to this building is right at the subway exit so it's easy to get to. The line to go up can be long but not more than 20 minutes and you don't need to buy tix. Good views of Tokyo from the 45th floor and we could clearly see mt Fuji. Was definitely a nice start to our day with less hassle than Tokyo tower. Gift shops up top are nothing special.

Very nice view- easy access from JR Station. It is free. Go for it. Around 3 minute walk from JR Station (Shinjuku) and show your ID (passport) to go up. There are two elevators, one is south and the other is north. Both had excellent views and we were able to browse information on the city, the cities in Japan, and the country itself. There also was a cafe if you would like to relax and have a cup of drink or a piece of sandwich. We got there around 2pm in the afternoon and there was no line at all. Give yourself around 1-2 hours to look around and enjoy.

The only great free of charge observatory. I formerly used to work as a receptionist at Tokyo City View for almost a year during my gap semester. And I used to get lots of complaints from tourists on why it costs 1800 JPY (around 15 USD) to simply get into the observatory, as they asked me if there is a observatory free of charge. The answer for their question was of course HERE.Located around 10 minutes by walk from the west side of Shinjuku Station, there is a couple elevators that brings you all the way to the top.The only problem about this observatory is the location, since it is located in the West side of the Tokyo Metro, you don't get the best view of the entire Tokyo, but it is more easier to see the Mount Fuji since there is not many buildings that obstructs the view.The big plus is definitely the FREE admission. Before heading to the elevator there is a brief security check, but nothing special.I advise you to take the Toei Subway Oedo Line and get off at Tochomae since it's just right behind the building.Also, you can get free English guidance at the entrance, so make sure to take advantage.

Great views of Tokyo for free. There was no wait when I went. It's free and you can go to both the North and South towers if you want. At the top there is a cafe and a large selection of craft goodies from all over Japan, mostly food stuff like cooking oil, snacks, sake, etc.

Free with great sights day and night. We enjoyed visiting the Observatory on the 45th floor both during the day and in the evening to take in the fantastic Tokyo skyline.As you have a choice of two towers (North and South ) the waiting time was minimal although in the evening one of the towers is closed at 5.30pmThe facility is free and has a restaurant and gift shop.

Nice free view but not the best. So this is a free place to have a nice view of Tokyo. But if you want to see Mt Fuji it's a bit tricky. The building opens around 9AM (if my memory is correct) and Mt Fuji is to the west of Tokyo. I think it might be good to view Mt Fuji if weather is good and you can get there early. Lots of ppl go there for sunset where the sun just hide behind Mt Fuji. That's a bad decision to take picture if you are not a pro.. nothing but the shadow.

Great observation deck . Right best to Hyatt Regency Tokyo in Shinjuku. You can see pretty much of nearby big Tokyo. There are a restaurant with piano music performance and two souvenir shops. Two comfortable elevators zip your up in less than 30 seconds from basement. Loved the sunset view. There are also some tourist information and agricultural exhibit at the time of my visit which I bought some refreshing and sweet strawberries and interesting coffee flavored lotus snacks. Both were very tasty. Highly recommended.

Nice view of the city - if you can get a clear day. Best part of this is that it is free!Decent observation deck at the top of the building, you can see Mount Fuji when the weather is clear.There are souvenir shops and a "one price" restaurant at the topWorth taking the time to visit
What a view!. Definitely worth a visit. The view this place gives you of Tokyo is amazing. There's a restaurant at the top of one of the towers if you wanted to make a night of it.
Amazing views . Easy to find and the views are spectacular me and my mates enjoyed a coffee whilst taking in the views were amazing a definite must see

Worth the effort to get here at dusk. I had quite a lot of difficulty finding this place, but it was so worth the effort. It is amazing to have such a great view of Tokyo, and all for free! If you are not used to Shinjuku Station then this can be a bit tricky to find. The station itself is enormous and has about 60 different exits, so if going here from Shinjuku directly, make sure you have clear directions. I got lost for about 45 minutes trying to find it, as it was hidden among dozens of other skyscrapers just west of Shinjuku!That said, it was great to visit in the early evening, when there was a fantastic view in the last hour of daylight, and again in the darkness when the whole city was lit up. There are a few chairs on the observation deck as well to rest weary feet. Would definitely recommend!
It is free!!!. How can you not give this 5 stars... it is free and gives you great views over Tokyo. Make sure you visit during your time in Shinjuku.

Free alternative for Tokyo Tower or SkyTree. Awesome view from up top. Even when it is crowded you do not wait long for the lift and it goes pretty fast. Good to visit both during the day, a clear one to see Mt. Fuji and at night to take photos with longer exposure. Awesome gift shop as well, with some really nice, not too expensive stuff.
Best free observation deck.. It's not the tallest building but it was a very good observation deck considering it was free. I would definitely stop by there if you are in the district!
Amazing view of Tokyo at night. I visited this place at night and it had one of the best views of Tokyo city. It had a stunning city view at night and won't be the one that I'll forget for a while.

Nice place. Nice view from the North Tower observatory, but it's a bit smaller compared to the observatory in Yokohama Landmark Tower.
Worth a visit, preferably at late evening.

Great view of Tokyo and beyond. The observation deck was fully accessible by wheelchair. It provided an unimpeded 360-degree view of Tokyo. This is a must visit place for visitors who want to see the landscape of Tokyo from high above. There were signs to indicate various landmarks.Don't forget to use the stamp to mark your visit there.

Great Tokyo view~~~. This is definitely the first place to check out when you're in town. 7min walk east of the Shinjuku station. There is also a flea market nearby the day I visited with locals trading and selling vintages and second hand merchandise.

Great free view!. A great free view!
Was a bit tricky to find the entrance at first as you have to go down to go up, but once you get to the top it's a brilliant view.

Amazing city views. And even better - for free!. The Government Office Tower in Shinjuku is one of those great little gifts that Tokyo gives you.The access to the observatory floor is made from the Tower 1 and you have an elevator reserved for it. Depending on the hour, it may have a line to go up.And when you get up there you get some of the best views of the city possible.An absolute must go if you are into that kind of sight.
Great view of Tokyo. Free great attraction, go up one of the tower and admire the view of the city. Souvenirs shops and café at the top are available as well.

A good option for a free view of the city. You can go up this tower for free and whilst the view is not going to be as spectacular as from the Skytree (I wouldn't think), you can get a largely unobstructed view of most of Tokyo (on a clear day)

Great view but it's just a building . Thinking of going to Tokyo tower for the view? Probably should just scratch that off your list and come here instead. The government building is completely free to visit. From here you get a great view of Tokyo and if you visit on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji from here. Apart from the view you can get a tour of the building which is nice to learn a bit of history and like all tourist spots there's a souvenir store; but at the end of the day its just a building.

Uncrowded and free to get a great view of the city. I was against going up the Tokyo Skytree after hearing about the price and crowds. This observation deck is free, and I didn't have to queue at all. A nice cafe at the top and a cute souvenir shop too.

Great view. Great view for free, with souvenir shops on site. Winter time is best if you want to see Mount Fuji. English speaking guides are available to show you a few things and a bit of city history.

Beautiful Tokyo view . Here is the best Tokyo view with free entry, you shouldn't miss. So beautiful Tokyo city view on 45Fl. They have north and south buildings you can visit. The staffs very polite and good service even free entrance. I'm high recommend here.

It's just a building. Appreciating all the architectural merits of this building I would still say that this is a new tourist spot. There is no special kind of tour that will take you around the building or show some historic facts about it. At the end this is just a building
Good view on a clear day.... Unfortunately, it was a bit hazy when I went up the towers but they still offered a good view of the city. Free trip, centrally located and easy to find, worth a visit.

Fantastic View. Not only it is free entry, they also have a free guide (from the tourist office) to tell you more about the building and surrounding area We had a very good guide who speaks good English. It is near to the train station and there is no long queues. The view is fantastic and if you are lucky, you can see Mt Fuji.

Top of Shinjuku. Situated a short walk from the train station amongst the sky scrapers is the Govt Office. You can visit until quite late, 10:30PM I think and is a great way to take in the City Scape of Tokyo. A good restaurant is on the observation floor and plenty of souvenir shops. The entrance at night can feel a little

Just great. Comparing with skytree, this is great value. Entrance is free, not long queues and perfect view. There was not very much people so You can enjoy atmosphere. Also I checked opening times from net and there was, that one tower is open till late evening but it was not

Amazing free view. We didn't want to pay for Tokyo Tower or Sky Tree so we decided to go there. And it was really worth it. It is in the center of Tokyo and the observatorium is really large so you can see almost every part of Tokyo. You can also buy some great gifts there. I don't think that Sky Tree is a lot better than this ;)
great view. Great chance to see Tokyo from an elevated position, free to visit the viewing platform gives great views in all directions

Great city views for free. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building observatory is a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku metro station. The building has two observatories, one in each tower. We only visited one of the observatories and it had great views of the city. When we visited in November 2015 at about 3:00 p.m., there were no lines and we were able to get to the observatory quickly.

Nice view, ordinary touristic place . Great place to get a birds eye view of Tokyo for free. The observation deck is just an ordinary place with a couple of salespersons trying to get you to buy unnecessary stuff (since they're Japanese they're very nice and friendly and non-intrusive).

"Awesome View". Since it's near the hotel I'm staying in Shinjuku, I decided to check this place although it's not included in my itinerary. The building does give a good view of Tokyo but the time I went there it is so crowded . I took some pictures then spent most of my time looking at a wide array of souvenirs sold on the stores. What's great about this place is it don't have any entrance fee unlike Tokyo Skytree. Both offers the same awesome view so you got to save a few bucks by going to this place.

Really nice free viewing tower ... on both sides ... cool to see the night skyline.. Really nice free viewing tower ... on both sides ... cool to see the night skyline.I loved the view of all the skyscrapers from the viewing deck ... and it is free, amazing!!

Great free viewing tower. Located on the 45th floor of this building is a large viewing floor, mainly occupied by a shop selling the useual TTT, Typical Tourist Tat!. Ignore that and just take in the views for free. The small cafe is worth a coffee stop to take the views from their side of the building. No need to pay to go up the Tokyo Skytree or Tower.
Great Free view of Tokyo. This is worth a walk too. Great 360 view around Tokyo from ShinjukuAnd completely freeNo line ups on the sunday that we went.

Great views but not an excellent set-up.. The views of Tokyo are amazing, it simply looks (and pretty well is) never ending. The windows are not huge to look out so crowds are an issue and there is also minimal information on what you're looking at. But still, it's free, the views and good and it's a definite box to tick.
Great for free. A great free experience. Easy to find from Shinjuku Station. There are lovely guides at the top who are very helpful.

Great view for free.. Easy to get to and well marked out once you arrive. The north tower is where they funnel visitors to and there is a gift shop on the viewing floor. Views are great and you can easily view Mt. Fuji on a clear day. The south tower requires a little bit of looking to find the way up but it is empty of tourists so you may find more time to be able to actually spot local attractions/landmarks, etc.
Definitely worth checking out - and free!. If you get a clear day in Tokyo the view from up here is worth seeing - close to Shinjuku station and it costs you nothing!

Great views of the city. Why wouldn't you, it's free and on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji, on the day we visited there were English speaking volunteers who were offering a quick explanation of all the sights you could see and were on hand to answer any questions you might have.

great view. it is unusual to get an observatory view for free. i looked for the catch but there wasn't any. the view was excellent even on a cloudy day. the lift was smooth and the ambiance was excellent. the food in the cafe was a bit lacking though.

One of the coolest places to shoot the skyline at night!. In Shinjuku, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observatories are one of the few locations to get a great look at the city, but also to get night shots of Tokyo at night (if you are a photographer).Unfortunately, the location does not allow for a tripod and there is light being reflected on the window, so you will have to put your lens on the glass and have a towel to block out light.But the South Observation Deck is great for taking photos during the day, while the North Observation Deck, which is open until 10:30 p.m. are for those who want to enjoy the Tokyo view at night and also want to eat at the cafe and bar.My first time going to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building (back in ’99 – shown above), I went to the South Observation Deck and personally, I feel you get a better view without the obstructions during the night shots versus the day. So, I recommend the North Observation Deck at night (just remember that it closes at 10:30 p.m.).But the South Observation Deck does give you a good peek through Odaiba, which is a plus.
Great view and free. Excellent view and could see Mount Fuji. You can see from north or south viewing area. Is free and easy to get to, definitely worth a visit.

worth a visit to observatory. On a clear day, wonderful views from the FREE OBSERVATORY on 45th floor - clearly signed to explain what you are seeing on all sides. You can even see Mt Fuji on a clear day. Nice little souvenir shop and exhibits too

Great to see a view of Tokyo.. We went here as we didn't really want to pay a small fortune to go to the other towers. Absolutely beautiful view from the top, it's free and there are some gift shops to wander around in which are very well stocked with souvenir's. The line was pretty long and it was packed up the top so you had to wait to move into an area where you could see out the window but not a problem if you want a free experience!

Finally saw Mt Fuji!. It rained the day we planned to go see Mt Fuji so we did not take the tour that would have been costly and iffy. On an earlier trip to Japan Mt Fuji was covered in fog as we went by on a bullet train. I was disappointed not to see this iconic sight on this second visit...but late in the day the rain cleared and we went to the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office Building and there it was! Oh, it was far away and not like my National Geographic memories—but we saw the snow covered peak as well as sweeping views of the city. It's amazing that going to the top of this spectacular building is free.
Great view . Great views, free WiFi, and it does not cost to enter. The toy shop is entertaining as well, which is a plus.
Great for evening sight seeing. Great, free, opportunity to get some good sightseeing in. We went in the evening and we weren't disappointed

Stunning free Tokyo views. This is worth the effort - stunning 360 degree views over Tokyo with a clear Mt Fuji in the distance and harbour in the opposite direction. Free entry to the 45th floor with café & souvenirs - 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station
Observatory. It is worth the time to take the elevator to the top floor for the view over Tokyo. We also took a free tour offered by the Tourist Office that showed us around Shinjuku.

Great views at sunset. We were lucky enough to have clear views of Fuji at sunset then see the rest of Tokyo turn into a beautiful night. Just be aware that one of the towers, I think the left,closes at 5, so we had to go down and up the other tower. It wasn't too crowded and is free. The district around the government office is interesting if you like modern skyscraper design. We wondered into another close by building which had a brilliant atrium and lift up to top level, but no viewing platform.
Great views for free. You can get pretty high up (45th floor) with great views of Tokyo, for free. Best to come before noon (before all other tourists come)
Must come. You can get very nice views of Tokyo from high enough. If I am not wrong it is also free and during good days you can see Fuji as well!

Great views of Tokyo. High above the hustle and bustle of Tokyo lies two observation decks at the Metropolitan Government Office. They are free to guests. Well worth checking out if you want a fantastic view of Tokyo and all that Tokyo offers.

The view is great!. The view from the top of this building made me feel like my home town city is so tiny.. it is just endless concrete views. I don't know what I was expecting really but I was still amazed by it all. On a clear day you can apparently see Mt Fuji too.

Awesome views of Mount Fuju and Tokyo for free!. Downstairs there is a tourist info center; handy. And high up there is an observation deck with almost 360 degrees views. For free. Highly recommended. If possible, visit on a clear day, in order to see Mount Fuji.

Superb views of Tokyo and Mt Fuji, and it's free!!!. If you are close to Shinjuku, this is an absolute must to do. Unlike all the other high rise attractions, this is totally free, and offers panoramic views over Tokyo and beyond. We were lucky to see Mt Fuji when we went, one of the 10% of days when it isn't shrouded in clouds.There is a cafe, shops selling an amazing range of tat, and toilets on the viewing floors, it was not crowded when we went, so we were able to stand and gaze and familiarise ourselves with Tokyo from above before setting off at ground level. If it's not raining or snowing, it's a pleasant walk to the Meiji shrine and Shibuya from here.

Nice spot, easy to find. This is an ideal spot to view Tokyo, with almost 360-degree view. Plenty of signages to help you find it, starting from Shinjuku train station, which is about 10-15-walk away, part of it is a travelator, saving you quite a few steps. Just follow the direction on the signages. There are two towers, the escalator is about 50 meters from each other, which you can choose at the last moment once you are inside the building. One of them opens much longer into the night (up until around 10pm). I arrived around 4pm,so it didn't matter to me. The service was great with courteous attendants, although it was completely free of charge. There was a café at the top and an exhibition of various local products from different areas. No obligation to pay for or buy anything, though; no pressure at all. This place is as good as any other towers in Tokyo for the view, and - once again - it's free. What more could you ask for?

See Tokyo from above the crowds. On a clear day, the view of Tokyo from the top of the Government Office builiding is superb. You may even catch a glimpse of Mount Fuji depending on weather conditions. There is a gift shop as well, but expect long lines for the elevators.

A great view of the city. This was a surprisingly good find and well worth a visit, plus it was for free unlike the other tower visit attraction. The view from the top was great especially on a clear blue sky day. At the time of our visit they had a trade fair on showcasing the produce (mostly foodstuff or tea) of all the different areas of Japan which were for sale. A great way to get a glimpse of what was on offer from around Japan. They also have volunteers at the top floor whose English is great and are willing to show you round, point out major landmarks and answer all your questions. On a good day you can even see Mount Fuji. The place is easily accessible by train/underground.

Majestic!. This is a free lookout tower hosted by the Tokyo Metropolitan government building. Easy to get to from the Shinjuku business district (either by the long and winding underground passages or I'd rather recommend a nice walk through the neighbouring skyscraper district), the building offers free admission to the 46th floor which has a 360* view of Tokyo. There are really friendly local guides who are happy to explain to you through the nearby sights, and offer advice / a personal view on living in this amazing city.

Unbeatable view of Tokyo for free. This is a must visit for anyone in visiting Tokyo and it is best done early in the visit. The views from either the north or south towers are fantastic and encapsulate the entire city. We were fortunate enough to even see Mt Fuji. The relatively short waiting time and the expansive room to move around is amazing especially given the free entry. Sure you could visit the paid Tokyo tower or Skytree for a view but this way you get a better view (you can see the tower and Skytree) without the cost. It is also very easy to access with signage from Shinjuku Station.Will definitely recommend this to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Great views on a sunny day but couldn't see Mount Fuji - free of charge. A fairly long queue to get to the top, lift was quick but again jam packed full of people with queues to get back down the elevator. Great views though that the best part is its free.

Great View . We came to this building to get a view of the city from above....and what a view! This place gives you a wonderful 360 view of Tokyo and is made all the more splendid at Sunset. There is also an area to sit, rest your legs and have some cake. Wasn't a fan of the cold sake in a wine glass but dessert was good!Unlike the other viewpoints from high up in Tokyo, this is free! So definitely a look!

Amazing view for free!. I came here on the 2nd Monday of the month and thus our only option was the South Observation Deck as the North is closed on the 2nd and 4th Monday's of the month. Despite only having one option, the view was incredible. Only about a 10 minute walk from the Shinjuku station and it is free. I came here around 3PM and it only took about 5 minutes of being in line to get on the elevator for the way up. At the top is a cafe as well as items you can purchase that are native to every prefecture in Japan as well as vacation guides. A good way to spend an hour of your time visiting Tokyo.
Great views!. It's a place to come and see beautiful views of the city - well organized, efficient elevator up and free.
Great Views and all for Free!. You can get some awesome views across Tokyo and it's all for free! Couldn't recommend this place any higher, to get a different perspective of the city.

Great view of Tokyo. Can't really beat this as a place to look over Tokyo. Sky Tree had zero visibility when we visited which was disappointing, so tried here a few days later and got some great views of Tokyo. Best of all, it's easy to get to, and admission is free!

Must See!. Anyone looking for spectacular views of Tokyo without paying high prices should definitely not miss the observation decks in each tower of this office. There is no admission fee and there is lots of room when you get up there so it isn't too cramped. Also, there is a little toy shop in the middle of one of the decks that is great for getting Japanese souvenirs.

Great views. You must visit the South tower observatory for a brilliant view of the city, especially on a clear day when your bonus is the view of his Highness Mt. Fuji. Theres information on all the buildings you can see from each window. And the views are absolutely worth your time. The biggest bonus - its free!

Great views of Tokyo!. When visiting the Tokyo metropolitan government building you are given 2 options, the south or the north view... The south has a complete 365 view, while the north side, has a lovely restaurant bar with reasonable pricing. We opted for the happy hour menu, has 2 glasses of wine and 2 beers for under 2,000 yen (about $18USD). Can't beat this view!

ENJOY THE VIEW. We went in mid-January 2015, on a cold evening, the place was deserted, no wait at all straight up to the observatory deck. The view was fantastic by a clear sky, very windy. We almost had the place to ourselves .. Took the time to explore each side, except for the side occupied by the coffee shop. We watched planes land and take-off from Haneda airport. Then we went to Yakitori alley for a bite.

A must .... Visiting the Metropolitan Government Office is a must for any visitor to Tokyo who is keen to get a feel for the lay of the land. Its free, not difficult to find and well worth the effort! Going at dusk is a great time as you get 2 views; the daylight and then the night shots. Just do it!!
Great view of Tokyo!. On top of this building, there are two observation decks.(Each building has own business hours and operating days) I enjoyed great view of Tokyo. Free admission.

Great view for $0. Don't bother with the high price attractions like Tokyo tower if you just want to have a great view of the city. The government office building observation deck is free, and if you go on a clear day, take the elevator to the south tower (left line) and you might catch a glimpse of Mt. Fuji.

Fantastic views of Tokyo - for free!. Forget the shop and restaurant that is there and spend time gazing over the city. We went at night and the view of the city lights was stunning, it makes you realise how big Tokyo is. A must see as it's free!
Great Tourist Activity. Great to visit at night. I think it closes around 9-10pm. Great views of Tokyo. Free. Has a little café upstairs to get snacks.
Meh. There was no line to take the elevator to the roof, and everyone was very helpful. But not particularly interesting views of a city more exciting from the street than the sky.

Free Tourist Attraction. With no queues and no costs it was a great way to spend an hour. The views were fantastic on a clear sunny day with Mt Fuji in the distance. We went up both towers and as they weren't crowded we were able to take photos easily and sit on the lounges and take in the view. There are souvenir shops, cafes and toilets available, (toilets were down a flight of stairs). The Government Building is within easy reach of Shinjuku station.

Ok views, mainly a shop on the 45th floor. Great that it's free. Views were ok, would have liked some more info about the city. Most of it is a kids shop and a restaurant that wouldn't let us in for a cup of tea (apparently they didn't have any!). Good for a free 15min viewing but not more.

Great View. I loved this free view of Tokyo. There is always a line but it moves pretty quickly and soon you'll find yourself on the way to the 45th floor and an unbelievable panoramic view of Tokyo. Also some good souvenir shopping opportunities at the top and the exit at the bottom.
Awesome view from top!. It is a free oppertunity to view Tokyo from top, You can see all of tokyo in a clear sky. Also good place to pick up some souvenir.

If you're in Shinjuku, don't miss this. I went here late one evening and the views were stunning. I did have a lot of trouble finding the entrance to the North Tower though and it was only due to the kindness of some English-speaking young locals that I found it! So do your research! There's a little gift shop there and you do have to be patient and wait for people to move away from the windows if you want to get a good clear shot of the view, and at night you need to get right up to them because of the interior lights reflecting in the glass. I wish I'd gone there during the day as well. NB: I travelled here in April 2014 - not 2015.

See the sheer sprawl of Tokyo for free. We visited the Government building twice when we were in Tokyo. Once during the day and once at night. If you are staying in Shinjuku it's well worth a trip. We managed to spot Mt Fuji as it was a clear day. It also wasn't to busy when we were there meaning that if you wanted to take photos you easily could. At night time it was even quieter.

great views for free. The views (especially of Mount Fuji) were better than the Tokyo sky tree. An English speaking volunteer came up to us and showed us all the points of interest. Would recommend it although there was a 15 minute wait to get into the lift and a 10 minute wait to come back down but well worth it as the wait to come down at the skytree was about the same.
Great FREE view of city. Great view of the city from a high floor observation deck FREE of charge, as opposed to similar view towers in other places that charge a fee for the elevator up.

Free views of Tokyo! . Beautiful views of Tokyo day or night. You enter through the underground access to the foyer of the building.There are two towers, south and north. The north tower has a restaurant and limited views. The south tower is MUCH better, no restaurant in your way so you get a full view of Tokyo...plus you get to look at a regional delicacy pop-up shop. In short, go to the South tower.

Amazing views of Tokyo for free. Skip Tokyo Skytree and Tokyo Tower if you want to save up; Tocho is here to save the day. Not the tallest but you'll surely get amazing views of the city in the building's public viewing deck for free.

Wonderful. I have given this 5/5, because you cannot grumble with this free opportunity to see such glorious views of Tokyo!I visited this the morning of my first day in Tokyo, at about 9:30am (when it opened). Mt. Fuji was majestically shaping the skyline, and it was very, very beautiful. I also visited this attraction on the last night of my visit to watch the sunset, which again, was incredible. It is easily accessible by the subway system, and sign posted clearly from the station. It's just a short elevator ride up to the top, and going on weekdays, there wasn't any queue, even at sunset. It did however get a little crowded at the windows looking out at Fuji. For this I have a cheeky tip. If you follow the signs down to the toilets on the floor below, there is a smoking area with a huge window looking out at Fuji. This is usually more or less empty, so it's a good space to get your own personal viewing. It would obviously be better if this was open air, so that you can feel more on top of the world and get better photos. But honestly, it is such an amazing gift to tourists, to see these views for free!

Great spot to see the scope of Tokyo from 44 stories up and Free! . This is my favorite place to take people to see the Solti skyline and to truly appreciate the vastness of this huge city. It's free and has a metro station exit in the building. It's well signed at each viewing window so you can spot all the major buildings and places of interest. Top tip: head here for sunset for a truly spectacular view. You can see Mt Fuji from here easily on a clear day too!

Wonderful Views of Tokyo. There's nothing bad to say about this attraction. The views of Tokyo are excellent. There are two different towers, one is much better than the other but I can't remember which.We managed to spend over an hour trying to pick out all the places we had visited and taking photos (not very successfully as the glass is quite scratched in places). Best of all, it costs absolutely nothing!We found a tiny little coffee bar in the ground floor lobby. Excellent coffee and nice cakes.

good views of Tokyo. we stayed in Shinjuku and this was our first port of call to look at tokyo from above and get our bearings... Very simple access... from the lobby go down the escalators to the lift that takes you up..

Amazing views from the 45th floor. We went here at dusk to see the city from above. There are 2 wings - the South and the North. The South closes at 5.30 so we chose to go up that one first. The views are spectacular. We could see all the way to Mt Fuji and as the sun was setting behind Fuji-san, it made for amazing photos.There are photos around the edges of the windows pointing out the sights and areas of Tokyo. There is also a shop and cafe up there. The shop has specialty goods from all over Japan.The best thing...it is completely free and there was no wait to get up to the 45th floor. There were a few people up there but nowhere near the types of crowds you get at Sky Tree. I certainly got loads of amazing photos.

good view and free. Went up one of the towers and viewed mt fuji from afar.love the fact it's free of charge yet there's a food exhibition in the middle of the observation deck where u can buy food from all over Japan. Think it's a clever idea.

Free night view! . Just minutes away from Shinjuku station the Tokyo metropolitan government office offers a free view of Tokyo city on the 45th floor. The night view was gorgeous and you can see both the Tokyo tower and Tokyo sky tree from the window next to the elevators (although it's very far away). However since it was free we didn't expect much. Also they have a cafe there, the night we went they had a live band on which equates to an extra 1000yen per person for music that I thought was a bit steep. Overall the night is nice given what it's worth.

Amazing view; lovely volunteers. . The view from the building is absolutely amazing. There is no charge to go up to the observation floor, and the volunteers who work there are able to point out any landmarks and give history lessons behind each building or garden. Great way to see the city of shinjuku and beyond

If anywhere close to Shinjuku definately stop here. OK first and foremost this is a FREE attraction. The Government has done a great service to visitors. An outstanding building with a first class tourist visitor center. Brochures available in many languages. Finally take the ride up to the 45th floor for the viewing. You get a panoramic view of most of Tokyo (at least as far as you can see). Unfortunately it was a little hazy the day we visited so we could not see Mt. Fuji. but regardless it is definitely worth a visit.There was a very interesting shop with products representing all the major cities of Japan.We went up the south tower but I really do not think it makes any difference.

Great View of Fuji!. If a particular tower is open, the observation area is beautifully decorated with a great bar area. If the other tower is open, you will still enjoy an amazing view of Tokyo and Fuji, however, the observation area is under construction and leaves a fair bit to be desired.We stayed in the observation area for a few hours, watching the sun go down, fascinated by the transformation that Tokyo undertakes in the fading light. It's my favourite place to go to see this, I fully recommend a visit though keep in mind, there's not much around. The bar requires a table charge as it's rather upscale but it too has a lovely view of the city and is a nice place to sit and watch the world go by over a few glasses of wine of beer.
Amazing Views!. Must visit on a trip to Tokyo, great views of the city not alot to see or do around here but worth a visit.
Great views! . This is a fantastic place to see the Tokyo skyline. Either north or south tower provides a great panorama.

Good enough.. Great views. Never been to the Sky Tree but this is adequate. And it's free vs.the Skytree's 3090 yen (both observatories). Higher doesn't mean better. You might pay to see only a little more on a cloudy or smoggy day.

Amazing view like Tokyo Tower but FREE!. This place is awesome because it's free to go up to the tower! The view is the same as Tokyo Tower (where you have to pay for entrance) here you don't have to pay and you get the same amazing view! They have a bunch of gifts and restaurants on top to choose from but most people just go up for the view, history, and pictures ^_^ Totally recommend to check this place out...and it's right in the middle of Shinjuku! Very easy to find and in a business environment. Everyone is so posh and on the go go gooo! Yossshhh!

Great view, and free! . Basically a great view of Tokyo for free. Couldn't complain about free things. Though if you're looking to get some great night shots of the city from here you probably might run into some difficulty with the lighting and the insistence by the staff that tripods are not allowed to be used.
Meh. Not that much to see really. Expecting much more, but the glass are full of finger print so it's so hard to take good picture with the strong light from within and the dirty glass...
Great views. Want to sightsee someplace free in Tokyo? Go to see the view from the metropolitan government building. 45th floor, open till late, and free!
Great free views of the city. Great to be able to see the whole city for free from the top of the building! We could see Mt Fuji too. Little shopping area in the middle and views all the way around.

Observation Deck of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is located approximately 10 minutes from the Shinjuku station. The walk is easy and no need to take a cab. I visited the building on a Friday morning at about 10:00 am and there was absolutely no line. In less than a minute I was at the observation deck. The view is stunning. It is something you really should do if you are in Tokyo. There is a small souvenir shop at the deck. It sells the usual knick knacks. Since the observation deck is free I highly recommend a stop here.

Disappointed. Went up there for the tokyo skyline. It was quite a far walk from the nearest station. When we were up there, it looks more like a flea market and the light was really dim. The place looks old and poorly maintained, especially for Japan standard. I just don't feel comfortable and will not go there again.

Nice view and friendly staff. We go inside the building to see the view for free..its on the 45 floor and staff are very friendly and accomodating, they will guide you with the directions on how to get there..up on the building, the place is clean, tidy and the re is a shop for souveniers..perfect view for Tokyo..

Even just walking past it is an experience. From someone who lives in a small city, I was amazed just standing outside and looking up at this incredibly tall skyscraper - we had to crane our necks and felt dwarfed by comparison! It truly is an impressive building, and I'd recommend going up to the observation floor at night where they have giant windows all around the whole floor. On the top floor you can see all across Shinjuku, and at night with the city lights it is truly breathtaking. My partner and I spent ages up there just enthralled in how beautiful the city was from up high. There is also a restaurant and souvenir shop, though we didn't check either of them out.Essentially, it is perfect for a laid-back tourist activity.

Free, easy to access and large viewing area.. Unlike the other major Tokyo viewpoints the government building is free, so it is difficult to find much fault. Visited at about 10am and the queue up the building was only about 5 minutes, however it was about 20 minutes for the elevator down. The building, in my opinion, is not as well placed for views as say the Tokyo Tower, but it was a nice supplement and worth doing if you are in the area. Perfect for those not interested in city views but wishing to do so at no expense. There is a cafe situated a the top of the building and it can be reached convinently from the Shinjuku station through a long underground route.

Well worth the free entry!. Observation decks are pretty common around the city, in the TGM building(s) there are two, one each tower, that are free to access and give some pretty good views. There is a reasonably priced cafe on the floor and plenty of room for exhibitions such as the regional foods show this month (Jan 2106).

Great bird's eye view of Tokyo. We loved the view from the government buildings! 360 degrees of Tokyo. The line was long but moved quickly. We probably waited about 30 minutes when we went around sunset. It's free, which is great. It was neat to watch the city transition from day to night, and to see the city lights illuminate the skyline

Free City View, Even for Tourists. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is one of the tallest building complexes in Tokyo, and it is open to public for an almost panoramic view of the city. The viewing spot we got into was on the south tower. Got there around 4pm on a rainy day, there was no line getting up. Coming down took 30 min, waiting for elevator mostly.If you like to see Tokyo from the top, and are reluctant to pay a fee for Skytree or Tokyo Tower, this office building is the best alternative. It is free. If you have been to or planned to visit the other two, visit this observation deck anyway. You can easily get here via buses from Shinjuku station. Come early or late to avoid the crowd.There is a small restaurant and some shops on this observation deck. Budget your time for souvenirs. Some unusual stuff, such as Hello Kitty music boxes, were sold here but not available at usual tourist shops.Some people said they have seen Mt. Fuji from here. We did not . Will try again next time in Tokyo when weather is better.

Great views of Tokyo. We had a pretty clear day when we were there and had a good view of the City. Well worth going up to the observation deck. There is a deck in both towers and one has a bit better view than the other so check this out before choosing which one to do. Sorry i have forgotten which one it was. Our tour guide made sure we went up in the one with the most unobstructed view.

The most amazing view over Tokyo. We were here a sunny day but a little foggy. We saw very far away and even a little bit of Mount Fuji, so cool! There are two towers to visit and the view are both equally good. Its a bummer that it is no outside observatory only through windows.

Nice views, also has a little restaurant. Everyone will tell you about the view, so I'll tell you about the restaurant. Impeccable food (of course), tiny portions, borderline posh atmosphere but not actually all that comfortable. (There are better sky view restaurants in the city, both with better views and seating, and in some cases even more affordable menus of similar food quality.)The time of our (phoned a couple days in advance) reservation we learned only on arrival that they were hosting a wedding party, so we were relegated to the bar and had to spend the first half hour listening to a loud game of bingo (is there any other kind?). I don't know if this happens often, but I can't imagine they didn't know about the event when we called -- they just chose not to warn us.However, the tower is as awesome as everyone says, both to go up and look at the city from, and to look at from afar, such as points further west up the Kanda river. At night, it's a striking sight, lit up in green, pink or whatever (it varies).The nearby park (Chuo koen) is not bad for a visit too, though watch out not to trip over the homeless folks if you're there at dusk, and watch out for the cyclists silently careering around ignoring the no-cycling signs. (Mothers whose bikes are loaded with babies are the most notoriously kamikaze-like of these wheeled human missiles with, but that's the same throughout Tokyo, not just here.)

Free city view. It has pretty good views for a free site. Few points to take:
1. Usually long lines to get in and out of the lifts.
2. Weird souvenirs for sale.
3. Two towers to go up in.
4. Cafe available for lunch.
5. Visit on a clear day so you get the most of the views.

Japan holiday . Amazing view, and it's free. Hard to go wrong with that. It was the first thing I did on my trip and I'm glad I did it! There's two sides so you can pretty much get a full view of the landscape. Highly recommended.

Free view over Tokyo. If you are in Tokyo you should definitely make some time to visit here. Go to the top of either of the towers and see a 360 degree view over Tokyo, you can spot Mount Fuji on a good day. It's free aswell which makes it even better!
Free and a very good view. The view is very good from there. It is free. The staff which helps going up to the top is very kind and helpful. I would recommend that activity.

Great Views for free. The observation decks on the 45th floors of both buildings provide fantastic views of Tokyo and beyond. If the weather cooperates you are able to see Tokyo Skytree, Odaiba, even Mt. Fuji!

Free view. Always visit here if you are in Shinjuku, government office buildings with free viewing platforms saves you paying a lot of money for a similar experience at the overpriced sky tree (shopping mall) or Tokyo tower (wax museum). 2 towers to choose from and excellent views, as it's free you can try both towers and go at daytime, wait for the best weather or night time and it's all free. Best to walk from Shinjuku station as its not far.

Free View of Tokyo. Instead of paying to go up the Tokyo Tower or Skytree, you will have a good view of the Tokyo skyline free-of-charge in this building. There are the North and South towers and you have to take separate elevators up to the 45th floor, the observatory deck, to get a great view of Tokyo. At a particular spot you could see visitors in the other tower too.A great place to see Tokyo from high up. What's there to lose when it's free!
Lunch and Wow!. Great views all around from the top!We planned our lunch just before 12noon and have the experience of 100s of the office workers coming in for lunch too. Both great experiences!

A gret view of the city!. Anything free is welcomed! We found out about their obeservatory deck which is open to public and decided to skip going up the Tokyo Tower and Skytree. The view was great! Unfortunately it was too cloudy that day that we didn't manage to catch a glimpse of Mount Fuji.
Great View. Great view of Tokyo. We could see Mt Fuji the day we went. Was a small queue, but moved quickly. Free entry.

Stunning views. Free to enter & we didn't have to queue at all. We visited once in the morning then returned at night & neither times was it overly busy so the viewing was outstanding. The souvenir shops in the viewing area are very reasonably priced also. The only problem we had was actually finding where to enter the building from the square outside. There was some construction going on so quite a lot of boards were up & the entrance wasn't signed at all (in English). We had to ask a worker how to get in. However the view was spectacular & a must to do while in Shinjuku

The great FREE view of Tokyo City. this building is located in Shinjuku area.You can take the train to shinjuku (JR) station and take the west exit. Then follow the sign, it take about 15mins walk. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office has two side observatory, South and North. Open daily 9.30 am - 11 pm ( south observatory closed 5:30 pm) but it will be closed at long New Year weekend. Remark*** IT's FREE!ตึกนี้อยู่ในย่านชินจูกุค่ะ นั่งรถไฟมาลงสถานีชื่อ SHINJUKU (JR) นะคะ ออกทาง west exit เลยค่ะ จะมีป้ายบอกทางเรื่อยๆ แต่สังเกตดีๆหน่อยนะคะบางครั้งบางก็แอบข้างเสา ฮ่าาา เมื่อมาถึงมีให้เลือกขึ้นสองฝั่งค่ะ เหนือกับใต้ เลือกตามสะดวกเลยค่ะ เพราะวิวดีทั้งคู่ ข้างบนมีคาเฟ่เล็กๆให้นั่งกินขนมเล่นด้วย เปิดทุกวัน 9.30 - 23:00 ตึกฝั่งใต้ปิด 17:30 นะคะ ส่วนตัวคิดว่าชอบกว่าโตเกียวทาวเวอร์ค่ะ เเถวน้อยกว่าเเถมฟรีด้วย ข้อควรจำ - ตึกปิดช่วงวันหยุดยาวปีใหม่นะคะ

Do NOT miss to visit both SOUTH and NORTH Tower.. Do not miss to visit both South Tower and North Tower. South Tower Observation Deck is nice to see the view with the Dynamic Tokyo (central of Tokyo). North Tower is nice to see the view with Mt Fuji and suburbs Tokyo . Enjoy !
Great view . It's located around Shinjuku, instead of spending a lot of money with Tokyo Sky tree, why don't you just come here for almost the same great view. It's free !

Good Recommendation. During our recent visit to Tokyo our hotel recommended we go to the Government Building across the road from the hotel and take the elevator to the spectators lounge at the top of the building which had unrivalled views of Tokyo in all directions.The bonus is - its totally free of charge.It was a busy attraction and there was strict security with regards to bags being checked but that's not a bad thing in these turbulent times.The views were 360 degrees and amazing. There was a gift shop, a restaurant and toilet facilities so everything you need.With regards to transport, there is a metro station close by and the Tokyo metro is so cheap.A great location and great attraction. You don't get things for free usually these days so make sure you use this attraction.

Excellent view and free. If you want a great view of Tokyo from the 45 floor this is a free and fun way to do it. Great bookstore on the second floor and easy to get there on two or more different train lines.

It is free so there is not much to lose. Tokyo Metropolitan Gov. Observatory is an OK place to see Tokyo from above. The windows were dirty because of the rain and in the evening the inside's lights were reflecting from the window making it really hard to enjoy the view. If you have limited time in Tokyo, skip this one.

Nice view for free. Easy to find from the metro, we used the Nishi-shinjuku station and the building was well sign posted until you could actually see it, taking under 15 mins to walk. This is a free attraction as per the other posts and when we went had no queue! the observation deck is inside and has a small restaurant and gift shop. We decided to eat there and for just 1000 yen we had a drink, small salad and a tasty curry which was nice enough for lunch and allowed us to enjoy more of the view.

Free and excellent view . What's not to love? It's free and the view is amazing. It's a great way to get your bearings early in a trip to Tokyo. The observation area is large and not too crowded with other tourists. The access to elevators is well managed, and although I had to wait in line for 20 minutes to get in an elevator, I was grateful when I got up there that it wasn't jammed full of people. Definitely worth the walk (potentially out of your way) in Shinjuku.

Great views and it's free!. Why pay so much when you can have the same amazing views for free?I was hesitant at first, thinking I can't just go into a government building, but the viewing area is made for tourists, so there's no awkward explaining or trespassing. On a busy day, it can have queues, but never as bad as the touristy towers. The view from up here is breathtaking. You can even see the famous Mt Fuji! Btw if you go on a weekend, there are no workers and the area is a lot quieter. Also the square 'inside' the building is worth to visit, with its beautiful flower beds and interesting sculptures.

Great view . If you want a great view of the city this a the place to go it's free and a better view then Tokyo tower, expect a 10 minute wait in the line for the elevator and a quick bag search which is normal for any government building,

Great view. Organized acces. Free.. We loved our visit to the government building. From the statues on the lower level to the great observatory in each of the two towers. If you have time you can visit both observatories. There is a cafeteria up there as well as good variety of souvenirs. Entrance was free.

Free view of Tokyo. Its great that this tourist spot is free, but if you go on a hazy day , the view isn't that clear. Another positive - we didn't have to wait in any queue to go up in the lift. This may have been because it was Monday after the holiday period. Mount Fuji could only jsut be seen due to the haze but still worthwhile to get a perspective of the size of Tokyo.

Easy to find. Easy to access viewing level. Great views. Tacky gift shops.. Choose a clear day when the smog levels are low. Doesn't matter whether you visit the north or south tower, as the views are spectacular from either.

Nice, free viewing platform. This is an impressive and imposing building. The tower has a couple of excellent viewing platforms (one in each of the north and south towers). One is open at night for excellent night-time viewing. Although there is a small place to get food at the top, I think it would be better simply to enjoy the view and eat at one of the many places nearby in Shinjuku.
Gorgeous views. Perfect alternative to Tokyo tower if travelling on a budget, as there's no entry cost. Gorgeous views on a clear day, including Mt Fuji in the distance
Great view. You are able to see the entire Shinjuku area, even further away. The gift shop is also very nice. It is within walking distance from most hotels in Shinjuku.

Amazing views. We arrived late in the afternoon and visted both observation decks. Tge lines went quickly as they squeeze you into the elevator. Amazing views an with the sun setting behind Mt Fuji was spectacular.

Good, but not the best views of Tokyo. The advantage of the view from Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is that it's free and as it's close to Shinjuku makes for a worthwhile visit to experience 'another' view of Tokyo. Not as good as Tokyo City View in Roppongi Hills (although you need to pay at this attraction).
Nice free attraction. Nice view at the top. There are also souvenir shops at the top. It's near the Tochomae station and there's also a park nearby.

Great free look out with views of Mt Fuji. Went to the south lookout and was very pleased with the view. The observatory provides about 180degrees of Tokyo viewing, including Mt Fuji in the background. Really great to get your bearings and comprehend how massive Tokyo really is.

A view from heaven!. The view took my breath away! Be prepared for a 30 minute wait for the elevators to the observation floor. It passes very quickly as you people watch. A charming cafe is there on the observation floor for coffee & desserts. A wonderful experience I will never forget.

Great view.. Fantastic view of the area. But pity it was indoor. I thought it would be an outdoor observation area.
Nothing much to do except take pictures at the small and limited window spaces.
Staff were courteous.

Great view of Tokyo. Instead of spending time and money getting up to the Skytree (upwards of an hour in line and 25 or so bucks a person) go to this building! Enjoy the view from the top floor of the government building. Definitely a worthwhile trip!
free night view on the observatory deck. nice place to visit for a FOC night view of Tokyo on the observatory deck, it's better than paying a lot of money to get up to Tokyo skytree

It's a good place to view Tokyo but do not expect too much. Just in case you don't already know, it's free to go up to the North and South Towers. We visited the South Tower in the morning. It's a big room with huge windows, where you can get a good view of Tokyo. We went there on a good day so we have a clear view of Mt. Fuji's ice-capped summit. The room itself, although big, was nothing special though. There's a café in the middle that serve food and beverage. You may expect to pay a minimum of 500Yen for a hot/cold drink and a minimum of 900Yen for food. I just looked at the menu and decided not to eat there. There's a small souvenir shop behind the café where you can buy small trinkets like Sushi Keychains, postcards, etc. The overall feel was a bit dated and it would do well if they could provide seats outside of the café so visitors can rest up a bit. Do remember that there is no entrance fee so if you're on a tight budget and do not want to pay just to get a good view of the city from high up, then really, this is the place to go.

All positive. There is nothing I can complain about our visit there. First of all it was free. The viewing tower is on the 45th floor. You can either take the separate lifts to the north tower or the south tower. On clear days (which may only be a limited few per year) you may be able to view the magnificent Mt. Fuji. We didn't manage as the sky was very cloudy and foggy. We could only view Shinjuku area and slightly beyond. The tourist volunteer did a great job. She looks like a retiree but she could speak excellent Chinese in which we had no barriers at all. It's good to employ retirees for such work in which is value added to the society. You can either walk there if you live near the Shinjuku Station area or you may take the Oedo Line one stop to there. We took the Oedo Line. I think walking there may be better, for you can see more of the other side of Shinjuku away from the shopping areas.
Start here. A very good place to start you Tokyo visit. Gives a vey good perspective on the scale of this amazing city. Although a bit of a walk from Shinjuku station, it's worth the effort

Amazing views. Got a free guided tour around this building which was great. Got to look around the whole building which you cannot do unless with a guide. The views from the top are amazing. On a clear day can see right out to Mt Fuji !!!

Tokyo Night Scene From An Observation Deck. A visit to the Tokyo Metropolitan Govt Office Towers is a must. On a clear day you can have birds' eye view of the city. I have been told that if you are lucky, you can even catch a glimpse of Mt Fuji. But its at night that I recommend especially. From the North Tower, , you can feel the vibe of the city, looking down from 200 hundred metres.Great shopping for souvenirs at your leisure and nice eateries. Remember to take a free momento, a rubber stamp is provided to indicate that you have visited this site and this you can stamp on your programme or diary. BTW, this facility is Free. No entrance fees.
Spectacular views on top of Tokyo!. I have been to the free observation deck, the views are spectacular from all the different angles. it's impressive no matter you visit during day or night time.

Excellent with free English guide. This was a excellent place to visit. The view is amazing and it is all free. When we arrived a volunteer offered us a free english tour, we agreed not expecting much, however we were both surprised by what she new and the information she gave us. She was only new (second tour) but she was very knowledgable and friendly.We would absolutely recommend to family and friends.The information centre downstairs was also helpful.

An view of Mount Fuji from here. I went to the South Observation Deck at the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. No entrance fee is needed.Lucky even though it was not a very clear day we still can see Mount Fuji.
Great view. Definitely worth a visit on a clear day. View was fantastic although Mt Fuji was covered in cloud. Best of all it was free!

Great view. Very impressive building with a free trip to the 45th floor with unbelievable views of Tokyo in most directions. Viewing is from inside the building through windows but still very worthwhile.
Good free view. It is a good alternative to Tokyo tower for save money. You can go up on the upper level to see the beautiful view of Tokyo .

Free view of Tokyo. Free place to view Tokyo. Go on a cloudless day and you might even see Mt Fuji. It's on the 75th storey. There are 2 towers. I was recommended Tower B. There's even a Tourist Information Counter on the 1st floor. Show your passport and you can get free wifi ID. Not many places to eat here( or at least, I didn't find cheaper alternatives). There's a place to eat on the 75th storey but I thought it wasn't worth the price. Eat elsewhere before going there.

Free View of Tokyo Skyline. Perhaps the only sky view in Tokyo that is free to ride. And that's why you have to stand in a queue most of the time. There are souvenir shops & restaurants at the top too. Two towers have two observatories.

impressive building and great place to see tokyo. This building was massive, very impressive architecture and one of the tallest building I have ever been into. The staff were friendly in facilitating the lift. A restaurant was located on the top and shops were available.

Get up high to appreciate the vastness of Tokyo. This one was a highlight - an amazing way to get an idea of just how vast Tokyo is. We enjoyed views on a gorgeous clear day, with a stellar peak of Mt Fuji the icing on the cake. The knick knack stores were great for picking up a few treats for home. Brunch in the restaurant offered a quiet point of reflection amongst the usual Tokyo bustle. Well worth the visit.

An Observatory of Tokyo. This is a good observatory for day view of Tokyo and not the night view. There is shop inside with lots of lights on and so, you can imagine the reflection of light off the glass panels. However, there is north and south observatory towers and both of them are free. I happened to found its north tower and prior to entering the observation deck elevator, you will be checked by its security officers. *To come here, take Toei Subway Oedo Line to Tochomae Station. Be warned, there could still be some walk from the station.

Recreating a family memory. We were last here when our daughter was a baby but now 13 years later, it's still a great outing. Amazing views across Tokyo for free! It's a little more crowded but you don't have to wait long before space clears for photo opportunity.

Excellent view of tokyo and mt Fuji. Pretty cool view of the city of tokio at sunset...restaurant wasnt open when we got there...they have souvenirs and other tourist goodies and is located on a 45th floor.great for landscape pictures
free with no charge. easy to locate and the most important thing is, its a free observatory area where you can see as far as mount Fuji in a good clear weather.

Good views and free. Definetely worth a visit or two. Queus are never long and the fact is free makes it a perfect place to take a look at Tokyo/ Shinjuku both at night and during the day.Souveniers can be bought on the viewing platform and are actually very reasonably priced.
