AMAZING VIEWS FROM THE OBSERVATORY FOR FREE!. Visiting this observatory is definiately one of the best things we did whilst visiting Tokyo. The views from the observatory are breathtaking and you really get a feeling for the scale of the city.A MUST SEE!

North/south observatory tower. It was a pleasant trip. It is free of charge and there are two shops on the same level as the observatory corner itself where u can buy souvenirs and toys.Think u can see Mt Fuji from here but wasnt able to experience on my trip there. In my opinion, better than Skytree(where you hv to pay).Alight at Tocho-mae station. Near Shinjuku stn.
free for Tokyo city skyline. It is free to go up and check out the tokyo skyline. Anything free is good. And they do open late too. worth to visit
Nice observatory tower for FREE.. There are two observatory in the 45th floor. Nice place to see the view of Tokyo. Its near Shinjuku, so take time to be there and see the night view of Tokyo.
Awesome views of the city. Awesome views of the city!! Would recommend going at sunset so you see the city come alive at night! Beautiful!

Free view of Tokyo and Mount Fuji . I visited during the day and it was a great way to see Tokyo from above without paying the hefty Skytree fee. I was lucky to be there on a very clear day and could even see Mount Fuji off in the distance. There was a cafe, gift shop and small exhibition of anti-drug posters on the level of the observation deck. Let's be real though, everyone was just there for the view.

Free and awesome . First of all I'd intended to visit in the day to hopefully see mt Fuji but rain ruined that. I ended up going that same night and it was pretty great. It's a bit of a long walk from Shinjuku station but considering it's free and the views are really quite amazing, I think it's worth the time.

Cheap lunch at 32nd floor. Primarily, I visited the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building for the observatory they have at the 45th floor. It is free admission and has a good view of Tokyo. After enjoying the view, have some nice meal at the 32nd floor. It is somewhat a canteen for the employees but open to the public. Meal price starts at 550yen and will be served hot. It was impressive that they have a tourist information at the ground floor. Grab some maps and brochures to know more about what to to see and do in Tokyo.
View of Tokyo. This is free to go up and see the beautiful view, there is a shop up on the observation deck if you want food or souvenirs

Short of time, see all of Tokyo here. Easy access and free of charge, this is the place to see highlights of Tokyo if short of time. We visited Mt. Fuji years ago, so not willing to travel and spend another day there, came around 3.45 pm so that we could take a glimpse of the sunset and the early street light-up. Started with the North building and went on to the South building which we think have a better view of Mt. Fuji. Lovely view of sky in shades of orange and red with hint of Mt. Fuji on a not very clear day. After that, one by one, the buildings' and streets' lights came to life. A wonderful view.If you have the time, check the weather, come once in the morning when the morning sun from the east shine at Mt. Fuji. Tour Shinjuku and Harajuku areas including the lovely gardens and Meiji Shrine during the day and come back again for the sunset view. The cafe there offers decent cakes and local sweet stuffs.

Free view of Tokyo. The view from the 45th storey of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (North Observatory) was breathtaking! It's free and you get to see a bird's eye view of Tokyo. Of course going to the Tokyo Skytree offers a better view, however, you can make do with this if you don't want to spend anything. It is better to go during the day as it was already dark (17:00) when we were there and we could not really make out the famous landmarks in Tokyo. In the end, my children and I ended up buying souvenirs from the 2 gift shops there! The souvenir items there were simply irresistable. So the visit was not free after all!

Skyscraper district . . Good place for you to chill and relax. Nice design especially the art college/university that looks amazing cool. Quiet area. Check out the observatory deck. The view of Tokyo is amazing. Catch the mountain Fuji on a great day

Fantastic architecture. Designed by architect icon Kenzo Tange the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Centre provides anyone interestedin architecture a great experience! The two towers and its adjoining buildings shows Tanges genius in combining elementsfrom western and japanese architectural elements. The view from the towers is also outstanding.Worth visiting even for small children as there is room to play between the buildings, and they'll enjoy the view.Recommend a weekend visit, as there are fewer people around so you can encounter the architecture and environs on its own.

Wonderful Free View of the City. We spent a little over an hour enjoying the view of Tokyo from the 46th floor of the Tokyo Metro. Government Building. It's a great place to take pictures and buy unique souvenirs as there's a little shopping area in the center of the floor. There's also a restaurant but we didn't try it. About a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station.

Great Views. Offered amazing views of Tokyo free of charge. Super helpful attendants. Be sure to check out both South and North observatory. North observatory opens until 10pm and South observatory opens until 5.30pm.

Free visit to top floor. Very helpful people. They offer guided walking tours in different languages within Tokyo at a more than reasonable price. Walk is done by volunteers. Also check their website for reservations. German volunteers are good. You can also visit their top floor café with stunning views of Tokyo and mount Fuji when the weather admits.

Poor view, Bad operation. Don't waste time to come here. . I would not recommend this location for a short-stay tourist. First of all, the evening guards told us to go around to the back of the building although their front entrance where the guards were standing can lead us to the elevator within 10 seconds. And the arrow signs lead us to another direction, the upper deck, to access to the same elevator. This was really confusing. When we called their office, no one answered.Free entry with a bag check.It was a run down cheap sad tourist trap.When I first visited here in 1993, it was nothing like this. Because of the added souvenir store in the center, you cannot see much of night spectacle due to the lighting reflection on the windows.The whole place is dingy, with few seats. The cheesy restaurant also takes up 1/3 of the best viewing angles. We felt disappointed for how it was advertised as a tourist destination. We had visited Mori center skydeck previous night. You will have a better spectacles 360 degree from Ropponggi hill over Shinjuku and afar. It took us an hour to get to this government building but we left in 10 min. It was a humiliating experience. From here to Shinjuku, we took a taxi as the tranport wasn't too good in the dark. Getting to a Taxi waiting was also a bit of a walk. Without street signs, it was very disorienting, altough we were using smart phone gps map. That was equakly discouraging. Definitely thumbs down unless yiu have nothing else to do.

Vacation . We strolled around this area which they called The Avenues because the area are mostly offices and businesses. The streets are so wide on both sides and at night it was nice to walk as there are cafes and restaurants where you can dine.

A must in Tokyo (its free). We visited this building and Tokyo tower and really the views from this building are much better. In a sunny day you can see the shape of Monte Fuji. You can visit the Assembly too (We prefer going to eat to a typical and traditional small bar :o)

No cost and no line. Free! No wait for elevator on a clear Monday afternoon in December. Observation deck on 45th floor of Tokyo city government building The building is nifty as well. Great view of some of the nearby buildings and parks. Shinjuku is a nice neighborhood. Gift/toy shop at observation. It isn't as high as some skyscraper views (e.g., the Empire State Building) and not as close to other buildings as places in Hong Kong.
Great view of Tokyo for free!!. A free government building which offers an amazing panoramic view of Tokyo. You can even see Mount Fuji from there. I believe we were on the 44th floor.

Great Views on a Budget. Very Close to Shinjuku Central Park and the Tochomae Subway station this free government building offers great 360 views from Shinjuku of Tokyo. They have a coffee shop but I would go for the views. Total time at this venue may top out at an hour. If your staying at the HRC, Hilton, Washington hotel, or Hyatt it's worth the stop.

What a view. Take the free lift to the top and see the views, there is a lovely restaurant at the top to relax in. Gifts are plentiful and very good value. But it is the views on a clear day that make it such a good place to visit, if cloudy there are better things to do.

Free views of a marvelous city!. This is a great place to go for free views of the city. The fact that it is free makes it convenient. We couldn`t go to the Sky Tree it was very cloudy and I didn`t want to waist time in a line and money going up to be able to see nothing. This building was the next best thing, who cares if we could not see the city? it`s free. I couldn`t be more wrong. It is perfect! there are no lines and you can see the city just fine. There`s a store up there so it`s not like there`s a lot to do other than shopping. It`s more a go up, enjoy the view, take some pictures and let`s go.
Great view of Tokyo. Walking distance from subway station. Free entrance to the building observation deck. Souvenir shops, exhibition hall available. Good place to see Tokyo from a high level view.

Good place to get a fantastic view of central Tokyo. Fantastic views of the city and way out to Mount Fuji on a clear day. Typical gift shops at the top. Shop staff are friendly and very committed to serving the customers. Not for a long stay but you can get some fantastic pics
Fun-ish. Really nice views given it is free (a rarity in tokyo) however only really good for a 20 minute browse. Nothing special otherwise.
Nice view . Just a nice free view of the Tokyo area without having to pay for entry to other viewing buying such as Tokyo sky tree, small shop of souvenirs but otherwise nothing much else.

Fuji revealed at sunset!. During our visit to Japan we had traveled close to Mount Fuji but had not been able to see it because of low cloud cover but on the day we ascended the tower we witnessed the glorious sight of the mountain in late afternoon sunshine and then watched a spectacular sunset. I took so many shots that my camera overheated!!
The view at floor 45 worths visit. A hug place but worths to visit , there are two views , both of them nice, besides at the top you can have some gifts and snacks.

Great overview of Tokyo. We visited this building as it has an observation deck and gives a great view of Tokyo. Also it was my sisters birthday and they had a bar therefore enjoyed a lovely wine with perfect views.

Free and offers great views of Tokyo!. You can't complain when there's a free observatory that gives you a great view of Tokyo, can you? This place is easily accessible from Shinjuku Station as there are clear signboards and an underground walkway that leads to the area. They will inspect your bags before entering the elevator. There's also a souvenir shop on the 45th floor observatory that seems to be quite popular with the tourist. Overall, a good place to drop by if you're in Shinjuku Area or if you want to get free views of Tokyo!

Free views. Easy to access this building and you decide which way you go North building or South. You could choose to do each at different times of the day since it is free to go to the Observation decks. The views are brilliant and I was guided by a volunteer who spoke excellent English and had a cracking sense of humour
Excellent views of the city.. From the top of the building you can see the vast expanse of Tokyo extending out of your sight. It is well worth the trip to the top to gain perspective on the city.
It's free. Great views of Tokyo and all for free. When we went there were only a handful of people there, we had a volunteer guide explain parts of the city that we were viewing.

Great Heights For Free And An Awesome Cafeteria. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office offers 2 observatories free of charge. It's not the best or highest view in Tokyo but it's also the only one that will not cost you anything. Entrance is through the building lobby and bags are subject to search. The 45 story elevator ride takes less than a minute and the observation deck is completely enclosed. Those that want to take pictures of themselves with the city backdrop will have a difficult time since windows are tinted and the lighting is not optimal. The North observation deck offers a cafe and has a gift shop. The best kept secret in this building lies on the 32nd floor; the cafeteria. To access this you must check in with the security on the 2nd floor (just fill out a paper and get a visitor pass). Lunch starts at 11:30am and is paid for by vending machines. The cafeteria offers very affordable food when compared to other eateries in the immediate area. For an example, Tonkotsu ramen was one ¥460 and a soba set was around ¥300. A great way to experience the salary man lunch!

Great free views, staff canteen worth a visit too. This is a well known place in Tokyo to get free views from very high up (45th floor). Cannot fault the views - absolutely breathtaking, Mount Fuji can be seen on a clear day (unfortunately was too cloudy when we visited).We visited on a Wednesday lunchtime and it didn't seem overly busy. You have the choice of the North or the South observation deck. We picked the North and there was a few decent gift shops and a small restaurant.The real find however was the staff canteen on level 32. Once you return to the ground floor after viewing- ask the security staff for a pass to access the canteen. They will give you a temporary pass. Now go up on the general access elevator to level 32 and you will find the most amazing canteen, loads of choices at crazy low prices. 500 yen for a main meal, 150 for a drink. There is a system- all meals are on display with a code, take a note of the code, buy a ticket from a vending machine with the relevant code, then go to the relevant serving station with your ticket.Find a seat and enjoy lunch with great views for next to nothing!

Good city views. Went here twice during our stay in Tokyo. Can get quite crowded but offers a good view of the city at no cost. Make sure you come here when the weather is clear and you will be able to get a view of the spectacular mount Fuji.
A good view of Shinjuku Tokyo. A good view of Shinjuku though you will still be inside the observatory. Unlike the one in Osaka where you will be outside on top of the building
Tokyo up high. Great way to see the city on a fine day and it's free. Choice of aspect - north or south observatory - can see Mt Fuji as well
Great views, lots of souvenirs!. Go up to the top floor and you can get an idea of how enormous Tokyo is!There is no charge and there are lots of souvenirs for sale.

A free view over the skyline, even at night. I visited at night and unfortunately the view was obscured by a partly cloudy/foggy Tokyo sky. Still it was worth to visit. I find it extremely attractive that the sight is free of charge.

the building itself is nice but i'd say dont waste time going up there for the view even though its free. its nothing special to see from up there. so boring just look at the building from the outside and thats about it

Great view, free of charge. I went on a weekday, one of the tower was closed. The queue was well organised & it took 10 to 15 min. Great view, you can see very far ahead on a clear sunny day. There's a restaurant (set meals were reasonably priced) & 2 souvenirs booths. Worth visiting since it's free of charge.Tips: Do check the opening days. There're 2 towers, North & South which close on certain days.

Panorama view of Tokyo. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is locate near Shinjuku station. There are two towers that you can see Tokyo view from the observation decks at 45 floors for free! First thing you need to know is entrance is look like construction site do not be hesitate go stead my find an elevator to 45 floor.

Foggy day. We visited this in expectation to catch breath taking view of Tokyo.
It turned out the weather was not in our favour but good stop nonetheless.
Excellent views of Tokyo!. A must do for great views of the city, we were lucky enough to have a volunteer guide explain some key facts. The best thing is that it's free!

Free lookout and cheap lunch. If you are in the area, don't miss out on this sometimes overlooked attraction. The building offers free lookout points from its north and south towers (I recommend you do the southern tower as better sights are had). Also, in the mid-levels, you can access the government workers' cafeteria from where one can purchase a cheap but yet delicious lunch.

Fast and free!. Wanted to see Tokyo from above, and I got a tip about this building, wich gives you that experience for free. My first meeting with it, was with a friendly security officer wich pointed me in the right direction. There are two towers, but the view is pretty much the same from either one of them.By the elevator, there was a brief search through the backpack, and then straight up the viewing level. All fast and easy.There you could wald around as long as you like. There were also a nice cafe at the tower I was in (think it was the southern tower), where I had a relaxin beer before I went down, just as fast and easy as I went up.

FREE Things to do in Tokyo. This building is close to the Washington Hotel, short walking distance, practically right across the steet. It has twin observatory buildings on the 45th floor that allows one to see a vast area of Tokyo and other areas of Japan. On a clear day, one can even see Mt. Fuji, although there was too much cloud cover during my visit to see it. There is a gift shop and drink/snack lounge there. Lots of windows to see out of with informational plaques to name certain landscapes that are visible. You have to go down to first floor, then wait to take an elevator up. When leaving, it brings you back to the 2nd floor. If you exit from the interior and not the street level, you can walk out into a park that makes a nice interlude. It has a waterfall, but it was out of service during my visit. So if you tire of all the buildings, this makes a nice respite. I enjoyed my visit even through the drizzling rain. The temperature was in the 50's F. The foliage has the trees changing colors and leaves falling, but still lots of foliage at this time. The building itself is worth a look.

free to go in. If before coming here you have been to Park Hyatt Tokyo, don't bother comingm the view is sort of the same. But do come here if you want to support the local community of elderly working people. you get a quick tour of the viewing platform and a bit of a chat, which was lovely. I don't regret coming here. there's also a lovely cafe if you fancy something refreshing.

Great View for FREE!. I went on a Tuesday morning and there was less than a 10-minute wait for the elevator ride to the 45th Observatory Floor in the South Tower. There is also an Observatory Floor in the North Tower but it was closed that day. The view from the South Tower was just as good as the view from the Tokyo Tower that I had visited a few days earlier.There is no charge to visit the Observatory Floor in the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Offices. There is security checking people’s bags before going up the elevator. There is also a cafe on the Observatory Floor.

Great viewing. First thing it is free. First time went up tower on left as you enter building great views of city, when we arrived were greeted by a local lady and she walked around explaining all the sights. Then left us to take our pictures and admire the view. We also went up at night time the right tower open till around 9pm. Another way to appreciate Tokoyo. On a good day you are supposed to see Mt Fuji, the day we went it was cloudy.

Free view!. This is by far the best place to go in Tokyo for a free view - no need to go up the Tokyo Skytree after going here! You can go up either the North Tower or South Tower, or both! Its a little hard to figure out, where to go once your in the foyer of the building, but just ask one of the security personnel to help you out or go to the tourist centre! Also check out the staff cafeteria for a great, cheap lunch!

A place with a view. Visited the North tower observatory recently, however the day was cloudy so was unable to see mt fuji. The average wait to the building is less than 5 min and the crowd at the observatory is well controlled so you can have time to enjoy the view.

great view, worth a quick visit. Amazing 360 degrees views from high above Shinjuku. Worth taking a look.
The bar / restaurant seemed overpriced but did not actually go there.
The only draw back was the tourist junk on sale up on the viewing level. but not too intrusive, and easily ignored when you have such a great view of Tokyo.

Well worth a visit - and free. We had heard you could go to this twin tower building to get a view of the City and it was well worth it. Not too long a line up to go on the elevator, security check before entering, not your clothing but any hand held item such as purse, computer etc.The elevator takes you to the 45th floor. It was muggy and sunny so a little smog did not help the view which was amazing. There is also a small souvenir shop on this floor. As in all of Japan there are very few places to sit down but on the way from the metro to the Metropolitan area there are some small walls to sit on.

Great view of Tokyo for FREE. Enjoyed the view of Tokyo from here. I am also glad it was free of charge and not overly crowded like most places are. Not only that, it's near the Tochomae station. If you're on a budget and want a good view of Tokyo, this is the place to go.

Great views of Tokyo. No charge!. You can pay to go up in several large towers in Tokyo to see a view of the city, but this building, operated by the city, is free and open to the public. Accessible by the metro, and easy to find if walking, head down to Level 1 and get in line for the elevator ride to the 45th floor. I was there on a Monday morning, so didn't have any wait in line on the way up (about 5 minutes on the way down). Up at the top, you have a 365 degree view through large windows. There's a gift shop and cafe as well.
Great views of the city and central park.. although it was cloudy when we visited, i recommend this as a great place to scope out the area from above.

Cheap Treats of Tokyo. Don't have the cash for Tokyo Skytree or Tokyo Tower? Go to the top of Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office for FREE! Great views of the city and you can see Tokyo Tower easily from the building. It's easy to get up and down the tower, and typically there's no line. A MUST go to spot.

Take the time to go to the top - worth the view alone!. We stopped here out of chance on our first tour day as it was right across from our hotel. What a great way to start things out - the view is phenomenal and easy in and out. 360 degree view of the entire city and if it is clear a great view of Mt. Fuji.

Good views. I visited the observatory and had the most wonderful 360 degree view over Tokyo - on a good day you can see Mt Fuji. It is free to visit and I was lucky to be shown around by one of the guides who really helped to orientate myself in this enormous city.

Absolutely stunning sunset, and it's free!. I just cant beleive thus view is free!! We spent over and hour watching the sunset and the lights come on. We were fortunate enough to see the silhouette of Mount Fuji as the sun set, which was a real treat. It was very quiet and peaceful, with few visitors which gave us a chance to relax after a busy day touring Tokyo. We even found a socket to recharge our phone aftet taking so many pictures. Definitely worth the walk from the station.
Free Admission to Observation Deck. Definitely try both the south and north towers which give different views of tokyo. Its free admission!

Great place to visit and see the Tokyo skyline for free!. You can enter through the front entrance and there are lots of tourist information freely available. We took the elevator to the 45th floor and got to see the beautiful expansive view of the city. There's a restaurant and souvenir shops.

Observation deck good. I was a bit underwhelmed at first with the observation areas at the top of this building, but I'm sure it had to do with the fact that it was at night. It was still great to see the city all lit up, from several great vantage points. I was probably expecting large panoramic-style windows rather than the relatively smaller ones, but the views available were still very good. And the toy souvenir stores right there are pretty tough to pass up for things to bring home to kids, or for the kids at heart.Not a bad place to visit, especially considering it is a free attraction. Easy to get to from several transit options; located a short walk from the Shinjuku station.

Great Source of Information. The office in located in the Tokyo Metropolitan Office building complex, and there is an observation deck on the 45th floor of the building. You can get maps and guidebooks here and find out about nominally priced walking tours offered by volunteers. You can also eat the the reduced price worker's cafeteria that is on the 32 floo.

Free view of Tokyo. Nice view of the city. There's a North and a South building you can go up in. One of them has a souvenir shop but for the view itself there's not an absolute must to go up both sides. Also open at night (not always though so make sure you check). And best of all: it's free :)!

Take your first glimpse of Mount Fuji. It's free to just go up and check it out. It is well sign posted from Shinjuku station, maybe allow a bit of time for the walk. There's a quick security check and then up you go! At night the interior is well lit making photos a little challenging, but never mind, it's free!
Good View. Best part is that it is free and you get a very good view of Tokyo. It also has a descent souvenir shop.

Completely free! Great views of Tokyo.. Fantastic experience! Full panoramic view of the Tokyo skyline, seems to go on forever, was astonished this was a free attraction! Right near the Park Hyatt Hotel if you feel like soaking in more of the views with a fancy cocktail. Arguably provides better views than the skytree due to its locale.

Great views over a part of Tokyo. It's really fantastic that this place is kept open until late hours and completely for free. But it's a pity only part of the panorama is available as some is reserved only for the visitors of the restaurant located on the same floor.
Great place to enjoy a bird's eye view of Tokyo!. This is one of the places in Tokyo which you can go up high in a building to enjoy a very nice view of Tokyo. And the best part - it's FREE!

Great free views of Tokyo. weather permitting.. The building provides a great 360 views of Tokyo from two towers. The viewing level has toilets, gift shop and a small cafe with food and drinks for sale with a seating area with tables and chairs. The viewing level also has volunteers that offer information about the city and its surroundings. The only thing i would say is if you want to see Mt Fuji, you might be disappointed by low level cloud that surrounds it for most of the year. Well worth going up especially as its free.

Free and Nice. I've been here before 10 years ago and today it is still open for free.Do plan your time, I suggest:1. To see Fuji mount, better come in the morning or clear sky.2. I like to come around 430pm when the sky is bright for city view.3. About 5-530pm the sky turn dark and you have beautiful night view.Note: Entrance locate at Lower Ground.Please check the time table. Some Monday and Tuesday is close

Amazing view. A good place to see Tokyo, on clear day there is a chance to catch Mount Fuji but this time it was relatively cloudy. Read on the the structure of this building and how it's build. Amazing engineering.
Sweet free view of city. . Gives a great perspective on the expanse of Tokyo. Yhe cafeteria on level 32 is amazing value eith a great range of food.
Fab architecture. This is a great building to visit and to admire the views over the city skyline! I was staying at the Hilton Hotel nearby so it was a short walk!
Nice views. Quite easy to find and a quick elevator ride up to see the views at no cost at all. Small cafe and shop. Hardly any queues at all. Would recommend to go there if you are in the area.

Great Free View of the City. A wonderful view in all direction and all for free. Close to Shinjuku station and situated next to a lovely park. English speaking guide available to point out the various iconic buildings and landmarks from each window.

Great view. This was really a nice thing to do especially because there is no admission charge. Worth checking out. There were also several displays of art ( origami ) in the middle that were interesting and beautiful.

Free view of Tokyo. Go to the FREE observation deck on (I think it was) the 45th floor and enjoy the skyline of Tokyo. We went at nighttime and the views are stunning, as they surely are during the day as well!

It's free, doesn't take long, worth a stop. The visit is well-orchestrated, efficient, and free! The views are spectacular and the window guides are useful. Just across the street from the Hyatt Regency Tokyo and subway station next door. Definitely worth a quick visit if you are in Shinjuku. We did Sky Tree at night at Metropolitan Government building during day to have contrasting views.

Amazing view of Tokyo. Absolutely Free!!. What more is there to say? You get some nice views of Tokyo. And there is no charge for going up. there is a Souvenir area on the observation deck level, and an expensive Restaurant (500 yen +- for a soda, where you can pick one up at a vending machine outside for 130 yen)

Great views from the top at no cost. This imposing government skyscraper is very Orwellian but boasts one of the best views of Tokyo and is free. We went to Tokyo Tower the day before and I think there are better views from the TMG building. Definitely worth a visit.
Amazing Tokyo view for free!. Amazing view of Tokyo from 45th floor for free! They open until 11pm and they have a restaurant and shopping booth as well on top. Highly recommended!
Great view. Very popular so the best free view can be quite congested. Bar/restaurant quite expensive as they charge a separate music fee.
Best views around, and it's FREE!. Always a great view, but we went at sunset and the photo opps are stunning. Many others had the same idea.

Great views but get there early. . Loved getting up high and not having to pay for the pleasure. If you get a chance, have a wonder around the gardens before going up for some fantastic views. We arrived at just before 9:30 and there were already queues forming. If the weather is good, you will also see Mt. Fuji on the horizon. A few souvenirs can be bought if you like. There's also some tourist information and some great hand crafted pieces which tell you what the different areas of Japan are famous for. Definitely worth a visit.
Nice view!. Good view of the Tokyo skyline. No entrance fee. Gift shop has cute stuff. Must visit is the Tourist Info Centre, they have very nice and helpful staff and lots of info available.

Excellent views and for free!. The building from the outside is impressive enough, but given that you can enter and take in the views it provides for free is excellent. Unlike other viewing areas of Tokyo, I think that Shinjuku and it's surrounding areas provides a good focal point for spotting famous sites and parts of the city.The south tower provides the best views.
Great views. Good for views over the city, but a bit out on its own as there is nothing much around it to do bar the sword museum.

It's free and better than Skytree.. What is it? Well, it's a viewpoint, but, it's free.We did this the day after doing Skytree. At Skytree we queued for 30 minutes, then paid a fair amount of money to go up.Here, we queued for perhaps 10 seconds, then paid absolutely nothing. And guess what the view was? The same.Although, in fairness, we also went up Roppongi Hills Tower, which you do pay for (but less than Skytree), but you get to go out on the roof in the open air.So, this is my favourite free viewpoint in Tokyo, and my second favourite after Roppongi Hills Tower.Recommended.

Good observatory. The view from the top is worth the trip. The fact is though that Tokyo does not have an exceptionally pretty skyline. But if it pleases your eye, this is the best place to observe it. And it's free!

WOW. !!!. Just opposite The Hilton Hotel, it's free and catch the lift which is free and the view is amazing ,you can see all over Tokyo. Then went back in the evening, it shuts at 10pm, and wow, fantastic. Staff are so nice, telling you which area you were looking at.

Views of Tokyo for free. This is totally free. Well worth a look. Other tall buildings charge. This will be almost as tall and almost as good. Restaurant charges for the view but the rest of the building is free. Go up it. You won't be disappointed.

Nice free views. Do yourself a favour and go here rather than the Sky tree which will cause you to lose it with queues. This building is free and has 2 floors to ascend to. There is a lot of tourist tack on offer from the gift shops but you are here for the view so they can be ignored! On a clear day you can allegedly see Mount Fuji but the haze didn't allow on the day I visited.

Out of the world view of Tokyo and its free too. I was there recently after my conference. To go there l took the JR Yamamote line from Tokyo station Gate 5 and exited at the Shinjuku Station. After that l took the western exit and walked through a covered passageway for about 10 minutes passing the entrance to many shops under office buildings. After coming out of the underground passageway l passed by a tree lined boulevard for a distance of about 100 metres to reach the compund of the Tokyo Metropolitan Office Buildings which comprise of two towers north and south. The northern tower was opened until 11am whilst the southern tower is only opened until 5pm. I was ushered into a lift after a brief security check that took me to the 45th floor. I was not disappointed at all. The view was out of the world!!! I was there around 10pm and couldnot see Mt Fuji which was obvious on a clear day. The views of the surroundings was really incredible amazing. The only thing you coukd not do was to set up a tripod to take long exposures. They close at 11pm.
Great Vista of Shinjuku. Great place to have a literal overview of the city. Free to see and a walking distance from most hotels in the area.

Bar, but not coffee. The view is amazin. Not the highest view in Tokyo but still beautiful. The whole building itself stands so bibblically proud. I really like it. The bad is that although there is a bar on top, they do not really have real coffee. It's a cheap B coffee shop. If you get an orange juice then you can relax without problems, but if you have in mind to go up there and drink a coffee, you'll be left disappointed. The mt. Fuji is visible, but super small. Nothing like those photoshopped post cards where Fuji San takes the whole background.
Public Service Headquarters . Quite an amazing piece of architecture housing some of the many publuc servants that make Tokyo tick. There is also a viewing platform

nice view to Tokyo!. Excellent place to explore the view. We went to the place with JR train. We took a long walk to get to the place and we almost gave up since we could not find the entrance of the (only) building that opens at night. But we made it znd did not disappoint.

Vacation/tourists. I kept seeing this building from my hotel. I finally walked over and saw a line. Without knowing the what the building was, I stayed in line to see what everyone was waiting for. The building was enormous, had art inside the building. Even had displays of inventions you could see and touch. Getting to the top floor where you could see all the city and shop for souvenirs. Me being a tourist, I loved it, everyone was friendly. I recommend checking it out. Great views.

360 degrees of Tokyo. We walked to the Metropolitan Government building from our hotel in Shinjuku. The views were great, but unfortunately, it was a cloudy day and we could not see Tokyo Bay or Mt. Fuji. The building is across the street from a nice park and a short walk from two metro stations in Shinjuku.

Free views of Tokyo!. The views from the observatory are fantastic. I had planned to pay to go up the Tokyo Skytree as well but decided there was no need. It is free to go up here and I can't imagine you would get much better pictures from the Skytree (plus you can see the Skytree from here, which is nice!). I went up both during the day and at night as we were staying nearby and views at both times were lovely.There is the obligatory gift shop and cafe/restaurant at the top.

Great views for free. I think the general perception out there is that Tokyo (or Japan) is an expensive place to have a good time. This is one of the few places that helps to dismantle that perception. You will have a good time here without paying a single yen. It is also a good thing that the building is not far from JR Shinjuku station and it will only take a 10-15 minute walk to get there.The North and South observation decks (on 45th floor) are all free to enter - all you need to do is to show up at the 1st floor lift landing and a guard will wave you through after checking your belongings. Once you're at the observatory, enjoy the free view of the Tokyo skyline - from the South Observatory you can see Yoyogi Park and even the Tokyo station district from afar! If you are lucky, on clearer days you would be able to see Mount Fuji. There is also a small cafe for drinks and a gift shop for souvenirs. The money you can save going here and not to the Tokyo Tower or Skytree can be spent on a nice meal. This is an excellent place for a view and a must-do in Tokyo. Highly recommended.

Endless views, free, easy access. Recommended.. If you're in Shinjuku, take a walk down to this building at check out the 360 views. We went first thing in the morning (I think it opens around 10am?) and there weren't any queues but there was a regular stream of people. The viewing area is huge so there's loads of room and photo opportunities. There's a great park just around the corner if you want to have a break afterwards. Souvenirs are available to purchase on the observation deck. Plus, the view is free!

Amazing free view across Tokyo!. We visited the Metropolitan Government building at night to get a view of the city. It is actually extremely difficult to find where to go (at least for us) because you need to go down some stairs to underneath the building to then get access up to the observation level. We wandered around the front at night and couldn't work it out, but took a chance at some dark stairs and eventually saw some other people and followed them. It is completely free and we went straight into an elevator as soon as we arrived. Mostly tourists at that time but not overly crowded. The room has windows on every side so you can see the entire city. The view was amazing at night and I would highly recommend. I cannot say what it is like during the day. Ultimately, it's free, centrally located in Shinjuku and you'll get some great photos!

Amazing view. This is a must, you have to do it, also because its free!! Amazing view and the building is lovely, from a very famous architect so try to learn something fromt he guide guys ;) because it is interesting.

Fantastic views and helpful volunteers. This building has an observation floor on the 45th level which is free to visit. The views during the daytime are impressive but it's also worth returning in the evening. Be aware that sometimes in the evening the observation deck can be quite full, somtpetimes with noisy groups. During the day we did not encounter this problem. We were approached by an English speaking volunteer on our first daytime visit. She was helpful in getting oriented in this vast, crowded city. She even gave us a gift of an origami crane as we left. All of this from a free attraction!

Coughing etiquette. There are view points in south building and north building. We went up to the north building. Entrance is on 1st floor, but looks like B1, and pathway was surrounded by repairing work areas. One elevator is used for free observors. On top floor, one side is blocked by cafe but you can see almost of Tokyo city and buildings and parks. Many people are coughing or sneezing without covering their mouth even inside of elevator. Especially Chinese and Koreans.
Great free plac to visit. Very easy to get to and considering it is free a great view of the city is available. We went at sunset and great shots

Great view of Tokyo and surrounds from the top. This place is a must to visit if you're in Tokyo. It free to enter and is open until 11pm. From level 45 (if i'm not mistaken), you get 360 degree view of Tokyo, even Mt Fuji on a clear day. Visit during the day and also at night to get different views.There are little kiosks/stands around the floor that sells souvenirs and toys. You can even get those copper souvenirs coins if you're into collecting these like me :)

Gorgeous views!!!. Amazing views from the 45th floor!! No need to spend your $$$ for the view from sky tree!! This is free! Both towers have observation decks. . Amazing views. . What a sight to see. On days when the smog isn't so heavy or weather isn't overcast you can see Mt.Fuji. . I'm so glad i made my way here! Beautiful!! beautiful!! Beautiful!!

fantastic free view of the city. This was a real find and I can highly recommend it! Free access to a view of all Tokyo including mount Fuji. Free and easy to get to, the gift shop is really good as well.
Impressive views. It's a prominent building with excellent and free of charge observatory. We got there for sunset and were awarded with majestic Mt Fuji silhouette. Well worth visiting.

beautiful modern design. beautiful modern design, with a network of underpasses connecting it with nearby buildings all the way down to Shinjuku Station. Best view you might get from the coffee shop up in nearby Park Hyatt

Great views for free!. With it's free admission, the Metropolitan Government Office is a no-brainer if you're in the neighbourhood. Within walking distance from the major Shinjuku hotels, both towers offer great views of the city. Seeing Mt. Fuji is possible, but only on very clear days!

Amazing views of Tokyo and completely free. About 200m high with a vast viewing gallery in each of two towers. Entrance in the main government building itself. On a clear day it's easy to see Mount Fuji.

Great city views for free!. From the subway exit, we were right outside the TMGO grounds. Took the South Observatory after waiting in line for about 15 minutes. It was a pretty clear day, but not clear enough to see Mt. Fuji. A nice attraction to add to your Tokyo itinerary.

Free and some nice views. It's free, the building has a very cool, gotham style look, so definitely admire the building before you enter it. Upstairs you have some very nice and free views because this building is located in an area with plenty of skyscrapers nearby. You can spot an ocean of tall buildings in the distance as well. Only downside is that there's no outside deck, so not brilliant for pictures. It was not superbusy when I went, all except one window were free. At the best one you had to wait for a minute or two. There's a gift shop and a cafe on top which isn't super expensive.

Overcast, but still great views. My family and I went to the Tokyo Metropolitan Building Observation deck in the North Tower early in the morning in hopes of seeing My. Fuji. It was overcast, so we were not able to see Mt. Fuji as anticipated.However, one is able to see most of Tokyo from the deck, as there are windows all around the deck and you can see for miles in any direction.We took the Oedo Line from Yoyogi to Tochomae Station, thereby skirting Shinjuku at rush hour. A short walk through the connection tunnel and up the stair into the Tokyo Metropolitan Building. You have to go through a security screening before boarding the elevator to the 45th Floor, but that is fast.Besides the view, there are two small gift stores and a coffee shop that serves good breakfast for reasonable cost. Since the observation deck is free, this is one of the best bargains in Tokyo. Go if you have time.
Free city views. Great views of the city, similar to Tokyo Tower, but this is free! It's a shame they block off 20% of the views with a restaurant.

Wonderful view of Tokyo for free !. The southern section is more interesting. I also appreciated the information at the observation deck so we could identify the buildings we were looking it. For those who are afraid of taking the lift up to the 45th floor, fear not ! The ride up is so smooth, you don't feel any discomfort and before you know it, you would have reached the observation deck.

Great views for free. As many of other locatios in Tokyo, you can go up the Tocho building towers for free. And you should, because it's one of the tallest buildings in the city, and sports a wonderful view of Fuji mountain on clear days. Besides, it's a rather privileged location, you will be able to identify many a landmark in Tokyo while up there.

Magnificent views. A lift to the 45th floor leads to a 360 panoramic view of Tokyo. Outstanding on a clear day when yo can see Mout Fuji but equally impressive when overcast. Need to check opening times.

Great panoramic views of Tokyo for free. You wouldn't expect it: you can take the lift all the way up to the visiting platform free of charge and get the chance of 360º superb views of Tokyo and surroundings. If weather permits, you can even see Mount Fuji. It is also great for sunsets and when I was there it was not crowded at all.
Great view and it's free!. We struggled to find this building and the first time we tried we actually went to the wrong place! We are glad we didn't give up as its a great view and it's free!

Great View. For a free trip to the top of this building is it well worth the visit. On a clear day you can see a fair distance and maybe even catch a glimpse of Mt Fugi! Greay views and it is nice that the panorama has labels for you to distinguish the buildings tou sre looking at. We also grabbed a bit to eat at the top, reasonably priced food with a good view! Would recommend.
Free observation deck. A nice view of Tokyo and best of all it's free! you have to walk a bit from shinjuku station.Love it.

Didn't see the hype. I had heard amazing things about the views from this building, but in comparison to tower in Toronto or Skygarden in London it was fairly average. It is free to go up and you just have to queue to get up and down.I think my experience was made a bit less special as the only thing up there is a tourist souvenir shop and loads of people. Tbf I may have been spoilt by previous similar experiences. But it could do with some modernisation.

Great view. I went here mainly because it had no admission fee. Apart from the big groups and the tight squeeze in the elevators then it is well worth the visit. There is a cafe at the top playing piano music and two small cute gift shops.If your looking for an usual souvenir there are a bank of gacha machines dispensing cute pins! I got 3! There are two Towers.

What a view!. Went to see the view at 4pm on a Monday. No wait. There are 2 towers-North and South. We went up the South Tower. Again, not many people. We easily had a view straight on without any people in front of us. FREE!

View of Tokyo city line for free. For those tourists who wants to have a view of Tokyo city line for free Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building is the place to go. There is a observation floor at the 45th floor of each of the twin towers. There is a 360 degree views of the city from these floors. Tocho-mae Station on the Oedo Subway line is located in the basement of these building. As these are government buildings you need to go through a metal detector and clearance checks of bags before you can take the lift to the observation floors.
Too low. You are only allow to the 4th floor. There is no outside observation deck. Not much to see. Save your time for other activity.
Observation of Tokyo. Great views of Tokyo and admission is free with no time limit. Best time to go up is just as sun is setting and it turns night time.

A free deck for tourist to visit also location of tourist information center inShinjuku.. A panorama deck for sight seeing around Tokyo and far off the nearby area in the clear sky day, including Fuji Mt..
Best free sunset view in Tokyo. Dont miss the view from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. The viewing level offers a great view and a variety of quintessentially cool Japanese products.

A free high level view. Easy enough to find, and a great view (especially at night) of Tokyo. The building is nowhere near as tall as the Skytree, but a visit is free so if you are cash strapped then try this one first.

A Bird Eye View over Tokyo City. What I liked about Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office:1) Free entrance to Observatory 2) Visitors can have bird eye view on Tokyo city as long as they want3) Guide can be requested to give an overview or interesting aspects about the cityWhat I disliked about Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office:1) Physical information boards - it seems lacking when it comes to history or origination of components of Tokyo city (though guides are provided FOC)

Totally worth the price of admission. Great views, the lines weren't too bad on a weekend morning for us. My 6 y/o got a total kick out of seeing the Tokyo cityscape from that high up! Also - access from the subway was pretty easy
free spot to enjoy Tokyo city view. You can enjoy a great view of Tokyo city full of lights, including Tokyo Sky Tree, Tokyo Tower, etc.

Wonderful view of Tokyo for free ... but your feet will beg for mercy in the mean time!. My wife and I may have taken an absurdly long route, which maybe is our fault, but as you know ... Tokyo is quite a complicated, overwhelming city so it's quite easy to follow directions not knowing you're taking the long way. With that said, if you DONT go underground and walk in the walkway underground, you will be about 1000 steps less than you would if you had just walked above ground. Trust me - you will thank me for this advice later.Now! The top of the building is very nice. I personally love skydecks, watching the city and etc. However, I will say, it's more a tourist attraction than anything since it's free (and Tokyo is incredibly expensive) and the views aren't so spectacular, while they have shoved every possible item for sale, or restaurant upstairs just so you have something to spend your money on.Again, I'm not saying I disliked it - especially if you have a day with bad weather, this could be almost the perfect attraction. However, it's not going to give you views of anything you're expecting and unless you have money or a really nice camera - expect it to be rather an in-and-out experience.

good view, free guide,. Very nice place to see Tokyo from the top of a building. And it's free!A volunteer guide welcomed us and proposed us to tell about Tokyo. For sure, it's a place to visit in Tokyo.

Good view of the area and is free. You can go up to the observation deck of the municipal building and have a bird eye view of Tokyo. It is free and open till early evening so you can have a night view of the city.

THE VIEW MAY BE GREAT, BUT WHAT IS TRULY STUNNING IS KENZO TENGE'S ARCHITECTURE. My wife and I visited on a rainy, foggy day - which did detract from the view from the 45th floor observation level - but did nothing to detract from how impressive this imperious building appears from the ground.

Great "free" attraction in Tokyo. One of the few free attractions in Tokyo. Be sure to go if you are in the area. The only comment is the night view isn't as great as they have so many lights on in the observatory - making it tricky to get good photos. But definitely worth a stop, day or night.

Stunning building ( we took 40 photos) and the view from the top floor.... Walking all around this huge building complex is like being on the set of some science fiction movie of the future. You half expect a rocket ship or hover taxi to cruise by. But let's face it you are really here to go up to the 45 th floor for the stunning views on all sides of the city. And it is great.

make sure you go to the observation deck. This is one of the best free activities to do. The 55 second trip to the observation deck helps to create a sense of awe and anticipation. One gets to see the sprawling size of Tokyo - it is truly a modern metropolis. On a clear day you can even see Mt fuji.
Awesome Views. The observation tower is a must stop in my book. Only there did I grasp the expanse of Tokyo. City as far as the eye can see, in every direction, it's truly awe inspiring.

Great view from Tokyo skyscraper for free to go in!. you can go up to the top observation floor for free! And many Tokyo souvenir you can buy there,too. Also free Maps of Tokyo or tour guide will,be there,too.Down to the 15th floor, there is a huge cafeteria/self style restaurant for civil worker working that building, but still visitors can use. Very very reasonable price. Ramen is my recommendation.

Free attraction in Shinjuku, Tokyo. Must for everyone in Tokyo and it's completely free too! Amazing 360 degree views over Tokyo! There's restaurant on the top of the building and some cute souvenir shops aswell!
A Must See in Shinjuku. Beautiful view of the surrounding community! It's a bit of a walk to get there from Shinjuku station, but well worth it. -- Plus IT's FREE!

The most impressive town hall. This is the town hall of Tokyo and is even featured in animes it is so famous. It is free to go to the top deck, which is an observatory with a restaurant and gift shop. Go in the day if you want to take pictures otherwise you will get too much of a reflection in the glass.

Great view of Tokyo. This was a great place to visit with children. We stopped at the information centre on the way into the building and was greeted by a volunteer English speaking guide. She took us around the building on a 30min free tour. The tour ended at the observation deck where we were able to take amazing photos of Tokyo. A must do if you're in the area and the guided tour made it all the more interesting.
Great views at night . Probably during the day as well. This place is next door to the Keio Plaza Hotel and is well worth visiting from there.

A must go when in Tokyo!. We didn't plan on many events while in Japan that gave us great views, which was a mistake on our part. But we did make it to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building North Observatory and it was well worth it.I believe the south observatory was closed due to it being Silver week, a banking holiday in Japan.We got up the elevator just in time to catch the last glimpses of light in the sky, and I highly recommend going to sunset!This was free to us, and they have a cute gift shop, and lots of coin turn machines for little goodies. And if you're hungry there is a restaurant as well.You must go here if you're in Tokyo!
Love this place. Free of charge, great view on whole Shinjuku and nearby park, its like 15minutes walk from JR Shinjuku station. If visiting Shinjuku (or Tokyo) u must see this attraction

A very kind and helpful staff at the Tourist Office. We have come here to seek help from the tourist office. They were extremly nice and helpful, so if you are in the are I strongly reccomend to visit this place. Assistants with proper english, and a willingness to organize things for you via telephone. Apart from this, the building is huge, and if you want to look around Tokyo, then this may be your destination to visit.

Tokyo city skyline. Enjoying city skyline of Tokyo for free. Great view. Also get a chance to buy some gifts for friends as there was lot of famous food from different region selling at the same floor.

Worth the effort for the view. Beautiful 360 degree view of the area from way up in a very high building, pleasant walk and helpful guidance from locals to get to the Metro building, easy train ride back to Shinjuku. No charge and pleasant staff around to assist.

BEST Free View in Town!!!. 360 degrees from two different vantage points, north and south. The 45th floor of this building has floor to ceiling windows and written guides in English and Japanese to tell you what you're looking at. On a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji. On even a rainy day the views are stupendous. Also a very good gift shop for souvenirs.

It's free.. It's free. It offers the best view. I went on Friday around 10am, not crowded. Easy breezy. There was a Japanese food fare and there was a staff wearing a badge stating "I speak English". On ground floor there is a tourist promotion board "shop" where you can pick up a card bearing free wifi password to use on any area with free wifi hotspot. Useable for 2 weeks (I could be wrong)

go there. It had been raining and cloudy but still worth the visit. Not far from Shinjuku Station. From there you can visit a number of other places.Took us a while to get our head around the station and unground shopping.

Great views for free. Building very close to Hilton Hotel. Free entry to 360 degrees views of Tokyo from a long way up. A clear day is essential. Good souvenir shop on the viewing level and on the ground floor.
Freeview. As there's not much for free in Tokyo this is a must and the views are pretty good too. Go at dusk and see the city with the lights on.

Tokyo Metropolitan Government a Office. If you are near Shinjuku, well worth a visit to both the towers, which is free of charge. Great views of Toyko. Nothing much else up there (there is a cafe) but if there is a event, such as an expo of local produce ( bottled, canned etc) then you can come away with some interesting things.
Nice views from Tokyo!. Nice views from Tokyo and for free! Upstairs you can buy souvenirs at good prices! Recommended during sunset time! Beware of the queue (around 15 minutes) to go upstairs.

best view in town and for free. i was staying at the hilton hotel close by and was on arun when i saw that opportunity to get on top of the metropolitan building. took that chance and loved it. you are close to high buildings, but can also look at shinjuku park from the top. rare thing in tokyo, its absolutely for free. but not open on sundays.

Free view, but less impressive than other Tokyo locations. While the panoramic view is free, the indoor view with inside lighting makes the view less than prefect. Paying for views at Roppongi or Tokyo Tower worth it instead.
Great views!. If you don't want to pay to go up Sky Tree or Tokyo Tower, then go up to the top of this building for free.

Should be on your list of places to visit in Tokyo. Free! and right across from the Keio plaza hotel. There's a cafe and gift shop at the observation floor which offers up some fantastic views of Tokyo. I recommend it!

Great views for free.. It seems that all the high rise buildings in Tokyo have an entrance fee for their viewing platforms, except for this one. We did not have to wait at all to get to the viewing floor and from there we could see a bit of Tokyo. Tokyo is huge so if you are not there on a clear day dont expect to see all the highrise landmarks from any viewing point. When we got there there was also a market with products from all over japan that you could buy and try. Overall on of the best spots if you are on a budget.
Best free view of Tokyo. Great view, and free! If you're willing to pay, then go to the Sky Tree instead though (much taller).

Nice view over the city. You can enter the building and take the elevator to the 45th floor. You can walk the whole floor and you have a lot of windows from where you can enjoy the view over the city. There is also a souvenir shop in the middle of the floor. One part is shield of by a restaurant and you can only enter if you order a meal here.

Great view. I was fortunate to visit this place when it wasn't too crowded. The people managing the lines and the elevator were efficient and polite. I didn't eat at the restaurant but the menu looked very reasonable. There is also a gift shop full of fun kitsch gifts. Best of all it is free.The Shinjuku Gyoen National Park is very close by if you feel like a peaceful stroll after the view.
View of tokyo. The building is beautiful and you get a panoramic view of Tokyo but disappointing was that I could see Mt Fuji . The queue going down was quite long . A bit of a let down for me

Free view of Tokyo. Try to go there early in the morning as it can get very crowdy but the staff is very efficient also for Japanese standard. It is free, so definetely recommended. AFterwards you can eat at the food court downstairs.

The best views for Tokyo for free!. The exterior is impressive if somewhat draconian looking (if Darth Vader did architecture...) but the real reason to visit is the free viewing floor in the 42nd floor. Great panoramic views all around Tokyo, and better in my opinion than Sky Tree because you're much closer to the centre of town, on a good day you can just about see Fuji. Also, the cafe is surprisingly cheap considering the views and location... you can't complain for 1,000 yen for coffee and cake whilst enjoying the views.

Good city viewing without a hefty price tag.. Good viewing platforms (200meters up) for free. If looking at big cities from above is important, this is definitely a good option. (Skytree gets you to 350m, but for a price.) Watch for the queues, but we only needed to wait 1/2 hour and it moved pretty smoothly. A much more pleasant experience than trying to get into Skytree.

Excellent because it's free and amazing. Before going up the building, we chose to admire the building itself from the ground level.We got very good pics of it.It was around 6pm when we got to ride the lift to the top. There was a crowd at the elevator area but the guards and guides managed it very well.Large windows afford anyone with great views of many structures in Tokyo. It was cloudy so we were not fortunate enough to see Mt. Fuji.40mins to 1 hour here may be good enough. Stay a bit longer if you have the time to get more detailed glimpses of the surrounding areas.

One fo the best and Free observatories in Tokyo. Come here an hour before sunset and you'll be treated to a wondrous view of tokyo as the day turns to night. If you're lucky, you might be able to see the silhouette of Mt Fuji. Lots of tourists local and foreign- a lot of Chinese take note. There are shops at the center area and a vending machine at one spot. Toilets are located at a floor below. Besides the Observatory, try out their cheap lunches at Tocho. Filling and the staff are very courteous. They helped us order in the ticket machine as we didn't know a character in Japanese. Great place to chill out even if the resto floor looks sterile.The tourism booth is very helpful and a lot of reading material are there for the taking. There's a souvenir shop too.MUST GO!

Crowds. The first time when we came here I was amazed at the sight. This time was our third time up and I found this less attractive. Yes, it is free but to me it's just too noisy, touristy and crowded. I like the Seaside Top at the World Trade Center much better for the views and the atmosphere. This one is convenient if you are in the Shinjuku area though. Worth going up if the line is not too long.

Wonderful views of Tokyo and free!. Visited here on a Saturday afternoon. The queue to go up to the 45th floor was long but staff managed the lines efficiently and we didn't have to wait long at all. The 360 degree views at the top are wonderful. There is a cafe on this floor where we had their Japanese version of high tea, while sitting at the window and taking in the view. PS Toilets on the ground floor are easy to find and were very clean ( but no paper towel vendor or hand dryer)

Great views over Tokyo. Ride the lift to the top of the government office building for great views over Tokyo. A friendly guide offered to show us the highlights (no cost), but there are plaques below most windows identifying the main sights if you prefer to go DIY. On a clear day you can see Mount Fuji, but go in winter to improve your chances: the weather's too hazy on 300 days per year.

Large view of Tokyo!. If you want to see the expanse of Tokyo, visit this place! The 45th floor view makes everything else look small. It's a beautiful building with designated observation deck lines and elevators. We visited around 9:30 AM -- about the time they were opening. The line was short and the elevator up was quick. Your bags will be checked by a security agent but that doesn't slow things down much. There is a nice bar/restaurant area and gift shop so you may want to spend a little time up there. It's definitely worth a visit!

Amazing view. Who doesn't like free things?! Why pay thousands of yen for the other towers in Tokyo? This one is just 45 stories up but still gives you a great perspective of the city. Fully recommended by me!

Best FREE view of Tokyo!. The Tokyo Metropolitan Gobernment (TMG) Office was next door to our hotel so we couldn't possibly miss it, especially when my hotel concierge told me that there iwas no need to book tickets as it iwas free! We arrived at around 6pm to get a sunset view.You have to queue for the lift to the Observation deck. When we went the queue was relatively short so we didn't have to wait long. The people who worked there were efficient, friendly and courteous. The Observation deck was great. We walked right round, and at different windows there is a big photo telling you names of buildings and districts. I am pretty sure on a good day you can see Mt Fuji. It had been raining and was actually raining whilst we were at the deck so it made the view a bit foggy. Having said that it was great to take photos of Tokyo on a rainy day! Gave it a different perspective. On the same floor are many souvenir stalls and vending machines.I recommend TMG highly to any visitor to Tokyo, especially if you are a first time visitor. I found it very hassle-free, calm and peaceful. Perhaps the rain had put off many visitors but for us it was a plus! Remember that it is a working office building for many of TMG's workers and not just a tourist attraction. It is very convenient to get it, being on top of Tochomae metro station.

Free air view lounge. In Shinjuku there are some skyscrapers.If you are thinking of going up to the top of one of them, then Tokyo municipal building is my recommendation. There is a lounge and it is open to the public. On a sunny day you can enjoy a beautiful Mt.Fuji !On the 2nd F information center w/lots of brochures.
Great free view of Tokyo. Great views when clear and the funniest tackiest souvenirs you will ever see! Guards are friendly and popular with locals and OS travellers

"Great View of the City for Free". We got there early and there were no lines at the elevators. Went straight up and the views were beautiful. All free! There is a restaurant at the viewing area, but we did not try it. Didn't look like much. But I guess, I cannot say as we did not try it. You can buy souvenirs also if you like. Over all, glad we did it. And would recommend if you are visiting the area.

Great view and restaurant nice also. Went up at dusk and the view was simply stunning. I was surprised at how quiet it was given how busy my experience of other viewing platforms in other cities has been. I went to the Skytree on a previous Tokyo visit. Whilst this isn't as high you are more in the centre of Tokyo so feel 'closer to the action'. Also I recommend the restaurant - nothing sensational but it is good value for money especially as admission is free.
Fantastic view from the North Tower at night. The North Tower Observatory opens till 10:30pm and there is a restaurant in the obervation deck. However, the entrance is difficult to find.

Free Views!. The best part is the free entry to the observation floor where you get a good birds eye view of Tokyo. A lot cheaper than lining up and paying at Sky Tree or Tokyo Tower. A good place for first time visitors to Tokyo, to see how big the city is.
Average view. The view from the Tower 1 was just average, nothing amazing or spectacular. Something you can passed if you are short of time in Tokyo.

Free observation deck, well worth the visit!. This building has a fantastic view from the top towers (north and south) and it is free! There is a restaurant at the top. The observation decks are opened till late in the evening.

It's free, it is astonishing --> don't miss it. What else would you like to get than a free 360 degree's view over Tokyo! I went several times up whilst being 3 days in Tokyo and I never had to wait at all.

Free view of Tokyo. Get in line if there is one and you get a free ride to the top of this building and get to see a panoramic view 360 degrees! Either day or night is good. Go on a clear day and you might see Mount Fuji.
its a breeze

Great cost-benefit compared to other observation decks.. The Government office building is a great place to visit. The building is monstrous. There are other skyscrapers famous for a very high view of the city, but the Metropolitan building does not fall behind. You get the same type of view you would get from the Tokyo tower or the Skytree (grant that those are higher, but everything looks tiny anyway from 200 Meters and higher). Best thing of all... It was free.
Great view and free. What else needs to be said, you get an amazing view of all of tokyo and sometimes can see Mount Fuji for free would highly recommend it for any and everyone
Free view of Tokyo. One from the best views of town(from 45F) and it's free, in Sinzuku perfecture.In the 45 floor also is a cafe-restaurant

Mount Fuji Views! And its Free!. Take the Free ride up the elevator after and orderly queue to the observatory where u can have breathtaking views of Tokyo and Mount Fuji on a clear day! No admission charge. It was at least a 15min walk from Shinjuku station, passing the Keio Plaza Hotel (see my other review of the hotel). It could be longer if you are distracted by Standing sushi bar and Yodobashi along the way :) Worth the trip if you are in the area.

Amazing views and open till late. When we came to the observatory it was quite late, the skies were dark and you could see the city and all the lights. It was definitely worth coming here! It's a really nice place to stop, with lots of little shops and 360 degree views of the city. Access to the observatory is free of charge, and like anywhere else in Japan, the workers are extremely friendly and make you feel welcome. The toilets are clean and there are facilities to get a drink and have a sit down.

Free view of the city - must-visit. Worthwhile to visit since it is free and gives you a great view of the sights surrounding it. Visit both towers for a different view if you have the time. Try non-peak periods so that there is a shorter queue heading up via the lift.
Beautiful views.. Excellent place to view Tokyo from their observation decks. Best thing about it: it's FREE! They have english signs to direct you where to go. Go early to avoid the large crowd.
Free view from above. If you have some time in Tokyo Shinjuku, pay this place a visit. It's free! A little gift shop can be found up top and you can also go into the cafe for more view of Tokyo.

Beautiful views of the entire city.. Goes up roughly 45 floors. The view is so great that you can even see Mt. Fuji from the top. You have the choice of the north or the south towers. Cool little gift shops are on the observation floors as well.

Great views of the city!!!!. The metropolitian is one of many buildings offering a view from a height..the attraction is free and the views are good..but the skytree or tokyo tower offer a better view. The building is located in an area full of skyscrapers, which is an attaction in itself. Worth a visit!!
Fantastic view. Excellent place to take photos especially at night. The views are superb and you get a good feeling for just how large Tokyo is.

Well worth the effort. Great place to see over Tokyo in most directions from the 45th floor both day and night. Good part is that it is free. Only about 10 minute pleasant walk from Shinjuku station through skyscrapers of some of Japans major companies.

Great free view from a height. Twin towers have observation floors on 45th level. Great view over surrounding Shinjuku and all the way to the horizon in every direction. Terrific way to start a Japanese trip if you're staying in Shinjuku, as it will give you a good sense of perspective.Each tower has two lifts, and both towers not always open together. You can't get directly between towers, but not really necessary to go up both. Generally a queue to get up and down again, but rarely a long queue. Your bags will be searched by security before entering the lift.The views are described a little so you know what features of the urban agglomeration of greater Tokyo you are seeing. On a clear day, you can see Fuji san (Mt Fuji) well, but this is pretty rare. Both levels have souvenir shops and a little exhibition space, while one has a coffee shop.At the bottom of the building, there is an excellent Tokyo visitor centre. Perhaps the best spot in Tokyo to get maps and tourist advice. Different areas of Tokyo displayed well and very helpful staff who have an encyclopaedic collection of information available on request.

Worth visiting. There is an excellent view across Tokyo from the roof of this building and it's free. The gift shops have a lot of variety and we purchased quite a few bits and pieces.It is well signposted and easy to get around with an organised and efficient lift service
Great view. Great building with free views from 2 towers. Cafe on top to spend some time. All staff are friendly and place clean

Great views and it is Free. We stayed at the Citadines Shinjuku, so this was a short metro hop away. I would recommend getting off at Nishi Shinjuku if you are on the Marounuchi line instead of Shinjuku station. Try to avoid Shinjuku if you can. It is a short walk to the complex. There is construction on the ground level, so you have to hunt for the entrance. Look for big arrows. There is a security check as you go in, and an attendant loads you onto the elevator. The views from the 45th floor are spectacular, The is a restaurant and a toy shop on he floor. Like other buildings and train stations, they have turned the A/C down to save energy. So it is hot inside. On the way out, we saw some art exhibits. Try to find he brochure, and it will tell you where they are. This is late August 2015, I don't know how long the art exhibits are. The best one was the interactive exhibit under the Keio Plaza hotel. You get to it from he outside of the hotel, not inside. It is a underground plazanade that links one side to the other.This area of town is also relatively quiet at night compared to right next to Shinjuku station. You see plenty to salarymen getting off work at 9 - 10PM, With less crowds, you can enjoy the architecture of the buildings. Try to find the cocoon building, a futuristic building with external lattice metal beams.The free view was great, along with the nice stroll back to the metro.

Tokyo in HD. Nice, free place to get an overview of central Tokyo. Direct access by foot from Shinkuju Station. We were up there when the weather was a bit foggy, but even though, the view was breathtaking.

Free Panoramic City View. It's definitely worth taking the free trip up either tower to get a view of the entire Tokyo Skyline. You can go in either building and there is food available for sale at the top (along with plenty of large windows to check out the view). Make sure you read the interesting info about the architecture too. It has a very unique structural support frame.

Visit because it's free and the building looks great. The government office was wonderful to see, can't believe it looked so nice up close. The observatory itself was just okay for me, and I didn't get to see much because there was a restaurant blocking 1 side. There's also a few stores there, which looks old already.
Love it. Great view and it is free. We did have a great time but had to speed up our visit because we had other things planned for the day. All and all, it is a place that you don't need to miss.
Great and free view.. It was raining and foggy when we came to Tokyo and we didn't want to go to the sky tree for nothing. Here is a great option for a free view, no matter the weather.
One of the nicest views of Tokyo. Its almost 360, and being in the middle of Shinjuku you get a pretty interesting closeup of the other buildings. Went there for sunset, wasn't deceived

Free and worth a visit. Went there on a weekday night, at approximately 10:00PM. The visitor elevators operates from 9:30am to 11:00pm. There was no waiting/line to get in. The views are splendid indeed, however the best part of the view is blocked and is exclusive the the restaurant patrons. Wish this was more of sit down bar, rather than a restaurant (they restaurant even levies a surcharge for the later part of the night).
free treat. it was treat to see the city from the 45th level. there was a little queue but ok. recommended for a short visit.
Incredible view. Very exciting view from the platform. Easy access with high speed elevators. Very safe. Merchandising on Platform Lack of Style.

If you can find your way in you get a great vieq. There is construction at ground level making navigation tricky but don't let that out you off. I went on a cloudy and humid day and apart from not seeing Mount Fuji I got a great view. Recommended as it is free too

Public view. Excellent top point to view Tokyo surrounding for free. Well organized. Quick to the top. You could go up to both towers to view both sides of Tokyo. Not so many visitors. No long queue as many other towers. Highly recommended.
Free view. Well organised, a lovely view of the city from the top. It's free and is not difficult to get to. A cafe and some shops on the 45th floor.
Wonderful FREE view. Wonderful FREE view from 45. Level. Visited both north and south tower night and day. Fantastic view. Only little queue.
Highly recommended. Very impressive views from the 45th floor! And free! Definitely recommended. Don't plan on spending a great deal of time here, but it is certainly worth making a trip to.
Nice view. Pretty good view of Tokyo (that's free) and neat architecture. Lots of moving sidewalks to get back to the train station.
