Unfortunately I was not the lucky one as was cloudy with some mist still I had some stunning views of Tokyo from 202-meter high observation decks, located on the 45th floor accompanied by explanation from the guide.To get there it is 5 minutes walk from Nishi-Shinjuku station on M line (Marunouchi line) and swift lift rideNorth Observatory: 9:30 to 23:00 South Observatory: 9:30 to 17:30 (until 23:00 when North Observatory is closed).

What a View. A short walk from the subway makes it easy to get to. It's free (though you'd never know it from the assistance given when entering) and there's an incredible view over Tokyo. What's not to like?

Great panoramic city view for free. The massive building is an awesome sight to see by itself. Going up to the 45th floor offers a great panoramic city view, for free! It also had some shops where one could buy some souvenirs and a coffee shop for a bite to eat or drink. The viewdeck closes by 10pm.

City viewing. Love the view from the 45th floor of the Metropolitan building! I recommend you to go there as it is free, but you might need to queue to go to the 45th floor. But then even the queue is long, it didn't take too long to wait. Go on & enjoy the beautiful view from the skyscraper!

Free view from the 45th floor. Really easy to walk to from Shinjuku station, and you can go up to the 45th floor for FREE. It's got to be one of the best deals in Tokyo, and will give you an idea of the immense scale of the city. I think they're open late too, so you can see the lights of the city.

Gives some perspective to shear size of Tokyo. A free attraction in a modern iconic building of Shinjuku
Expect to queue at lifts but it is well organised & the views are spectacular

worth a visit. We went up both towers. Good views of the city. Staff helpful and efficient.
Good tourist information veneration the building

Free access to 45 floor with good view. No waiting during week day to access lift. Pleasant & free service by government staff. Beside the view, there are a cafeteria on south tower and a restaurant on north tower with reasonable price. There were good souvenir shops on both towers

Bit of a trek but great views. Took a while to get here following the underground tunnels which were rather straight forward with nothing interesting to see. Staff on the ground floor were friendly in directing us to the right place. The views were great with detailed signs about different landmarks. Also an excellent little restuarant/cafe and souvenior shop at the top. We opted not to go to Tokyo Skytree after this.

Helps to understand Tokyo. It is a free and easy way to understand Tokyo. There may be a long que but it is quick, don't worry. At the deck where you will be directly taken by the elevator, there is a restaurant but most of the windows are outside the restaurant so you can easily and freely look around. For the toilets, you will need to walk one floor down. So, if it is difficult to use stairs, it may be better do it in advance.

Wonderful view and FREE. We arrived in Shinjuku early on Sunday and rode to the top of the Metropolitan Office (to the 45th floor) where you can walk all around and look out over all of Tokyo. If you are feeling tired or hungry, try the brunch cafe that is on that floor for a small snack. I had traditional pancakes with a latte and my son had a quiche and some tea. It was lovely to sit and admire Tokyo from the top of the building. Entry to the tower is free and as we went early, there were few crowds and no lines.
Free view of Tokyo. Free access to the North or South observation decks. Nice view. It was somewhat cloudy on the day we went. Nice perspective of the City from here. You can't beat free.
Beautiful & Free. Go to the top of the Metropolitan Government building for free and see an awesome view of Tokyo. Definitely worth a visit. You'll no doubt be in the area at some point anyway.

great tour, free viewing platform, excellent views of Shinjuku. The free tours are really interesting and you get to go to lots of parts of the building. The viewing platform is open early and late and offers the most western platform to see Fuji by and its free. It sometimes closes for high winds, but very safe and normally open. You get to the top by the elevators in the main lobby, there is a bag check, no tickets required.

Amazing views. My partner and I visited the Metropolitan Government Office observatory in Autumn 2014. The views are stunning! It was free to enter and was very easy to get to. It is definitely worth visiting if you are in the Shinjuku area.

Nice view of Tokyo. Going up the observatory is free. So if you are in the Shinjuku area, try to go here to see the Tokyo view. However if you are not visiting the area, might as well skip it or best to go at night to see the lights.

Why not? It's free.... I stayed for two nights at Keio Plaza Hotel and this building was just next to it. People told me it's free to go up to the observatory deck to view the whole of Tokyo and it's best to go at night. So I did, it was amazing even though it was hazy that night. The lift ride up the tower was fast and stable. There's also a restaurant on that floor that you can dine in and enjoy the view while sipping some wine.

Great free high altitude viewing place. This building isn't as tall as the Tokyo Tower, but you get an outstanding view of the Tokyo Tower and the rest of downtown Tokyo. There are two towers in the building, both with viewing areas on the 48th floor. We went up the south tower because our guide said it was better than the north tower. When we got up, we could see why. Our tower was obstructing the best views of the city. We could see so much. Plus there is no charge for visiting it. A win win for sure!

Amazing views of Tokyo and it's free. This is one of the first places we visited when we arrived at Tokyo.It's a bit of a walk from Shinjuku Station, but it was nice to stretch our legs for a bit. We bought snacks from the station and had a bit of a sitdown halfway along before arriving at the Tokyo Gov building.We were lucky as it wasn't busy when we arrived - as we were leaving though the line for entry was going out the building and around the corner!! It's a very popular location and for good reason - the views are fantastic.You can get almost 360 degree views of Tokyo - there's part of the floor which is set aside for the restaurant, but that doesn't matter as the views are amazing anyway. There's free water taps and some seats to sit down on as well. There are souvenirs to buy, but you'll see the same ones throughout most of the places you'll visit in Tokyo anyway.Go for the views, you won't regret it.

A free 45th floor observation deck. If you follow the signs from Shinjuju station you can walk through underground passageways for about one kilometre to reach this building. You can then take a free lift to the free observation deck and look out over a large part of Tokyo. Well worth a visit on a clear day, and you can also see Mount Fuji if the weather is clear enough.

Great views. Great free sightseeing option for visitors. 45 floors up with exceptional views as far as the eye can see! You can even see Mt Fuji!Both towers are very similar, so just recommend you do one - I preferred the North Tower, however there is a cafe which blocks some of the view (you have to buy something which we did ¥700 for a drink and cake so not bad and tasted pretty good.) The South Tower also had a cafe but it was in the middle so none of the view was obstructed.Overall, recommend visiting!

Great view of Tokyo. It's a free attraction and the queue was not so bad, about 15 minutes or so, that's a plus. The view itself was great, I visited at night and the sky was clear, so I could see lights of Tokyo at night, you can even see tokyo tower. The negative is that when at night you can't take a great picture because of the glare from the glass. For a free attraction though, definitely worth the visit an enjoy the view.
Okay. This was okay, it took a lot longer than it should've and after having a peek out the window at a few grey buildings I was done. I liked the gift shop.
Great view. Awesome view from the top and it's free - what's not to like! We visited around 5.30pm and didn't have to queue. Would love to go back and see the view at night one day.

Nice Alternative to Tokyo Tower. First thing first, this is a free attraction. There is a North Tower and a South Tower but we only went to one. The view was fantastic. You get a 360 degree of Tokyo and on a good day, can probably see Mt Fuji as well (we didn't - too hazy!) There is also a cafe where you can get a coffee and sweets. Price is on the high side but I felt that I should support it since we saved so much on entrance fee...

Great, free views and cheap Wagyu beef. A must-do if visiting Tokyo, to experience the FREE views of Tokyo from the penultimate floor (as far as Mount Fuji on a clear day, apparently, though it rarely is a clear day!). Note though that as it is free there can be long-ish queues, although we queued on a Saturday evening and got through within half an hour, which I don't think is bad. We also went midweek during the day and there was no queue.Perhaps the best thing about it is the restaurant, not only for the views but the inexpensive Wagyu beef dish on the menu. From memory the dish is about 1400 Yen at lunchtime, we went in the evening so it was around double that price, which is still good value for an upmarket restaurant dish!
Long queues but worth the wait.. Ignore the tourist tat at the top and enjoy the views. Mt Fuji if the skies are clear. There's 2 towers, same views from both.

Amazing, free, view.. Excellent view on a clear day. A quick security bag check is carried out, before entering the lift. Be patient, there can be queues for the lift going up and down. Best of all its free.

best FREE view in the city!. after reading about the high cost and busy nature of the "tokyo tree" we discovered you could get a great view of the city for free from this building. even though it was a foggy night, it was still a great view and memorable for the last night. Its open until 11pm, we got there at 10pm and were one of 6 people. Also in the area is the Hyatt , where "lost in translation" was filmed..you can visit the bar from the movie but it has a strict dress code...no crocs allowed..
Top of building view is nice. The view from the top of this building is nice, but not much photo opportunity because of the glass windows. But then going into the building is free!
It's Free but go on a Clear Day!. Free! which is nice in Tokyo. Sweeping views that are best on a clear day - especially if you can see Fuji.

The great thing is it is free!. We went up to the 45th floor of both the North and South towers. Apparently on a clear day you can see all the way to Mt Fuji, but not the day that we went. It was sunny, but the smog was pretty bad. I imagine that at night or when it is clear it would be spectacular.

cozy great view FREEEEE. I came here because i was freezing cold in shinjuku and lost on the office side haha it was my first day alone wandering tokyo so. I just remembered it was free, googlemapped it and went. Because it's free you value it much more; the view is from floor 40 or 50 and you can see pretty much all tokyo because it's kind of center. Tokyo tower and sky tree and yoyogi park and meiji shrine… And the place where the viewing platform is is very warm and cozy. I went for sunset (just for luck) and I strongly recommend it!! It is an amazing sunset. I'll attach the picture so you believe me hehe good luck! Also if you go to Tokyo tower & sky tree, and still have time to come here, do it. (I did 3 of them! worth it!!!)

They say its the best daytime view across Tokyo. It was a very clear day when we went so you could see Tokyo in its fullest....It goes forever!!! Gives you a great perspective. I recommend that you go on your first day in Tokyo- gives you and idea of the geography and the enormity of the place

Great views of Tokyo for Free. A short walk from Shinjuku station is the Metropolitan Government Office which offers free entry and views from the 45 floor. Just a short queue and a lift to the observation floor. 360 degree views of the city, with helpful staff on hand to give information. Small cafe and shop are available. Unfortunately it was too misty to see Mount Fuji but on a very clear day I am told you can get great views of Fuji from up here.Worth a visit.
How could it be less. its free great staff great views easy access no more left to say really a great experience worth thirty minutes of your time.

Simply a must do. Great views at an unbeatable price (for free). View of all of Tokyo and mount fuji on a clear day.
It will only take you about 15-20 minutes.

Amazing view of Tokyo skyline. Walked here from Shinjuku station. Arrived around 7 pm. There was already a line but it was manageable. The view of Tokyo skyline at night was amazing. There is a cafe and souvenir shop on the viewing deck.

Amazing sunset view!. Although it took us a bit to find this building, it was well worth it. We did see the only homeless people we saw in all of Tokyo near the base of this building. However, the views and the fact that it is free make this a must see activity. I would recommend going a bit before sunset so you can see the almost 360 degree (maybe 280?) views during the daylight and then at night as well. They are absolutely breathtaking. I still haven't decided if I like the sunset views or the nighttime views better. There is also a restaurant at the top where you can eat or grab a bite, but it is definitely overpriced. There is also a small gift shop at the top. Be aware that the lines to get back down are often quite long.
Great View. Great place to go on a clear day and see a view of Tokyo. I'd recommend going early on for short lines!
View from the top.. for free. Checked both North and South tower, since it's short queue. Nice view of Tokyo. Interesting statues at the office plaza
Brilliant View. Free panoramic view, great location. Gift shop is good and food available, however did not try the cafe or restaurant.

Best Free views. Situated in Shinjuku, it offers the best free view of Tokyo.Recommended to visit in night. Observatory is situated at 45th floor of a government office. The glass windows could have been better, reflects light & unfortunately there is a souvenir shop which blocks the best view. On the whole worth a trip for its free night view.

Great Views, for eyes only. This is in the business district and next to the main hotel chains such as Hilton and Hyat. The building is free to enter which is a bonus and there are 2 observation decks. The North is open from 9.30 - 23.00 and the south is open 9.30 - 17.30. We went at night and the views were good but the bright lights inside the building makes it hard to get any good photos. We went to the north deck and there was a restaurant and a small gift area. Overall its a good place to go and free with good views of the city. Nearest station is Shinjuku.

Free view of the city . Great way to see the city for free. Be aware there's two towers, which means the view is "blocked" on one side, so you'll have to go up both of the, if you want to see it all. I would recommend the south tower if you're only doing one, as you will see most of the important sights from there.
Great view. Its a huge building and in the heart of the business district so you should definitely check it out! , the main USP - its FREE , and the view is great !

Free top view of Tokyo. We went to the North Tower in the evening. There was a baggage check given it is a working govt building but the staff members were very courteous. The tower is around 100m high and the view from there was very good. We could not see very far though since there was a cloud cover; presumably one can see Mt Fuji on a clear day. There is a souvenir shopping area on the viewing floor. There is also a restaurant with a relatively limited menu. Good way to view Tokyo from the top for free.
Must do in Shinjuku. Great place To get amazing views over Shinjuku and so much more...If you get to visit Shinjuku, this is a must, and totally free too!

Great views from the top. We enjoyed a quick ride up the elevator to a spectacular view including Mt Fuji and Tokyo as far as the eye could see - such a clear day. We enjoyed tea and a pastry for breakfast. Great location.
Great view, and free!. You can go up to the 45th floor and see the view, and it's free! There is also a restaurant if you'd like to grab a bite to eat.
Nice view from the observatory. The view from the observatory is really amazing, you will really enjoy getting at the top of the building, there is a restaurant for dinning as well.
Trip to Observation Deck. Free observation deck on 45th floor. You can see all of metro Tokyo for free including Mt. Fuji. Great observation windows to be able to see 360 degrees of downtown Tokyo.

Not bad view for free. Tower is not to difficult to find with minimal waiting times.Not that exiting for the view but being for free worth it if in the area.If you had limited time I would give it a miss.

Amazing Views. WOW what an amazing view of almost all of Tokyo. Make sure you go at night and then again during the day because its like two different events. Its not just the view thats amazing but the building is also worth some time very cool modern building. And its all free.

View of the city!. You get a great view of the city from the free observation decks! We got to the observation deck about a half hour before the sun was setting so we stayed to see the sunset, it was really nice. You can see (though small) Mt. Fuji as well. We visited Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka. If you're visiting all 3 places, you definitely need to allocate most of your days to Tokyo because there is SO much to do and see. We spent 4 nights in Tokyo and wished we had stayed longer. I'd say 1-2 nights in Kyoto and 1 night in Osaka is sufficient unless you're venturing outside the city. It's difficult to communicate with the locals and if you don't know how to get around to explore (outside of touristy areas), you'll probably get lost.

There are not many freebies like this!. The two observation decks at the 45th level of the Tokyo Metropolitan Office north and south buildings are worth visiting to get a bird's eye view of the city. Best of all of course is that there is no admission charges! They operate different hours with only one open at night. But obviously getting a day panoramic view and a night view is worth considering.

Amazing views!!!. Well worth the trip, it is free so why wouldnt you!!!The observation decks offer amazing views of Tokyo. There are many large clean windows for viewing. There is also a bar where you can purchase a beer for $7AUD (expensive for Tokyo but not for any Ausy). Probably the best place (view wise) to sit for a beer that I have been to!
Great views on a clear day. What great views, and its free. Well the views are good if the weather is not hazy. Easy to find and very little wait time for the elevator
Wonderful building. You can go upstarir for free. Amazing views of Toky from the top. Very clean ang government people is truly friendly. Nice Cafe up there to take a rest.

Free observatory + good daytime view(not great). - I didn't expected I can go to such a nice observatory for free. -- Observatory was neat and tidy.- However, view from observatory was under my expectation. -- Skyline of Tokyo was not interesting. -- I could see few(not "a few) skyscrapers and unique architectures while I saw the great view from Palette Town in Odaiba. - Overall, Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is worth to visit. -- Building is unique, and I could see many interesting things around the building.(Yes, it is Shinjuku!)-- But if the observatory were not free, I would not enter.

fantastic views and it is free !. You can visit the observatory for free. It is located on the 45th floor and the views are great. We almost saw mount Fuji , but the mist was still lingering. Given the cost of going up the shard in London, well worth a visit
Free view from 45th floor. Easy to negotiate, well marked gives you some knowledge of the many buildings in this area. Nice souvenir shop. Open even on Sundays. Short walk from station.
Architectural beauty. This skyscraper building towers over the area, but shows a modern approach to design. Lovely to look at.

Great Views for free. Probably not worth a specific journey here but if you are staying in or around Shinjuku then why would you not come here. Although it was obviously not purpose designed as a viewing facility it nevertheless gives great views out to the mountains and over Shinjuku and its suburbs. There is a particularly good view of the funky Design Building. The government buildings themselves are also interesting to nose around

Free, and a pretty good view, but not spectacular.. The observations deck is the 45th floor of the building with a series of windows and a few maps telling you what you are looking at. There is a restaurant, and of course a tourist shop!!The views are good, but being just the 45th floor, not breath-taking!The queue for the elevator took about 15 minutes, despite a reasonably small crowd.On the up side it's free. A nice spot to get your bearings, but probably only worth it if you're staying nearby.
Great View and Neat space. This building affords amazing views of Tokyo and its vastness. The building itself is also a very neat space!!
Amazing views. coming up here really bought into perspective the size of Tokyo. Was lucky enough to be up here on a clear day and was amazed by the 360 views on offer

Must visit when you're in Shinjuku. Whenever you visit Shinjuku, just dont miss this place, the observatory on the 45th floor is for free !, i visited the place at night and got wonderful view of Tokyo. The building can be reached for 15 minutes walking from Shinjuku Station. I also found the other side of Tokyo near the building that in such big & modern City, there were many homeless people stay under the building at that time.

A vantage point to view the city for free. We visited the place twice, once in the evening and one time during the day when the sky was clear. The place opens at 9:30 am to 11 pm and it is free. It gives you a bird's eye view of Tokyo and nearby places. Nighttime provides a view of the Tokyo lights and during the day when the sky is clear Mt Fuji is visible as well as the famous building and sites. A must visit.
A tourist must. Good and easy way to see the tokyo skyline. Not the highest building but if you are staying in shinjuku its definitely the most convenient.

Nice observatory in Shinjuku for free. Except for this place and some shopping area, there isn't much to see in Shinjuku, tourist-wise. But it's worth the subway trip (the station is very close). It's a beautiful tall building where you'll find an observatry, mostly empty, for free. On a clear day, Mt. Fuji can be seen from here. At basement there is a tourist information center. Except for that, it's mostly government aids running busy. There is a nice plaza and underneath it, small simple restaurants with extremely cheap, very good food for a quick lunch. Just follow the locals.

Stunning views of Tokyo. Amazing view of Tokyo and open for day and night views. I suggest coming here on a sunny day for Mount Fuji's view and then come back again in the night for Tokyo's equally great night view. Free admission. For the north observatory, there is a restaurant in there, which I think has a wonderful offer in the morning, a breakfast set, and you can sit in there to marvel at the wonderful views of Tokyo. It's very relaxing in my view and worth the price tag.

Nice view of Tokyo. Nice view of the city but if you want to visit a more iconic place, visit the Tokyo tower or The Sky tree! But this place is free.....other two are not.......less crowded too! Choice is yours!
The view.... If you want to get the photo of a sea of house in Tokyo, this is the spot! You will love the building.

One of the best ways to get a view of the city.. Ok guys this is free, yes free. For the cost of nil, zero, nada, zip you get one of the best views of Tokyo. So go. Now. Stop reading, just go. So, if you've not been to Japan before, one thing you'll have to realise is that they do big building as well big, I mean impressively big. That this building could house just civil servants is stunning, the building is huge,Anyway, the views are brilliant. A lot of tourists visit here, so be prepared as it will be busy. When we visited, we were able to wander round, muscle up to the glass and get the required photos. We had to wait only occasionally to line up 'fun' shots. There is a gift shop at the top as well as a good cafe. TBH, one of our best experiences here was at the cafe. We met some retired civil servants who had worked in the building. With very little English language, and lots of gestures they told us of their time working there. The pride these guys had in their jobs and council was impressive. They also bought us some traditional Japanese biscuits. Excellent.Do visit, the views are great and the cafe is too.

Ideal for city views. If you want views of the city but not to travel out to the sky tree, try the viewing decks in the government building. Just at high as the sky tree but free and equally spectacular views. We only went up one tower (there are two) but really enjoyed the views over the city. there is a small gift shop and a nice cafe as well on the viewing deck.

Awesome views, a MUST SEE!!. My family of 5 walked from the train station to the building in less than 5 min. and entered from under a covered driving area. The signs are marked very well "Observatory" in green and white. The elevators take you up to the 45th floor and there is a huge hit circular room with windows on all but 1/6 of the sides. We went at 5pm and the sun was blazing hot into the room. It was gorgeous but quite hot. We had coats and hats from the 40degree weather outside. I seriously recommend this sightseeing stop!!!
Enjoy the View for Free. Entrance to this is absolutely free! It's not to be missed if you're in the area. The view was really special. There is a gift shop that offers so many cute Japanese items.
Nice view from the top. The entry is free! But the observatory is a closed room and you don't get the best view and photos because of the glass!!
Tokyo on Budget. Maybe this is not the best spot to see Tokyo in panoramic but hey, it's free!! So be grateful and enjoy the view :)

What's not to like about a free view!. This place was fantastic for 2 reasons. Firstly it's free, and secondly it gives you a full view of Tokyo and helps you to get your bearings. We arrived 5 minutes before opening on a Friday and got the first lift up - no waiting in lines for us! Highly recommended as your first stop in Tokyo.

Can't complain about free views!. Fun little way to see the city from up high. Quick and easy to do. Great to see the difference from night and day too if you go twice. Souvenirs shops at the top observation decks too.

Awesome view of Tokyo for free. Why pay an arm and a leg for Tokyo Tower or Tokyo Skytree when you can get a view of Tokyo for free? The day was overcast so we didn't see Mt. Fuji, but the view of Tokyo was great. We also had lunch at the North Tower so were able to enjoy the view from our table. Just take the train or subway to Shinjuku station, follow signs that say Tokyo Metropolitan Government Offices. If you miss the signs, just ask anybody. The Japanese are the most helpful people you'll ever meet. Enjoy.

Awesome view for free. We went down on a Sunday morning so it was pretty quiet. The day was beautiful so we got to see Mt Fuji.... Typical touristy souvenirs on sale but a fantastic perspective on Tokyo.. Well worth it...
Great free attraction. This place was awesome as it gives you a full view of Tokyo, for free! It is easy to find if you know where you are going.
Great!. Reasonable entrance price (especially in comparison to Tokyo Skytree) with great views over the city. I definitely recommend it!
Great view. It's a large building and provides a nice view of Tokuo and Mt Fuji on a clear da the morning provides a better photo op of Mt Fuji

It's free to go up & metro is close. The got the metro to the towers and it's only about a 15-20min walk, although it seems longer after sightseeing the whole day.The towers are free to go up and the queue moves quickly. We went at night and then again the following morning, and both were impressive. On a good day you can see Mt. Fuji but sadly we were not that lucky. Definitely worth an hour or so!

Great views!. I had been reading on tripadvisor about the views from the top and the free viewing platform, we jumped straight into the lifts after a quick bag search and went up to the top, great free views over tokyo!
free observatory. just 15 min walk from the shinjuku main station, great view from 45th floor! i recommend north tower and going at night!

Beautiful Views, amazing elevator!. The free entrance and beautiful views make it a must see attraction for us but when we rode the elevator to the 45th floor and hardly feel it moving we were amazed! I recommend going at night.

Nice for the price . Entrance to the Government building and the viewing platform at the top is free of charge which makes this easily a winnerIt would be a different story if there was a charge though

Good view and Free!. I squeezed this in on my last day in Tokyo. It ended up being a slightly overcast day so by the time i got to the top, fog/clouds were setting in. It was a really good view, but I was sad It wasn't clear enough to see Mt. Fuji. It wasn't super exciting, but I didn't have to wait in any lines and it was FREE! I'd recommend trying to go on a clearer day.

Not bad, but not exciting.. The top of the building offers a pretty good view of the east city. The actual building its self and the interior in unimpressive. There was a small line up when we went there mid afternoon, but not bad. Fast lift!
Great view. Great view especially at night (recommend)from the Tokyo Tower. The crepes stand at the base is a must for dessert lovers.

Beautiful Sunset Spot & Its Free!. I'd say one of the best decision I made on my trips to Tokyo. Went here twice and learned the hard way that its pretty much nothing to enjoy during the night. So here's a tip, come here 20-30 minutes before sunset to park your camera a nice spot next to the window to capture that picture perfect sunset photo. If you're late that's okay, you can always move back and take the silhouette of people taking picture of sunset. That's pretty dope as well.

FREE SPECTACULAR VIEWS. There is nothing not to like. You can go up to the top for free and from there you can see the entire city. On a clear day you can see all the way to Mount Fuji. It was clear when we went up and the view really was awe inspiring.

Go, You Will Be Impressed and Wonder How a Civil Service Building Can be a Major Attraction.. I live in Tokyo and never made a special attempt visit the Metropolitan Government Office. I thought that it is lame to accord a civil service building a tourist attraction status. However one day I found myself walking past it and was lured to walk into the court simply because its magnificence is magnetic. It is huge and stunningly beautiful- an architectural gem.
Waste of time during the night: positive aspect: it's free. Long queues to go up (35m) and down (10m)Nothing spectacular to look atBonus: it's for free (vs the expensive Taipei 101)

Free views. There are no shortage of places to see the view in Tokyo, but you'll have to shell out a large chunk of change to gain access to most of them. Unlike every other tower view in Tokyo, the Metropolitan Gov't office is free. What to expect.... lines to enter the elevator and bag search. Two towers to choose from. A lack luster restaurant which you shouldn't bother with. Glass enclosed 360 views. No outside access. Considering it's free, it's worth a look. Don't expect any Earth shattering views of Tokyo or even a view of Mt. Fuji, which can be quite elusive.

amazing panoramic views of the city & it's FREE!. this place was a bit of a trek from where we were hanging out, but the views were fantastic & totally worth it! i wouldn't recommend eating there (the food looked MEH) & the souvenirs were totally overpriced, but you get wonderful views, so can't complain. :)
Great view plus it's free. Went up twice in the day then at night had a lovely meal in the evening and it wasn't expensive if it was london it would of been lovely view at night with a visit

One of the best free attractions in Tokyo. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building can be reached by a 10-minute-walk from Shinjuku Station. When I visited, on multiple occassions, queues for the elevators were bearable (less than 10 minutes each way). Visiting the observatory is absolutely free, no registration is necessary, you just queue in for the elevators. Chances of seeing Mount Fuji are highest on clear days in winter and lowest in summer. If you would like to experience it in daylight, go there in the morning (the observatories open at 9:30am). Viewing from Shinjuku, the sun sets almost exactly behind Mount Fuji. Because of this I couldn’t see much of Mount Fuji in the late afternoon, but then seeing the sun setting behind the mountain, giving it a golden backdrop was a truly amazing sight.
Nice sunset view over Mt Fuji. No a very great place to visit, but people visit this place to get nice sunset view over Mt Fuji on a very clear day.

Comparison Skytree, Tokyo Tower.. Skytree is tallest,newest,most expensive to climb,a little bit far from Tokyo station, may be crowded .T.Tower is taller,oldest,reasonable,nearest to Tokyo station.T.G.office is lowest (but enough for nice landscape),not new but not old,free to climb,not far but not so close to Tokyo station.My recommend is T.G. office. It has two rooms, So It would not be so crowded. It is located most West than others to look Mt. FUJI closer. Anyway FREE!!

One of the Best free views of how Tokyo is laid out.. You can't go wrong with free, and will all the souvenirs you can get for friends at home when you're on the viewing floor, you can take care of that issue efficiently. Other towers are all over the place, but this really shows e sound corridors, heliports in the city, and gives you a great perspective.

Great Nightview. I went to the observation decks and the view is amazing! They have souvenirs & toy shop, but a bit pricey compared to the other. They also have restaurant which might be very romantic to have dinner at.
Great views. Well worth going up in the lift to get a fantastic view of Shinjuku. You can see Mt Fuji in the distance.

What s great place to visit and it's FREE! Visit here first to get your free wifi voucher to use across Tokyo.. We visited with two boys (10 & 8). We all loved it. It's an easy walk from Shinjuku (about 10 mins from the station). We snapped up a free tour offered by a group of lovely volunteer tour guides. Very knowledgable and helpful with any questions about Tokyo and Japan. The views are spectacular. Just as good as Tokyo Tower, with more on offer here (two viewing decks, tours of govt offices, tourist info). Everything is in English and Japanese. To get a tour guide, go to the gift shop/ tourist info centre. When you are there get the card that will give you free wifi in selected areas across Tokyo. They've also got lots of general Tokyo information.

superb skyline view of tokyo. Not well signposted or easily accessed by maps of the city although fortunately for us we had phone maps that we were able to access offline. Only a 5-10 minute work from Shinjuku station altogether and is certainly worth a visit to see the sprawling skyline that the urban city of Tokyo has to offer. This metropolitan government building is the tallest in the Nishishinjuku area but 7th tallest in Tokyo at 243 metres. The tallest is only 5 metres taller. The building itself is impressive with 2 towers both offering viewing points from the 45th floor. I was initially weary about distance up or down in the lifts, but was pleasantly surprised as I did not feel it moving (unlike my experience at empire state building in nyc). Free to enter. We opted for south tower to try to get a view of Mount Fuji. Luck was however not with us as it was an overcast day. The observation is well equipped with maps that pinpoint important buildings in site and there is also a free guide stationed there whom can highlight many things for you for free. Lovely touch. Would definitely go again.

Great views on the cheap. Free admission and great views of the city. Went on a weekday mid-morning, no line up at all. Bit out of the way from many of the attractions but lets you tour all of the skyscrapers in the area.
Fantastic views. Free to visit - and a great way to see the great expanse of Tokyo - well worth the small queue up to get up the tower - a must do in Tokyo

Nice view. The building lets you see a great view of Tokyo at night. The queue is relatively long but it didn't take too long before it was our turn to get onto the elevator. There is a restaurant on the observation floor (we didn't try) and some souvenir shops. The best part is the entrace is free.

Great View, Great Price!. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office in Shinjuku offers what the SkyTree and Tokyo Tower don't: a free view of Mt. Fuji on clear days. Observation decks on the 45th floors of both towers are open to the public daily, as is the glorious Meiji Jingu that the civic skyscrapers overlook to the south.

Amazing view and free!. Most places would charge you for a view of the city as spectacular as this. On a clear day Mt. Fuji is very visible and the city skyline is amazing. There's a lot of souviner shops, vending machines and even a resturant. Of course you're not obligated to spend a single Yen and can simply enjoy the view.
Amazing view!. Worth taking a trip up one of the towers for an extensive - and free - view of Tokyo. Mt Fuji can be seen on a clear day
Great views at no cost. Great place to get a birds eye view of Toyko. Views to Mt Fuji. Lines moved fast and no cost for admission.

Great free view of the city. Excellent view of the city from the 45th floor for free!
Good photo op.
There is a reasonably prices restaurant and trinket shops up there too...

Free!. This is a free attraction and the views are spectacular, perfect for budget travellers as well as those wanting a drink or meal at the top (ridiculously over priced and not that nice) but at least you get the view. You can't miss the building and everyone is so helpful. Shops at the top selling toys and pens and socks etc. and if you collect pressed coins, the machine is here too!

Stunning views. Only a couple blocks from our Kei Plaza Hotel you can enjoy fabulous views which you would only be able to see from an expensive helicopter trip. Coming from a country where few tourist attractions are free, this was really a bargain. You can ascend both towers and as there were only a handful of visitors the experience was most enjoyable and enlightening. To look down on a city that extends to the horizon in all directions is amazing

Worth a visit. visited in december. Nice Sunny winter, we could see MT FUJI. Yes it is far away but we can still see it. part of the cone is hiding behind the white vanilla cream ( clouds) . The photos are beauiful taken up from here! Q up was manageable too.
Fabulous free view of the city!. The observatory on the 45th floor offers a great 270 degree view of the city. This is free of charge and quite popular among tourists

Visit in winter for best views!. The Metropolitan building has two towers where you can gain free access to the 45th floor for sweeping views of Tokyo. To the west you can see Fujisan and to the east you can see Tokyo. There's city in all directions as far as you can see.... Kinda crazy!! The north tower has a restaurant and several gift shops, the south tower is much simpler. In the spring you won't be able to see much- the sands from China sweep in and everything is hazy, summer is hit or miss but visibility is usually low- the best time to see Fujisan is on a cold, sunny winter day!

Free Observation Deck. We were expecting a great view from the Observation Deck but it was a disappointment. It was so hot up there that we couldn't wait to go back down. In addition, most of the deck was taken up by shops and a restaurant. We had a better view from a restaurant we visited across the street. While it is free, there are other free ones that are better.
Observatories 202 meters above the ground. There are two observatories in this building. I saw the whole Tokyo and Mount Fuji. The best part of these observatories is FREE OF CHARGE!!!!!

Free views.. Very close to Hilton Hotel and gave fabulous views the whole way across the city from the 2 towers of the building. Easy access and open seven days a week.
Well worth a visit.

Free View!. A free view can be hard to find in Tokyo. If you're in Shinjuku, take time to stop by the metropolitan building and check out the view. You can see the bay from the South Tower and on a good clear day you can see Fuji form the North.
Excelente view of Tokyo. I liked it because the view from the 45th floor is fantastic and the entry is free. When I went I could see Mount Fuji and Tokyo Sky Tree .

Very good. It's always good to go to a free top attraction! No queues on a saturday, so we went up both the north and south towers. Fuji wasn't visible, but it was exciting to see weather systems roll down over the mountains and hills in front of it. We took a cheap (Y1000/£5.20) curry lunch at the top with views towards Tokyo bay and Haneda.

Great views for free. Super easy to get to- signs will point you to an underground thoroughfare all the way to the doorstep. It is free and the views are great.Be warned at the top its just all shops of souvenirs etc.

OK but.... It is great that you can get this view from a tall building for free BUT it is pretty busy and the floor that you view from is basically a tourist shop and restaurant.I would recommend getting there to watch the sunset, but get there early as there will be long lines for the elevator. Nighttime is good too the lights of the city are pretty amazing!

Great view of the city. What more can you say, it's clean, it's free and the observation deck on the 45 floor offers great views of Tokyo...on the day we went we could even see Mt Fuji with snow on top. There is a cafe on the same floor if you want to stay for a while, toilets and a gift shop.
Great Views and it is free!!!. Easily reached from MTR. Quick lift to the viewing level and wrap around windows for good views. Hard to stop taking photographs .May see Mt Fuji on a good day.

Worth it for the price (nothing!) alone. There are a few different options you can take if you want to get a birds-eye view of Tokyo (the Skytree, Tokyo Tower, Mori Tower), but if you're on a budget, the Metropolitan Government Office is the one to choose. I went to the Mori Tower on a previous trip (but not the other two), and while the view was indeed good, it also cost 1500 yen. Visiting the observatory of the Metropolitan Government Office is completely free.My brother and I went there on a sunny afternoon, and the views were breathtaking. You get a 360 degree view of the city, and if the sky is clear, you can see Mt Fuji quite well. There's a café on the top floor (where the observatory is) and also a little gift shop, if you want somewhere to chill for a bit after admiring the view (which is what we did).All in all, considering it's completely free, you really can't go wrong with making a stop here. I honestly would have paid for the experience if you had to. The Metropolitan Government Office is fairly easy to reach from the JR Shinjuku station - try and spot the towers if you can, so you can get a visual reference, as Shinjuku can be a bit of a maze.
Perfect thing to do in the morning. Shops open later than expected around Tokyo so head to the Tower and go up to see a beautiful view and a lovely gift shop for afterwards. Free and easy
Nice view. The view was really nice. It was good to see at night. Also the best part is it's free. If you do go at night, there isn't too much around there just business buildings.

View of Mt Fuji. This is a great FREE attraction, and a short walk from Shinjuku Station. On the day we were there it was clear enough to reveal a lovely view of My Fuji, not to mention a 360 degree panorama of Tokyo.

Worth a visit. Visited on a clear day so had a great view of the city
Free to enter to if you are in the shinjuku area worth a visit for a sky line view

Great free views out over Tokyo. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building is actually 2 towers that are pretty easy to find from the Shinjuku JR station.Signage is good - keep an eye out for it abbreviated to TMG on some signsTake the lift to the 45th floor and take in the views - there is a North & South observation deck - we only visited the North oneOpening hours for The North Observatory: 9:30 to 23:00 and you can access to go up until 22:30
Great views. Two towers both pretty much the same in the views you get so go to either! Free admission. Little bit of a queue to go up & down as the lift is quite small but not really a problem.

Tips to Fellow Travellers. (1) Yes, admission is free. (2) Both the South Tower and North Tower have observatory platform. (3) According to the tourist information office there, the South Tower has a better view, although it is closed earlier (except two days in a month) earlier. (4) The observatory platform is actually on Level 45. (5) Entrance to two special lifts is on Level 1, after passing through security check. (6) Adjacent to the entrance is a tourist information office where foreign visitors can get a 14-day free WIFI pass (user id and password) by presenting their passports to confirm their foreign visitor status. (7) However, not everywhere have such WIFI network. (8) There is a pedestrian underpass connecting the Shinjuku JR Train/Subway Station to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office Building (with clear direction sign in the Station. (9) The office building is quite close to the Keio Plaza Hotel on one side and opposite to the Hyatt Regency Hotel on another side. (10) Both Towers open at 9.30 am. Check latest information about closing time (generally 10:30 pm) on the internet.

Great views of Tokyo. From here, you can get a great view of Shinjuku and the surrounding suburbs. I think it's nicer at night to see all the lights of Tokyo. It is convenient to access, as the building doesn't close until 11pm, but they stop letting people in around 10 something. It is also free admission, so it's a great sightseeing activity if you're on a budget. They also have a souvenir store located in the building.
Good View of Mt. Fuji. This was an ok place to visit while in Tokyo. It is free to get into so you won't be too disappointed. We visited other towers in Tokyo and found the views better elsewhere.
fantastic and free!. worth a visit up to the 47th floor for great view of Tokyothere is a cafe up there and plenty of space to walk around to see each direction

Wonderful views, but with one criticism.... I visited the TMGO as darkness enveloped the city in the early evening. I then had one criticism of TMGO and that was that there was too much going inside the room, what with the souvenir stalls and the general illumination of the room that it made it difficult, even impossible, to get a photo of the cityscape without ‘reflection interference’. It seemed that, the more interesting the vista was, the more lights you had to deal with. I felt that the actual window areas could have done with some kind of curtain screening to block out the light pollution. Not beyond the wit and ken of man, surely, but there you have it. As you walked around the windows, photographers, straining and audibly cursing, while trying to get the ‘killer shot’, accompanied you. To compound my irritation with this avoidable blight, the queue for the lifts taking you back down to ground level was immense and required, on this occasion, a twenty-minute wait. I was in some doubt whether I would be able to make it down and across town the second leg of my evening, at the Robot Restaurant. I did make it, but the queue made it nerve-wracking.

Great views for free!. We visited the observation deck early January, during the day, and were able to access the lift (up and down) to the 45th floor immediately. There are some great views and photography is possible (although keen photographers won't like the glass). There were some helpful information boards and guides who can provide further information without charge. There is a large restaurant and small souvenir shop.

Get a perspective of how big this city is!. We had this on our list of places to go. My expectations were not high as sometimes these sort of sites can be a little underwhelming. We entered the massive building following the green signs outside that point you to the "Observation entrance". Its free to enter and once at the top after the ride in the elevator to the 45th floor you can see a really spectacular view of Japan. Amazing.

Great views, for free! . We were staying at the hyatt regency hotel just across the road from this building, so we went here once during the day and again late at night. The views were fantastic both times and during the day we could see Mt Fuji. There wasn't ever a massive line up or ever crowded. Best thing is that it is all for free.

Great views. You can see the city and Mt Fuji (if the sky is clear), and also grab some food at the cafe in each tower. From memory, the South Tower seems to offer a better view of Mt Fuji.If you have an hour to spare, it's a good idea to get a free tour from the Visitor's Centre - they'll be able to give you some good background to the building, and you might get to see the government sit.
Great. Worth a visit - easy to find. Was very quiet the day we went. Nice views of snow on Mt Fuji. Good little gift shops too. Recommend. And it's free!

Good views. The observation deck gives you a good perspective of the city. Especially good that its free. There is a restaurant at the top that takes up roughly a third of the area, and you can't look out that direction unless you buy food.Shouldn't really complain about something that is free. But if you don't mind the cost, the experience at the observation deck at roppingi hills is much better!
Great panoramic views. Can't really go past the opportunity for a free panoramic view of Tokyo. Pretty spectacular at night.
High rise. Great lifts to the top of the building and fabulous views when you get there. Not for the faint-hearted. Outside they were stall sna entertainers too.

OK. Sick of paying exorbitant sums for tall buildings such as in Shanghai, I was pleased this one was free. Not overly tall....45 stories I think....but in Tokyo that's fine. No pollution, no low cloud, so a nice little diversion. One section is a restaurant which you can't wander into, so you get about a 240 degree view only.
Free View of the City. This building has a free observation floor with views of the city. Also a little shop with souvenirs including Astro Boy and other manga stuff.

View of city. Followed the map directions but still getting used to Tokyo and her ways. I expected lots of advertising, queues, souvenir sales...but nothing.The kind security man beckoned us over with welcome smile and conformation was at right place. Yes I know the fact of high building was give away but there was just an efficient free service on offer in what from outside looked like an office block.The polite staff and information requested streamlined the experience.
Catch a glimpse of Mt Fuji. Great views and on a clear day you can even see Mt Fuji. Nice way to spend an hour and grab a coffee or beer in the cafe

Best free view of Tokyo. Has a good view of Tokyo city. Needless to say, go here during the evening. And did I mention it's free?There's also a couple of souvenir shops at the top where you can buy from.

Views over Tokyo and Mount Fuji. Forget about paying to visit observation decks in Tokyo , just come here . First it's free , it was not busy and the views are epic . If it's clear you will be able to see Mount Fuji clearly , a amazing sunset and the lights come on over the city . Why would you not visit ?
It's free!. This observation deck is a must to have an overview of the City. Interesting and very informative. And of course, what could be better than a thing that is free?

Great views, easy access via Tochomae station AND free. I was staying next door to this building and visited a bunch of times at different hours, after visiting tokyo tower which was not worth it. Less crowded than the popular observatories and got amazing photos of Mount Fuji. Great location, nearest station is Tochomae, literally 2 minutes from it. There is a lovely little park (Central park) near by where you can take some great photos of the building which is quite pretty :)
GREAT observation area!. WOW - talk about great views!!! Went up on a clear day and could actually see Mt. Fuji! Could still see a lot of fog/pollution, but had great views and enjoyed the visit.

Amazing view of Tokyo. Definitely worth a visit. It is free and it is worth doing both towers. You do get a little lost from Shinjuku train station so its about $8 AUD. Worth going up both towers to get the full 360 view of the city.

Tochomae station is closer than Shinjuku. We walked to the building from Shinjuku and it was a fair hike. On the way out we saw Tochomae station on the Oedo line, just a short walk away. No queues to go up at 6pm on a weekday evening in December. It was a clear night and the views were great - for free!

Views are good only.. Free admission is great. Nothing much else to do on the Observation floor except look at the available view of Tokyo. In the North Tower, almost half the observation windows are off limits to guests as located in the cafe. The toilets are one floor down and the route there is full of cigarette smoke. Enjoy the limited view.
Such amazing views. Absoutely amazing views. We went on a clear day and even got to see Mt. Fuji. It is free and such a great experience. Must do!

Good view of the Tokyo skyline. Since we were staying at the Shinjuku Washington Hotel, which is just a block away from the Metropolitan buildings, we visited the towers twice - during the day and night. Its a free attraction and offers good views of the Tokyo skyline, though not as good as the Skytree. If you are in Shinjuku, this place can be a good option. If you have already been to Skytree, this trip may be omitted!
Great place to see Tokyo and Fuji. On a clear day you can easily see Fuji from the lookout on top.Also free and easy access. Only once you see Tokyo from the air do you realise how large it is.

Great free view of Tokyo. One evening, we dropped by to see the view. Signs clearly direct you. There was very little wait when we visited. There is no admission charge.The view was fabulous, but because the observation deck is indoors, all photos suffered from the reflection. I regret that we didn't visit during the day, because the photos might have been better.There are a few souvenir shops with inexpensive gifts. You can stamp a brochure to show you were here.

Brilliant vistas and absolutely free. We went up to 45th floor in morning for brilliant vistas of Tokyo city..queues start early at 09:00 am, so try and reach early. There s nice souvenir shop on observation deck. There are informative maps and guides too. Skip the Tokyo Tower / Sky Tree..and visit this place instead.
date at night. free for all- no entrance fee collected, you can see the perfect night view of tokyo with the Tower. There are cheap souvenirs you can buy.

Excellent views of the City!. This was closely located to where we stayed (Nishi MyStays) the building is very impressive! unbelievable tall!When you enter you follow the signs and join the queue for the lift, depending on what time you go will determine how busy the queue is. We were recommended to go just before sunset in late September.The lift takes you up to the observation deck and there is a restaurant and a souvenir shop, the views are great of the city skyline, great chance to get some quality pictures.We went back the next day, as it was my birthday, to the restaurant. a little pricey but we were expecting this and ate at the bar overlooking the night-time sky view. Worth a visit at night too! :)

View of tokyo from high above. Its free entrance. Besides other high rise you could also see mount fuji from far. There is cafe and souvenir shop at the observation floor too. The building is near to shinjuku train station makes it easier to visit if you are not staying near the area.

A free observation deck!. It is located in Shinjuku, it's actually quite a long walk from Shinjuku station to the Metropolitan Government Building. Nonetheless, it's worth going there as it's free, it's very rare to find a panoramic observation deck that do not charge any fees. The views were great! You can see photos of the night view taken from the observation deck on my blog: http://idylsherry.blogspot.fr/2014/11/japan-trip-tokyo_20.html

Free, easy to access, and a great view!. If you're looking for a great view of the city, and don't want to either a) pay or b) queue for an hour, then the Tokyo metropolitan government observation decks are a good alternative to the skytree or the Tokyo tower. Open late into the evening too, they're situated a few minutes walk away from Shinjuku station - it's signposted from the concourse but, like all of Japan's transport signage, the signs disappear and reappear along the way!
Free views of Tokyo!. Those wanting to avoid observatory fees (e.g. Tokyo Tower, Skytree) can go here and get good views of the city at no cost. 10 minute walk from Shinjuku Station.

Terrific View from observation deck. Went to have a look up here the other day; what an amazing view on a clear day. The place is a bit tired and could do with some TLC however the view makes up for it.
Oh and the cafe sucks!!
Well worth the trip on a clear day....

So nice.. The building grounds are very nice, but to be honest, we went to see the observatory on the 45th floor. Was really beautiful to look around and see the city. You can also see Mt. Fuji. There was no charge to go to the observatory either.

Great view at night. We went there a night. The lift takes you to the viewing platform where you can see many of the Tokyo landmarks. Obviously good clear weather is an advantage. There is no outside space - so photography is through the glass. It is free of charge and a fairly quick walk from Shinjuku station.
Great view and free. I went at night time and the view was great. Very easy to find, no queue for the elevator, no charge!

Great starter to get your bearings. I had a tour guide when I went to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office and she was wonderful. Definitely recommend visiting there on day one or day two of your visit.
Great view that doesn't cost anything!. I always come here when visitingTokyo because its FREEEE. Come on a clear day after it rains and maybe you can see Mount Fuji. I've had no luck thus far.

Well worth a visit. It's free which is amazing because the view from the top is spectacular, despite only being 45 floors. It was closed when we arrived due to high winds and a very helpful lady have us a free tour of the building and it was actually pretty interesting! If it's a very clear day you might even be able to see fuji as we did, very beautiful.

Excellent view over Tokyo and its for free. A great view from the 45th floor. If you're lucky there is a guide available who tells you about the different kind of buildings you see, some history and additional information about the areas of Tokyo. I took the subway, went down at the Nishi-Shinjuku station. It was quite a long walk but so worth it. Its located in the middle of high rise buildings, impressive.

A good view, nothing else. Weather permitting you can get a good view of Tokyo for free, a very rare case.There isn't much else, on the observatory floor two or three small shops selling tourists souvenirs and some queue for the elevator, both up and down.But what did you expect? It is a government building after all.
Very interesting!. Nice to see the view of Tokyo. Worthy the visit. However, I wouldn't recommend if you are afraid of heights or being in a tall building, I felt lightheaded because it's so high!

Interesting Building and Observation Decks. I've visited the Tokyo "City Hall" on a couple of holiday occasions and enjoyed the place as a sort of off-beat tourist attraction. As noted, the view is great and it is free. Most of the people there seemed to be visiting Japanese. We first went in December of 2010 and while at the tourist information centre near the ground floor we noticed a desk with a sign offering free guided tours in English. The four of us were the only guests on the tour. A very pleasant volunteer guide showed us around the building for over an hour, ending up at the observation deck. She also mentioned that the employee restaurant was open to the public, so we ate our lunch in the very large employee's cafeteria as the only outside guests (buy ticket for the chosen meal from a machine then give the ticket to the appropriate counter person and grab a table). On my return trip to the 45th floor in November 2014 we had a very reasonable set lunch meal at the small restaurant on the south observation deck. The observatory is entirely glassed in. In 2010 we had a fine view of Fuji-san from the south tower. Easy access from Shinjuku.
NIce view of Tokyo from atop. Free and on most nights open till 11pm! The only con is that the view is not full 360 degree and depending on the time you visit, it could get crowded.
It is an all right trip.. Considering the fact that it's free, it's pretty worth going up. It's wuite strategic and easy to access. Good view of the Tokyo landscape.

Excellent view for free - to be visited at sunset!!. You can see Tokyo from several tall buildings, but in most place you'll have to pay a consistent amount of money. This observatory is located on floor n.45, it's free and offers at least a 180 degree view over Tokyo. I definitely recommend to go there at sunset, you can even see mount Fuji and the snow on its peak if the weather allows it.

Free view from the top!. There are many places to view Tokyo from the sky and most of them charge a fee. The Tokyo Metropolitan building was open late on a Sunday to allow elevators full of tourists the chance to ride to the top floor and see the city for free. There are reasonable gift shops and a small, but elegant, dinner restaurant on the observatory floor as well. As you exit there are two areas showcasing products from each of the prefectures and a tourist information center. I wish we'd visited here earlier in our trip to take advantage of the valuable information offered in both.
A "Must Visit". Liked the fact there were two towers to visit providing fantastic views of the city.Liked the fact souvenirs were on sale and a reasonable coffee shop was available for tourists.

A must see!. If you don't make it to Skytree or Tokyo Tower, this is the next best thing. The best part about it is - it's FREE! The long opening hours (9am - 11pm) allow you to see Tokyo from both day and night perspectives and the views are quite stunning, especially at night. We had breakfast at the North observatory restaurant, and for 700 yen per person, enjoyed a morning set of waffles and coffee looking out over Tokyo.
Nice view and it is free!. Great way to see Tokyo from above. Close to Shinjuku Station and free. When we visited there was no waiting line and the place never felt crowded.

Adequate attraction. The signage out of Tochomae Metro Station is good and it is easy to find the two buildings once you are at street level. The entrance to the observatories themselves is not so clearly marked - just keep looking! There were surprisingly few people for a late Sunday morning, even though it is free of charge. Perhaps most people now prefer the prestigious Tokyo Skytree although, apparently, it is expensive! The views of the concrete jungle from the 45th floor are fairly good. I was not there on the 1 in 5 days when Mt Fuji can be seen but as I had had a clear view from my plane a couple of days earlier as it approached Tokyo and as I was going to take a close-up view later I was not bothered by this.

Free panoramic view of Tokyo. This twin-tower is quite easy-access, 10 minutes by walking from Shinjuku-station. Moreover, it is free. From the observation desk at the height of 200 meters on floor 45, at night visitors can get an magnificent panoramic view of Tokyo at night, or during the daytime they can see Meiji Shrine, Tokyo Skytree and even Mount Fuji on clear day.

Bird's Eye View of Tokyo!. You will be able to enjoy a bird's eye view of Tokyo! If the sky is clear, you will get to see Mt Fuji which is more than 100km away from Tokyo! There are souvenir shops and cafes in both north and south observation tower! Most importantly, there is no entry fee so make sure you check out this place when you are in Tokyo!

Fantastic view of the rest of Tokyo. Went to the northern observatory as night fell for a view of Tokyo at night. It's free! Great place to look out from, they say if the weather is clear/etc you can see Mt Fuji from here. I didn't, though.It's a bit confusing to get to personally, but that may be just me. From the station, just went straight out to the centre of the office building (from the inside coming from the station, it looked like the ground/basement is a ring) and head up the stairs outside to the street level. The entrance to the main building/observatories is from the street level.Up on the deck, there is a restaurant and a toy shop and some benches for sitting at the middle of the deck.
Nice view. I love the views from here and it is FOC. Not so crowded and very convenience. What a good choice if you want to have a free tokyo city view.

Get an excellent view of Tokyo here. First of all, it is free :) It provides a spectacular view of Tokyo. Can even see Mt Fuji! The security personnel were very polite when checking out bags, before we went up to the observatory deck. The place is spacious but can be noisy if there is a big group of tourists.Worth going, if you are around Shinjuku area.

Vast and impressive granite twin towers. This building was adjacent to my hotel, and I could see it from my room. The buildings (two of them joined together) are enormous skyscrapers which attest to the importance and size of the Tokyo municipality. They reek power and influence. I couldn't get inside when I was there. Outside, the area is set with exquisitely manicured planter boxes in the spotless modern plaza. It is amazing to me that the Japanese set such a high standard of cleanliness and elegance, while we in the West put up with graffiti and trash everywhere. This is a squeaky-clean setting for one of the largest city councils in the world, and its size and perfection show how it should be done.

Fantastic View. Free elevator to the top of the tall building ... very nice service by all staff there ... excellent atmosphere around, neat & clean area ... also out of the world view with fantastic self explaining boards. Really Enjoyed & also happy to see my Nihon Kohden AED on the top of building...

Great free viewing platforms. The free viewing floors from both the north and south buildings is an excellent way to take in how big this city is. Look down on modern and cultural areas and we were able to spot parts of the city we had previously visited. A great way to get a perspective on Tokyo.

Amazing Landscape. I went to this place 3 Times and i would recommend any of you to do so. Go one time on the morning aroudn 10, make sure it's sunny and clear weather so you can have an immersive view over Tokyo. You can even see Mount Fuji with some luck.Second time went on sunset (as it was just near my hotel) and last time at night. YES IT IS OPEN, till around 10pm, so don't hesitate to go for a loock over A shiny Tokyo landscape.I should mention that it is totally free. There is two buildings so make sure you are in the right one, if not ask for help they will kindly redirect you.

Night View in the Rain. This place was less than 10-min walk from my hotel. Arrived at 8:30pm, there was no line and we took a free elevator to the observation deck. There were a couple of restaurants (smell was good) and a gift shop with lots of classic Japanese characters (Totoro for example :) The view was great and there were signs on every window for aid. Too bad it was a rainy night, I couldn't see very far. But it's not difficult to imagine the view would be much more impressive on a brighter day. Staffs were extremely friendly and helpful!!!

World-class freebie. Take the free elevator up either / both of these towers to find an empty cafe, uninspiring mini-exhibition about the building's construction, a tourist-trap gift shop and one of the best views in Tokyo. On a clear day you'll see the Sky Tree, Tokyo tower, Fuji etc. we were staying at the Keio Plaza next door and made this our first stop to get our bearings. The building keeps office hours so, if you go in winter, you can just about catch the sunset.

A brilliant view for free!. It's not often you get to go up to an observation deck for free! The host and lift staff were very friendly and welcoming. There are signs above each window to tell you what you are looking at too. You can even see Mount Fuji on a clear day! A must do while in Tokyo.

One tower is better than the other. An amazing view of Tokyo if it is a clear day AND FREE! Easy to find and well signposted from Shinjuku station, go up the SOUTH tower as the North tower has a restaurant and a large souvenir shop that cuts out a lot of the view. The South tower only has one souvenir shop so maximum viewing area. On a good day you can see Mt Fuji.
Observation tower. Great views, free admission, nice walk from Shinjuku station. Went early Sunday, no crowds. Also have a nice gift shop.
Free view. Great place to see the Tokyo skyline for free, would definitely recommend this if you are in the area.
Beautiful views. Free except if you shop at top level and spend on souvinaire items or food Wonderful views awesome to visit / free

Free view of the city. This was our first view of the city. Was worth going to just to appreciate the size of tokyo. The buildings go on forever. Bit of a line up we got there at 9am. Can do the whole thing in 30 minutes

Nice view of Shinjuku. Walking distance from Shinjuku train station. But with elderly or young children, recommend to take 1 train stop away. This attraction is free so didnt expect much. There is English guide available. Ok experience.

Excellent and free view of Tokyo. Tocho observation view located on the 45th floor of the building gives you a fantastic bird's eye view of Tokyo.The best part is that the view is free.You have to queue up to ride the elevator.There are two towers North and South but the view is pretty much similar from both.All the attractions visible are well marked in photographs.Souvenir kept for sale are overpriced.Do not forget to get a rubber stamp imprint of the tower for free as a souvenir.We at least got a good view of the Shinjuku Gyoen from here as the park was closed because of the Ebola scare.

Incredible view of Tokyo for free!. Don't bother with Tokyo Skytree or Tokyo Tower. Avoid the long lines and high cost and get virtually the same views for FREE. We went at about 9 pm and there was no line. We got right into the elevator and were on the 45th floor in 2 minutes. There are 360 degree views (with maps in front of each window describing what you're seeing), and a lovely piano bar where you can have a cocktail or a bite to eat. I imagine it would be pretty cool during the day too, especially if you can see Mt. Fuji, but we wanted to see the nightscape, which was fantastic. Don't miss it.

Nice View,. Its a very nice view. It was free which was very nice, but seemed a little bit old and the windows were quite smaller then some of the other nice views in Tokyo. If your on a budget and want to see how beautiful Tokyo is, Then I recommend it.

Neat photo opportunity for free. For free, this is a great chance to see some great views of Tokyo from the top of Tokyo City Hall. You can go up either tower (North or South). We went up the North tower, but I don't think it makes too much of a difference. The price is totally right: free! Even better, we saw Mt. Fuji through the mist. It was very special to see it almost floating in the distance above the endless urban sprawl of Tokyo. You also get a very good sense of just how huge this city is. We are currently staying in Shinjuku, but even if we were in another part of the city, I think it would be worth the trip to to see the sites. I'd only budget about an hour of your time in total, but combined with a coffee somewhere in Shinjuku, it can make for a fun morning.

Shinjuku + Tokyo lights for free. Just around 5-10 minutes walk from Shinjuku station west exit. There was a bag check when we wanted to enter. I went there at night with a friend living in Tokyo.Observatory in floor 45 is around 202 meters above ground.The great thing is: it was completely free!It offers 360 view if Tokyo so other Tokyo landmarks can be seen from the observatory Shinjuku + Tokyo lights from above were very pretty !! ^^
Looks futuristic. This building is quite tall - quite unusual for a government building.

Amazing view for free. You dont need to go to Tokyo Tower or the Skytree to get a good view over amazing Tokyo. From the government building its free. Great shops and a nice place to eat also. Highly recommended
Great view. This building has great view, but offers no other thrill or excitement. Worth to visit during night when the view over city is the best.
Worth a visit. Worth a visit for the view and for the walk around the nearby area, excellent that it's free, and that it helps you get your bearings for the layout of the city.
Nice views and for free. The views are very good and its free! There aren't any seats unless you go to the café/restaurant which I did.

Tokyo Skyline for Free. Easy to find via train to Shinjuku and then 200 yen shuttle bus will deliver you right to this doorstep...45th floor views of Skytree and Fuji in the distance. The price is RIGHT!!!

Great Views - and Free!. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office observation deck provides great views over Tokyo. I went early evening, and got some great shots of Tokyo will all her lights shimmering.You can get some great views of the landmark Tokyo Tower from up here.There is a restaurant and bar also that have some great views - if you know when you are going to go - I would recommend booking a table in advance as it seemed quite popular the night I went.There is also a gift shop for those looking to squeeze in some Japanese souvenir shopping.It is around a 10 minute walk to get to the building from the JR Shinjuku station, with plenty of signs pointing you in the right direction. However this takes you in a subway sort of promenade. I would recommend at least on the way back, walking along at street level, which gives you some nice vantage points of some great Tokyo architecture including the Cocoon Tower.Only dislike was the no tripods allowed policy, as well as too many lights providing reflections on the glass for photos.
Free and the same views as other towers. A short walk from Shinjuku station, this free observation deck is well worth the effort to get to - we went on a clear Autumn day and the views were great.
Fantastic views. Free to visit, amazing views, good gift shop, cafe . Can stay as long as you like and it also open till later at night.

Big and bureaucratic. A little bit of metropolis in Shinjuku. Architecture seems a bit out of character with some of the innovations thru the area, and really a bureaucratic temple hardly seems to justify going for the view.

Well Worth the Walk. These twin towers are a bit of a walk from the metro station at Shinjuku. Nevertheless, it is well worth the effort first to see the towers and then to take the elevator to the top of one of (or both) the towers to see the view of the city. The view from the tower will illustrate the immensity of Tokyo both in terms of people and size. If the skies are clear, you will even get a view of Mt Fuji. There are staff available that will also give you a free 10-15 minute tour of the views and what you are seeing. Take advantage of this free activity and the tour.

Tokyo at its best via (free tour). A hidden gem of a free tour. I happened to find this tour via fellow tourists. A massive building with ceilings that are designed to resemble circuits. One can see Fuji on a clear day. Well worth the free tour. One can also see the Park Hyatt Tokyo where "Lost in Translation" was used as a backdrop.

Fabulous View of the City Without a Line. We asked several people which of the towers in town had the best views. They told us to go here, and we are certain we made the right decision. There was no charge, and there was no waiting to go up. The city couldn't be different looking from the other towers, as we were able to go all the way around the building to see from every angle. We couldn't see Mount Fuji, but this isn't a good time of year to see it. Winter has better views, as there are fewer clouds. If there is a good time to go off season, it would be early and when it is windy.

Tallest Observatory in Tokyo. There is no fee to go up to the Observatory and check out breathtaking panoramic views of the beautiful Tokyo including Tokyo Tower and rest of the high-rise of Shinjuku. I stayed at Hyatt Regency last time I visited which is literally next to this building. Going again to Tokyo and this time I am going to stay at Washington Hotel next to it as well. Its a great location for all the tourists. Its walking distance from the Shinjuku train station as well.

Great view on a clear day. We walked here from our hotel located in Nishi-shinjuku. The entrance is located downstairs around the side of the building, as you are not allowed to enter through the front. The view is quite nice, but it was cloudy the day we went so we could not see as far as we would have hoped. But considering it is free to go up, one can't complain.

Waste of time. We are not sure why people are raving about this place, we spent 20 minutes walking from the station to the building, queued with other tourist for another 15 minutes.Upon going to the top of the building, the view was nice, we spent about 10 minutes looking around the place and that was it, nothing special. The souvenir shops were selling the same thing throughout.Overall this is a wasteful trip, personally regretted going.

Free, easy to get to and has amazing views. I would recommend going to the North Tower (you can choose from either at the ground floor); this tower has the best view of the nearby park and then the towers of Shinjuku and beyond. It's fantastic that this is free, since in many cities it costs a significant amount to get a view like this.
