I was high above Shinjuku during the day and evening, and both are worth it if you have the time.There's a reasonably-priced cafe and gift shop as well, nice spot for a coffee or beer.

The best view in town. This is much quieter than the Tokyo tower and it is free. The view across the city is wonderful and it gives you a sense of the city that being on the ground cannot. Tokyo is a difficult city to get your bearings from the ground as the high rise and twisting streets disorient. From the tower you see it all in perspective

Overlooking Tokyo City. Go there on a clear, sunny day and you'll never disappointed! Guides are proactive, speak good English yet knowledgeable. I would recommend this the very first spot before you start exploring Tokyo.

Great View. Yes like everyone else says it's free so that means you can skip doing the Skytree and Tokyo Tower, It's quite a long underground hike from Shinjuku station so I recommend getting on Oedo Subway Line to Tochomae Station it's only 1 stop away.There's a gift shop at the top which is pretty good I bought a few things there. If its a cloudy day don't bother going up because once I could barely see a few meters out the window, on the other hand I've been up there at sunset and the silhouette of Mt Fuji way off in the distance looked great.

Can't beat the price; great views. We checked this out later in the afternoon (around 4p). It was free, which was pleasantly surprising. We ended up staying to watch the sunset and get the views at night. I highly recommend doing this. It's nice that they have a small cafe where you can sit and get a drink and snack. They have a small gift shop too.

Good view of the city. Pretty good view, small line-up to go up, a little bigger line-up to go back down, but it was pretty efficient. We went at night and while the skies were clear, the glare coming from within made it very difficult to take pictures.

Free amazing views. This is well worth your time, it is free and the views are incredible. You can pretty much see a 365 view of Tokyo . They have a really nice gift shop and cafe on top. There are two observatory towers, South and North towers, we went to the south tower.
Great Views. The main thing is its FREE!! So if you want to see Tokyo from great height then this is the place to go. Easy to find and wasnt at all busy when we visited

I can't believe it's free!. This was a fantastic find. The observatory on the 45th floor of this skyscraper offers an amazing view of Tokyo and beyond. We were lucky enough to visit on a clear day and could see Mt Fuji in the distance. There was a long queue for the elevator but the line moved quite quickly and we chatted to some other tourists while we waited. Definitely worth a visit and the small gift shop has some quirky souvenirs available at reasonable proces.

free view of Tokyo --without needing to use a train. There is an elevator to take you up 45 floors for a great view of Tokyo.I liked the opportunity to walk around at leisure and as a short person,found it easy to access the space.

Impressive city view - and for free!. The whole Shinjuku skyscrapers district is quite impressive... with some truly amazing buildings and Tokyo Metropolitan Gov. Building is just one of them... What is of course most interesting for visitors is that you can go and visit observatory on 45th floor and you can visit it for free! We opted for early evening visit and it was really amazing - Tokyo city lights all around... very recommended!

Must visit. Completely free to visit. Staff even gave us a talk about all the different buildings and how they make them earthquake proof.
Amazing view and surprisingly peaceful and quiet when we visited.

Tokyo from 45th Floor. Very easy to get to and it's free! Don't miss this wonderful building that is now promoting the 2nd time Tokyo will be hosting the Olympics (in 2020) 56 years after it hosted one in 1964.
The view is amazing and certain building structures were just grand.
Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (TMG) is impressive, I must say.

TOKYO FANTASTIC VIEWS AND IT'S FREE!!!. From the outside, the structure is impressive with high twin towers, each with an observation e in deck on the top floor. The view of TOKYO is impressive!!!! Tokyo sky tree near asakusa also has an observation deck and an impressive check structure.If you are hungary at lunch, you can eat in the employee lunch room. They have life like samples of food/$/and a number. You first go to a ticket cashier, and then another line to get food. I sat at the window.

Best view obstructed!. There's no entrance fee to go up there which is great. The view is impressive BUT.... they've built a restaurant on the side you want to see! The restaurant has the best view towards the harbor. They have built walls around it and only customers may go inside.
Great, free view of Tokyo. The view is great, the view is free, but it's a bit camera-unfriendly (brightly lit, tripods are not allowed). I think it's worth a visit if you're in the area.
Great views. Free entry to both towers with fast trip up in the elevators and great views weather permitting. Unfortunately we couldn't see Mt Fuji as it was covered in clouds.
Great View of The City for Free. From the 45th floor one has a great view all over the city FOR FREE! If you travel on a budget it is a great alternative to the Tokio Tower or Sky Tree.

What a view. Staying close by we were guided to visit the observation floors. Admission is free and the views are amazing - obviously rather weather dependant.There is a small snack bar/restaurant on the observation floor - although we didn't use it.Lifts were busy which meant a little wait in a queue to come back down.
Great City Views. Excellent city views, free entry and on good days you can even see Mt Fuji. Quick lift ride to the top of the northern tower will get you there.

Good overview of the city. This is a nice place to go if you will like to see Tokyo from abouve. It's free, and Sunday morning it was no waiting time. If you will see Tokyo by night, this is the place.After you have been to one of the two towers, you will need to go down and take the elevator up to the next tower. Recommen to do so.If your able to, go on a day with clear skies and you might see Mount Fuji in the distance
Must visit when in Shinjuku. My wife and myself stayed in Shinjuku and we walked there at night. Beautiful view of the city and its free. Must view at nice as its a nicer view.

Some of the best views of Tokyo and it's free!. Super fast lift to the top (almost ) of the building and you get 360 degree views of the city. Very pleasant restaurant to relax in and shop with decent gifts.

Good views of Tokyo if it's a clear day...and it's free. There are seven buildings in Tokyo where visitors can access a high-rise observation deck for spectacular 360 degree views of the city. Most have (nearly) floor-to-ceiling glass panels thereby offering the maximum amount of viewing space while one is open-air. Because they're all at different heights and are located in different parts of the city, the perspective from these galleries do differ slightly. However, the most important thing about the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office viewing gallery is that there's no admission fee. And in a city like Toyko, that's a benefit not easily found. Located on the 45th floors of both the north and south towers, and slightly over 200 metres high, it's possible to see the elusive Mount Fuji...but only on a clear day. Nevertheless, explanation panels are available to point out other highlights around the city. There is also a small souvenir shop which sells snacks. Note the opening hours of the observation decks - only the north tower is open till late and night.

Fantastic views with no entry fee. Probably the best place to get a 360 degree view of Tokyo. Go up the South tower (it's completely free) and there is a little cafe at the top if you want to grab an overpriced drink whilst looking at the views. Tokyo doesn't have much of a skyline for such a big city but it's still worth seeing. One of the locals also told us that on a clear day you'll also get a good view of Mt Fuji.

great view. we visited both decks and found south tower is good enough for the view. walk around and follow the poster to the get an idea of city layout, it was cloudy and could see mt. fuji. short walk from shinjuku or metro line exit at the north side of the building. its free!

Good views. we decided to have a meal here in the restuarant. there was a pianist playing and we had to pay 500 yen each for this. we didnt realise we also had to pay 1000yen to just sit in the restuarant. the food was small. I had a chicken leg with veg. I wouldnt recommend the restaurant but definietly go to the observatry and look around.

Amazing view for free. Take time to visit this tower, during the day, evening, views from here are always amazing. You can visit both entrances, both building. For posh lovers, take a drink in the bar/restaurant on the top of the building.
Free entry to get a beautiful view!. Loved the fact that it stayed open late ,entry I believe even beyond half past ten at night. The support staff was very polite and systematic.

Great views...for free. Easily walkable from the shinjuku shopping area this building offers great views if the city. What's better is that it's free! The toy / souvenir shop had some great gifts too (overpriced though). Beats paying for the sky tree

Toy Store on one of the viewing towers. We actually went for the toy store and got a great view while we were there! Also its free, so you can't beet that. It's a quick visit, but if your there do it.

Stunning city views. Free entry to top floor observation deck. Worth a visit at night. Had to queue for less than 5 minutes for security and express elevator.
Coffee shop and souvenir shops at the top but the real reason to visit is the stunning 360 degree views.
Great city view free of charge!. Great vista of the city free of charge. The Govt Office also offers free tours in English, just ask at tourist information as it's worthwhile and very interesting.
Great views and free. Located about a 10 minute walk away from the station it is fairly easy to find. You get some great views of tokyo and it is free.

All round views. The first place we visited on arriving in Tokyo. The view from the observation deck gave an overview of the city. The locator boards help you to understand the views. There is a small cafe at this level. It's open late to see the night-time scene.

Massive structure; breath-taking observatory view.. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government building is perhaps the tallest skyscraper there is in the Shinjuku District, thus providing a very good view of Tokyo. Visiting the observatory is free and if one is lucky enough to come on a clear day, Mt. Fuji is can be viewed from afar.

wow. you can reach it easily from the subway exit. the entrance is free and in a few seconds by elevator you reach the 45th floor of this majestic palace.from here the view of the amazing tokyo is marvellous.i suggest a visit at the sunset... very romantic

the observatory is cool and free of charge. The TMG building is right in the middle of Shinjuku area and very close to my hotel. We went there at 5 p.m, and the staff welcoming us in front of the elevator that would take us to the observatory floor. When we got to to the observatory floor, the view of Tokyo is amazing, we could see so many buildings up there and there's no charge for it! I recommend you to go there when visiting Tokyo.
Tallest view of city. This was great. A short walk west of the Shinjuku station the building has a 45th floor free observation deck.

Best bang for your buck. For a free observation deck this place is awesome. After going up here, we had no desire to pay big money to go up the Tokyo tower. The lines get a bit long, but it moves quickly. The elevator to go up is on the lowest floor, near the metro station entrance

Great place to see city of Tokyo from the observatory floor. There are tourists information offices for all you need to know before starting off to explore Japan in level 1 and 2(Japanese way, Ground floor is Level 1).

AMAZING VIEWS. Easy to locate. Amazing views from the observatory. Free admission. Souvenir stores. Restaurant with fixed choice menu where you can enjoy a meal or a snack with views across Tokyo City.
First time visit . Love that we didn't have to queue and that it was free to head up to the observation deck. There are a few government buildings that are interconnected which was pretty cool.
free <3. before walking around shinjuku, you should visit there... because it's free and you can see japan from 45th floor...Lol

Great Views!. Went to the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan building twice during my visit to Tokyo. I had hoped to see Mt Fuji but is wasn't to be. Fabulous 360 degree views of Tokyo. Took some great pictures from the top of the building. It was great to get a visual of the layout of Tokyo. When you are on the ground surrounded by skyscrapers in every location you can't see things that are only 1/2 mile away. You can view the locations of the stadiums, parks and other landmarks from the top of the building.Highly recommend and free!

Amazing views. This is definitely worth a visit, it's free so you can't go wrong. I went up on both the north and the south side. Amazing views of Tokyo! I may go back to see what it's like a nighttime since its only 10 mins from my hotel.
Excellent value. As the view was excellent and free and we didn't have to queue, I was very happy. We saw Mt Fuji too.

Beneficial. Great place to see Tokyo and all its glory. I didn't experience the night time scenery but the daytime was good regardless. you can see the sunset around 4pm. I didn't see Mount Fuji due to the weather but its free so re-entry on any other day is definitely recommended. I couldn't due to lack of time but I can honestly say that Im glad I stopped here.
Awesome views. Free, retro-futuristic, place looks like a Transformer - in night time the lights of Tokyo blink beautifully.

Great views, very impressive!. The view is certainly very impressive. It's free, so if you like high places come here. Might be best to come at night - the view is spectacular and there's less people. The entrance might be a bit hard to find, so make sure you know where you're going beforehand.

What a view!. I had no idea Tokyo sprawled out so far in every direction! For a free attraction this is definitely a must-see. It was a lovely clear day when we went and we could see almost all of Mt Fuji and got incredible views in every direction.
Great views and free. These buildings are literally two minutes from the hotel we stayed at. It is free to get into both towers and give amazing views of the city

beautiful view for free. The observatory deck at the Tokyo Metro Govt Tower has one of the nicest views of the city, and its free! If you're staying in Shinjuku this is a good place to hit up on a clear day. We went there on our first day in town and it really gives you an idea of how huge Tokyo actually is. Highly recommend!

Awesome views!. Loved that the observatory was free. I wish i had watched the sunset from here, you can get pretty much 360 degree views with access to both towers. Would definitely recommend making a quick stop here if you're in Shinjuku.

Nothing to rave about. I went to the observatory deck a long time ago and was really impressed by the view. However, this time round, I was totally disappointed. The glass was not clear which affected the view. Secondly, there are 2 hugh sourvenior shops on that floor, it makes it very difficult to enjoy the view at night due to the reflection.

Amazing View. This is definitely worth a visit. The Government Office is easy to find by subway or metro and access to the Observatory is free. There are two sets of lifts on the ground floor, one for the north tower and one for the south tower. My husband & I arrived around 4.30pm and there were no lines to the lifts. There is a quick security check on your bags, a short wait for the lift and then you ride up to the 45th floor. The view is amazing and you can see Mt Fuji on a clear day. The floor area is spacious and there is also a cafe/restaurant and souvenir shop to. If you need to find your way to another sight, there is also a Tourist Information office on the ground floor. Highly recommend.

Free and Fantastic Tokyo View. Within walking distance of Shinjuku Station this is well worth a visit. Easy to find and with very friendly staff. The 45th floor Observation Decks afford wonderful panoramic views of Tokyo and beyond. Despite the sunny day, Fujisan unfortunately hid behind clouds in the distance and this is often the case. No queues and no crowds.
The best view. From the 45th floor, one can see the very best view of Tokyo. There are souvenir shops on the same floor as well, and a nice restaurant. Do not miss to go up there, once in Shinjunku.

Great View of Tokyo. There are two observation decks from the bldg. Both have amazing views of Tokyo and beyond. From one side you can see Mt Fuji. If you're a fan of buildings and architecture, you'll find plenty to see from here. The Cocoon Bldg is right there and is spectacular. Downstairs is a nice gift shop. The courtyard of the bldg has beautiful statues. Definitely worth an hour stop out of your trip time.

PANORAMIC VIEW OF TOKYO & IT'S FREE... We visited the North & South Observation Decks on the 45th Floors..The view was amazing...altho the sky was cloudy at that time..August 2014...& Mt Fuji was nowhere in sight, yet Tokyo @ 360-degree view was awesome. If you don't have the time to tour the city, go to TMG bldg. There's also a food court on the 32nd or 34th floor which serves authentic japanese food.

See Mt. Fuji from up there... for free. ... if the weather is good. From the Government Office you can see the whole city and if you are lucky also Mt. Fuji. In the middle of the observation deck there is a small souvenir shop and a coffee place. Best thing though that you can go up there for free. I don't think that you can see much more from the Skytree or any other observation deck where you have to pay to get up there.

It's free and beautiful. Why would you not take the time to go here if you're in Shinjuku?! It's so pretty and the staff are really friendly. I went on a Saturday and there were no lines at all. The views were amazing.

Great views and helpful staff. We visited the observation deck on this building when we visited Tokyo in March 2012. Easy to locate, the views are excellent. We saw Mount Fuji which apparently is quite a rare occurrence. English speaking staff were happy to help us work out the various buildings in the view. And all free!

Fantastic view!. How can you not like this place? 45 floors up with a FREE observation deck! And we were greeted by a host who spoke perfect English and gave us a guided tour, pointing out all the important sights of the area. Also pointed out that free maps in English were available down on the 2nd floor. Gift shop prices were reasonable too.

Good place for a first stop. It was next to our hotel Hyatt Regency, but we only visited at the last day. Going on the first day or earlier on your trip would be ideal. You get a panoramic view of tokyo city. Advisable to go around 3-5pm.
Great views for free!. Great views over Shinjuku and the Tokyo Business District. And free!! It's close to the station so definitely worth it.
Very nice views for free. Perfect spot to view Tokyo, beautiful by night. And it is all free. There are some turishops at the observation deck and a bit crowded. But worth a visit
Boring place. The good point about TMGO is just free sightseeing and free observation deck, and good scenery around this building.

Good visit for free. The building is very easy to find. There are signs in Shinjuku train exit going to the building. The observatory is in 45th Floor and is open until 10PM for free. We went there at night and appreciated the view of the entire area. There is no limit on how long you can stay in the observatory. You can go whenever you want. You can also buy some souvenir items there.

For a different panoramic view.... I tried this skyscraper and I found it easily enough by following the directions of people gave me and comparing the photos here on tripadvisor, I have to admit that from the nearest subway station this building is a bit 'hidden and hardly visible, except that if I had not read reviews about it not I would have never been able to visit it, totally unknown. Not very crowded, lift fast enough reaches the top floor, where a huge glass window at 360 degrees projected over the city to enjoy a panoramic view quite good. Sky Tree is not the obvious but being totally free it's ok! One side of the top floor is closed and is occupied by a restaurant lounge bar. The panoramic view of much of the city in particular of the Shinjuku district. Beautiful at night with all the surrounding buildings lit and if you are very lucky you can also see Mount Fuji. All in all a positive experience, maybe it is a bit 'hard to take pictures when is getting dark outside, with the reflection of light inside the photo did not come out perfect.

Amazing views!!. The views from the top of the building are amazing - I went in the daytime and went back at night. It is not far from Shinjuku station and is very easy to find. And it's free!!! Definitely worth a visit!
very modern building. The Tokyo met govt office is very modern building as one of the architect experimented with the government money
Miss it and weep! :). The visit to the top floor for fantastic views of the city and Mount Fuji is a must! Miss it and weep! :)
Definitely worth it. the view from the top 45th floor is wonderful, and for free! go at sunset. You can see Mt Fuji on a clear day!

Brilliant and free - fantastic views. Fantastic sky scraper views. Shop and restaurant at the top, well worth a visit and about 2 minutes walk from the Hilton Hotel. Gift shop was excellent vfm. It was easy to find and quick to get in - a quick bag check and short q. Well worth making effort if in the area.

Incredible View - For Free!. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building doesn't really require a lengthy review. Basically, all you need to know is that it offers a 360 degree view of Tokyo from 202 meters (660 feet) above ground free of charge and that view is spectacular! In fact, I would say this is an unmissable attraction when in Tokyo.
Awesome sunset view. Loved the 360° view of Tokyo. Entry is free, no fee. I recommend to go there around sunset time. If there is no fog, you might be lucky enough to get to see Mt Fuji (Fuji-san)!

A nice and quiet observation deck to enjoy the view. plus it's free.
The entrance is a bit hard to find. Very short line up.
The souvenir shop at the ground level is very small, however, provides good selections of items such as bookmarks at very reasonable price.

THE Place to start your visit to Tokyo. First grab some maps (free!) from the ground floor tourism center and then get up to the observation decks (free!) to get your bearings straight for your visit.

Excellent view for free. Great view of Tokyo and free of charge. Very nice alternative if you dont want to go to Tokyo SkyTree. You can go to nearby park after and it is very nice to stroll in Shinjuku, as the streets are almost empty (if you came when everyone is at work).

Excellent view of the city. Excellent stunning view of Tokyo and admission is free. Open both day and evening. Absolutely worth a visit. It is nice to visit one viewpoint to see Tokyo by night and Another by daytime.

Great!. You can go at the 45th floor for free and enjoy a beautiful view of the city, until 11 pm.
There you can find an elegant restaurant and an interesting shop too.

Near to Hilton Hotel - 2 blocks away.. It's free. You can go up to enjoy Tokyo Skyline and it's just two blocks away from Hilton. Just walk straight on and it can be identified with a somewhat "H"-shaped building

Big and beautiful City Hall. Entrance is free, nice viewes from top.
You can see mount Fuji at a clear day.
At the top there are little shop with nice souvenirs to buy

Good view from top considering its free. Close to subway so easy to find (although we found it thanks to our guide) and it gives a good view from the top. Being a govt building its free to go up and if you can ignore the tacky giftshop at the top it is worth a visit
Nice View. the tow tall towers here are ideal for affording stunning views of Tokyo. You can see Mount Fuji from the towers.

Terrible. Visit a Different Observation Deck. This is easily the worst observation deck I have ever visited. The deck is inside, with large windows. However, there isn't a very good view of the skyline. Furthermore, since you are inside and the room is well-lit, taking a picture is nearly impossible unless you wish to see your reflection within the picture. Overall, I was very disappointed and would not recommend this particular site to anyone. Find one that is outside and higher up.

Brilliant views of Tokyo. We visited on a Sunday and chose to go up the South tower. Staff were so friendly and helpful in directing us to lifts etc. At the top there were amazing views, each wall had almost ceiling to floor windows with a different view of the city. We took some excellent panorama pictures when we were there. On clear days you can see Mount Fuji, unfortunately it was too cloudy the day we went.There's a nice cafe in the middle of the observation floor and the prices (looking at the menu) weren't too bad.Worth visiting for the breathtaking views over the city, especially as it's free!

EXCELLANT BIRDS EYE VIEW OF TOKYO. Why pay at the SkyTower when this is free.360 degree view of Tokyo and on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji so I was told. I went back of a night to see the night of Tokyo and again amazing.Only one tower was open both my visits but my night visit the tower was open till 11.30pm.Again this city just offers so much and one does not have to go far to find it.When you leave the tower walk through the underground to the rail station just to experience this hub of electricity with shops and people so many people.Or walk across the court yard to see the many sculptures on display.

Great Views!. This is a highly polished, easy way to see the city skyline. It closes at 5:30 so you can't see it at night unless you visit in winter, but the views are incredible! City in every direction! There are two observation decks - one on the north side and one on the south side. You should use different elevators for each deck, but both are very big and easy to find. Just follow the green "observation deck" signs. Helpful volunteers on the 45th floor give more information about the buildings you can see and can even recommend other places to visit nearby. Great experience!

Excellent view . We visited this free observation tower on our first day in Tokyo which was a great place to start our visit. The place was very calm and quiet. On a semi- cloudy day we could just make out the outline of Mount Fuji. The Seaside Top offers a better view at night. We also enjoyed a great iced coffee on site.

Good view and free!. This is nice to check out when you inevitably pass through Shinjuku metro station (the biggest and most complicated station that I have ever visited).
This is on the 45th floor, which is more than high enough to see a panaramic view of the city
Free guided tours. This is the administration building in Tokyo, and offers guided tours in english. Views from the top are amazing.

Perfect city view for free. See the whole city from here! There's no cost and plenty of space and windows up top. We were there in the morning (8-9 am) with no wait and only a few other people up top. No need to spend your money at the Sky Tree or Tokyo Tower when you get the perfect view from here.
Great views of Tokyo. Great views of Tokyo (especially because it's free), but get there early to avoid having to queue. When we were there they had free guided tours as well, which were really good.
On a clear day... It is something that you should do as the views are magnificent and it is free. Sadly, Fuji-san was hidden by cloud.

Fantastic view for FREE. If you want to enjoy the aerial view of Tokyo freely please don't miss TMG office 45th floor. It is
about 10 min. walk from Shinjaku station.
"Highly" attractive and free. The free elevator whisks you to the 45th floor for an unparalleled 360 degree view of Tokyo. Walk all around the observation floor. Food on top may be pricey.

Great view of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji. Get to the top observation floor. High speed elevator takes you to the 45th floor. Very vast and comfortable at the top and did not feel crowded, even there were lots of people. The view is fantastic as we were there just before sunset. The view of Mt Fuji was gorgeous. We were lucky when we got there. Shinjuku is on the west side of Tokyo and much closer to the mountains including Mt. Fuji. Compared to views from Tokyo Tower or Tokyo Skytree, though much lower at 600 ft, I think the view from this building is much better with more green and mountains. Looking to the east you can see the great views of multitude of skyscrapers of Tokyo. The observation floor stays open until 11:00 PM which is rare in Japan. Nice cafe and bar here too.Only problem, it was quite a walk from Shinjuku JR Station. I learned that you can be closer taking the subways. But that's extra when you have JR pass.Worth the visit.
Great view for free!. There are many viewing platforms in Tokyo, but this one is for free! Also this place wasn't crowded like others.

Free cityscape view. The attraction is free and offers views from the 45th floor, 202m above the ground. The glass is slightly tinted and fairly clean offering some good views over the city.The South tower offers better views over the Meiji Shrine area. In the afternoon this had better views over the city due to the location of the sun. If you are in a rush and don't have time for both towers I recommend the South tower over the North.Both towers have a shop and a cafe.The views were quite good and on a clear day you can see the city of Tokyo spread out before, you all the way to the horizon. I do think the view from The World Trade Centre is better as you get 360' view over the city. Part of view at the metropolitan government tower is blocked by the other tower that makes up the government offices. However, it is free so do go take a look.

Great views.. The views are fantastic from the viewing floor of city hall and its free! We received a free tour from the observation floor by a very nice woman. She knew everything about Tokyo and its history.

Free city views. It was a bit cloudy the day we went so we couldn't see Mt Fuji, but do you get great city views for free!! We took the underground walkway from the station and it is well signposted so easy to get there and maybe a 10 or 15 min walk from the station.
Definitely worth a visit.
fabulous views. The viewing towers are on the 45th floor on both the north and south tower.... Great views from both buildings
Free City views. Allows you to see all of the city and Mt Fuji on a clear day for free. Use the subway under pass to avoid walking in the sun.

Best city views for free. We caught the subway to Shinjuku to this impressive office tower. The best part of going to the observation deck is it is free and open to the public. Although it was not the perfect weather conditions and we could not see Mt. Fuji, we enjoyed the views of the city and its surroundings. The massive and modern skyscrapers in Tokyo reminded me of New York. It is indeed a big city.
Amazing view!. Can't believe this is free! Brilliant views at sunset ; apparently when it's very clear you can see all the way to Mt Fuji. Worth coming to see the skyscrapers in Shinjuku area.

great view. Within walking distance of Shinjuku station. There is also a shuttle bus service that takes you from the station for around 100yen pp. Really great views of the city with café and souvenir shop. We were there on a Friday afternoon and it was fairly empty. Definitely worth a look.

Vast. We walked from Shinjuku to this place. Its huge and quite impressive but its also a lot of concrete. I did wonder why so much space was waste though especially given it is so much at a premium in Tokyo.

Great free attraction.. If you're in the area, take a moment to go up the TMG offices. It is completely free, and you get a 360 view of Tokyo. There is plenty of signage, and you can go up the north or south tower, or both.In the observation area there are cafes and souvenir shops.

Great views. Best travel directions would be to take the skyline from the airport, then the metro. Note: Don't confuse the subway and metro, they're different lines in Tokyo. Note this when buying metro/subway day passes.

Quite the view, but wished it opened earlier.. The views of the city from the top of the building were spectacular, but we had to kill over an hour waiting for the building to open at 9 am. Go stroll through the nearby park, it's pretty nice too.

Its all about the views!. Tokyo Government Offices is a" must do " purely just for the panoramic views of Tokyo from the Observatory 45th floor. On a clear day one can see Mt Fuji in the distance. Its one of Tokyo's landmarks & admission is free. There is a North & South Tower ( 243 meter tall ) offering fabulous 360d views of Tokyo. The building is used to house the headquarters of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government. One can walk 10 mins via the tunnel west exit of JR Shinjuku Station to the Tokyo Government Building or catch the train to Tocho-mae Station on the Oedo Subway Line to the basement level of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building.The Observatory has toilet's, café and a souvenir shop. The North Observatory remains open at night which is popular for viewing Tokyo at night.

Nice view, but boring building. After seeing some of Tadao Andos arcitecture in the Seto inland sea,I must admit I was a bit disappointed with the architecture of this building. In my view, it is pretty boring. But on a clear day, the view is fantastic and well worth a visit. I'd recommend the south tower.

Bird's eye-view of Tokyo. In a city where almost everything is expensive, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office offers a great view of the vibrant city for free. There are two observation decks (North tower and South tower), and I think it is from the South tower that you can see Mount Fuji better. There are souvenir shops on both decks (North has more toys, South has more Japanese-related items) and I think the items are reasonably priced. The view area is at the 45th floor of both towers, and once you are done, you can alight on the 2nd floor. The building is connected to the Tocho-mae Station on the Oedo Subway Line, which is located at the basement.

Finally, something free.... I think coming here was a relief for my dad as he did not have to take out his wallet. If you're in Shinjuku, I highly recommend going up to the observation tower to have a look around the city. We went on a not brilliant day but we could still see most things clearly and point out all the places we already visited. There's also a tourist information centre on the 1st floor where you can find maps of other areas that are pretty handy for getting around (I suggest ignoring the attraction and shopping suggestions though if you're on a budget).

Great views of Tokyo - and it's free!. Visited this place on a friend's recommendation. There are two towers you can go up (North and South tower), both offering wonderful views of Tokyo. On certain days it is possible to see Mount Fuji, but not when we went - too much heat haze - but that didn't matter too much to us. This place can get quite busy, so it is advisable to do the least busy tower first. There are restaurants and souvenir shops in the building, but I didn't use them so cannot comment accordingly. However, for brilliant views of one of the world's great cities (and it's free), this is highly recommended.

Best things in life are FREE!. Very nice to get a free high level elevator ride and great view (with indicator maps) to boot. Sure, tons of tourist shopping occasions while you are there, but up to you if you go for it. Entrance to North Tower was easy enough to find, but it seems that the most interesting view direction is taken over by a restaurant. For 1500Ypp for lunch not even a bad price for Tokyo standard. Lunch with a view :)

Observation Tower. It is the highest building in Shinjuku, aircond and free. There's gifts' shop and a restaurant which you can relax in.. You can see Tokyo with bird's eye view at this 45th storey high observation tower. On good weather, you may gleams Mt Fuji too. However this observation tower is close before the office ends. I would recommend you spent less than two hours here.

Shinjuku Metro Government Building. If you are staying at Hyatt Regency at Shinjuku, you can take the free shuttle to Shinjuku Station. This Metro Govt. Building is only 5 minutes short walk from the station. It is free and no fees to get in. You can go to the top floor and see the clear view on the city. On a very clear sunny day, you can see Mt. Fuji. There is a cafeteria in the building and one can get a reasonable lunch there. You can get your souvenirs in the gift shop on the observation floor. If have time, it is worth to check it out.

Free viewing platform. This building was recommended by a friend. It is a great opportunity to access an amazing viewing area and is absolutely free. You can catch a lift up to the viewing deck for a panoramic view over Tokyo at no cost whatsoever. A great alternative if you don't want to pay for Tokyo Tower or the Skytree.

Great view for those on a budget.. About 5 minutes walk from shinjuku station, and you can have a panoramic view for free! Great for those on a budget. Do note though that you may not be able to see very far if the day is hazy.

Great views for free. As others have said it is free and for that it is a win win. Only one side was open on the day our visit but it was well worth it even though it was a little cloudy. Located not far from the busier parts of Shinjuku the local area around these offices is rather clinical scattered with big offices. Its still worth a stroll and the view from the top floor gives a good view of how big the city is. From there you can look down at other buildings, parks and the traffic. Mt. Fuji was not visible on the day of our visit. There is a small gift shop and eatery located on the observatory floor - handy for some souvenirs and a quick break. If in Shinjuku make it a must see visit and it won't cost a cent (or yen!!)

Nice view, free . Went there at around 10am. Good view from the 45/F. It was a little hazy that morning, otherwise it would have been nice to see mount Fuji as well. Nothing much up there, except the ordinary souvenirs for sale. Worth a trip. Free admission.
Free!!!. It's free, and for that reason it's brilliant. I've been both during the day and at night, and there were almost no lines.Very enjoyable.

Interesting!. Very large building with interesting architecture. There is a tourism office there with lots of information. They have volunteer tour guides who will take you around and tell you about the building. There is a free observation deck you can go up and get a good view of the city. Well worth some time.
Free views. Free to enter, on either north or south side. Great views of tokyo but beyond that, nothing much else, if the weather permits, you may see mount fuji

Skyscraper visit on a budget. The best thing about this is that they don't charge admission fee; and it is so convenient as it is just around the corner of Tochomae station.On top, you can see great views of Tokyo. But nothing much beside that. There is a gift and toy shop at the top, but that's about it.If you happen to be around Shinjuku, worth pay a short visit to this building.

impressive... the building is in shinjuku area.we can find many tall buildings around the area.one of them is the cocoon tower.the building is free to get in.people say we can see mount from the top but the weather at that was very hot that we couldnt see the mountain. we also can buy souvenirs at the top. like many tower here we also can see tokyo from the top of the building. down outside the building there is an arena that look like the we can see in rom. very impressed with the tall and modern built building around it. should go there if going to tokyo.

Great viewing. Went to the govt building in late afternoon, waited in short line for elevator ride to the 45th floor where you can see great views from all sides of the building. They even have signs at each window so you can identify what you are looking at. On a clear day Mt Fuji is visible. The space in the middle of the floor is a toy/souvenir shop which is annoying, but we tried to ignore it (hard with kids!). However you can't beat the free views!

free and beautiful view of tokyo. Went during the day and at night and had a great view of the city, you can see the different view from both buildings during the day but only from one building at night. Great view !

Free and beautiful view of Tokyo!!!. Go out the west gate at Shinjuku station, it'll be a 10-15min walk. It's free and you ride to the 45F. I wanted to go in the South Tower but it closed at 5pm. So we ended up going to the other tower which stays open til 11:30. It was a beautiful view. It would've been perfect if the lights inside the bldg were off. You could see the reflection off the glass when you take a picture. But you can't really complain for a free view of the city!

Great view of the city landscape.. Located 15 minutes walk away from Shinjuku station, this is one of the best free attraction that Japan have to offer. Walking to the building, you will notice many homeless Japanese staking out at the park and compound around the building. It’s really thought provoking to seeing this other side of Japan as the government doesn't have in place a solid social welfare system. There are two towers that you can access for the view of Tokyo. I was at the west one which closes earlier at around 6pm. Sitting at the top of the tower, and drinking a nice cup of coffee while enjoying the great view of the surrounding was a great way of experiencing Tokyo. The tourist information counter is also located here on the 1st level where you can obtain information for your visit in Japan. Overall, would strongly recommend a visit here.

Great View of Tokyo... and its free. As we lived in Shinjuku area it was easy to get to the tower, the view at night was fantastic. There were no lines to get in and no money was paid! Can you ask for more?
Great view. Beautiful view over the Tokyo skyline and free. Just take the elevator from the first floor to the top.

Great views for free. Tokyo has lots of city viewpoints but this is probably the best because it's free and there's hardly ever a queue. Our hotel was nearby so we visited twice for daytime and night time shots.
Nice view. Nice view of the city for free. You can see the parks, the most important buildings and all the important places.

Views to die for..............and FREE!. The 45th floor of these imposing towers, offers a view of the massive sprall of Tokyo without the hype and seemingly endless queues of the new SkyTree. You can quiclly board a lift, without spending your valuable, limited traveller's time in long impersonal queues - Japanese are lovely people but are loath to expose their very limited English. Once on the observation floor you can stroll about at your leisure and with the aid of signs at each window, displaying good English descriptions, see all those places and things you wish you had more time to visit. Again as with so many of Japan's greatest attractions - pray for a clear day - winter or autumn or a very lucky day for you and yours!
Excellent view of tokyo. This is again a Tower to see tokyo for free from a height of 250 meters.Excellent arrangement made by the govt for people to see capital Tokyo

Very nice city view from the top. This is one of the buildings in Tokyo, from where you can See the city of Tokyo very nicely. It is free to enter the building, so a definite must-go if you are visiting Tokyo as a tourist. However, we had to walk a bit to find the building. Also, it would only make sense to go up here, if the weather is nice and sunny - to give you a clear view over the city. There are souvenir shops in the viewing gallery, but is damn expensive to buy something from here.

free and great overal view of the shinjuku area. can see Mt, Fuji. visited this on sunny day. got to actually see Mt. Fuji!! There were some parts that you couldn't see because of the restaurant in one of the towers, but hey free is free!!
Great to see Tokyo at sunset. A free elevator to the 45th floor, you get about a 270 degree view of the Tokyo skyline, you can get the other 90 degrees if you want to sit and buy a drink.

Free Observatory Deck. There are lots of tall building and 2 structures like the Tokyo Skytree and Tokyo Tower in Tokyo that offers observatory decks or floors. But you have to pay an admission fee. The Metropolitan Government Office offers it for free and you can even choose between North or South tower. You can even lounge around and take a sip of coffee to rest after walking around the Shinjuku area. On a clear day you can even see Mt fuji. The view will be the same and best of all its FREE.

Visit Sky Tree Instead. Formerly the tallest tower in Tokyo, this location once offered unsurpassed views of Tokyo and beyond. However, the newly opened Sky Tree tower presents grander views along with shopping and dining options. If you don't have time for a trip to Sky Tree, and want to see the city from above, definitely check out the Metropolitan Government Office.

Free views of Tokyo. The views here are free, so you can't really complain. However, after reading guidebooks we were under the impression that these would be external views on the top - they are not, they are through glass still, but you can see very far on a nice day!That being said, it's definitely worth a trip if you don't want to pay for a view of Tokyo from above!

To visit during day and night too.. First didn't know that it was open by night so i went there during the day and was not disappointed. a laaaagarte panoramic view over Tokyo ! if you are lucky enough you can see fujisan from there too.The night view is also totally amazing.I would recommend this over Tokyo Sky tree as it's free and excellently located !
Good and free. I was looking for the tourist information when i found out the there is free viewing from this building It is not bad and free so if you are around this area it worth a visit.

Not spectacular, but a real bargain. The views of Tokyo isn't all that spectacular, but when compared to the cost of going to the Skytree Observation deck, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building is a real value. There are dedicated entrances to the observation level and the area is spacious and points out some of the Tokyo districts and historic buildings. It's an easy and great value in this crowded and expensive city.
Good price lunch. On top of the building there are several restaurants and it's very easy to pick your choice since they have food display with the price. The food is cheap and also good quality.

Nothing spectacular. If you will be visiting Tokyo Tower or Skytree, you could give this a miss as the view is not that spectacular from this building. We went there at night as it's just beside our hotel. Anyway, the entrance is free but if you would like to have a romantic dinner with a view, you could consider the restaurant up there.
Average. It doesn't cost you anything to go to the viewing deck but it's worth it to see Mt Fuji on a clear day.

Free Great City View. So my initial plan to Shinjuku was to visit the shopping centre within the metro station (yes , I spotted Isetan nearby from my pocket Lonely Planet guide, and immediately had some excuse to find some decent rain coat.... ). I split with my friend at the metro station, and we agreed to meet each other again in about 1.5 hours. I decided that I didn't need to be inside shopping mall for 1.5 hours, so I walked towards Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. At the beginning I didn't realize that there were observatory towers at the top of the building. As I arrived at the entrance, I realized that it was free, so I decided to give it a go. The view from above is really nice, in fact, it is one of the most descriptive viewing tower I have ever been (after the NYC's Empire State Building, but only because there is English auditory in NYC....). The view of the landmark skyscrappers were described with the photograph by the side of the viewing windows. You can find some other events' explanatory boards also, depending on what is the closest event in the city. There is nice looking restaurant there (I didn't try), and of course souvenir shop. I felt lucky to stumble into this spot, especially after cancelling to go up to Tokyo Skytree the day before (you need to pay for Tokyo Skytree). When I was done, I strolled back to the metro station, however the building complex nearby were also fabulous, with very well maintained gardens at the side of the street. I ended up walking towards Takashimaya Times Square (yes another shopping mall) afterwards.
Free Tokyo View. From the towers of the building, you can enjoy the view around Tokyo. A bonus of it is that it's for free.

Free, not crowded, and beautiful. It's a great destination that have no entrance fee and not crowded. The view is magnificent. It might not be necessary to go to both towers, but if you have time, it wouldn't hurt to take a look at both.
Nice view of Tokyo. 360 degrees view of the city for free. Easily accessible by Metro and a short stroll to the building.

Free city view but other services are declining. We were here two years ago and we were able to get a great city view of Tokyo , the services of an English speaking guide who provided us with explanations on different buildings and after that a free guided tour of the Imperial Gardens arranged by the Tourist Office located on the 2nd floor of the Building .  This time around , we still got the free City view , we also had breakfast ( excellent) on the same floor but we never found a guide to give us explanations ! Worse than that , when we showed up at 13.00 hrs to meet for the tour we had booked and received confirmation of our request , we were told that there was no tour available on that day and that we should have called prior to showing up !!!  We had considered so far that Tokyo had one of the most interesting places in the world for free services for tourists but unfortunately it seems to be a thing of the past !  We were luckier with our Tokyo Greeter whom free services we used two days later !

Free Tokyo city view. Can't argue with that. Thanks Trip Advisor people for pointing out a free and easy way of getting a good city view so close to the Hotel district. Easy to find and easy to ascend. Like the open area with gift shop and restaurant. Views very good. Though night views suffer with reflection issues from glass, especially for camera shots. Staff very helpful and welcoming. No brainer if you are in area.

Great place to see Tokyo. The Metropolitan Government Office is easy to find and easy to get into without hassle. Best of all, it's free! On a clear day, you can see Mt Fuji and even if it's overcast and smoggy, you can still see the jam-packed streets of Tokyo. There weren't too many people when I visited and the line-up to get in was pretty small. You have to have your bag checked when you enter the bottom of the building (standard) then take an elevator up. The views are stunning and it's a great place to see Tokyo, especially if you're on a budget.

Good view for free but the Sky Tree is better!. The building is very impressive from the ground level view. It's a striking futuristic twin tower structure and for me this was actually the best photo from the visit. I also visited the Sky Tree and Mori tower (Tokyo City view) which were far better but were 2000 and 1500 Yen respectively. Obviously this is free but I think if you were short of time I'd pass and do one of the others and of course don't mind paying the entrance! The reason they are better is because you get floor to ceiling views and a full 360 view, whereas with the TMG building one side is taken with a restaurant and it feels cramped to get a decent view. It's also not as high with Mori 52nd floor and Sky Tree at 350m Vs 45th floor. In terms of getting there it's in Shinjuku but the nearest station is Tochomae (E28). I visited at 5 pm on a Saturday and it was a 5 min queue but on leaving half an hour later it had grown considerably and the barriers were suggesting a 30 + min wait. Possibly there was a rush to catch sunset. In summary I think this was OK as it was free but would suggest the Sky Tree if you don't mind the entrance fee, BUT for the Sky Tree you MUST go early to avoid the queues.

on a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji. this is one of Tokyo's landmarks and has an observatory on the 45th floor (free). From there you can see much of the city spread out below you. It's an impressive view that puts the sheer size of this city into perspective. For us it wasn't quite clear enough to see Mt. Fujij - unfotunately.

Must see! - Panoramic view from Tokyo for free. Amazingly 360 view from Tokyo, for free! You get up to the 45th floor, and have a panoramic view of Tokyo huge buildings and can even see Mount Fuji! I was there from 5pm ultil the dawn and was amazing. At night Tokyo is even more beautiful with millions of lights and the view is even more incredible. Don't miss it for nothing!!!There's a restaurant as well, so it's prefect for a romantic diner.

Super freindly and free. It is almost certain that you will go to Shinjuku when visiting Tokyo, and to get the best out of your visit most likely you will visit the tourist information. We went for the TI, first visiting the one for Japan as we are travelling further afield, then onto the one specifically for Tokyo. Wow so helpful and so much information, a tip for the wise there is so much to do in Tokyo you will need to decide what sight are most important to you, they certainly helped us do that.Then we stepped a few steps to the left and we were boarding a fast lift to the observation floor where we had free views across Tokyo giving us a feel for its complexity. Toyko's government are to be commended for their treatment of their guests. Highly recommended.

Nice View. Free entry and open until 11.30pm means you can easily fit this in to your Tokyo itinerary. From the observation platform on the 45th floor you have a great view of nearby skyscrapers such as the Cocoon Tower. On clear days you are meant to see Mt Fuji. Other attractions are pointed out on photo boards around the observation area. There is a gift shop where you can get a hello kitty medal stamped to say you've been here. Even a vending machine of model trains. Back on the ground floor is a big Tourist Information Centre where you can stock up on maps.

Great views for Free!. It is quite a walk from central Shinjuku, though if you take the underground route there are some travelators (of the type found in airports) to provide some assistance. However, if the weather is good, the underground is not an interesting route. In good weather it is a very pleasant city walk.There is plenty of tourist information at ground level. It is a swift ride up to the observation level. And with good weather, what a lovely view. Fujisan is visible when there is no haze, and both SkyTree and Tokyo Tower can be seen 'together'.For good free-of-charge views over Tokyo, this is about as good as it gets. But the best views over Tokyo will remain that of the dearer SkyTree.

Not a must unless it's a clear day or you little money but plenty of time.. Being a working government building, the TMGO is not near much else and is not as simple to get to as other attractions but, if the day is clear with no rain or haze, the views are gorgeous. Downstairs is a tourism office with great information about all of Japan, guides who would genuinely love to take you on a tour of the buildings, and occasionally there is a small market set-up to sell specialty foods from the different regions. The viewing deck, in addition to the views, has a little gift stand and cafe. Entrance and the tour (if you want one) are free.

Great view. Worth a visit if you're already in the area and the best thing about it is it's free. There's a great panoramic view of Tokyo but the whole experience won't take longer than 30 mins so I wouldn't trek out there if you're not already in the area.

free view of the city from the top!. There are two elevators that takes you up to the observation floor, and this is the best free way of marveling the view of the city. There are some seating available, too, so you can bring your lunch!

Close early on Fridays. I read online that you could go up top to look out at Tokyo so I made the trip. I was under the impression they were open until at least 8 during the week so I went around 7 since it was dark out by then. When I made it to the buildings it was dark inside the lobby and there was no around. The doors were locked and it was closed. The building themselves were nice and good to see, but without going up to the observation area the trip was pointless.
Worth it. This is the best 360 view of Tokyo and its free! Shinkjuku stn is very close with lots of shopping and eateries so worth the time.
worth the walk. This was a real treat as it was free entry to the top of the building to see the great vista. The scenery around is beautiful and definitely worth a visit.
Great view. What a view. Nice place. It is for free. We saw it sunday morning and there were no crowds. Easy to find and there r other tourist infomarion in the building as well.

Breathtaking Views!. The views from both the observatories in both towers are beyond words. It is one of the best (and free!) ways to get a real feel for how huge Tokyo is. Both towers have a gift shop and cafe area where you can pick up a reasonably priced breakfast and take in the views. You can also visit the observatories in the evening, but beware, the queues for this can be long!!

Free observation tower. Go to the south tower first as it closed by 5 pm, north tower closed by 8 pm but it's unless as most of the view can be seen by south and in the north's best view is block by restaurant. If going for both, still south first as when coming down, you had to walk to north lobby to exit.The view is great, you can view lots of landmarks there and it's free.
Government buildings. Very impressive, surrounding area is great too, it's clean and there is a park and water fall, sometimes a market too, lots of big buildings

Great views and it's free. Went there early Sunday afternoon, not much of a queue and everything was orderly and moved quickly. Please note that there are separate lifts for the North and South Towers. Great views and there's a souvenir shop up on the 45th floor too. Worth going to check out the views plus it's free admission!

Visit just before sunset. It's hard to argue with free entry! It's actually a pretty good view of the city, with a restaurant and souvenir shop.Would recommend going around ~5pm to catch pictures of the day-view, and then stay until ~6-6:30pm to also catch the night-view with all the city lights lit up. Beautiful!

The top view you need from Tokyo. We followed the recomendations from other trip advisor reviewers and we did not regret.High enough (you do not need to go higher to see the city from the top) - on good days it seems you can even see Mont Fuji...No queues... at all... You get up immediately... and you have room on top... on the contrary we went to see SkyTree and the waiting time was 45minutes... we decide not to go up, after having the experience of the Metropolitan.And for free...It also stays close to the Shinjuku area (a very nice area of the city), so you can plan to do it together.

Great views of Tokyo from 45th South observatory. You can see Mount Fuji on a clear day - great views of Tokyo and it was free entry. The observatory restaurant prices seemed reasonable considering its location (menu out the front, didn't eat there)
Mediocre Views but Free. The view was not the best compared to other places in Tokyo but it was free. Also, there was a good souvenir shop inside so overall it was a positive experience.

Great views and free of charge. Great views from the top of the towers, they say you can see Mt. Fuji on a clear day, but whether you can or not the views of the city are magnificent.There is hardly no wait to go up the elevators and the operators are courteous and speak some English. It is also worth visit the open atrium and sculptures.
Great views and free. Wonderful views of Tokyo. We went up both in the morning and evening. Good souvenir shopping. Great outing especially being free.

Awesome view for FREE!!!. It's a short walking distance from Shinjuku station (around 8'). You can see this TWIN TOWERS clearly from Shinjuku station. There is an observation deck on each of North and South tower. To access to observation deck, use Observatory elevator on 1st Floor, (Note: there is a security check before you can get in line), line is moving pretty quick since elevator is SUPER FAST. Everything is fast in Japan, from internet to bullet train, sushi train and this elevator. Lol. Elevator's guides will take you up to 45th Floor. As soon as exit elevator, from a panoramic window, you can view the whole Tokyo (or almost) from 663ft above the ground . On a clear day, you can also view Mt Fuji (I took a picture from my cellphone, I could see just the top of Mt Fuji which covered with snow). Observation deck also has a gifts shop and cafeteria.I enjoyed this place a lot. The view is awesome and best of all, IT'S FREE. (Where can you find a free attraction in Tokyo? Lol).Tips: - Before you leave, don't forget to get all travel pamphlets from Japan National Tourist Organization (JNTO) office on 1st Floor. This is only place that I could find those pamphlets or brochures in English.- Depends on where are you coming from, these are trains that pass by Shinjuku station: Yamanote, Chuo, Keio, Sobu, Odakyu, and Marunouchi lines.

Nice view but not exactly a nice place to go to. The observatory point is indoor (no possibility to go outside) and it smells like cheap fried food because of the restaurant that takes up half of the floor. You get a good view and it's not too crowded, but the place is definitively not as beautiful as other skyscrapers I've been to

Amazing View But Too Much Souveniers To Choose From. Great view, worth to visit, and it's FREE. That sums it up.Oh no! This place has so many types of souvenirs you may spend a fortune and a large portion of your schedule trapped here!

Freebie but Goodie!. A short walk from Shinjuku, this venue is a must for a first-timer to Tokyo as it offers 360 views for as far as the eye can see. Whether you have a good experience or a great experience really depends on the weather so fingers crossed!For a Government building, security is fairly relaxed and you're not hurried along in any way to 'move along'. Best time to go would be in the afternoon around sunset so you can see the cityscape transform into a sea of neon lights!

Great spot for an orientation view of Tokyo.. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Buildings are a great option for visitors who wish to see the sprawling expanse of Tokyo and maybe a peek at Mount Fugi for free! Arrive early (opens at 9am) and get whisked to the observation floor for a breathtaking view of Tokyo spreading out in all directions.

Free entry, Well maintained and Convenient.. A better view and less troublesome way to enjoy the great view of Tokyo, altho its covered unlike Tokyo tower where you can stand and take photo open air. But the good thing about this is, Free admission. How did I get there, I went all the way by walking, from Shinjuku, pass Shinjuku Main Station, again to the west for another 15-20min walk, via a tunnel with people walking back and fourth to catch trains or get their lunch in work attire. Before reaching the TMGO, you will come across a huge bookstore which you can take a rest and read some books if you're solo-ing the trip taking time, else, follow the sign board, there will be Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office all the way from Shinjuku Area. With a little help from Google Map, things will be easy and simple.Once you exit the tunnel, look up, and look for the twin looking building which is the TMGO, walk towards it, pass a traffic light, it'll be on your left once you exit the tunnel and another 5 min walk. There is a restaurant located on the observatory level, and 2-3 stores for souvenirs, selling Tokyo Tower's goods, etc. Nice and clean washrooms too. Worth for a free and convenient observatory trip.
good place. great place to visit in tokyo, its not too far from train station, really near to other attraction around, just come around.

Good view and free. Most good views come at a price but this one is completely free! We went at night time and it was quite a good view but could have been better if it was darker inside the room. There are a few signs to explain the buildings that can be seen. The souvenirs for sale are interesting to look at as well. It might be better during the day but definitely worth a visit.
Free Tokyo view from 45th floor. Its free view of all Tokyo from 45th Floor. They have South & North Buildings, so dont forget to visit both.

Good view of Tokyo. We walked 15 mins-20 mins from Shinjuku station. Went up to North observatory as the South observatory was closed at 530pm. No entrance fee. Took a elevator to 45th floor for the view.

Great views. Free entry and no queue. Great view. Full of locals so that tells me its not a tourist trap. It was a bit hazy the day we visited but on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji from the south tower.
Free view from the observatory. Free city view during day and night from 45-th floor. Great way to see Tokyo from above. Souvenir shop inside.

good views are from the tower that closest sooner.. With a bright day you can get to ser Fuji and many of Tokyo landmarks. In winter also tokyo tower lit up. summer and spring it clases to early to get to see the lights at night.
It is free.

Tokyo view for free!. One of the best places to go to if you're not willing to fork out 2000yen for Tokyo Skytree but still get a good view of this amazing metropolitan. Be sure to pop by if you're in the Shinjuku area.

Great Views of Tokyo for free. Impossible to miss, there are directions here from Shinjuku Station and the building itself is impossible to miss. The views are great (not as good as Tokyo Skytree, but its free, so you have no right to complain) and you can see Mt Fuji on a clear day. Take either the south or north observatory, really good side trip to do

Excellent views over Tokyo for free!. The 42nd floor observation rooms in the two towers are free to access and open into the evening.We were lucky to visit on a sunny day when Mt Fuji was visible in the distance which was great.There is also a tourist advice centre on the bottom floor with free English speaking guides to show you around.

Better Than Sky Tree. After hear about the two hour wait at Sky Tree (just to purchase tickets!) we decided to divert to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office instead. No tickets required.No line when we arrived at 4pm (although there were corrals set up for a longer line) and we were whisked to the 45th floor by the fastest elevator I've every been in.Views were spectacular and definitely worth the visit. I've heard that visiting at dusk or after dark is spectacular. One of the towers is open until 11pm and has a bar with food and drinks.
Stop by. View from 45 floor observation deck is quite breath taking. We went up both the North and South Decks. The tourist information center is very helpful.

Free access to great views. We went at night, there was no queue. The views are great, although the windows are not set up for photography (lots of reflections and marks). Good place to pick up a post card as well.

It's free!. You can go up both towers and see the slightly different views from each. We did not manage to see Mt Fuji at all, too hazy. Do look out for reflections in the windows when you are taking pictures, it is almost impossible to avoid them.The explanation of how the building was constructed is on the wall in one of the towers (the one on the left as you go in) It is really interesting to hear how the method enables such huge interior spaces without supporting columns.Recommend you do go here.
Great View for Free. Open from 9 AM to 5 PM, completely free to go up. I recommend going to tower I and then going to tower J. What a view!!
Pricless view. Beautiful view over the city. Almost no waiting time at around 11:00. There is no charge for the two towers to go up there.

Amazing views of Tokyo. The views are simply amazing and show just how massive Tokyo really is! On a clear day you can see as far as Mount Fuji.
The best part is that there's no entrance fee!
There's a shop and a cafe, so you can buy some momentos while you're up there enjoying the views.

Well worth a visit. This time we actually visited the observation floors twice in the same day. A morning visit and a night time one. If you've got a little bit of spare time when visiting Tokyo it's well worth a visit. On a clear day a few years back I actually saw the snow peaked Mt Fuji which was a bit of a rare occasion. This time around she alluded us but it was still enjoyable experience none the less..... and it's free!!.
Beautiful building, great views. This is a masterpiece of design. The marble interior stunning too and the view from the observation floor is great. Admission is free as well.

Best view of Tokyo for free. Love the price. Excellent way to end our trip. Even got a pretty good view of Mount Fuji. Kirei! 360 degree view of Tokyo. Signs explained the famous building and places seen in each window. Fabulous!

Great AND free. Don't bother about paying for a building with a view when you can go here for free. We visited both towers, one in the day time (you can even see mount Fuji) and the other one in the night time and they were great. Night time we had dinner at the 'good view restaurant', it was our first night in tokyo and it just made it SO special! Fabulous view with lovely background music, great food, reasonable prices. Highly recommended. Queues were reasonably short and quick both times, especially night time, we went almost straight in.

A photographer's dream!. You'll be able to have the most beautiful and complete view of Tokyo from here. Even now, years later I look back at the photos that I shot and gasp. Well worth the trip. (Visited in 2011)

A Must See!. Absolutely worth the visit! This complimentary site offers a 360 degree, picturesque view of the entire city, all the way to the mountains. Accompanying the view from each window is a photo map pointing out key buildings and locations across the skyline. I took the time to go up both towers to see the full view. Each tower had restrooms, a restaurant, and gift shops.
Great view. We visited this building on a walking tour of the city. A great place to view the city. on a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji.

Beautiful view. Definitely worth of visit!! It's free and down stairs there is a tourist information centre where you can find new info about current exhibitions in Tokyo and a lot of materials about all 47 prefectures. The stuff is very helpful and kind. On a clear day you can see Fuji San and the mountains surrounding it.Also there are souvenir shops upstairs so if this is your last sight to see you can get some interesting presents from there.

Great views of Tokyo!. We were shown this place by our host family as an alternate to other places which were expensive and further from our accommodation. The view was fantastic - you could see almost all of Tokyo and we were lucky enough to see Mt Fuiji in the distance as it was a clear and beautiful day. Like other attractions, I would recommend visiting this place during off peak times as it is free and I could imagine it getting quite busy.

Great view, very cluttered. We dropped by after a day trip to Hakone as it is only a ten minute walk from Shinjuku station. Unfortunately, the south tower had closed by then (1730) so we had to enter the north tower observatory. There are some great views, especially as the lights came on in the evenings.However, be aware that it is pretty cluttered up there. I guess since it is free, they have to make some money back by putting a small restaurant and stalls selling souvenirs and toys to kids. As a result, navigating around when the place is crowded is a bit tricky plus the restaurant blocks off one entire side.For a free attraction, you can't complain - and it is still a buzz to see the city from so high. Views of Mt Fuji will depend on the weather. We were a bit unlucky that the air wasn't clear enough. Worth a visit but apparently the south tower is better so try and arrive earlier

A free view of Tokyo. There are many places where you can look down on Tokyo city. Some charge a lot and you may have to queue for quite a long time. This one is free and the queue is small. The observatory is on the 45th floor and on a clear day, you can get views of Mount Fuji.

Not a good winter visit - Nothing beyond the snowflakes. Fortunately, it was free. I was told that one could sight Mount Fuji on a clear day and February was not a good time with a day snow in tow. But the briefing given by the free friendly guide was good – informative. I enjoyed the coffee break in the café on the top floor which I think would have been filled on a clear day.

Fantastic view of the city. Well worth a visit, particularly as it is free to enter. I went up at sunset midweek which was an ideal time to visit. The cafe/bar at the top also looks out over the centre of Tokyo and was a nice relaxing way to watch the sunset over the city for relatively cheap food and drink.
One of the best views over Tokyo. The free observatory on the 45th floor is probably one of the best views over the city, truly worth a visit
Great Views. Get there early for no lines. The North Tower has the best views and gift shops. Too cloudy when we went to see Mt Fugi. There is also a rest room on the same level. One seat, one squat.
Must visit!. I think anyone visiting Tokyo should make this a priority - it's free of charge after all. Wonderful view from both towers - you can even see Fuji on a clear day.
Free views of Tokyo. A good spot to get a free helicopter view of Shinjuku & the broader Tokyo. Visited on a weekend, wasn't crowded. Would recommend.

Make sure it's sunny. Fantastic views from the observation deck on the 45th floor however ensure you head up on a clear day to see further.
The toy shop on her Northern Observatory is filled with fun souvenirs, a photo booth and places to make your face on a keyring so keep your coins handy!

Great view for free!. Why pay for a view in any city? They all have a free one. The TMG has done a great job of offering visitors a wonderful view of Tokyo. Super clean; great facilities; wonderful staff from ground floor to top. Clean benches to sit and enjoy view. Large cafe at top; people seemed to enjoy.Can get off at Shinjuku Metro Station. Easy walk from there, mostly in subway's tunnels. Or go one short stop more to Tochomae Station. Outside Tochomae look up for twin towers. That's your building. Easy.
Ok for a freebie. Top view of the city. I found the history and architecture of the building really interesting also, its also in english. Took some great photos.

It has a special meaning for me. I went to the observatory to say goodbye to Tokyo. It had been 1year and 3 months that I was living in Japan. I knew how much I would miss it!! At night, the lights are beautiful like stars in the universe. Looking from up there, the city takes another perspective, inviting us to reflect upon what we have become by the paths we took and how life was lived.I say it with great euphoria that my paths are leading to Tokyo again, as I will be taking my mom to sightsee the TMG observatory on April this year.
Free view of Tokyo (Shinjuku area). If you are in the Shinjuku area it is worth going to the government building for a free view of Tokyo. The queues are usually short too.

Must see!. This is a great (and free!) attraction to add to your Tokyo itinerary. I visited twice, once during the day and once and night and was amazed by the views of the city. It really gives you a great perspective on the size of Tokyo. I was lucky enough to be able to Mount Fuji on my day visit (South Tower). The views from each are slightly different: I think I preferred the South Tower for views and atmosphere of the viewing area.

Best free view!. We walked to the tokyo metropolitan government building with low expectations as it was free and we knew the tokyo tower and the skytree had similar views but cost around 1000yen. We went on a morning during the week and walked straight in, elevator to our selves and then up to an almost empty south tower. The views were spectacular and there were even helpful volunteers that would answer any questions. Later that week we payed over a thousand yen to get to the top of tokyo tower, and found the view to be worse then the TMG.

Stunning view - for free. Want to see Tokyo's huge city area with Mount Fuji in the Background, and at zero cost? go there and enjoy. For fotografers: there is still a glass window between you and the stunning view, bring polarizing filter.

Great views for free. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is definitely worth going to, even if you've been to the other towers in the area. Before I went to the TMG, I was at Sky Tree, and Tokyo Tower (even Kyoto Tower), and this didn't dissapoint me at all. I was able to see Mt. Fuji very clearly when I went, which was great since I couldn't see it from Tokyo Tower the day before. The fact that there was no entry fee makes it even better.

Get your bearings here!. We visited the day after we'd gone up the Tokyo Tower to the first level. From the TMG we were able to see Mt Fuji, when due to a haze, we couldn't see it from the Tokyo Tower the day before.Took a walk from the Shinjuku station, so enjoyed stunning architecture in the buildings surrounding here, so a wonderful way to see how big Tokyo is.We came up about midday and it wasn't overcrowded. There's a cafe there, but we didn't eat there. It looked a great place to spend some time at though. I should have bought some souvenirs there though, because some of the items I saw there, I didn't see again.

Must go for free view of Tokyo skyline. Since I was under a budget, TMG is such a great place to see Tokyo skyline. Go there during near sunset, so you can see both the view during the daylight, sunset and at night time. Definitely worth a visit!

Soo much better than Skytree. Free observatory, not as busy as the other ones, great 360 view, cafes and gift shops. A little hard to find, but just ask around and follow your map - you'll get there and you won't regret it.
