Daytime is better. I visited the building in the night, just before the closing hour. Last round and elevator is 10h30.The building is 240m (787-ft.) tall, the tallest building in Shinjuku disctrict, boasts two observatories located on the 45th floors of both its north and south towers, with access from the first floor where you have the Tokyo tourist center with a lot of useful information. The view is fascinating, but the problem is the inner light of the shop, it is really a problem. This is the reason why it is difficult to make good pictures....Nevertheless, the panorama is fantastic, there are a lot of information about the surrounding buildings and shops and a cafetariat in the middle. Even if it is quite far away from the center, its worht to visit, acces is easy by metro.One of the closest staions is Sinjuku, both for train and metro. Or take the Marunouchi metro line and get off at Nishishinjuku station, it takes 40 minutes from Chiyoda, 60 minutes from Asakusa district. Still 10 minutes walk from this station. It is well indicated where the bulindig is. One thing must underline: there is no entry fee to the bulinding, so you have a great view to the town for free. You will appreciate it in Tokyo....

view without yen. this is great..without spending a pie (yen) u can see top view north and south .. very good hospitality nice service .. Japanese.. great personalities honesty hospitality respecting others discipline... view from the top u can see the entire city... night upto 11pm they allowed to see .. very excellent...

Great views. Well worth going up here by day for the sensational views of Tokyo. Great view of Mt Fuji from here. You can also go up at night but it is quite well lit up inside so visibility from the top of the building isn't great.

A view for free. If you go to Tokyo, you probably would like to go to i view point, right? Then, go to this place because it is free and because you will see the entire Tokyo. Totally worth going. We spent around ten minutes there, and then we had an ok pasta (only 1 000 yen including a drink, which I think is fair because of the view) at the posh looking sky café on the same floor.

Best Free View of Tokyo!. Want to get a great view of the city without paying the crazy costs of the Sky Tree? This is perfect! It is totally free to go up and the view is great. Easy to get to in Shinjuku as well!

Grand Entrance. This building is awesome. Look up as soon as you enter. The glass ceiling is amazing. It also has the world's largest pendulum clock. There are restaurants on the 30th floor and a cool old London pub on the ground floor.

A nice view of the whole city. Similar to Jin Mao in Shanghai. The observatory station gives you the whole view of the city and you can see Mt. Fuji if the weather is okay. It worth spending one to two hours there. BTW, it is free to get in.
FREE. FREE view of the city. GOOD views of the city. Come here! Super close to Shinjuku's electric street and easy to find.

Should not miss this. I usually do not visit over touristy spot but TMG is really a great place to spend some time in Tokyo. and i ended up going twice - one morning and another time at night. The view is stunning at both times but gives me very different feeling about this wonderful city.both observatories are good and easily accessible from one another - do check timing because they have different hours operating on different days.Try to go during weekday to avoid super big crowd. Signs and direction are easy to follow - easily accessible from Tochoeme station.If you are hungry - there are staff canteen(a huge one) on both tower that starts serving at 11AM(level 32) . Both Western and Japanese meal choices are very reasonably priced and respectable quality. even the view from the canteen is awesome
Great views. Nice views from here. We were lucky enough to see Mt Fuji. Clean and not too hard to get to. We recommend it.

Great views for free!. Forget paying for a view of the city - Tokyo - and Mt Fuji. Go to the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office and from the top floor there is a magnificent observatory and cafe.Highly recommended. A short work from Shinjuku Station - west gate.

Great views of Tokyo . The night time views from the top of the tower were excellent, although as had been said in a previous review the lights are on full blast and it does affect the view. The other downside is that 20% of the view (and from what i could glimpse through the partitions, the best views) can only be seen if you are in the restaurant. However it was free and warm and a short walk from Shinjuku Station.

Amazing!. Dont go to the expensive towers but go to this FREE spot! Amazing view! Little hard to tind if you came from different side then front of the building, but just walk around it and you will see the big main entrance!

Good view that is free. An excellent view of both Tokyo by day and night. Very quite when I visited but easily located, take the subway to Tochomae and come up exit A4, which is right at the base of the towers. The follow the green signs for observatory, depending on days they open either the south and north tower.I am not sure what made me feel more queasy looking from the top or looking up from the bottom.There are some tourist shops at the top and a café in one of the towers. They were open till 11pm. Unfortunately for night shots the lights reflect on the graph, so take a coat to cover the camera and lens. Saw Mt Fuji through the mist so on a clear day, it would be excellent.They search the bags at the bottom of the lift.

Don't miss this wonderful free view of Tokyo. Anyone and everyone would probably go to Shinjuku while in Tokyo. It would be well worthwhile to visit the Metropolitan Government Building which is a 15min subway walk from Shinjuku Station. Not only is the entrance free, but the views of the city are fantastic as well. There is no time restriction so you can wait for dusk to see the city lights if you are inclined. A must visit.

Great Views for the Perfect Price...Zero!. There are observation floors at the top of the two government buildings. The are 45 floors and provide great views of Tokyo. The price is just right....nothing! It seems to be a meeting place for locals as well.

Great view and helpful info centre. This was a great start to Tokyo. The information centre here is very helpful and speak English. The observation deck is a great way to orient yourself before heading out into the city and it's free.

See Fuji and buy cute gifts. Very helpful guides with two viewing areas complete with cafes and gifts from Tokyo to take home. Fuji can be seen clearly and how much you see will depend on the cloud cover the day you visit.. Also tourist info about Tokyo or other prefectures of Japan generously given out with tips on what to look out for when you visit.

An outstanding way to see all of Tokyo. This is the best way to see Tokyo from on high. Yes, there is the Tokyo Tower and the Skytree, but these are expensive (up to 2000 yen) where the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (TMG) is free. Yes, free. No, there isn't a catch. It's free. How much? Free. There is a couple of downsides to the TMG. First, it is not very close to other tourist attractions. Second, there are two towers. Both are free, but because they are almost back-to-back, each tower only has about a 270 degree view. Even with these inconveniences, this is the way that I recommend getting above Tokyo.
fantastic. certainly worth a trip to see panoramic views of tokyo and Mt Fuji on a clear day. Its free and over 40 stories high.
Beautiful views. On a clear day, worth the visit for the gorgeous 360 degree view of Tokyo. The north tower is less busy than the south tower for some reason, but the views are just as nice.

Visit at night. Best accessed by Tocho-mae Station on the Oedo Subway Line. Otherwise you'd spend 20 minutes walking from Shinjuku station. The south tower closed at 5pm but the north tower closed at 9pm. We visited the north tower and were not disappointed. Spectacular view of Tokyo city. Wished that there were seats where we can chill. A lot of souvenirs were sold on the observation deck, so get your purse out!

Visit at night. Best accessed by Tocho-mae Station on the Oedo Subway Line. Otherwise you'd spend 20 minutes walking from Shinjuku station. The south tower closed at 5pm but the north tower closed at 9pm. We visited the north tower and were not disappointed. Spectacular view of Tokyo city. Wished that there were seats where we can chill. A lot of souvenirs were sold on the observation deck, so get your purse out!
Free view of the city. It probably only takes about 10-15 minutes to view the the whole thing. It is a great view. It is probably not worth going out of your way. The great part is it's FREE!

Tremendous views of Tokyo for free. The Government Office building is mentioned in guides for several good reasons but number one has to be the two free observatories on the 45th floor. Anyone who wants to see how vast and beautiful Tokyo is, just come here and get ready to marvel.

Amazing views. Free. . Its free! You have no excuse to not visit. The 360 degree views of Tokyo from the top are breathtaking and making for some outstanding photo opportunities. There is also a little cafe at the top. Was very nice to sit and look at the views with a drink. On clear days you can even see Mt. Fuji

Go at night for fantastic views. At first I was thinking it was a Government office and I had no idea why it was so highly recommended. But the views from the top are stunning, almost equally good by day or night, but I preferred the night views, with the lights. It's not too crowded and you can stay as long as you want. You'll find some annoying Japanese school kids trying to take kissing selfies with the view in the background, but ignore them and you'll have a good time.

Free view of Tokyo. Who doesn't love something free while in Tokyo? It was nice not to take out the change purse and we were rewarded with an amazing view. We visited in the early part of the evening so it was dark but seeing the city all lit up was beautiful. After taking in the views, we decided to eat at the italian restaurant on the same floor as the observatory. For ¥500 for a cover charge for each person was a steal compared to the New York Bar and Grill in the park Hyatt. The food was mediocre at best but the view was spectacular while eating the subpar food!

Lovely views. Really fantastic was to get a 360 view of Tokyo without paying for it!! Nothing fancy or exciting within the building it's self but the views were wonderful... and it cost nothing to go up. There were some souvenir stalls set up. What more could you want!

Beautiful view of Tokyo!. We came to TMG at night, no queue at all! There are elevator attendants who point us to the lift taking us up to the observatory floor.
Reached the top really fast and had an excellent night view of Tokyo!
Theres also shops and a restaurant on the observatory store. The shop is full of souvenirs!
Bonus: Free admission!!
free Tokyo item number 1. you need to pass a security check before proceed to the observation deck. 45floor hight Tokyo and you do not have to pay

A free view of Tokyo. Whoop dee doo!. I was tempted to give this place four stars in comparison to the ripoff that is Tokyo SkyTree or Osaka's Umeda Sky Building, but I had to remind myself that this place is just a simple observatory. Yes, there are great views of Tokyo from either of the two observatories - there are two sections/buildings. However, it really is just a simple observatory only fit for a one hour visit. You will definitely want to come here on a clear day - otherwise, you won't see much. I visited in the afternoon so I don't no if the night view was any better. It is indoor and not outdoor. There are large windows on the observatory floor. There are a few places to sit (e.g. cafe) and there are a few benches.Note that there is a 10 minute walk from Shinjuku station, of which part of the walk is uncovered so remember to bring your umbrella if there is the threat of rain. There is a gift shop and cafe in the observatory. There's not much else in the building though as I recall there was a shop or two in the first floor of TMG. If you're short on time during your visit to Tokyo, there are plenty of other places to visit instead.

Compulsory for every traveller. This place was really amazing. A fascinating view for FREE. There was a souvenir shop, cafe and vending machine for drinks on the observation floor.However for security reasons, you need to pass a security check before proceed to the observation deck. Very friendly staff though.Just few minutes walked from Shinjuku Station West Exit via underground walkway.
Free view. Why pay to go up Tokyo tower or the skytree when you can go here for zilch? Great service, easy to find and 45 floors above Tokyo with restaurant and gift shop available.

TMGO (Tocho) Free visit. It is free, why not give it a try? Clear indication, they provides paid service with free. Each observatory has a cafe and a souvenir shop.Because it is at the last exit and 1 exit distance from Shinjuku Washington Hotel, took 5-6mins via underground linked walkway from Shinjuku Station. Was no regret.P/S: Early booking for restaurant in the observatory is needed.

Amazing Views. Awesome views over Tokyo and free, so worth a look. Easy to get to and access and handy public toilets. The viewing area itself is a bit disappointing - very few seats and those there are, are in the middle of the area where you can't gaze out at the views. Clearly the idea is that you walk around & view, shop in the gift shop and leave, not hang around. For all that, it's worth a visit.There is an info centre in the ground floor lobby for tourist info.

Wooooooow!. Awesome view and the best thing it's free :-D. .. Oh and if you wanna go here don't worry they have an elevator and guides especially for visitors and the top floor has souvenir shops... And the view is just WOOOOOW!

Terrific View. At the top of the TMG, you get a really good idea of the size of Tokyo. From the bay to the mountains, it is solid city.There is a tourist info center in the building that was very helpful also.

Terrific views of Tokyo for free!. The Michelin travel guide lists this building as a three-star attraction, which is the highest mark that Michelin awards. Considering that it costs nothing to go to the top floor for breath-taking views of Tokyo, our excursion to TMG was well worth it.

Definitely get a brief free view of the city on a clear day. Why not get a free view? The time spent was enhanced by visiting various parts of the city before going for the panoramic view. A glimpse of Mt. Fuji at sunset was a bonus but agree with others that inside lighting after dark precludes good photos by someone with my level of expertise and are a waste of time at that point. I suggest arriving later in the day to spend some time before viewing the sunset which could be quite striking.

Must Visit to see the whole of Japan. Its FREE. better than tokyo tower which is not free. I went there at night and could see all the colourful lights of Tokyo. The lights are endless which shows how big tokyo is, Tokyo is a city dessert where buildings are very close to each other. Could barely see any greenary. There are a few gifts and souvenier to buy.

Reccommended to everyone of all ages. The government building is free, with a tourist centre on level one which conducts free tours with an english guide around the building. North and south observation decks have relatively cheap toy/souvenier stores (depending on area visited) and on a clear day you can even see mt fuji. Make sure you visit on a week day and pick up the tokyo brochures and/or guide at the tourist centre.
Waste of time. Its not necessary to go to this place. its basically dots of skyscrappers all along central of tokyo. It will be good for professional photo taking lovers.

view from above. This is a great spot to see a free panoramic view of Tokyo. Fuji was snowcapped and fabulous this week. Added bonus with a bonsai display and the bonsai artisans. Free audio headsets as well as English speaking docents. Nice little gift shop as well.

Free Place But Lights should be Dimmer at Night. Wanted a Night View of the City and as we were staying nearby decided to visit the TMG building. Wait period is short. But at the observatory, the lights are too bright and it reflects off the glass. Maybe that day was also a rainy day, cant really see anything except the reflections of the souvenir shop. Perhaps it would be better to visit in the day-time.

Tokyo Skyline Viewing on a Budget!. I had high hopes for a trip the Skytree, but between the lottery and payment requirements (not sure of the current situation, but back in June 2013 you had to have a credit card issued on a Japanese bank to make an online purchase) it just wasn't going to happen. I mentioned this to my who was showing me around and she suggested we hit the government building instead. I was very surprised that this location is open until midnight and there was only a brief wait for the elevator up to the observation deck. The observation area is a large enclosed space, comprised of several souvenir areas surrounded by large plate glass windows. Excellent panoramic views of much of the skyline and completely free. Great stop for those on a budget or one a night when you want to get in "one more thing."
Nice views. The trip to the tower was complimentary and allows visitors a Birdseye view of Tokyo. On the ground floor is a souvenir shop which showcases Tokyo products all in one place.

Excellent View of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji. The view from the observation floor was excellent, and the day was clear. Mt. Fuji was also visible. I would highly recommend visiting the observation floor to obtain a great view of the city. In one area, you have to purchase food or a beverage to gain access. I did not go in the evening, but I'm sure the view would be stunning.

Top during the day, flop at night (but all day long free). The view is great during the day. I think the pictures say more, than I could do in this comment. So, let me just mention: Unfortunately, at night, the room is so bright, that the lights are mirroring at the windows. It is almost impossible to see something, without touching the window, covering it from the light around you. Of course, under these conditions, it also impossible to take good photos.PS: If you are on the Oedo line, you can exit at the station Tochomae, which is right next to the TMG, and therefore avoid the crowd at Shinjuku station.
Great views for free!. We walked here from Shibuya Station (about 3 miles). It was definitely worth it, great views for free and we liked the sites along the walk.

The north observation deck is highly recommended.. I enjoyed a fine view of Tokyo from the north observation deck, watching Tokyo Skytree. In addition, there are many interesting souvenir shops there and I also had fun shopping for my daughters. If you look for a tourist attraction at Shinjuku, this building is highly recommended.

Great view of Tokyo. This is a great place to have a 360°view of Tokyo. Just enter the building and take the elevator to the 45th floor. It's free. There is a small café and a souvenir shop. Volunteers will answer all your questions upstairs, very friendly people. I think they volunteer to have the chance to practice their English.
Free and the views were good. It was free and a short walk from our hotel. We only had time to go up the North tower since there was a lineup for the South tower.

Great view, great guide, great value - it's free!. We needed belief to find it via the subway as it's a long walk (there are a long series of travail actors to help) but well worth the effort. The views of Tokyo from the 45th floor observation deck (there is one in each tower but we were in the South) were without obstruction and superb. Big plus was not only did we pay nothing to go up but we also had a personal free volunteer guide to talk us through what we were looking at. They are sitting there just waiting to help.

Nice view from the rooftop. Best way to have a view over tokio.But if smog is lasting on Tokio not so good.Very exciting is the elevator.This is a real running machine.Be there in the morning.Later its very crowded.Positive aspect is,you will not have to pay for your visit.
Average. The views are breath-taking. Not much shops and restaurants though ... For a betetr view deck experience, go to the Skytree.
Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. The view was marvellous. You can see the whole Tokyo panorama. Cannot believe that it is free. You can even see Mount Fuji from here.

Not Much To See Other Than The Observation Deck. There isn't much to see except the enclosed observation deck. Also, it seemed like it was a VERY long walk from the subway to the building. Maybe I took the wrong exit but the walk was quite long. If you want a view of Tokyo (and that's more accessible and outdoors), go to the observation deck of the Sunshine City building.
TMG. Amazing panoramic views from observation deck! Each view has a picture below describing everything that you are overlooking. A great way to view Tokyo!

Convenient, free, and beautiful. Based on reviews and travel guides, we decided to check out the view from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office.Conveniently located at the Shinjuku train stop (though a bit of a walk from there, it is well signed) we took the elevator to the top of the North tower as it was the only one open late at night. From here we had a breathtaking view of the night lights of Tokyo. Pictures didn't come out very well, however, because there are a lot of lights on in the observation room so there is a lot of glare. But it's free, so who am I to complain?On our way out from Tokyo, we stopped by here again for a day time view, this time from the South tower. We were approached by an official guide who was able to show us around and what we were looking at (including a rare view of Mt. Fuji!). She didn't ask for any money or tip, and was quite helpful!I would highly recommend visiting here, especially given its convenience and price (free!)!

Free for a reason. Whilst it is free there are better views to be had from other buildings such as the Park Hyatt New York Bar but then you obviously have to pay for it. There was no queue to get up to the viewing area but a long queue to get down.

free observatory deck on level 45(202m) tall.. our hotel is in west shinjuku and only lesser than 10 min walk to tokyo metropolitan goverment office. you can reach here through underground pass if you come here from shinjuku JR station, after the pass only another 2 min walk then turn left, the signs are clear.we had lunch before we went up, thought higher you go normally food should cost more, later we found out a plate of set lunch cost only 1000-2000 per person, really should have lunch here.from the top you can have a good view of whole tokyo, you can see the skytree too. and famous cocoon tower.lots of chinese tour including this one-mainly because it is free.there are reasonablely selection of souviours to buy here as while, the prices are not higher neither- seem to me whole country the prices are all similar, at osaka universal studio the drinks vending machines are only 20 yen more.if you want to save money and avoid long waiting for skytree, this is definitely the alternative to see tokyo from top.

Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (TMG). The observation deck from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (TMG) is spectacular, offering 360 degree views of Tokyo and its surrounds. The crowds are not as big as Tokyo Tower and the Sky Tree, and its free, so its a good alternative.

View from 45 storeys. It's free for one thing which is good.The view was so-so, buildings and tall buildings.The souvenirs sold up there were very expensive, most tourists only view the items. None bought. If they could lower the prices perhaps they would bring back an item or two to their own countries to promote Japan Tourism

Nice panoramic views and what a bargain. If you find yourself having some time and a clear day in Tokyo, make sure to make it to the TMG for great views of the city, and even of Mt Fuji from this strategic location. Both buildings have an observation deck on a high floor (don't remember how high) and the best thing is that going up there is free. What a bargain. Don't miss it. They have a cafe and a souvenir shop up there in case you needed something while visiting.

Great free views of city. Went yesterday and the wait to get up was about 3 minutes. You enter building 1 which has the twin towers and can either go up the North or South side. There is a sign outside stating how long the wait time is for either side. It said 30 ,injures but only took us 3 minutes wait. Takes you to the 45th floor. Has English pictures pointed to locations you are viewing. There is a cafe restaurant which was a little pricey and also a gift shop. The wait time to go down was about 10 minutes. Currently there is only one elevator for either side open as they are updating them, so wait times may very until they are completed in November.

Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (TMG)_ beautiful view. The tallest building in Shinjuku, TMG No. 1 offers sweeping views of Tokyo-- On a clear day you can see Mt Fuji from the 45th floor observatory. Easy to get to and definitely worth a visit. South tower offers more views than the north tower, but you can comfortably do both within an hour and a half. The building has a few gift shops in each tower and a restaurant. The South Tower is open late. The city at night is worth a look.

It's free!. we lived very close to it. we went on for both night view and day view.liked it both :) but unfortunately it was so foggy couldn't see furtherbut it's very nice already since it's free! and oh, the souvenirs shop was awesome too hahaha

It has a view so nice you need a security check to see it.. After the baggage search you usually need to wait in line to go up to the observation deck .That said the view is nice enough. There are a few gift shops in each tower and a restaurant.The South Tower is open late. The city at night is worth a look.I found the view at Bukyo Civic Centre better and less crowded.

Free Views of Mt Fuji & Skyline. It's a 15mins walk or so from Shinjuku station. Do go before sunset at 5.30pm to catch views of Mt Fuji from afar and of shinjuku national garden below. Skyline is great at night when the buildings are lit up.
Nice view and free. It will be better to go there instead to go to SkyTree. There is no queue, it's free and you have time to see the city

Free observation deck. Well, it's an observation deck, right? So if you like them, you won't be disappointed by this one, although the view is partly obstructed by a near-by high building, walls of the building itself, and in one corner of the Northern tower there is restaurant prohibiting the view in that direction. That said, you will get a fair share of views in most directions, the restaurant itself is reasonably priced so it may be worth trying (I didn't) esp. for couples, the entrance is free and it's quite close to the train station. The major let-down is the souvenir shop, which is way worse than shops at comparable tourist spots. Recommended overall - you probably want to see Shinjuku at night anyway, it wouldn't take you too long, and you can save a few bucks if you are traveling on budget.

The cheapest high you'll get in Tokyo. This is one of the only free things we could find to do in Tokyo, although it takes a while to get to as it's a little out of the way. There's two separate towers to go up, both with equally impressive views. There's clear pictorial displays pointing out important buildings and landmarks (including the elusive Mt Fuji) so you get a sense of where everything is. We were most impressed by the huge park we could see as it was an usual sight amongst such tall buildings. There was a cafe and a souvenir shop at the top although we avoided both due to the price.Worth the trek for a free stunning view.Tip: Visit at dusk and watch the sun go down.

Up in the clouds. it's free which is an obvious positive. You need to get the tube to Tochomae station and then it's very close by. There's 2 lifts but only 1 functioning when we were there. You get in from the 1st floor. The lifts stop at the 45th floor only on the way up and takes you back to the 2nd floor. The view's good with pictures telling you what you're looking at. I think the pictures showing Mount Fuji might be artist's impressions. We couldn't even see the mountains infront of Mount Fuji and it was a reasonably clear day. There's a cafe and souvenir shop there. We were staying in Shinjuku, so the trip made sense. We didn't go to Tokyo Tower or Tokyo Skytree so not sure how it might compare.

A free viewing platfor.. A free viewing platform from the top of this monolithic building, there are two towers, so make sure you check the views out from them both.In winter views to Mt Fuji are possible.

Cool view. It's definitely a cool view atop the TMG building. But after seeing way too many observatory decks, it just got old. Tokyo Tower, Tokyo Sky Tree, Asakusa Tourist Center, Mori Tower, ferris wheels, etc. are some other options.If you're in Shinjuku, there are better things to see than to wander into its business district.

Don't miss it. it took some time to walk from the metro to be there. it's also not easy to find TMG and its entrance, I had to seek help from passer-by. You can go shopping while enjoying the great views upstairs. NICE!

free entrance, great view but it was a labyrinth to find it. from the shinjuku station, we followed the offcial signs plus our guide. we failed two times and we were redirected two times by security staff who didn't speak any word in english but were ready with their guide for directions. after 30 minutes we finally reached the actual building. there were security staffs who checked our bags and guided us with the lift. on the 52nd floor was the platform tower. the view was simply breathtaking. unfortunately it was covered with glass and we had difficulties taking night shot photos. it was worth it.

Good place to see Tokyo from top. There are some good point about coming here to see Tokyo skyline. It's free, opens at night and it's likely that you wouldn't have to queue long to go up. However, the building interior is a bit dated, only because there are so many other modern candidates which you can get the same bird's view in this magnificent city (Tokyo Tower, Skytree...). I would only recommend this if you couldn't make it to other sky high attractions in your trip.
Great views. This is a great place to have a bird's view over Tokyo. It is free and has a café. Really worth a visit, particularly if you are staying close by.
Tokyo Metro Government Building. The view was awesome from the 45th floor and there was no fee. Easy walking distance from Shinjuku Station.
Free views of Tokyo. Compared to the new Skytree, the view is not as fantastic. However it is free! There were no queues even on a Saturday.

Best Value in Tokyo. The observation deck is free and offers great views. It is a great brief stop on any tour in Tokyo. The tourist information booth on the lobby level is very helpful and full of helpful brochures
it is well worth a visit. The view is amazing.make sure you go to the top for an amazing view of the city. It is free and is open till prety late in the evening for a nighttime view.
Great view. I went there at night and I had the chance to have a breathtaking view of Tokyo at night and most of all..it is completely free..be sure not to miss that opportunity!
awesome view, FREE,, dont miss it. its free, dont miss it - better view than tokyo tower.... also has a nice bar at the top with beautiful japanese only cocktails...

Nice free attraction. A nice place to get oriented if you have not been to Tokyo before. You can get to know where the important places are, in relation to each other. The Tokyo tower is actually not as tall even if you pay for the higher level, but it's more commercialized and have lots of shopping, whereas, this is a government building, so not much else around other than a small souvenir shop.
Clean and well organized. We went to the top of the building to see the whole city. The view is beautiful. We also bought some local souvenirs there for our friends.
Great views for free. Impressive building by Kenzo Tange, no queue and you ride the elevator for free. From the top, great aerial views of the city. Worth a visit for sure

Awesome view of the city and Mt. Fuji. It's FREE! So, that's good!
On a clear day, and if you're lucky, you'll be able to get a glimpse of the majestic Mt. Fuji. It's just really a wonderful sight to see.
Other than that, it offers a good view of the city and gives you brief info on what the places are.

Nice views with very good explanations of the city. We went to the view floor and took a tour with one of the volunteers that show you around. It was a very pleasant experience. The Japanese lady that took us around was so gentle! From up there you can see pretty much all the city boundaries and landmarks. It worth a visit!

Great view, poor food. This is well with a visit, especially at night, as the view is great. The restaurant is a little pricey, but not bad at all for the location. The quality and quantity of some of the food is very disappointing. We planned to start and finish our two week holiday with a meal here, but one visit was enough and we wouldn't go back.

Why bother with Tokyo Tower ..... ... if you can get a panoramic view of Tokyo at TMG for free !! There are directions at Shinjuku station leading you to the free bus service from the station to the doorstep of TMG. There were not many dining options here, as compared to Shinjuku station and its surrounds. There is also a tourist information office on the ground level with a good selection of English guides relating to different districts of the City.

Free observation tower in Tokyo. Pros- It was free, fairly easy to locate, and a good view of the city. It was tough taking picutres (a bit dark), but a nice vantage point to see the city. As an added bonus, and a must visit, there is a vistor's center downstairs with free maps, sightseeing resources and an extremley helpful staff that speaks English. Make this one of your first stops to ensure you're taking advantage of the cities sights.
Its worth a visit. Its free and a great view of all of Tokyo. It was only a short walk from the Hilton hotel and worth the elevator ride up. They had a nice gift store as well.

Really Average. We were told to get there at night to get a great view. It was on a very nice day with no rain no cloud and the view was there but really nothing special. We were very disappointed. Maybe the day view is actually better. Will tray another time to tell. But night was just average.

Free Guided Tour provided !!. There is a free guided tour organized for tourist by the Tourist Organization at the ground floor,You need to email and book where it will send you details if confirmed.We got a very good tour escorted by two volunteers for half-day visit. It was free except the transport fees but it really worth as we knew much more from the local.You could also select language as the volunteers would like to have this opportunity to practice foreign language.

great view over the city. 2 observation areas (North and South) are open to public for free admittance, they offer great look over the city and you can even see Mt. Fuji if you are lucky with the weather. Both observation areas are located at the 45th floor. One of them has a nice gift shop. The line for the elevator was not long and moved quickly

Great view of the city as well as Mount Fuji. Brilliant experience and its free. Easy to get to and definitely worth a visit. South tower offers more views than the north tower, but you can comfortably do both within an hour and a half.
Great free view of the city. Fantastic views of Tokyo and you get a real sense of how huge it is. Brilliant that this is for free rather than having to pay for other places in Tokyo.

Great place to visit for free Skyline view of Tokyo. This place is open until around 11pm and skyline view of Tokyo at 250m above ground is great. Even better there there are no entrance fees.
This building also has the Japan Tourism Office for al the maps and details you are after..

Beautiful views for free, but wouldn't be on my must-see list. Let me start out by saying that the views really are beautiful. You can't beat seeing the city that way especially for free. If you're going to go, go at night. Its hard to take pictures because of the windows even if you have your flash off. If you're near it, definitely go see, but I wouldn't go out of the way to see it.

Best view for free. Seeing a city from a high vantage point is one of the best advantage of modern architecture. This attraction combines this feature with an other evergreen attribute: it is free! You cant hate it. Granted it seemed like there is always a half an hour long line, but at least there are only one elevator and that is fast - unlike the torture they put you through at the empire statebuilding in the Nyc which is awesome but there are multiple elevators with lots of long queues...Anywas the metropolitan government center is a cool sight and it is also useful to get a directional sense of the city or as Bear Grylls would say: get your bearings.
Nice view all over Tokyo. When we went there the weather wasn't really good, but the view was still pretty good. Sadly, we haven't seen Mount Fuji, but on good days you can see it!

Brilliant Views. A wonderful location to enjoy a bird's eye view of Tokyo and almost no queue! On a clear day you can see Mt Fuji in the distance; at night you can enjoy the glittering lights of Tokyo. The night that we were there, we practically had the place to ourselves. Highly recommended.
Great Views of Tokyo!. Multiple views of Tokyo, but you have to change towers. Great information center located on main level. Gift shops up on viewing level.

Free and wonderful!. Go to the top floor of this modern, well-signed building for a beautiful panoramic view of the city. Take note of the closing times. It is open on weekends and best of all, there's no charge.

nice staff with no fees!. I went there during lunch time. The building has 7 eleven shop and also a book store. when you go up, there are two towers, North and South. One of them has a cafe where you can see the from only if you purchase something from the cafe. you can skip the cafe and go to the other building, better views for completely FREE.

Free - morning visit. I was there at 9.30 in the morning on a Sunday. It was quiet and I had to wait for only 5 min for the elevator that took me to the 42nd floor. Audio guide was free (bring your passport) and very helpful. I was lucky with the weather, it wasn't too cloudy, but I still couldn't see mt Fuji. Highly recommended!

Awesome. Great free view of Tokyo. Everyone we encountered was so helpful and polite, the view speaks for itself. There was a line up which moved very quickly to use the lift going both up and down. We didn't get to see mt Fuji on the day we went. Only a short easy walk to the train station.
Free observation deck. The free observation deck a little bit touristy but worth a visit if you are in the area. interesting architecture inside the building.

Amazing View!. My tour guide (Tokyo Free Guide) brought me here to see a view of the city. It was breathtaking. You can get a 360 degree view from the tower, and it's amazing to see how extremely large the city is. I viewed it during the day, which was beautiful, but I think it would've been nice to see it at night as well. Definitely recommended if you are in the area.

Free view of the city!. The fact that it's free makes it great. You can take the lift to the 45th floor of either south and/or north tower to get a great view of the city. Better to view on a clear day to see mount Fuji as well. The north tower also has opened to 23 if you want to view the city by night.

Free and Fun way to get a view of Tokyo. The 45th floor of the tower offer great views of Tokyo in all directions. You can even see Mt. Fuji! The best part was that there is no fee- you just show up and you can take the elevator up. It is close enough to both JR and subway stations that it is worth the trip here just for this if you are interested in seeing Tokyo from above. There are lots of souvenirs available for purchase at the top as well.

Free views of Tokyo from the 45th floor. It is great to be able to go up into the observatory and see a 360 view of Tokyo for FREE. There is a restaurant and a gift shop. Recommended especially if you are in the area.

Great views. Great place to visit and FREE!!! Choice of two towers to look at this great city from and both Free, have a coffee in the Caffe take your time wonderful views. On a clear day you can see Mt Fuji.
Total view. Here you have a recommanded in all the reviews a total view of Tokyo. And that's for FREE! In July they are renovating one lift, so there is only one available what can cause some delays!

Great views. We had already been to the Skytree but decided to visit the viewing levels here whilst exploring Shinjuku - I actually preferred these views to the skytree and these platforms are free (great for those on a budget). We went up the South Tower (which is meant to have better views but closes at 17.30). Would definitely recommend doing.

Free Observatory at the Top. You can go up to the North or South Observatory above to see views of the city. And it's free. People say the South Observatory has slightly better views. I read it saying South Observatory closes at 5:30pm and North opens until late, I think until 9-10pm. But we found out that schedules vary on which observatory is open on which day, or at least in June. We were lucky the South Observatory was open that day it was already pass 6pm when we went. Unfortunately, it was cloudy and hazy so we could not really see that far.The building in itself is a nice one, and there is a garden at the back which you can walk around and just sit an enjoy a rest.
Free. One of the few free things in Japan. But if you go to the Sky Tree, this is smaller, but allow to understand your location between Shinjuku and Shibuya areas
Free and good for viewing. Free entry and on a good clear day, you can see Mount Fuji. If you don't want to go up any other paid towers for a view of Tokyo, the TMG is a good place to go.

Nice and free !. Why waiting hours to get onto the SkyTree ? or Tokyo tower ? the TMG is free and less crowded than big towers in Tokyo. Open on weekends too. Two buildings, I personally prefer the south/east one as you can see Tokyo Bay and Down Town. North/west building is maybe lest impressive as the best part of Tokyo is hidden by the South/East building. Mount Fuji can be seen from both (assuming weather allows it).

Nice view in Observatory and it is free.... Walking distance to the west from Shinjuku station, you can find this famous building. There is no queue when I arrive and I can choose to go to the north or south tower. I choose south. The elevator bring me to the observatory and I can start to take a look the bird view. Unfortunately the weather is not good. The Fuji-san is not seen due to the cloud. However, the rest of Tokyo view is amazing. There is free tour as well in the observatory. The officer approach me without I am asking too and she start to explain about Tokyo and show me the area. There is souvenir shop and cafe as well in the observatory.
An eagle's view of Tokyo.. Easy to get to and is free and gives a useful overview of the city for 360 degree! Make the most of it and visit both towers.

The view is OK but not amazing. The view covered the vast metropolitan sprawl of Tokyo, and wasn't particularly attractive. Mt Fuji wasn't visible due to haze the day I went. Some of the more modernistic skyscrapers were worth seeing from this angle. Part of the floor was a cafe too, so viewing wasn't available from those windows.

Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. First of all, it is free so you basically can't go wrong here. The office is located in a business district so naturally, the buildings nearby will be offices so that provides a less interesting view than temples or other cool buildings. Still, I would recommend this because it is one of the higher buildings in the area so the view is quite nice. It doesn't take too long to go up and have a look, it is worth it for sure.
fantastic views. TMG provides fantastic views of Tokyo metropolitan areas. It provides the description on the landmark buildings in Tokyo. There is no admission fee. It is a must place to visit.

We Could've Missed This One. If you are staying in a high-rise Tokyo hotel, went up either the Tokyo Skytree or Tokyo Tower or are short on time in Tokyo, skip the TMG. Yes it's free and yes you have a view, however, the elevator ride up to the observation floor is extremely slow and hot. Then once on the floor, since it's floor to ceiling glass it is very, very hot - didn't feel like the air conditioning was even on. Since there is a restaurant on this floor and it is hot, the entire floor did not smell very good. Additionally, suggest using the restrooms on the TMG's ground floor as if you need to use one while on the 45th, must walk down and very dirty (which was surprising) dingy stairwell one floor to use what turned out to be the crummiest public restroom in Japan (had western toilets but I would have preferred to use a nicer Japanese toilet restroom). On the plus side, since we went to the TMG around 5:30 p.m. - 6:00 p.m., there wasn't a very long wait time. I did have to have my bag checked by a security guard which was no big deal - he was very polite and respectful. This was the one and only bag check I had during my entire Japan trip (expect for the airport).

It's free, but that's about the only draw to this place. It's OK, and if you want to go up high and see the sprawl of Tokyo, then check it out. The attraction is free, which is nice but that's about it. You're going up to about the 45th (?) floor of the government office.The location is about 10-15 minutes walk from Shinjuku station. The building is easy to find because it is a giant building straight out of a Batman movie, and the entrance is relatively easy to locate as well. Budget about 1 hour for this activity, including walking to/from the station.

Good, free view over Tokyo from near Shinjuku centre.. We went up both towers though they were very similar.Good views, limited by the haze which I think is air pollution, so no view of further away Tokyo nor of course of Mt. Fuji.Finding the towers with no map pre-prepared and expecting the locals to know where they are was hopeless. We spent over half an hour with the Shinjuku Bic Camera tourist guide looking at her internet, but no-ne had heard of their Government building. In the end we followed our noses and saw a shape which matched the picture in our guide book so the rest was easy.Well worth the visit.
Decent view. A good view of Tokyo, and its free! Only issue is that its a long walk from shinjuku station. I would choose this location over the sky tree considering the cost.

Great views on a clear day!. We were staying just opposite and decided we must go to the towers but is was raining so the cloud obstructed views in some directions. We were met at the entry by a volunteer guide who escorted us up in the lift and gave a very good commentary (in English) about the various land marks of Tokyo. Very helpful & unexpected!In the evening we decided to go up again but they had changed the entry point & after being directed by several different security guards we got to the right door. Here we were met by about 6 security men who all bowed politely and partially inspected our bags & then directed us to the lifts. A very different procedure to what had happened during the afternoon. Unfortunately, there was still a lot of cloud around and the views were obstructed. However, we found the souvenir shop had a wide variety at reasonable prices so we bought some things here.A good place to visit if you are close by & the weather is good.
Must go for first timer to Tokyo. The entrance were a little difficult to find, but we were not disappointed when we finally found it and reached level 45. Admission is free and it is open till 11pm

Go at sunset!. I went with my wife and father around 17:30. So, the place is a little hard to find but if you keep looking up and spot the towers you'll find your way easily enough.So, it's free to go up. We had to queue for the lift for about 5 minutes, and security checks everyone's bags too.It seemed as though other people were wise to the idea of getting a good view of sunset so it was quite busy up there on the 45th floor. There were toilets on the next floor down which you used the stairs to get to.Sunset was great. It's brilliant that they keep one of the two towers open every day until 11 pm!

Amazing views of Tokyo. We went to the south tower where there's a cafe at the top. It was a nice and relaxing atmosphere. There are free tour guides as well ready to give you a good explanation of the views. It's best to go on a sunny day of course but the views of Tokyo are simply amazing - one truly appreciates how densely populated Tokyo is. Rather than going to the Sky tower and paying, we went to the Metropolitan building as it was free. Definitely worth a visit, especially that it's free as well.
government building. great views, no cost 45th floor excellent views over all of tokyo, on a good day mount fuji also visible
Tokyo Metropolitan Gov't Office. Go up to the 46th floor and enjoy a free 360 degree view of Tokyo.Do it after you've seen some of the city in order to get a better taste of what you see.

What a way to see the city!. The observation floors on top of the TMGO give you a breath-taking view of the city. Each tower has a observation floor on the 45th floor - they open on alternate days. The central area of the floor is a collection of small "tourist souvenir" shops - which can be a little noisy.

It's free and the view is fantastic!. It opens at 9.30 am and you line up to go up in the lifts to the 45th floor, the views are fantastic of the whole area. Mt Fuji stands out on a fine day and you get the real scope of how intense the urban area is. Nice touristy gift shop on floor too.

Definitely worth a visit. Views are breathtaking!. This building was very close to my hotel so I decided to visit.
You get the most anazing views of Tokyo and it's all for free!
You get taken up in the lift to the 45th floor and you can wander round, take photos, go the the cafe.
If I have time, I'll try to visit again in the evening.

Great Views. The observation decks offer great views of Tokyo. There was overcast so my first visit had limited views, but the second time the weather was perfect and could see Mt. Fuji. There will be a long line on good weather days, but it is worth the wait.

Great view and Free!. There are a lot of great spots to get views of Tokyo (Skytree, Tokyo Tower, Mori Tower), but this one is the best because it's free! It's a bit of a walk from Shinjuku Station but otherwise, isn't too hard to find.The view is a 360 one and on a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji. It's closed on Tuesdays so don't go on that day :)

Fantastic view with no end on the horizon. It was worth waiting in a cue for like 20 minutes, than with express elevator to the 45th floor, one elevator is broken, will be repaired until november 2013, the other two are running normal, up to18 people at time. No entrance fee, view is fantastic, gift shops are only for children and those without the taste, avoid. You can certainly enjoy the Tokyo view, when even the tallest buildings look like dwarfs, but that's pretty much all there is. I recomend it, it's free and it' s great view. Stop at 2nd floor on the way down at the touristic centre, great staf, plenty of information, maps and goods. Worth taking a look.

free 360-degree view of Tokyo. This is located in Shinjuku. There are 2 towers, north and south, and you can go up both for free. On a clear day, the views are fantastic. There is a tourist information centre at ground level and they can speak English and Chinese (could be more but these were the only ones we used).

Overlooking Toko Skyline. Morning is the preferred time, or evening after sunset.Since the place is free to public, the queue is quite long, need to wait 10 to 15 minutes.At top has chance to see Mt. Fuji on clear sky.Should put this least priority among all sites specially if you have very limited time in Tokyo.
Easier than SkyTree. Can't be bothered lining up to get into the Sky Tree? Try the free viewing platform at the TMG building for a birds-eye view over Tokyo!

Great view of Tokyo!. It's open till 7.30pm on Sundays so my boyfriend and I went lateish on a Sunday and it was perfect as it was just getting dark so the lights looked spectacular.It was fairly crowded but not too bad, you might have to wait to get to a few of the windows (its not just one big panoramic window) but the views are second to none.Was slightly spoilt by the naff shopping stalls in the middle of the room and lame cafe, would be better if they spruced it up a bit and put more seating around - but hey, its free and definitely worth a visit!

Great View. The top floor of this building gives a great view of Tokyo and it's free and less crowded. I'm glad we got our view of Tokyo from this building instead of waiting on long lines and paying a fee for the Tokyo Sky Tree.
Good view of Tokyo. We loved the views from the observation floor - however the whole place feels a little dated, the new Tokyo Skytree Viewing Decks might be more fun.
Tremendous views. Easy to access and with a nice cafe on the observation deck and very helpful diorama so you can identify districts and sights

Great view of the city!. Located in the mix of high rises in "downtown" Tokyo. The 85th floor hosts the best views of the city and Mt. Fuji in the background. A lot less busier than the Sky Tree or Tokyo Tower

Good View (On a Clear Day). The view from the top of the TMG building can be exceptional provided that the weather is clear. I have been to the observation deck twice in this building, once in winter and once in summer. In winter it was crisp and clear so I was presented with stunning views right out to Mt.Fuji. Im summer however the warm humid air reduces visibility dramatically, although still views over Tokyo itself.

Amazing view of the city at night, for free. The observation deck is open all day from 9:30 a.m. - 11:00 p.m. There are two observation decks that are open in the daytime and one at night. Check on the website to make sure that they are open when you plan to visit.On a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji (although I went at night) and an incredible view of the city, especially at night time. There is a small cafe at the top, although I cannot comment on it's quality.The building is about 15 mins walk from the main Shinjuku station, or is closer to a few subway stations nearby. Go in the evening and then explore Shinjuku where there are many interesting restaurants and streets to visit

one of the best views in Tokyo for free. The area around the TMG is ultramodern and nice for a casual walk, but the best thing is the free observation deck on top of both the north and south towers of the TMG. Usually there are not too many people, so just a few minutes wait and you're high in the sky above Tokyo and, if the weathe is clear, you get to see Mt. Fuji. There's a cafe there and it's great to enjoy a coffee or a light meal and just relax and take in the spectacular views. On ground floor there's a tourist information office for all regions of Japan and it's a perfect spot to pick up info for various Nippon adventures.

Great views and it's free!. In the Shinjuku area, the TMG offers great 360 degree views of the city, day or night. Either walk or use the Metro (Tochomae station-Odeo line). The station puts you right at the base of the building. The entrance is under the covered area on the east side of the building. You have the option of the North or South towers. They alternate closing Mondays and the North tower is open until 11:00 p.m. or so. There is no admission, just show up, go through a brief security check, then enter the elevator for the ride to the 45th floor!We only visited the North tower (both during the day and night). There is a restaurant and large gift shop there as well as restroom facilities (you have to take stairs to a lower floor).Be mindful if you are taking photographs...at night, the glare on the windows is really bad. You can take measures to minimize it. Also, tripods are not allowed!On the ground floor, there is a tourist information center as well.If you like over-the-city views, this place should be on your list!

Awesome views at any time of the day!. Came here in the morning, and again at night before they closed. The skies weren't very clear that day, but still the views were excellent and I really enjoyed the views. The staff were extremely polite, and unlike everything in Tokyo, this baby is free!
Great free view of the city!. Don't pay for the view from the Tokyo tower, this is a Great free view of the city!Lots of tourist souvenirs waiting for you when you finish the view!
Great free view of Tokyo at 220m. Join the queue and take a lift (elevator) to the observatory floor for a free 360o view of Tokyo at 202m high. On a clear day, you can see Mt Fuji from 100km away!
The observatory is recommended. The north observatory is open for free until 9pm! great way to see tokyo at night. We haven't been there at daytime.

Magnificent view. Gorgeous panoramic view of Tokyo for free. It was a clear day so saw all the way to Mt. Fuji. Reasonably priced cafe on south side observatory. I had tea and cake with an unbeatable view of the city.

Skydesk is free to observe the city. I was surprised that I could get on top of this government office for free of charge. The staff there is very nice and the build is elegant. I was directed to take a separate lift (for the sky desk) and we get to the top of the building. The space there looks cool, you can observe 360 degree of Tokyo. Note that you can observe Fuji Mount. Highly recommend.

Great views. Lovely buildings, nice area and amazing views. Many amazing skyscrapers in this area, nice park nearby, Starbucks and Dennys nearby if you need a break after.I didn't go early enough to see Mt Fuji from here but caught it from the Shinkansen to Osaka which was unexpected so made it more special.

Not much thrill but it's free. Not much, really, from the South Observation Wing. This might be because Tokyo landscape is not that interesting. Unlike London, New York and Paris where I am thrilled by brilliant architecture, old buildings and parks.

Great free view. We were lucky and got in right away. Fun ride to tzhe 45th floor. Great views at the top - but don't count on seeing Mount Fuji. It only happens a few days every year. Helpsame guides if you want them

It's free, but only worth it if you are in the area.. When you turn the corner and first see the building, it is massive in scale and very striking. The south observatory closes at 6 which is before sunset, so your only option after that is the north observatory. This was good but other than snap a few photos there is not much to do here. The view isn't as good as it would be from the south observatory and it is rare that it is clear enough to see all the way to Mt Fuji. What was worse is that the side facing downtown was roped off and couldn't be accessed. A cool 20 minutes if you're nearby, but wouldn't venture too far for just this.

Has a great view of most of Tokyo. I made a visit to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office on a Sunday. Kinda hard not to visit the place since my hotel room overlooked the building and seeing it everyday merely piqued my curiosity. I didn't think the wait for the elevators was too long, actually--i didn't think it was too busy either. The observatory is divided in half: the North Observatory and the South Observatory. The room was spacious and massive, giving visitors an almost-360 degree view of most of Tokyo. There's a restaurant smack in the center of the room and a souvenir shop near the elevators that descend down to the lobby. Quite a marketing strategy--what do you do when you're waiting in line to go back down? Well, if you have eyes like mines, they'll wonder to the souvenir shop. Yes, I did end up buying things. Hehehe.Honestly, the experience is not only looking at Tokyo's city-scape, but learning the background of the city's famous buildings and landmarks. When I arrived, a couple of nice elderly women handed me an iTouch look-alike device. As I walk to certain areas, I listen to narrations of famous buildings, parks, and stations. Each area of the observatory is equipped with a sensor that pings the audio device notifying the change of view. Basically, the narration changes based on the change of view. Pretty nifty, huh?Gorgeous view. Did I mention admission is free? Yes, it's free. You can't go wrong with an observatory that is free.

Price/value ratio good. Currently only one tower open.. As its free it is definitely worth it, when around the shinjuku area. Until Nov13 the elevators are serviced so it might be that only one tower is open for the public. Of course - as it comes with all platforms - weather depending. I was said, that the south tower is better regarding a view of Fuji-san when the weather is good.

give it a miss. This used to be a cool place to go and check out great views of Tokyo. It was a wide open space where you could peacefully wander around admiring the city. Now it is crammed with stalls selling cheap souveneirs and you can hardly move.

Nice view, long queue. We waited nearly an hour to get into the elevator and then around 20 minutes for ome to go down. The view is nice but not breathtaking. Though we met a very funny 66year old Japanese man there and had a very funny conversation. He made our day:-)

Great place to go to see all of Tokyo!. The lines were not long to go up to get a 360 view of Tokyo. There are two elevators to go up and bag search is mandatory. On the first floor is the tourism office and the ladies there are very helpful! And, it's free!
All the info you might need. great views from the Observatory, though the shop is tacky and the restaurant up there currently being renovated

great free views of Tokyo!. just a short walk from ehotel shinjuku
catch both elevators up to view from both towers and take your camera :)

Don't miss it. Indoor gallery with 360 degree view of Tokyo. Be ready for a security bag search. ( saw a man perhaps on his way to airport had to open his suitcase ). We did not have to wait long to get into the lift to the 45th floor- all handled effectively. We were fortunate to see Mt. Fuji from one of the many windows- the only problem is there were so many people- and it is hard to be able to get a decent photo with people obstructing your lines of view.

FREE, fast and awesome!. Great views, and we only had to wait about five minutes for the elevator. Didn't see Fuji on my visit, but I can't complain. I went to the South tower, but I think the views are about the same.

One-hour Line too long for us to wait to get in. We were very disappointed to spend a long time on the subway to get here to find that we would have had to wait in line for one hour to board the elevator to the 45th floor observation platform. My husband uses a walker, and it would have been impossible for him to do so. Only one of the two elevators was in use today. I'm not sure if the wait would have been cut in half if both had been working.

Spectacular view. First of all it is free and the metro runs almost straight into the building.Then we were lucky enough to go there on a bright and sunny day where we had a great view of the city and of Mt. Fuji.We had to take 2 rounds. One where I was taking many pictures and one where I just could enjoy the view!A good trick is to go early in the morning where it is most clear and not too crowded.

A fantastic free view of tokyo. We were going to up the sky tree when our guide suggested going up this instead. It is very centrally located in tokyo and even better it is free! The views are amazing especially at night. Would like to have gone up there in the day but ran out of time. The good thing is is that you can go up as many times as you like!

Best place to view the city for free!. Both the South and North Tower offer the visitor extensive 360 degree views over the city and in the South Tower you can rent, for free, an audio guide which tells you all about the buildings and a little history. The views from the 45th floors are amazing (on a clear day) and, if you're especially lucky and the skies are clear, you will possibly see Mt. Fuji. There is an Information Office in the North Tower which has really friendly, helpful staff who speak English and they are more than happy to help you. If you just look for any information centre they are always friendly and helpful.

Great views of a packed city. We were staying right near here amd popped up just before we left for the airport to fill in half an hour. It's free and you can access the observatory from under Building 1. We only queued for 5 mins.You can go up either North or South, pick South as you can see Mt Fuji on a fine day.Great views of Tokyo and the mountains and we were lucky as it was clear and fine. You get a good idea of just how packed the place is.

Amazing free attraction. Such a great place to get some good photos of Shinjuku and the surrounding area of Tokyo. Although the weather was a little gloomy,, the walk up to the TMG building was very pretty with plenty of cherry blossom. At the top of the tower (which was free to access) there were great views of the area, with helpful placards of which buildings were visible. We went on a Saturday afternoon and there was no queue at all. Helpful to visit the tourist centre as well for some information to help our stay.

Only go when the weather is clear. The day I went was not cloudy, but I still couldn't see terribly far. The souvenir shop was pretty sparse. If it is convenient to arrive by oedo line you can get off at tochamae. I wouldn't bother going unless you were planning on going to the area anyway.

Brilliant free attraction - possible to get some great photos !. We visited the towers about 8pm on a March evening - easy to get to - exit Shinjuku station to the West and it's really well signposted (The last few hundred yards seem a bit weird at night - wandering through an almost deserted area which is alive during working hours but dead by night).There was hardly any queue to get in - cursory security checks of rucksacks and up in the high speed lift.The views of a night are fantastic, esp as the towers are in the middle of other skyscrapers. There is a restauraunt which takes up one side so you don't really get a 360 degree view but almost.To get good photos we got my coat and put it over my head to black out the glare from the internal lights and make a kind of mini tent around the camera - rested the lens on the glass for satbility and got some really good photos.There are the usual souvenier shops etc on the viewing level but nothing too intrusive.All in all a fantastic free hour or so spent here - certainly worth the effort to get here.

Observation deck - free!. I would highly recommend you to go up to observation deck when you want to see the view of city of Tokyo.You will be able to see Mt. Fuji when the weather allows.I am a citizen of Tokyo but I pretty like the view from this observation deck and enjoy staying there for a while. There are South and North deck where you will see a slightly different view.Moreover it is free to access so check out the opening time on their HP and get there!

Free views but check out the cafeteria!. Short walk from Shinjuku station but took shuttle bus to save time. Good views of Tokyo. Overcast the day we went so could not see Mt.Fuji. The observatory elevators are going to be under repair until November 2013. Reduced number of elevators in operation but no long queues and wait time was less than five minutes (weekday). There is a café at the observatory level but go to the 32nd floor cafeteria of the North tower instead. It’s for government workers but they were open to the public as well. Inexpensive yet tasty meals and good serving size…..approx. half the price found in the streets around Shinjuku. Large selection of dishes to choose from. Sample dishes are displayed in a glass case. Descriptions were in Japanese but cafeteria worker took time to describe for us what dishes were. Order by number using vending machine and present the ticket to the counter staff. Go around lunch time....after 2pm. selection is limited as food is sold out.

A Great Free View. This turned out to be a very good place to visit. We had a clear day with good views of Mount Fuji and the whole city – and for free. This may be a better bet that the queues and cost of Skytree.

Great views but don't go expecting great photo opps at night. The free observatories at the top of both buildings provide great daytime views, extending towards Mt Fuji on particularly clear days but at night the reflections from the lights inside the observatories will frustrate photographers hoping to take advantage of Tokyo's outstanding night time vista's. Also, there are no tripods allowed which makes it even more difficult to take good night shots. The South observatory is only open until 5.30pm and is closed for the first and third Tuesday of every month. The North observatory is open until 11pm and is closed for the second and fourth Monday of every month. Whenever the North observatory is closed, the South opens until 11pm. There are cafes in both observatories and a bar in the North at night.At ground level, across the road, there is an amazing Assembly area which is reminiscent of ancient Greece and is worth a stroll through, or simply sit down and enjoy your lunch on one of the many bench seats.

Free tours and a great viewing area on top of either tower. The TMg is easily accessed from the Shinjuku Station or local hotels. The rooftop veiwng areas in either tower provide a 360 degree view of the surrounding skyscraper district and views as far a Mt Fuji on a clear day. You might see a person wandering around offeringa tour of the vista. Make sure to take them up on the offer as it will detail Tokyo's post war construction .and offer a view of the density of Tokyo living. But the real gem in this building is to go down to the tourist office on the first floor. Here you will find lots of free info and an opportunity to book a free tour of one of the prefectures. These guides, many of whom are retired, speak good English, and are part of a service provided through the tourism office. While they are free , you must pay for any expenses for the guide i.e. transportation costs, entry tickets etc. The one catch might be, you must book three days in advance. The office is only open till 3pm. The best times to view the city from the deck might be mid morning as it might be clearer.

Superb View...Wow!. It's worth a visit to the TMG, or "Tocho," as it's called in Japanese, to see the view from one of the two observation decks. It gave me a new respect for the enormity of the city's size and the largest metropolitan area in the world! I took pictures from every possible angle and hope to piece together the magnificent cityscape. Free admission is an added bonus! I went there in the late afternoon, but hope to go at night on my next visit to Tokyo.

Very nice view!. Definitely worth stopping by here to see the view from the observation decks if you can make time. An incredible view of just how huge Tokyo really is. I knew it was big but seeing it from the 45th floor brings a whole new and amazing perspective.

Great View of Tokyo - What a site!!. If you're lucky enough to be here on a relatively clear day, you can see Fujiyama ("Mt. Fuji"). Also a great place to see Tokyo Tower, Sky Tree and Tokyo Bay. Amazing architecture abounds. Also, wonderful shops to commemorate your trip or pick up souvenirs for family/friends.

Observatory for great Tokyo views. It's free and offers gat views of Tokyo there's even a little bar at the top to have a snack if you fancy it. It's all enclosed so if you want stunning photos make sure you take a polariser for your camera to cut down on reflections
360 view. One alternative if you're in Tokyo and wanting to get a 360 degree view of the city. Free and helpful staff.

Best Deal in Tokyo. This is a must night time experience when visiting Tokyo. The TMG is open to the public you can take the free elevator to the top of the tower which has an awesome 360 view of Tokyo. There is easy public access to TMG via the subway. There are interpretative signs at the windows identifying the major buildings and sections of Tokyo. This is best viewed at night as most of the skies during the day are smoggy and more difficult to see...but...at night spectular.There is a sovenior shop and restuarant. The restuarant has a small initimate bar over looking a portion of Tokyo. There are also tables next to windows looking over this fine city. The meals are reasonably priced ($12- $25). A beer cost $7. Some may debate the price issues but remember your at one of the tallest buildings and the atmosphere is very romantic and spectular. What a wonderful spot to bring friends or to impress your lady. You have to call and reserve a table next to the windows but we had a distant view at our table which was very nice.

Free views from a vantage point.. If you are lucky, you can see Mount Fuji and the setting sun. t's free, though it's a bit of a walk from Shinjuku Station. You can have a panoramic view of Tokyo from the viewing area. Recommended!

Nice FREE visit to observation floor. A nice view of the city with a gift shop and restaurant. First floor includes a Tokyo visitor's center with lots of information about neighborhoods and attractions.Worth a visit if only because it's free and in a great neighborhood.

a free overview on the Tokyo landscape. if you stay in shinjuku the visit to the 45th floor of the TMG is worthwhile:it's free, the queue to take the elevator is not so time consuming, and the view is really nice.no problem if you fell dizzy as I do: the feeling is not scaring, and the vision of night time Tokyo is distracting enough to forget the fear.there are plenty of souvenirs shop( not so incredible) and a bar/restaurant , sometimes with piano live music. the price are on the upper limit, and a " view tax" of 500 per person is applied ( just to give you and idea a guinnes and a coke plus the view extra: 2300 yen).

Amazing views. Went last minute in the evening and was one of the best decisions of the holiday!Incredible night views of the city, lovely (naturally expensive) bar/restaurant and would certainly recommend visiting.
Spectacular views. Long queues during the weekends, visit at dusk and you will be rewarded with spectacular views across the City,,,, and all at no cost.

An Ideal First Stop on a First Visit to Tokyo. After a number of visits to Tokyo & a couple of residences, I would recommend first-timers go here as soon as possible.Downstairs has a large clearinghouse of tourist information. Gather all your maps & guides into a bag (I think bags are even provided). Lots in English.The elevator ride is quick & the elevator ladies very polished. They give a very good & accurate impression of Japanese etiquette. They have the patience of saints with all us foreigners.What I like best of the city view is seeing how densely packed Tokyo is--wow! And then there's that one splotch of greenery down below: Shinjuku Central Park.Also, the architecture of some nearby buildings is pretty cool.The website is in perfect English & should be glanced at for hours & days open. The elevators are being worked on until fall 2013 so lines may take longer.I'd advise going on a clear day--we couldn't see Fuji. And we had no idea how people got in the other tower. Maybe next visit we'll figure that out!

Boring enough. The building itself is impressive, yes. And it has 2 towers with an observatory in each. Of course, the view from this spot is slightly impressive, and you can take a good look at the another buildings, but japanese people absolutely neglected of tourists. Sometimes I think that they disdain them. For example, in this observatory they have a restaurant. Nice! But... they close it at 5 p.m.!!! Very disappointing. Almost every park, observatory etc. in Japan close at 5 or 6 p.m. maximum. It's dull, really. They just kill tourism in Japan by their own arms.

great first stop!. I'd recommend this as a great way to start sightseeing in Tokyo. We had a clear day and could easily see Mt Fuji. Free 360 degree views of this amazing skyscraper city! (other towers all charge).
Check out Tokyo City Infrastructure from this building. It's close to the station so just a short hike and get the lift to the top for a nice view of the city.

Great FREE view. Great place to come if your on a budget and don't want to spend money visiting Tokyo Tower or any other high rise that might cost money to enjoy the view. This attraction is free and has the best views of Tokyo.

Free views!. Great place to go to see the tokyo skyline for free! two different buildings but the views aren't too different. To me, it's a lot better than tokyo tower and skytree because it's free and less well known so there is not too much of a line.
Great Views and organised. It was very orderly and had a great view of the whole of Tokyo. The kids like the minting machine for bronze coins.

Free access to observation decks. Great place to visit for views of the sun setting over Mount Fuji from 45 floors up as well as 360 degree views over the city - and it's free and a 10 minute walk form the west exit of Shinjuku Station
Great Views. Great view of the city! But go earlier in the day as it can quickly get crowded, and wait for a clear day to make the most of it!

Great Views Of Tokyo. Came here for a daytime view of Tokyo and best of all, its free entry! If you are in Shinjuku area (whether staying at a hotel in Shinjuku or intending to spend a good part of the day in Shinjuku), TMG is worth a visit (10 to 15min walk from South exit of Shinjuku station). Have yet to visit Tokyo Skytree so can't comment whether or not which building gives a better view but as far as I am concerned, it is more than decent on a clear day, and you can even spot Mount Fuji as well.Apart from both the North and South observatories, there are also tourist information centres - handy for picking up information on various tourist spots in Japan. As well as food outlets (basement levels and on the observatories itself - in North observatory, the cafe actually turns into a chill out bar at night, must say its a cool place to work in, heh) .... a 'hidden gem' will be the staff canteen at level 32 where you can get good value japanese meals for less than 700 yen.
