nice view of Tokyo. Go to the 45th floor and you have a fantastic view around.
Explanation (they are experimenting a new system) are not the best you can have) but you will enjoy

Great observation decks. There aren't too many places where you can get a great view of the city for free!
Also the tourist information desk in the foyer was very helpful and had some great maps of Tokyo.

OK in day time. It's an OK observatory in day time, but terrible at night. Stores there keep bright lights so you really can't see much night view. Don't waste your time going at night. On a clear day, you can see Mt. Fuji, so I guess it's an OK thing to do if you're on a low budget. If you can afford 1,500-2,000yen, I highly recommend the Tokyo City View or the Skytree.

Must visit when in Shinjuku. My wife and two grown sons visited Tokyo over the New Years holiday, and we love to search out bargains and free attractions. We were in the Shinjuku area and had to stop at the TMG. We had several days of heavy rains, but didn't get to go up the observatory until a few days later (we should have gone right afterwards). Even so, we still had a glimpse of Mt. Fuji. The elevator was fast, and we didn't experience any lines or waiting. Once at the observation deck, an English speaking tour guide showed us some of the major landmarks. Since there wasn't a wait, we also rode the elevator up the other tower's observatory. The views were almost the same, so if there's a long line, don't bother doing both. Overall, this is a must do. It really does complete your "sky scraper" tour of Shinjuku - and it's free!
Best free view in Tokyo. The view is better than Tokyo tower and it's free (at least it was when I was there). If weather is good, you might see mount Fuji!

Great Views, for free!. My husband and I visited twice during our trip to Japan - once during the day we visited the South tower. And then we came back at around 10pm to visit the North Tower, which is open to 11pm. The views are fantastic and we didn't find the line ups to be that long - we visited during November, not sure what it would be like during the high season. Even with a long wait, the price can't be beat! During the day, we were lucky to have fairly clear skies, the only thing we couldn't see was Mt. Fuji, which seemed to be a trend during our trip. At night, It was incredibly romantic - very few people, mostly young couples - and all the lights twinkling in the distance. Couldn't stop taking photos and videos. The only issue was that the gift shops had tons of lights on in the store and the vending machines, so it was difficult to take pictures - you really have to put your camera right up to the glass, and even then there was some reflection. But other than that, it was beautiful and I'll say again, you can't beat the price!

Excellent view, for free. The observation deck takes up the entire 45th floor of each tower. You need to select either the north or the south tower, so take this into account if there is something in particular you want to look at. Free admission, with a small gift shop, drink vending machines, and a small restaurant on the observation floor. Tourist information offices on the 1st and 2nd floors.

A great free alternative to the Skytree. Free entry to both the North and South Observatory. The north observatory opens until 11pm which is great for night viewing.Dining in the South Observatory was nice.

Great view for free. We went in the south tower only--I assume the view is similar from either, as we could see people in the observation level of the other tower. Just as we were thinking about leaving, a volunteer approached us and asked (in English) if we would like a free guided tour of the view. Eh...sure, why not. I have to say, I was very glad we took him up on his offer. It took about 15 minutes and was very enlightening; it was nice to know more about what we were looking at, and we left with directions to the Meiji Shrine (which is the big green area you see from up there), which we found to be a great experience we would not have sought out if not for our tour guide.

Tourist Info Office is EXCELLENT. If you really wanted to know what to do in Tokyo or how to gout to see Mt Fuji in a day, come here. They give excellent advice.If yo really are interested, you can even take a free English tour of the building.They can also share a list of places/venues where volunteers give free guided tours in English.

Great free aerial view of the metropolis known as Tokyo. This building is architecturally impressive in its exterior and is unique. It looks almost art deco in style. Enter the huge foyer and take the lift to the top floor to the viewing area. There you will see magnificent views of Tokyo from a 360 degree aerial perspective. The key buildings and landmarks are identified in Japanese and English to assist you with your bearings which I found very useful. Also on the top floor is a cafe and a gift shop with the surliest shop assistant I have encountered to date. This free view of Tokyo is worth the effort. It is about a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku station (provided you take the South exit).
45F's view is awesome!!. 45F iss free of charge and the view from 45F is great!! dont't miss this place when you visit Shinjuku station!
45F landscape is free charge. 9:30AM-11PM, 45F landscape is free charge. If you have a time, please try to have nice Itarian food at restaurant "OFFICINA".

Free and you may see Mt Fuji. Free attraction with 2 observation decks in the North and South Tower on Level 45. The views of the city are not fantastic, however it provides a good overview of Tokyo and the shear size of the city. I went up in the morning and there was no queue. As I went on a clear day I was able to see Mt Fuji in the distance which was very impressive.

Observatory in the South Tower = boss. In the south tower observatory, we had an English speaking volunteer guide who took us around and pointed out all of the buildings of interest. We also saw Mt Fuji as it was a clear day. The canteen in the south tower is cheap, the north tower has a pretentious and rather expensive faux-Italian restaurant.

a good overview. We were staying opposite at the Keio Plaza so this was our first port of call and it gave us a great overview of the area. The girl in the tourist office downstairs was also very helpful . There was also a display of produce from a regional area including lots of samples and this was great fun.
Great Views. Great free attraction for views from the 45th floor. Shops at top but very touristy. We went up at 9pm and the was a very short queue.

Free alternative to Skytree. There are 2 towers with viewing platforms in the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Offices. Admission is free, with luggage searched, and the queue on the day I went was not too bad at the North tower, despite only one elevator being in service. the view is OK but not outstanding; choose the clearest day possible and you may see more. Because part of the viewing floor is given over to a cafe, visitors not using the cafe cannot see 360 degrees round.One of the best parts of the visit is that on exiting, you leave by the main Tourist Information Center, with lots of opportunities for finding information and leaflets about the Tokyo area (2nd floor) and the rest of Japan (1st floor).
not to be missed. great views, free, no lines,,,,,a must for travelers that enjoy views,,,,without the lines of skytree

Free, great view of the city. Remarkably ugly (though impressive) building externally, offering fantastic city views from the gallery. I imagine the best time to go is dusk, though it was still worth the 30 minute queue for the night time view. They search bags on the way in, so avoid bringing contraband if you possibly can.

Excellent view of Tokyo and Mount Fuji. There are 2 towers to view, North and South. We had time for South tower only. It was a good choice as we saw Mount Fuji in the distance. Obervatory panels were large, unobstructed and there was almost a 360 degree view from the tower. Almost every view from the tower was scenic. There is also a souvenir shop and cafe there. It was also a good excursion location for lots of elementary school kids there when we visited. Lifts up were well controlled by staff and they were fast.

Awesome observatory. Great value for money at the free observatory. Ask for a guided tour from the visitor centre if you'd like. Nice views from 200m up, you can see Mount Fuji on a clear day. Also, interesting insights on how Tokyo is built up and laid out

Great views, affordable food.. I visited the South Observatory Deck at lunch time. The views were spectacular and it wasn't very busy. Be aware though that the windows are at odd angles so it is quite difficult to get a photo of the whole skyline. If you're happy to forgo a dazzling photograph, the views themselves make the trip extremely worthwhile. I also had lunch at the observatory restaurant - the food was average but very affordable.

top toy shop. went up the south tower at lunch time , free , fantastic views over Tokyo . Went up the north tower after dinner , wait for an hour then up top . View over Tokyo at night breathtaking plus there is a cool toy shop with great presents for family . also a coffee shop .

It's FREE, great views. not the tallest building but it was only two minutes from my hotel so went up to see the views of Tokyo. I was suitably impressed and did I mention it is free. Virtually 365 degree views of Tokyo well worth the very slow lift ride up.
Great View. free and worth going up at night and day, very close to the hotel and also a great park right near it, sadly there are a few homeless people sleeping in this park.

Tokyo under your feet. Went there on the first day, absolutely must go!!! It's free and you can see all Tokyo panorama. The day was quite clear and I was trying to see the Fuji mountain but did not get lucky. Still, definitely worth a trip.

Perspective. Flying into Narita, you really don't get a sense of just how huge Tokyo is. Change that with a trip to the observation deck of this building. You can also take advantage of the docents, who were very nice and showed me to areas that I had only ever seen on NHK. There is (of all things) an Italian restaurant at the top, along with some touristy gift shops, but go for the view. If it's too cloudy for Fuji-san, better spots are a short shinkansen ride away. Take your camera, sunglasses (the sun is really blinding up there) and leave your fear of heights/earthquakes at the bottom. For extra fun, leave your hotel room light on and something fun in the window, and try to take pictures from the tower at night.There is also a visitor's center with information for every prefecture, if you are spending more time outside of Tokyo than in it. After the observation deck, you could go to the park next door and see a great shrine, along with one of the larger homeless populations. Some bonus perspective for you.

Great views for free. One of several options for a sky-high view of Tokyo and the surrounding area. This one happens to be free. If you're in the Shinjuku area (west of the station), worth heading to the 45th floor of either tower.

Not bad. We walked from our hotel (Shinjuku Washington) to this building. Unfortunately it was overcast so we didn't get to enjoy the view that much. The good thing is that it was free to go up there.
Awesome.. Nice tokyo views. Good for photography. Day time is good time to visit. Audio free guides also available, which is nice.

Another great observatory and it's free. In a few words, it offers great views of the city, it's free, stays open till 11PM and you'll have a great time there if you have time to spare while being in Shinjuku.
Great view. I just went up for the view, and if you are on a budget and cant get to the Tokyo Tower or the Skytree, this is the place to go. On a clear day, you can see Mt. Fuji.

Great FREE Atrraction in Tokyo!. This is the best FREE view of Tokyo! It's even higher up than Tokyo Tower in Minato-ku and has sweeping views of the city in every direction. There's a gift shop on the observation deck and its open late; until 11pm. Definitely a do-not-miss attraction!
if you have more time. it's free.you can see tokyo from different angle. it's easy to find from shinjuku down town.actually it's not to special
Marvellous vista point. Free access to the observatory in each of the two office towers with beautiful views all over Tokyo; useful tourist info office on the ground floors

Stunning views and free of charge!. Lets face it, if you're in Tokyo you know how expensive it is! The Tokyo metropolitan government office is definately worth check out for two main reasons1) IT'S FREE!2) you get to see how gigantic Tokyo really is! It goes on forever and you really get to enjoy the view from up there. On a clear day you can see my Fuji!

A great free orientation to Tokyo. We took advantage of the free guide service and were taken to areas of the building that you cannot wander through. Our guide was a charming, well informed retiree. This service operates during office hours.The day we visited was raining so Mt. Fuji was not visible but in spite of that disappointment the vista was fabulous. Try to get back at night when the entrance is from the basement level.
Cheap!!!!. Great view over Tokyo, with clear view can even see Mt. Fuji.Great to see the sunset.The South Tower is only open till 5.30pm, the North Tower until 11pm
for free, it was great. Free entrance, opens late til 11PM and you get an English speaking guide for free. On a clear day or night, you can see Mt. Fuji.

Nice place but for "Free". It's a little bit far from Sshinjuku station (about 15mins to walk)
But nice view for FREE.
There is also a cafe at the observation floor.
If you are looking for the sightseeing spots for free, nice place.
Free views of Tokyo. You can go up to the 40th floor of this building and get a free panoramic view of the city...well worth a visit.
Free view from over 40th floor. Short walk from the main station. Sign posed from the station. A free view of this amazing city which stretches as far as the eye can see

nice place to see Tokyo city, and it's free!. went there in the afternoon as part of our short trip in Tokyo. location is really near from subway station, but you need to find correct exit. there are two tower there, south and north, with a different closing time, so you have to check it to the receptionist. you only need to queue in front of elevator, staffs there will help you to form the queue. a little inspection for your baggage, get in to the elevator, and voila, you have a free, VIP view of Tokyo city. I actually could see top of Mount Fuji from 45th floor. and it was really worth it, moreover considering that it's free. I really suggest you to make some place in your itinerary for a visit to TMG

View of Tokyo for free. Why pay to go to Skytree when you can get view of Tokyo for free. There are two lifts to take you to different side of the building. Try to go on clear day and see if you can spot Fuji-san

Visit the 45th Observation Deck in the North and South Towers. FREE, great views. All bags and packages inspected before you are allowed to go up in the elevator. Highly recommend you go up both towers, but if you can only do one, I would choose the South Tower - just my preference.

Awesome view-Free!. Awesome views of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji, all for free! Why pay for Tokyo tower? We went right at sunset so we got a beautiful day and night view of the whole city. For sure worth a visit.

well worth it. This is really easy to find - there is signed underground walkway from Shinjuku station - and its free! We went here in October 2012 around 10am and did not have to queue at all. As far as I can see both towers offered the same view.We had planned to go up the skytree but thought the view from here was great so didn't bother.

It's Free. Great way to get some sort of overview of Tokyo and apparently it is possible to see Fuji on a clear day. There's 2 towers with observation areas and souvenir shops. Tourist information is also available on the ground floor. We also went to Sky Tree which is an experience in itself. Do both.
Amazing view from 45th floor. Go to the ground floor reception....take a free guided tour and go to the 45th floor for a spectacular view....much better than Skytree.

Just OK but not impressed. We went on a Sunday afternoon ready for a long wait but surprisingly line was short. We were on the 45th floor of the North tower in 10 minutes. The view was nice but nothing to brag about. You can see the "cocoon" building, the Tokyo Skytree but overall I was not impressed with the city's panoramic view. Probably as they don't have that many very tall buildings and if you've been on top of Empire State Building that will not impress you, was just ok. I'm happy we didn't go to any of the other buildings that you have to pay for to get on top. This one is free. There are souvenir stands in the middle of the floor and also a restaurant with view.

Awesome panoramic views from two different towers on the 45th floor for FREE!. After reading reviews on TA about all the line ups and long waits to get into the new tower my husband and I opted to take in the birds eye view of Tokyo from the south tower of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building instead on the last day of our 3 day visit in Tokyo. We are so glad we did! Regrettably, it was only after we got there that we learned the north tower is open until 11pm for people to take in a beautiful night view of all the lights of the city which we weren't able to do as we were leaving Tokyo that afternoon. After taking the elevator to the 45th floor, as soon as we got off we were approached by an English speaking volunteer who took us around the 180 degree perimeter of the room to point out and explain various buildings. Some of the architecture was really interesting (the "cocoon" building for students of the arts) as well as both of the towers that Tokyo has become and is so famous for. We also saw the building where the Park Hyatt is located, the hotel featured in the Bill Murray movie Lost in Translation.One building she pointed out was 40 years old, with our guide telling us she remembers it being constructed and how special it was due to it's height back then. Since that time, buildings have become taller and taller.We didn't have time to explore the souvenir shop or dine in the cafe, both located on the 45th floor. We did obtain our "souvenir stamp" just in front of the elevator before leaving, two stamps actually; one with a picture of these twin towers and the other with the date and the name of the location. The lobby of the building is quite impressive and is directly above the subway, I believe it was the Odeo line. I believe our guide informed us the south tower is closed at 6pm (the north tower 11pm). Our hotel was able to direct us to this attraction so you may wish to have your hotel call to confirm the hours for you.This is definitely a great spot to take in a panoramic view of Tokyo without any cost or line ups for that matter.

Amazing views. There are two towers; go to the south one, where you will also have a clear view towards south (shibuya). I recommend going at/after sunset, since that's when all the lights turn on, and the scale of this metropolis becomes apparent.To make clean pictures, move your camera close to the glass wall, and use your hands or your clothes to block light coming from behind (and so prevent its reflection in your picture).

Great panoramic night view and it's free!. Went there during the night on weekdays, not so crowded so I can stand on a window alone by myself. If you want to take some pictures of Tokyo nightview, just put your camera lens close to the window and work on eliminating the room's light reflection by your hand. They also got a fine dining restaurant and souvenir shop.
Panoramic views. Free observation deck on the 47th floor. Panoramic views of Tokyo. We went up during the day and back after dark. There're English speaking guides on request.
Great view. Great views of the entire city. impressive gotham building. Tourist tinkery on top but fast to get to the top.

Great view for free. On a clear day you can see the whole Tokyo skyline. It's a fun free thing to do I you have some time to kill. It's not the most exciting thing to do but if you are in the area you will enjoy it. It is about a ten minute walk from the Shinjuku train station.
Excellent, FREE view of the city skyline!. Nothing else to see or do in the building blocks (except a cheap junk store and an expensive, busy restaurant), but worth a trip up if you are nearby!

A View of Tokyo for Free. What you pay for at Tokyo Tower, you can see at TMG for free :)Best time to catch a good view is before the sun sets... pictures away in the afternoon light and dusk. Wow factor.

Something free to do. Just a few blocks from Keio Plaza and other hotels. Find a clear day and head here for a panoramic view from the 45th floor. Some say the view is better from the southern tower. Above each window are captioned photos of the main highlights (city, building names, etc). Look for the commemorative rubber stamps by the exit elevator, past the gift shop. Visitor maps and tour information on the 2nd floor. Check website for exact hours and closures, as it varies by tower.

What a great FREE view. This was awesome. The view so nice we did it twice. Got lucky too, it was a eery clear day and we could just make out Mt. Fuji from either tower. I would suggest visiting the south tower as it allows for an uninterrupted picture and view of Yoyogi Park as well which stands out like a sore thumb for its greenery in the middle of the city. Super free too.

A sky view of the city. This building has 2 observation decks, one per tower. The good news is that they're free. They also provide good views of the city. The bad news is they've blocked some of the north deck with a cafe. newer buildings have also cut down the view.

Great Views!. Don't waste your time and money on Sky Tree! These two towers provide fantastic views of the whole city and, even Mt. Fuji on a clear day, and they are FREE!!! Two elevators, one for each tower, take you to the top where you can spend as much time as you like taking in the expanse of Tokyo. Each tower provides a slightly different view so it's worth it to go up both if you have time.

View is great - but food is even better!!. Yes, the view from the 45th floor of both the north and south towers is great - and it is free - but what a lot of people don't know is that you can get a great meal from the Government workers cafeteria on the 32nd floor. Even though it is primarily for the workers of this building, the public is allowed in as well. My top tip for lunch or dinner is to go to the 32nd floor of the north tower of the Metropolitan Government Office Building. There is a cafeteria for the workers there but the public is allowed in. Meals are very reasonable (all around 550Y) and the servings are large. Also provide free cold water. We ate here nearly every night as it was much better value that the restaurants around Shinjuku. The food was hot and fresh. When you get out of the lift on the 32nd floor, turn right and walk down the hallway about 150 metres. Food displays will be on the left down a small hallway. Note there are two lots of food displays so look at both before making your decision. Most of the words are in Japanese, but there is some english. But looking at the displays you can get a good idea of what each meal is. Then put your money into the vending machine and choose the corresponding number to the meal you want. Take the ticket to the counter and the staff will get your meal. Then sit at a table near the window for a great view over Shinjuku (remember you are on the 32nd floor). Return your tray to the mobile food racks (you can't miss them). If you are staying in the Shinjuku area, this is a real bargain, Enjoy!
Dizzy. A place to get souvernirs, thats all. Fun time observing statues at the square. Come early or late as there are only 2 lifts functioning. The souvernirs are nice, but not that cheap

free views of Tokyo and surroundings. the wait is only about 10-15 minutes long, the access is free and the view is stunning. we even got a glimpse od Fuji-san, the Landmark tower in Yokohama and of course the new Sky Tree, which is for now nice to spot from the little alleys in the neighborhood

Looking good. The view of Tokyo from the Government Office is fantastic. If you are an English speaker they give you a headset to tell you about all the building that you are looking at. The narration can get a bit boring but the headset is free so it is worthwhile. You get a 360 degree view of the city so even if you don't get the headset you can enjoy the view.
Nice Views. Interesting architecture. You can also go to the top of both the north and south towers for free to view the city. In one of the tower's there is a restaurant.

Awesome building and views. A very impressive building in a typically Japanese way. You can go to the top of both towers for free and snap pictures of Tokyo. There's also some pretty sweet gift shops up there too. I liked the maps showing the different parts of Tokyo. An excellent lookout.

The night views are not as good as before but sunsets are fab!. I have been up the towers many times and came to a conclusion that the night view is not as spectacular as before due to energy saving measures in Tokyo. Hence, I decided to time my third trip there during sunset and it was magnificent! I was blessed with a clear day and could see the sea from certain windows. My brother and I were going nuts dancing from window to window taking picture after picture. It is a very very long walk from the station, but the view is fabulous for a free attraction.

A 20 minute walk from Shinjuku station. Worth the 20 minute walk from station, the station at the TMG seemed closed. Free entrance, and really worth going to the Observation Deck on 45th floor to get a better idea of the scale of Tokyo. We were not lucky with a clear day that offers a view of Mount Fuji but found it well worth the visit.

Good place to get an aerial view of Tokyo city. The entry is free, and the view from the 45th floor is very nice. However, the area is way too large (around 700m in diameter) and hence it doesn't give the exciting feeling of being on top of a tall building. The view is very good (the places that you see are marked and named in a map next to the window, so you actually know what you are seeing). However, there is a lot of space around the windows that are used for multiple exhibitions, so it's a little busy. There is a restaurant also in the center of the floor, but has almost no view of the city beneath, since it's surronded by 4 foot high potted plants. A souvenir shop is also available. Overall a good visit if you are in the area, but okay to miss.
Great views. Get a lift to the top of the building for a magnificent, free, view of the city. Some kitsch stuff for sale in the shop on the viewing floor too
Great views of Tokyo-free. Can get quite busy but worth a little wait. Great views of Tokyo skyline for free, day and night, well worth a visit. Good central location in shinjuku.

Good views - needs upgrading. You are treated to good views at the top, but the viewing area and shop are outdated with printed out sheets of A4 paper and bad English in use, complimented by tatty surroundings. The ambience and feel of Roppongi hills is better. I went once to the TMG and never repeated; I have been to the viewing gallery in Roppongi hills countless times.

FREE birds eye view of Tokyo!. Free entry for a great view of a city that stretches to the horizon in every direction and Mt Fuji poking through the clouds. We arrived 20 mins before sunset on a weekday but the line was 30mins long so we just missed it. Highly recommend this rewarding observatory, but if you want to see sunset make sure you're there at least an hour beforehand.

Good views from the observation deck. TMG is open for free to the public every weekday starting at 9:30am. You should get there by 9am though unless you like to wait in long lines. They take groups of about 20 at a time up to the observation deck on the 45th floor, where you have nearly 360 degree views of Tokyo, a small gift shop, a bar/restaurant, and some exhibits. You can stay as long as you want, but realistically 30 minutes or so is probably enough. The views really depend on the weather conditions but if it's clear they're really good. The TMG won't be the highlight of your day, but you should definitely check it out if you're in Tokyo.
Free and not too busy. Went here the day after the Tokyo Sky Tree where we had to wait in line for an hour to get tickets. This place is just as nice and no people to block your view.

nice trip up the elevator with free views on top. i stayed at the keio plaza hotel so this place was literary opposite my hotel. easy access. many tourists but not too crowded. too bad we went up on a hazy day so didn't get to see much except for the nearby parks and the tokyo sky tree. too hazy to see mount fuji though. there were plenty of space for you to walk around the observatory deck and benches for you to rest your legs. there is a cafe, rest room, and a small souvenir shop on the observation floor as well. best of all it's free!!

FREE. FREE view of all of Tokyo. Views are better on the North Tower but the hours are different and limited. See both towers if possible. Free maps downstairs. A must first-stop for new visitors in Tokyo.
A must. Just for the view and architecture , make the trip. Central and worth the visit for the views. Great spot

easy to get to, great views and all for free. The TMG building is serviced by the Tochomae metro station E28 so is easy to get to. Alternatively you can walk it from Shinjuku railway station in 10 mins by following the signs. We only spent a few minutes queuing (even with the reduction in the number of available lifts) and were rewarded by spectacular views of the city and unlike every other site it was absolutely free. Note that the north tower is now open until 2300 so night time shots are possible although we haven't tried this - Roppongi hills is probably better located. Tripods are not allowed (nor for some reason is sketching)

Great views and convenient hours. The one downside to our trip to Tokyo was that it was cloudy the entire time so we were not able to see Mt. Fuji from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (or anywhere in Tokyo). Nonetheless, we decided to go there to see great night views of the city. I don't remember when it closes, but it is fairly late. I rather liked walking through the area (government/business buildings) at night when there was no one around because it was peaceful and quiet but still felt very safe. They have a very well-oiled machine there -- an elevator to take you to the top and attendants at the elevator helping you out, so it is very user-friendly (and free!) At the top they have 360 degree views, a cute gift shop, and a restaurant (I didn't eat there). And, of course, very clean bathrooms. It is certainly worth a trip -- the best place to get free views of the city.

Go only during the day time.. This is a nice free sightseeeing option, a must do to get a great view of the city. Sadly there are some major mis-steps that ruin its potential as a viewing platform/observatory for the city.Go during the day time, you will get the best pictures this way. I went at night and unfortunately the interior lighting is so bright and close to the mirrors they will ruin all your pictures. It's painful to travel to japan with expensive photography equipment with the hope of getting beatiful nighttime skyline shots only to find out that the interior setup is geared more towards selling you kitchy souvenirs than providing a proper observation platform.Second, a majority of the east facing windows, the ones you WANT to be looking thru are dedicated for a restaurant. So non-restaurant patrons have to fight over limited viewing space. There are more windows facing west but all you'll see is bland featureless suburbs.Honestly, I'd recommend going over to the Rippongi City View observation deck instead. It costs money, but the setup there is fantastic. At night the areas by the windows are isolated and not lit, photographers will be able to capture wonderful photos here.

Great view of Tokyo but.... Great view of Tokyo but be aware that only one elevator is operational (one is under repair) which means that you may have to stand in line for 30-45 minutes both on the way up and on the way down.

Very tall, very free!. I felt guilty getting in for nothing so I bought a bunch of junk at the souvenir shop (the one in the tower closest to the Hyatt is better). It's still sitting on my dresser, anybody need a Totoro phone charm?

Excellent view over Tokyo. Great spot to see how large Tokyo really is. Easy and free access. Reasonably good souvenir shop on the north tower, better one on the south (or that maybe be vice versa - sorry can't remember!) Well worth the visit!

Free Free Free. This building has great 360' degree views of Tokyo and best of all its free. It was like going to the Empire State Building, but it was Tokyo and it was free. We even got a free tour from a local volunteer of the inside of the building and learned about its history.
Great view from inside the observation level. It is no charge to visit the observation level. The view is very good of Tokyo.

Nice views but not the greatest. Given that is free, no reason to complain but if you want a view with a lot of skyscrapers this is not really it. Most view directions are away from the real big towers. But it's a nice quick trip, open until late at night. Combine with the huge camera shop and dinner at one of many little shops in the area.

The best / cheapest view in town.!. Ok , so head for shinjuku early morning and enter the Govt building . Ground floor you'll find tourist info in English ( great ! ) and head for the observation deck .From here you will get a excellent view of the city and on a clear day Mt. Fuji too . It's free and gives you a perspective of the great city of Tokyo !

Good views, easy to get to, and free. Free admission, interesting building, and easy walk from Shinjuku hotels. There is an underground passage most of the way from Shinjuku station, with some moving sidewalks (on left hand side of street). It's free! Gift shop & restaurant in at least one tower observation area (North if I recall).
The views!. Could not miss the view from the top floor of the governement office! Went there during the night, which provided an incredable view of the lights in the vast Tokyo area.

Great view of Tokyo. I recommend going here, especially since it's free. I have heard that the view is better from the Tokyo Tower (where you have to pay). Unfortunately we went up on an overcast day so we could not see Mt. Fuji but still it offers a great view of Tokyo.

A must in Tokyo, and it's free!. Great view from both towers. You'll even see Mt. Fuji in a very clear day from the 46th floor, but it's not easy to find one of these there in summer. 360 view with clean windows, a very importan factor to take pics or videos. Be sure to get into the main hall, because there are two main entries and two more that they would drive you to some public offices, in the annexed buildings.

Tired shops but wow what a view and free!. Forget about all the other lookouts including Tokyo Tower, the TMG is the best and its free! Awesome view right across Tokyo and even Mt Fuji on a clear day. The shops are a little tired and I think they are about to be renovated.

"Lost in Translation" view for Free :). What is not to love about this place? It's free and it's around the corner from the Park Hyatt New York Bar (as made famous in Lost in Translation) which costs Y2200 per person to get in, nevermind having a drink too. We went and watched the sun go down near Mount Fuji and hung around to watch Tokyo light up.
Nice views. Free access to viewing deck on both towers with great views of Tokyo. Theres a bar up there too, but it is expensive.

Interesting Attraction Venue. We went here by walking from our hotel at Shinjuku Prince Hotel and though we spent around an hour walking around and get lost occasionally, we are not disappointed at all.It was just after dinner so we decided to visit this place whom I read on the internet earlier. The government buildings are huge and you must carefully look for the entrance to the top floors. Once you are upstairs, you can basically see the Tokyo's glamouring skyline. There are also several shops selling food and unique souvenirs. I bought a small umbrella there.

Good place to start. On the ground floor, or maybe 1st, there is a tourist information centre that has many brochures and displays to assist the travels in Tokyo. English speaking staff are also on hand to assist with inquiries.

Great views of the city. It may sound a bit cheesy and touristy, but the cafe high up in the government tower is an absolutely fantastic place to get a birds' eye view of Tokyo. There is nothing much to see around the building, or even inside itself, but the view is well worth the minimal effort of getting there and going up.
baffling destination choice. who cares? I mean, are tourists really interested?

Hard to find on foot!. We went the wrong way a few times when trying to find our way here but when we did it was outstanding! The lift shot up and opened onto a huge room with shops and places to eat and an entire wall of windows giving the almost perfect views of Tokyo, with the naked eye the view was perfect, but when I tried taking pictures it was very difficult because of all the lighting in the restaurants.
Bird's eye view of Tokyo..Mt. Fuji and Tokyo tower can be seen too.. The entrance is free!! And you can see the whole of Tokyo so clearly!

Magnificient view of Tokyo.. I would say, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office is the better place to capture the view of Tokyo compared to the new Tokyo Tower. And the plus point is that it's FREE to go up there instead of paying few hundred yens to go up to the Tokyo Tower. And since there is not much high skyscraper in Tokyo, the TMG is good enough to capture the view of Tokyo (the object below the building will not look too tiny). If you go for the Tokyo Tower, objects capture will be too tiny to be seen inside the photos because it's too high.
Nice Views. Nice views for free on a clear day but otherwise not much else do to.

Grab a good city look. I walked from the west exit of Shinjuku station, its pretty much sign posted all the way and took me about 20 minutes or so to reach North tower. Security checks your bag before you enter the lift up to level 45, (well they glimpse without even the slightest bit of interest) and the veiws are okay i suppose. 45 stories is not a massive way up but i have no right to complain about a place designed at no cost for my enjoyment.
Fantastic view. It's a free view over the city. Go up ( take the camera) and look around. Most places would charge you an arm and a leg for that view.
free panoramic view. Access to 47th floor is free and views are superb.
Great view - for free. Go on a clear day and the view is outstanding. You are able to get a wonderful panoramic view of the city - and it's free!

Nice views, no queues, free. Definitely worth stopping by here to take in the views of Tokyo! Observation platform is free and there was no queue or long wait to go up. I think it's on the 54th floor? When you get up there, there is a small restaurant and souvenir shop. Nothing spectacular to do other than take in the views.

Free high view of Tokyo!. Catch the lift straight up and BAMM you have an instant view of Tokyo. Great shop inside to get a number of gifts.
Night time is a little tough to take photos without a massive reflection so perhaps they could have a dark room but then again you don't pay to go up so not a big deal.

Great views for free. This is a great building to go to in the heart of the "Skyscraper" district of Tokyo. Clear day views are amazing but even on normal smoggy days overlooking the city gives you an amazing perspective of the urban sprawl.
If you are in Shinjuku definitely worth the elevator ride to the top!

Excellent views and also free guide. The access to the Observation Deck on the 45th floor is not only free but a free guided tour is also available ! Go Tokyo provides the services of a knowledgeable volunteer to show around the Observation Deck the most interesting points of Tokyo on different topics : architecture , culture , finance , history and even sports ! Normally the tour lasts around 20 minutes but the guide that we had spent 45 minutes with us ! Just ask at the information desk at the entrance . The guide is usually available from 10 a.m. to 3 pm and no reservation required If the guide is not available or if someone prefers a self-guided tour , an audio-guide tour is available in different languages . One thing to remember : to get the earphones , one has to provide in garantee a driving permit or a passport and in both cases an original not a copy !

One of the best free sights in Tokyo. This observation deck is located near the top of the building. Its free. How can you go wrong?The line moves quickly for the elevator and like everything in Japan is very efficient. I can't imagine paying ¥1000-1500 on the Tokyo Tower or the new Sky Tree (wasn't open yet in April 2012) when this place is there.I went to the south tower because there is a cafe in that one.There is also a little souvenir shop and reasonably priced vending machines if you don't want to pay to sit.

Good views. The views are fantastic but the area has many areas to purchase toys rather than souvenirs which would be more appropriate. On the day we went the temperature was unbearablely hot and had it not been free we would have complained as it was uncomfortable. Go for the views nothing else.

Go to the top and check out the view!. There are two viewing points - north and south. North is better, in my opinion, because you can see Fuji on a clear day! Make sure you go up again when it's dark because it is fantastic!
Excellent views. Free, accessible day and in the evening. Excellent views, the evening wAs most interesting for us.

Don´t Miss This View. There are two observation platforms in the TMG : north and south. As they are both free of charge and next to each other, go to both - the views of Tokyo are breath taking. On a very bright day you can even see Mt. Fuji - but thats mostly in winter and I was not so lucky...
Bird's eye view of Tokyo. It's true, you can go up this one free of charge, nice views in all directions, also some souvenirs to purchase. Location is great.

Fabulous views. The best time to go is right after a big rain storm. The air is clear and this is the best time to see Mt Fuji. If you want to get an idea of the actual size of the Tokyo Metro area a visit here is a must. The best part is that it is free.
Nice building to get a view of Tokyo. No entrance fee, but the service is excellent, the staffs are very helpfull.

A Shrine to Excessive Gov't Spending. If you're wondering why Japan has the highest per capital government debt, look no further. This monstrous, castle-like mega complex, built at the behest of overpaid bureaucrats who wanted a cushy perch from which to spend their weekdays looking down on the worker ants who paid for it all. The upside is that the observation deck is free to the public. Take a ride to the 45th floor and enjoy the same great city views that the governor enjoys. Spectacular!

Good views on a clear day. Quick lift to the viewing floor and free. We stayed on a high floor in the Hilton so views were not that much differrent, but still worth a visit as given a guide so you knew what you were looking at.

Free view of Tokyo. If you're going to Shinjuku to check out the crowds and shopping, take the exit to TMG.You get to see Tokyo from the clouds. It also houses the Tokyo Tourist Office, and there are free tours of the building itself (40mins).

Brilliant views at no cost.. This buidling contains two towers both of which have viewing floors open to the public and they are completely free of charge. You can spend as much time there as you like walking around getting a 360 degree view of Tokyo and beyond, on a clear day you can even see Mt Fuji. There is a restaurant at the top as well as a few shops. We actually spent over an hour up there. Good place to go to on your first day in Tokyo and you can get an idea of the layout of the city.
Its FREE!. It really is free... the view from the top is magnificent.

Free Observatory!. The architecture of the Building is gorgeous, so as all skyscrapers in Nishi-Shinjuku, This building offers you a marvelous free observatory, there you can get a wonderful view of Tokyo. Since its free, I went there plenty of times to get different views and pictures of Tokyo (by day, by sunset, by night).

alternative observatory building. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office (TMG) can be an alternative to observe Tokyo. It gives the same view (in my opinion) as Tokyo tower and the good thing is it is FREE while in Tokyo tower you should pay for admission. I went to TMG in the day time and it was sunny, for me it would be nice to observe at night with the city light view.To get this building, it is easy to access from Shinjuku and you would find the LOVE sign like in Philadelphia that is the sign that you are close to TMG just cross the street and you will see the fancy building.

good view of the city, twice. you can explore the 2 towers viewing tower if you got time. and it is FREE!! however, one tower can allows you a good view of the city. Too bad it was cloudy when I was there and I cant view Mount fuji but still had a good time. You can also explore the park directly underneath the building but there are quite a few homeless people staying in the park. Next to it is a old temple worth exploring too. There is a direct underground subway that connects to the building.

Excellent views of the city for free.. Quick elevator ride takes you to the 45th floor of the TMG. There you'll enjoy incredible views of the city with printed guides calling out the points of interest in your view.
Did I mention this is free? Best bet is to take the subway there on the Oedo line, or to Shinjuku Station and walk.
good views of the city. excellent views of the city suggested as the first starting point of your sightseeing trip

Awesome view for free. The view is magnificent, I could spend easily an hour here taking pictures or just watching the buzzing city beneath. But do not expect that you will see Mt.Fuji, the chance is very low. I came here second time after the dark just to see the night city and it was again awesome.

Great views - and FREE. Located in Shinjuku, not far from Shinjuku Station. The building itself is cool, and the views from the top are worth checking out. And it's not usually very crowded. Preferred this to Tokyo Tower.

Never Knew How Fun This Would Be. Stayed in this area for years and never took the trip. It was free and there was no wait. English speaking guide volunteers gave personal insight. In and out in 20 minutes, and great tourist support offices on the ground floors. Do not let the entry way intimidate you.
A great view, for free!. It's free, and when I went just after dinner, there was no queue - what's not to like?
Best overlook. It is free and a good overlook about Tokyo. It Is also a good souvenir shop. I can't see Mt. Fuji becauce it was to cloudy. Come on a clear day

Birds eye view of Tokyo. Avoid the tourist traps and go to the top of the building complex - free observation tower with panoramic view of the city. Ten minute walk from Shinjuku train/subway station. Well organized with high speed elevators to the top of the building.
Less queues but still great views. The quieter option than Tokyo tower and the soon to be opened Sky Tree. Its free, its higher than the tower and the queues are significantly smaller.

Knockout panorama. This place gives one of the finest panoramas of Tokyo. I was hoping to see Mt. Fuji in the distance, but it was playing hard-to-get (hidden in the clouds). The observatory is free, and the views are breathtaking. Perhaps the best is the view of the Shinjuku skyscrapers at night.

Great free attraction....make sure its a clear day. Always come here at least once when in Tokyo. Always go up both towers. To see Mount Fuji from here you need to come on a clear day, otherwise its a view of Tokyo only. This is good especially at night when the lights are coming on.A nice cafe for a drink in one. The other has a good souvenir shop. Well worth a visit, not least because its free.
Excellent view from the top. Admission is free, five minute walk from Keio Plaza Hotel, can see almost all of Tokyo. Gift shops on the floor have good selection.
Great views for free!. It was a convenient walk from the Hyatt Regency and for free as well!

Wonderful Modern Architecture, Free Observation Towers. The architecture and garden areas with sculptures, and sitting areas were marvelous. The government buildings also offer two observation towers with great views, and souvenir shops, and a restaurant. Access to the observation towers are free! The structures also offer tourist information for both Japan and Tokyo, as well as a coffee shop, and other shopping. opportunities.
Observatory. Gives you a good chance to get an idea of the layout, size and in some parts chaos, that is this part of Tokyo

Great views of Tokyo. Awesome views of Tokyo from the observation deck. It was quick too, no queues to wait in to get up the top. Best of all, it's FREE! Definitely would recommend to any Tokyo sightseers!
Tall. Atchitecture great but just another getting old high rise.
Great View. If your staying in Shinjuku and it's a clear day get the lay of the land
Good view, but... Just like every other tall building, of course there is a good view, and it is free, but I wouldn't bother going back another time.
Great view up there!. Go check out the observatory decks. They offer a fantastic view of Tokyo's cityscape!
Great view, and best of all: IT"S FREE!!. Was there in the early afternoon.Unfortunately, wasn't able to see Mt Fuji as there was too much fog over the there. However, the view was still amazing.
A great free way of a taking in Tokyo's skyline. Great views of Tokyo from the top of this building, and it's free!
very good. Free observatory north and south,nearer to JR station,friendly volunteers

Great 360 degree view of Tokyo. As Tokyo is so built up, its easy to lose your orientation. This observation deck was a nice way to view Tokyo city from up above, and actually see how dense it really was!
There's also a nice tourist shop, though it was a bit pricey and gimmicky.
Free View of Shinjuku. You can go to the top floors for free and view sprawling Tokyo, definitely worth a visit.

Nice View and Inexpensive Meals. This observatory is free. When the sky is clear, you can see Mt.Fuji. There are shops where sell many kinds of souvenir. I ate some inexpensive lunch at the conteen where the goverment staff eat regularly.

night view is great. good view! you really feel like you r in Tokyo with all its skyscrapes all around. I cant tell which is better: to go during daytime, when you can see everything clearly or in the evening and to enjoy the night view of Tokyo. Both would be nice.
Budget Views. Forget Tokyo Tower. This is one of the cheapest (free) ways of getting that famous sky high view of the Tokyo.

Good things in life can be free!. Hey, this place is free. Great views all over the city, great for if you have just arrived in Tokyo and need to get a sense of directions! There is an excellent tourist office on the 1st floor as well with really useful guidebooks.
Views!. You might be staying near here. Great views of Fuji from the top - free viewing
Free!. It's free! You get to see all of Tokyo from the top! It's free! Can't ask for more. Did I mention it's free?

That's for free!!. You can enjoy sky watching from the top of Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office. (It's free). It might be the only place that doesn't cost you. Go, it is located near Shinjuku Station.

Helpful indeed. Been using the TMG tourist information few times during my recent stay in Tokyo. Nothing was too much for the Ladies working over there. Been given an answer on every question, pointed how to get to the place of interest, what to avoid, when to go etc.There is plenty of free maps of Tokyo with photos and directions what is a great help...
View from the top. You can go up to the top of the Metropolitan Government Office building. There is an observation deck where you can check out the Tokyo cityscape, free of charge.

Excellent view!. It takes about 10 minutes to walk from the Shinjuku Stn.You can go to the observation floor and see theexcellent view from there. It's much better than the TokyoTower... because it is free! Also you can see the Tokyo Tower!!When it's winter you can often see the Mt. Fuji, too.You can't miss this place.
Easy to visit if you're staying nearby. Not much to see other than the view. Lots of homeless sitting on all the benches in the park opposite.

Excellent Views.... The complex is easy to reach, there are two towers, entry to both is free and on a good, clear day you can see Mt Fuji (I could!).Be patient, find yourself a good spot, and take lots of pictures!
cool place. they are nice and kind to help you esp. in ridding train here in japan

On a clear day, you can see forever.. With apologies to Anthony Newley, the view from the 45th floor of Building #1 in the TMG complex on a clear winter day is exhilarating. A city of over 30 million spreads out to the horizon in all directions, with Mt. Fuji easily seen in the southwest. Making it even more memorable is the free guided tour from English speaking docents. The very sweet lady who walked me around the observatory was 56 like me and was able to add her own insight into the growth of Tokyo from post- war years to the present. This conversation was totally unexpected and very memorable. Take the 10 minute walk west from Shinjuku station. It will be well worth your time.

Nice view to the city and Fuji mountain fro FREE. Free, yes it is free to observatory deck. South and North building. We went up North at night (because they close south one at night) and South in the morning. South observatory deck has bigger windows and better gift shops.

Great views. Only about a 10min walk from shijuku station, but that is if you know where you are going. We circled the complex a bit trying to find the way in the the tourist information centre that is located there - poor signage. Just be chance we realised that we were able to go up the towers free of charge.There is a free audio guide (passport deposit required) though all it does is list the vital statistics of the building you can see. Is a gift shop and overpriced cafe on the viewing deck. Well worth it for the view - free of charge so why pay to go up Tokyo tower?.
Excellent views for free!. Excellent views for free! Cheaper than visiting tokyo tower. Tourist information is in this building too.
Great for a Tokyo night view. You can see all Tokyo city in bird eye view from this building for free, unlike Tokyo tower.
Great views of Tokyo. An added plus was the Tokyo Information Center in the building which was quite convenient

great views of tokyo. These buildings are a five / ten minute walk from shinjuku station. they are free and open from 10am until 11pm. the view from either tower is fantastic. One of the towers has a bar in the observatory. I was lucky enough on one the days i went to get a view of Mt Fuji , i think this happens about 20% of the time. The view on a night is something special as well. not to be missed.

Free Observatory Decks. Instead of Tokyo Tower, we walked 5 mins from the hotel to two observatory decks on the 45th floor that gave us a fabulous view of Tokyo skyline both from North and South Towers - go to both! It's worth the trip.

Great free view of Tokyo!. The view was amazing, and it was free! Quite fun just to walk around the area afterwards too with so many cool and tall buildings to look at... a great place to start to get idea of how Tokyo is oriented!
Good Views. Can be a trek from Shinjuku station, but the views are great.

Mt Fuji on a clear winters day. The observation tower at TMG is a must if you are in the Shinjuku area. We were fortunate enough to visit on a clear winters day and Mt Fuji was clearly visible on the horizon. This was our highlight but the views of all areas of Tokyo are quite superb.

Free Obsevation Deck. One of the best places to see Tokyo from above, for free.If you are here in winter, you can even see Mt Fuji.Not many other reasons to visit Shinjuku unless you are an architect student.
Probably best views 'in town'. The whole Tokyo splitted in four aspects - together one whole panorama. And it's free.
View from the sky. The free observatory is a great way to see an aerial view of Tokyo. Get crammed in to the elevator to the top and reward yourself with amazing views.

tokyo view for free. they have a saying that good things in life come for free... this sight is good especially in a city known to have very expensive upkeep...they give you a glimpse of tokyo skyscrapers without a fee... what more you could ask. the people are very helpful in maintaining the crowd and visitors in order. and the not so common manual bag check, which i think all my stay in japan happened for the first timethe building is like a replica of some building in NY. expect hoards of people coming....but the pacing is fast, so waiting is not so long.
Wonder City Views for Free. Most observation floors throughout Tokyo have an entrance fee but this is free and offers great city views and a reasonably priced souvenir shop - cash only though!
Take in a free view.. A quick little distraction if you have time to kill.

Fantastic! Free! Great view of Tokyo city.. We popped in here after realising our hotel was just round the corner. I didn't think my husband knew what he was talking about as he said he had read about free access to the top floor. As it's a government building I was sceptical but he was right. We went in & after security checks, got the lift to the observatory which gave us amazing views of Tokyo. Apparantly you can see all the way to Mount Fuji on a good day but it was too hazy for us to see that far. We took some really good photos as we were allowed cameras, which was good. There was a cafe but we didn;t have anything. There was also a few little displays, where I was able to dress up as a Japanese farmer & an underwater diver, getting ridiculous but fun pictures taken. There was a friendly member of staff who came up & started telling us about the area & some information about the building in English, which was nice. The souvenier shop had lots of lovely stuff in it which I hadn;t seen in other shops. Definately worth a visit.
FREE VIEWS!. fabulous views over Tokyo and to Mt Fuji. And not a Yen to pay.
great views. Normally great views from FREE lift to 45th floor but sadly it was dull, still great to look down on Shinjuku

great views, but was what you'd expect. great views of tokyo, bit of a line to get up there but only waited about 10 mins, when we came down from the lift the linewas very long would have been maybe an hour wait.

Magnificent. The best part of this attraction is that it's free. But beware of hordes of tourists since it is a tourist attraction, after all.Although it was raining the night I went up here, the night view was still gorgeous, regardless. There was a gift shop in the middle, which sold the cutest things ever! If you want souvenirs with "TOKYO" all over it, here's the place. Tokyo 2016 posters (this was in August 2008, in case you were wondering) were hung across the walls and even outside. Just a great experience and a must-see, you have nothing to lose! You usually pay to go up to see skylines and such but I'm glad this is a free attraction. I'm not sure if TMG is the City Hall of Tokyo (maybe it is), but

Birds Eye View of Central Tokyo. The viewing from the TMG is a wonderful experience. It gave us a bird's eye view of Shinkuku and seeminly the rest of Central tokyo. Seeing the place from above allowed us to orient ourselves which really helped in our walking tour. The best part of the TMG is that there are volunteer tour guides who patiently explained to us the view and the significance of the buildings around us.. yes we learned a lot from that one visit.

great place for tokyo night scene, most importantly, it's free. there's a south & north observation deck, which you can visit both with a direct elevator to the 45th floor, if u visit in nov, do note to go around 4pm, where u can see the sunset & the sky turn dark blue, which is very beautiful when all the lights are turn on prior to the pitchy dark. take note dat one of the deck closed earlier
Free and easy to access with great views. I accessed the top level to get a view of the city and Mt Fiji, pretty impressive and nice that is was free!

Terrific views of Tokyo at night. We visited the observatory in the South Tower of the complex. There are windows all around the observatory floor & the night-time views are excellent. You can really get a feel of the expanse of Tokyo city. Its a pity that one cannot shoot clean pictures of the city skyline at night due to the light reflections from souvenir shops inside. There's also a restaurant inside with live music.

Excellent views of the city...and its free. The observation floor of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government building provides excellent (and free, unlike the equally interesting views from Sunshine City 60) views of Tokyo. When we went up we were lucky enough to be able to see Mt. Fuji as well. Highly recommended for anyone that has interest in getting a perspective on the scope of Tokyo.

Spectacular views of Tokyo for free. This government building has free guided tours, just go to the tourist office downstairs from the main entrance. Even if you don't want a tour you can just take the lifts to the 45th floor where there is an observatory giving 360 views of the city. By each window is a photograph of the view indicating all the points of interest. On a clear day you can even see Mount Fuji. There are 2 towers each with an observatory, one of which is open till 11pm so well worth going twice, once during the day and again at night. There is also a restaurant, bar and souvenir shop.

Free and great views of Tokyo from the observation deck. If you are in the West Shinjuku area be sure to take a trip to the observation deck of the TGO building. It's free and there are great views of the city in all directions. We couldn't see Mt Fuji through the summer smog but it may be visible on sunny winter days.There is a cafe at the top but it doesn't have much in the way of food. Okay for a cold drink though.

Excellent as long as it's not a heatwave. This building is practically a wonder - and certainly most impressive. We found quite a bit of interest in it (and last time we were there we were given a personal tour of the building. It was free.)However, the observation tower was unairconditioned and it was so stifling we could barely manage to stay there for more than 10 mins. Maybe the a/c was broken that day??But the views are wonderful - and doubly so if you by any chance get a glimpse of Mt. Fuji.
Spectacular view. Get there early to avoid the line. Take your camera. It doesn't take long to see the view but you may find yourself gazing for a while.
Not bad for a free observation deck. Choice of 2 observation decks. Only building two is open late.

Free observation deck with great view. This building has a tourist information center on the first floor (of the first building) and also a free observation deck on the 42 floor, so you get a good areal view of Tokyo. For being free, it's an attraction you can't miss!

Great free view. Not many things are free in Tokyo, but looking out the windows of TMG is. On a clear day, you can see forever. The day I was there wasn't so clear, but you're so far up, you can still see quite a large portion of Shinjuku. Worth the money, and make sure you check out all the windows, the view is different from some of them.

Great view of the city for free with a possibility to see mount Fuji. Tokyo Metropolitan Government buildings are worth the visit if you are in Shinjuku. There are two observatories on the 45th floor at 202 m. On a clear day you might see mount Fuji. Overall you get a great 360 degree view of Tokyo, for free. It is also the starting place for the annual Tokyo marathon, so for many of us it's an emotial place to return to. To sum it up: it is wort the visit for the great view alone. In my opinion the view of the city is not surpassed by Tokyo tower especially if you can visit in the evening as well.

Great Place. This place is not only an observatory and offices (it is these of course), but also there are a complet tourism office (at first floor) to obtain a lot of information about Tokyo and Japan (maps, guides and other brochures). I was there my first stay day in Tokyo and this visit was really usefull. The view from observatory, I only can tell it are great.

The tour of the building is worthwhile, the observation level is a bonus. I stayed at a hotel in Shinjuku and this building was convenient for me to drop by. I went to the observation level twice – once during the day on a tour of the building with a volunteer guide, and again at night to see the Tokyo lights. The guided tour is worthwhile in its own right – some interesting features got pointed out and a lot of questions I had about the buildings were answered. The trip to the observation level was a bonus, and the fact that it was free was even better. The guide said that on a clear day Mt Fuji can be seen – the direction to look is marked above a window. (In fact, a lot of landmarks are named on the displays above the windows.)

Great free view. If you're in Shinjuku you should walk over to the the Tokyo Metropolitan Government buildings, each of which has a free top floor very large observatory with 360 degree views. When we went there was a man playing the flute and we met a Japanese man who hangs around taking photos and teaching people origami for free. We even got to see Mt. Fuji, which was pretty amazing since it had rained that morning. Highly recommended. It's on the west side of the train station with all the skyscapers.

Waste of time for a foreigner. Unfortunately this was a big waste of time by the time we travelled from our Tokyo hotel to the TMG by train and did all the walking in the train tunnels, etc...then found our way to the TMG elevators, and waited to go up...and just do a brief look at Tokyo from this vantage point. I imagine it to be much more interesting to the Japanese who are more familiar with what city buildings they are seeing. I think it would be worth your time if you were at a nearby hotel, but it isn't worth the time to travel there to see it. Our time would have been much better spent doing other things.

The best viewing deck in Tokyo, and free too!. The view from the government offices is every bit as good as from the Tokyo tower, and you are that much closer to Mount Fuji so are a bit more likely to get a glimpse of it through the haze. Shinjuku station is a treat in itself to experience the ultimate crowds and it is not far to walk to the municipal buildings; mostly along moving walkways and all signposted in English too. The coffee shop on the viewing level was a complete rip off but entrance was free so I guess it evens out.

View not to be believed!. As busy as the streets are, and as looming as the neon-covered buildings can be, you can't ever really get a true feeling for the sheer endlessness of Tokyo until you have looked down upon it from above. To say that the view from this building is completely staggering would be to understate it. Access to the building and observation deck is completely free (but you must pass through the gift shop on your way out). Of everything I saw in Tokyo, the TMG Building stands above all else. The breathtaking three-sixty degree view of Tokyo in all it's glory (with Fuji-san visible on a clear day) makes it very clear how you fit 12 million people into a city: you make it unfathomably huge!This place is free to visit, quietly beautiful, and mind-bendingly fascinating. I don't think any visit to Tokyo would be complete without seeing it.

Cheep Lunch in Tokyo. There is staff restaurant in 32nd floor. The restaurant is quite big, many seats.It's not only for staff, visitor can go there. (not many people know about it..)The price is very cheep and many choice of food. It's self-service.

View Tokyo From a Free Observation Floor at Tokyo City Hall. The vast urban vista of Tokyo can be viewed for free from the two observation floors of the Tokyo City Hall building. Standing at 48 floors tall, the City Hall building is one of the tallest in Tokyo and is a striking design by the Japanese architect Kenzo Tange. There are two observation floors on the 45th floor of both the North and South towers. The South tower observation floor offers a view towards Meiji Shrine and Tokyo Bay can be viewed on a clear day. The North tower offers a view of the urban sprawl towards Saitama. An express elevator, which is boarded on the 1st floor of the tower, takes visitors to the observation floors in 55 seconds. Each tower hosts a simple food outlet - the South tower has a coffee shop, while the North tower has an Italian themed cafe. The North tower also has a large souvenir stand operated by Hakuhinkan, the famous Ginza toy retailer. Better and cheaper food is available across from the 1st floor of the main tower in the Citizen's Underground Plaza (Tomin Chika Hiroba), with excellent and cheap Japanese and Western food available. Try the Tonkatsu restaurant for delicious and traditional Japanese style pork cutlet. Although not fancy, the City Government makes a good effort at providing a quality attraction at a great price - free. Its not as flashy as Roppongi Hills, but worth a visit.One disappointment is the observation tower closes at 1730, so is not suitable for viewing Tokyo's dramtic night scene. A trip over to Roppongi Hills is the alternative.

Worth a trip down for some free sightseeing. Like someone else said below, it's free, what's not to like. For a city which is relatively taxing on the wallet for a budget traveller, this is a good breather in between shopping and shrine trips. We stayed at the Shinjuku Washington and naturally visited TMG which was a hop skip and a jump across. There are 2 towers and I suggest that you visit both of them. Though the view from up there seems similar when you're there, the photos I brought back with me suggested otherwise. We didn't manage to see Mt Fuji as it was super foggy but the view of the city was just breathtaking. There are shops at the viewing gallery selling all sorts of souvenirs which is great if you're hard-pressed for time and need to get something cute for someone back home. There are these gachapon machines (slot in 100yen and turn the knob to get a plastic ball with an item inside) with small keychains and handphone thingys which look like they date back to the 80s. Nice...There's a park nearby which had a mini flea market when we visted TMG on a saturday. I'm not sure if it's a weekly event but we managed to pick up some 2nd hand clothing and cool knick knacks.

It's free - what's not to like?!. Access to the 45th floor observation decks of both towers of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building is free, although they're not both open all the time and you may have to queue at busy times.I went up the north tower, which has a cafe and suitably tacky toy and souvenier shop at the top.It was pretty cloudy when I went, but apparently on a good day you can see Mt Fuji, so I reckon it's always worth a go.

Worth the trip for me.. It was worth the trip for me. I stayed in a hotel in a different area of Tokyo, a low-rise building, so I seriously enjoyed the high-rise view of Tokyo.. Wow, Tokyo is a really huge area taking advantage of every square inch of space. The observing area is an entire floor, so you have a lot of space and look out the windows. No open air area here. Height of the building is on the shorter side of large skyscrappers but one of the tallest in Japan (I imagine due to Japan's higher engineering requirements due to earthquakes most buildings aren't built so tall). Anyways, it's FREE to go up. Yes, Free. No lines the time I went either, though of course YMMV. Now as I said, the trip was worth it to me because I stayed in a different area of Tokyo that was completley different in scenery (Ikebukuro) so I really liked to see the modern Shinjuku area, which reminds me of downtown LA when I went during the weekend (i.e. ghost town). If one was already staying in Shinjuku then they may not find it worth the time at all, I could understand that.
